headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the AvalonBay Communities Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Your host for today's call is Mr. Jason Reilley, Senior Director of Investor Relations. Mr. Reilley, pleas
componenttext: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the AvalonBay Communities Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Your host for today's call is Mr. Jason Reilley, Senior Director of Investor Relations. Mr. Reilley, please go ahead.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Greg, and welcome to AvalonBay Communities Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Before we begin, please note that forward-looking statements may be made during this discussion. There are a variety of risks and uncertainties associated
componenttext:
Thank you, Greg, and welcome to AvalonBay Communities Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Before we begin, please note that forward-looking statements may be made during this discussion. There are a variety of risks and uncertainties associated with forward-looking statements and actual results may differ materially. For discussion of these risks and uncertainties [indiscernible] press release as well as in the company's Form 10-K and Form 10-Q filed with the SEC. 
As always, press release include an attachment with definitions and reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures and other terms which may be used in today's discussion. Actual results are available on our website at www.avalonbay.com/earnings, and we encourage you to refer to this information during the review of our operating results and financial performance. 
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Tim Naughton, Chairman and CEO of AvalonBay Communities for his remarks.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jason, and welcome to our Q4 call. With me today are Kevin O'Shea, Sean Breslin and Matt Birenbaum. Kevin and I will provide commentary on the slides that we posted last night. And then the 4 of us will be available for Q&A afterward. During our
componenttext:
Thanks, Jason, and welcome to our Q4 call. With me today are Kevin O'Shea, Sean Breslin and Matt Birenbaum. Kevin and I will provide commentary on the slides that we posted last night. And then the 4 of us will be available for Q&A afterward. 
During our comments, we'll focus on providing a summary of Q4 and the full-year results and then time talking about the outlook for 2016. I'll talk about the economy, apartment markets and operations and turn it over to Kevin, who will talk about development as well as capital and risk management as we move further into the cycle.
So let's start on Slide 4. Highlights for the quarter and year include core FFO growth in Q4 14.4% and 11.4% for the full year, which is about 300 basis point higher than our original outlook at the beginning of the year. And importantly, we continue to generate FFO growth this cycle toward the top of the sector while having the lowest leverage. 
Q4 same-store revenue growth came in at 5.4% or 5.7% when you include redevelopment, as many of our peers do. And for the full year, same-store revenue growth came in at 5.0 or 5.2, including redevelopment. Same-store NOI for the year came in at 5.8%. 
We completed about $500 million this quarter at right around a 7% yield and $1.3 billion for the full year, at an initial yield of 6.7%. We started another 4 communities totaling about $400 million in Q4, bringing our full year levels start to roughly $1.2 billion or roughly in line with completions this year.
And lastly, we raised $400 million in new capital in the quarter, principally $200 million or $300 million unsecured debt offering. And for the year, we raised a total of $1.9 billion in capital to fund new investment and refinance maturing debt.
Turning now to Slide 5. The $1.3 billion of new development that we completed this year that I just referenced is contributing to healthy earnings and NAV accretion. Yields of 6.7% are roughly 250 basis points greater than our initial cost of external capital raised this year. And the cost basis of these completions at 310,000 per unit is more than 30% less than the value of our average stabilized asset on a per unit basis, with rents that are 12% to 13% higher, implying that value creation was around 50% over cost or roughly $650 million in net NAV created or $5 per share in 2015 alone.
Turning to Slide 6. In addition to strong financial results, we excelled another important aspect in our business in 2015, including customer satisfaction, lower rate, #1 nationally among all apartment operators for online reputation, associate engagement, we are ranked #1 on our sector and #2 among of all of DC metro based organizations on glassdoor. Corporate responsibility where our multiyear focus are on sustainability, that puts us towards the top of the sector in the U.S. and globally. And community recognition where a number of our newly developed communities procedures awards from various industry groups. We probably don't talk enough about this with investors, but we know that achievement and survey the needs of these important constituencies and our customers from our associates, the communities as well as the shareholders is critical to building the kind of culture and company that can be enduring and successful.
Shifting now to 2016, let's move to Slide 7. We are projecting a 9% core growth in core FFO per share this year, driven by about 2/3 internal operations from almost 6% thanks to NOI growth that was exactly at the midpoint. And about 1/3 from new investment activity once you net out the cost of new capital issuance, which is probably mostly from stabilizing new development.
The principal difference in growth between 2015 and '16 is that we expect less external growth from new investment activity, which, in turn, is being driven by the impact of fewer deliveries in 2015 that we will be stabilizing in '16 and some might even timing of capital raising activity. 
When looking at the earnings impact of our development platform, it's probably more helpful to view it over a multiyear period. For example, if you look at it over the 2015, '16 timeframe here, new investment activity net of changes in capital cost is projected to deliver approximately $0.70 per share to core FFO or around 10% cumulative growth over the 2-year period.
Moving to Slide 8. Given our outlook for 2016, we announced a dividend increase of 8% this year. The dividend is now up by more than 50% over the last 5 years and, importantly, has grown by 5.5% on a compounded basis over the last 20 years. Dividends are an important component of total return. They represent almost 2/3 of the total return of roughly 1,800% that we've earned over the last 20 years. And that kind of growth really does underscore the accretion and growth embedded in our business model. I think sometimes it just gets a little lost during the market volatility and rapid trading activity we're seeing in the sector today.
Turning to Slide 9. Our outlook is being driven in part by the prospect of stable economy continuing into 2016, and from our perspective, appears to have reached midcycle in terms of GDP and employment growth. An improvement consumer should benefit from stronger labor market in 2016. And then the public sector is expected to actually contribute to overall economic growth this year, although still at a lesser rate than the private sector after having been a drag for a number of years to overall economic growth.
Turning to Slide 10. Job growth in our markets is projected to outperform the U.S. again in 2016 as it did in '15 at just over 2%. The East Coast is expected to improve in '16, while the tech-heavy West Coast market should moderate off the blistering pace of the last couple of years, although still remain at healthy levels around 2.5%. 
On Slide 11, total personal income growth, which combines job and per capita income growth, is expected to accelerate in 2016 as wage growth gains traction, particularly for the younger millennial cohort, most of whom continues to rent. 
Wage growth, as we discussed in the past, become an ever increasing important driver of our business as economic cycle matures and more supply starts to come online in 2016. 
Speaking to that, moving to Slide 12 and supply. We do expect that completions in our markets will increase in 2016 by about 50 basis points to around 2% of stock or roughly in line with job growth, suggesting pretty stable conditions overall. Of course, some submarkets, particularly in urban cores, we'll see higher levels of deliveries that may impact local markets as owners use concessions to stimulate absorption during lease up. This is particularly true in urban and high-rise product where inventories can build quickly and deliveries tend to occur over more considerate concentrated beard of time. But overall, housing demand should continue to favor the apartment sector due to many things that we've been talking about over the last couple of years, including favorable demographics, pent up demand as millennials continue to unbundle and ultimately changing lifestyle trends with the late marriage and family formation. All these factors should help support another healthy year for apartment fundamentals in 2016.
And turning to Slide 13. That is reflected in our outlook for our same-store portfolio this year. We're looking for same-store revenue growth of 4.25% to 5.5%, with modest improvement on the East Coast. On the West Coast, we expect some moderation in Seattle, Northern California after exceptionally strong growth in 2015. 
Overall then, growth is expected to be healthy with performance between the East and West Coast narrowing a bit in 2016. 
And with that, I'll turn it to Kevin, who will discuss development and capital activity.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. Turning to development activity on Slide 14, this shows construction in absolute terms and relative to our total enterprise value, both projected for year-end 2016 and historically going back to 2004. As you can see here, ongoing development
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. Turning to development activity on Slide 14, this shows construction in absolute terms and relative to our total enterprise value, both projected for year-end 2016 and historically going back to 2004. As you can see here, ongoing development activity as a percentage of our total enterprise value has been relatively stable for the past few years at around 10%, which is at the low end of our target range. This reflects our continued disciplined in allocating capital for this activity as we move further into the cycle.
Moving to Slide 15. Profit margins on our development activity has remained remarkably resilient and healthy in the cycle, thanks to the underlying strength of the apartment fundamentals, our sector-leading development and construction capabilities and the decisions we've made about which opportunities to pursue as the cycle matures. Since 2012, our development completions have increased from about $0.5 billion to more than $1 billion. During that time, development yields have been around 7%, while corresponding cap rates for those particular assets have been at or below 5%, resulting in stable profit margins on development in the low 30% range. 
As shown on Slide 16, communities currently in lease-up continue to provide healthy profit margins. For the 12 communities undergoing initial lease-up in 4Q '15, which represent $970 million in total capital cost, the current weighted average monthly rent per home is $115 above initial expectations. 
In terms of yield performance, the weighted average initial projected stabilized yield for these communities is currently 6.7%, or 30 basis points higher than our original projection of 6.4%.
Turning to Slide 17. I'd like to talk about how we manage risk associated with our development activity. The first way we do so is by maintaining a broadly diversified development pipeline, one that is diversified by geographic regions, by product type and by exposure to urban and suburban submarkets. 
As the chart on Slide 17 illustrates, while our development pipeline remains diversified across regions, future development lies a bias towards suburban markets and Midwest products, construction and land costs are more affordable, development economics are more favorable and the production cycle tends to be faster. Going forward, we expect our development pipeline will continue to be an important source of outside growth in NAV and FFO per share.
Moving to Slide 18. Another way we manage development risk is how we source and structure new development opportunities, with the overwhelming majority being controlled through long-term purchase contracts with modest at risk deposits and relatively few being controlled through land we purchased on hold in our balance sheet. At the end of 2015, our development rights pipeline consisted of 32 communities, representing $3.4 billion of projected total capital cost. Of these 32 communities, 25 are controlled to be purchase contracts while we own the remaining 7. 
In addition, of these 7 where we own the land, 2 account for approximately $420 million of the $485 million of land held for development on our balance sheet. We expect to begin construction on these 2 community Development Rights, Columbus Circle and Hollywood in 2016, which would reduce our projected land held for development by year-end 2016, the lowest level in more than a decade.
A third method which we use to manage development risk is substantially much fund the long-term capital, a topic we've talked about a lot in the cycle. On Slide 19, we highlight our funding position against the total projected capital cost the development underway. As you can see, we only need to source about $500 million of long-term capital against the $3.4 billion of development under construction recently completed, taking into account the $2.2 billion of capital already spent to date, $400 million of unrestricted cash on hand and $350 million of projected annual cash flow from operations after dividends. This means that about 85% of the value creation from ongoing development activity has already been locked in for our shareholders.
Turning to Slide 20. We show how being substantially much funded significantly enhances our growth in EBITDA while simultaneously enhancing our already's sector leading credit profile, essentially making us similar to an acquisition REIT from a funding perspective but with lower leverage and stronger built in earnings growth. Specifically, the projected EBITDA for recently completed development and development construction totals about $216 million, as shown on the chart on the left. This represents about 18% growth in annualized core EBITDA from the fourth quarter. 
Even in a worse case, if all the $480 million of unfunded commitments are funded with new debt, our net debt to core EBITDA would still decline from 4.8x to the mid-4s after taking into account the EBITDA from new development. Of course, our actual net debt to core EBITDA will move around a bit as resourced the capital fund incremental development activity. And for the communicate the leverage going to decrease 4.5x [indiscernible] target leverage is 4.5x, affect our target range this metric communities to be roughly between 5 and 6x. Instead, the purpose in showing this slide is 2 much funding strategy, we are optimally positioned to benefit from development activity, that is expected to be accretive both earnings and balance sheet strength. And that our credit profile is actually enhanced by our profitable development capabilities given our funding strategy. 
And with that, I'll turn it back to Tim.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kevin. And just ending here on Slide 21 before opening up the call. In summary, 2015 was a very good year for the company and the industry. We're expecting 2016 to look a lot like 2015, once again benefiting from above trend growth. I think this o
componenttext:
Thanks, Kevin. And just ending here on Slide 21 before opening up the call. In summary, 2015 was a very good year for the company and the industry. We're expecting 2016 to look a lot like 2015, once again benefiting from above trend growth. I think this outlook is not surprising just given our view that we're midcycle with healthy apartment fundamentals continuing and then just a stable level of deliveries and help the accretion coming from our developing pipeline. 
As we move further into the mature portion of the economic expansion, we are highly focused on managing the investment and funding risk of the business. And as Kevin mentioned in his remarks, we're doing this through managing the size and diversity of our pipeline, reducing land inventory, match funding new commitments and maintaining leverage at the low end of our target range. 
And with that, Greg, we'll be happy to open up the call for Q&A.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] First from UBS, we have Nick Yulico.

componenttextpreview: So I guess my first question would be, you have talked a lot about how you've been able to deliver projects at higher yields underwriting for the past few years. You continue to do that. But as far as your guidance goes for this year, I mean, what is your
componenttext: So I guess my first question would be, you have talked a lot about how you've been able to deliver projects at higher yields underwriting for the past few years. You continue to do that. But as far as your guidance goes for this year, I mean, what is your -- is there assumption for a development pipeline that you're basically delivering at the yield that you give on the development page and so that if you actually beat by 30 basis points the high-end of your range or can you put a little sensitivity around that?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nick, this is Tim, and Matt, feel free to jump in. In terms of the attachment that shows the development pipeline with the projected yield of 6 3, that is based upon current rents and rents marked to market once we start leasing and you get up to about 20
componenttext: Nick, this is Tim, and Matt, feel free to jump in. In terms of the attachment that shows the development pipeline with the projected yield of 6 3, that is based upon current rents and rents marked to market once we start leasing and you get up to about 20%,  25% occupancy. For those communities that have started, construction rent growth and we haven't yet started leasing, we haven't marketed those markets just to be clear. I think you'll probably see over the last few years, we've totally been beating the initial pro forma yields by 30 to 50 or 60 basis points just because of a strong market rent growth and the fact we're able to bring deals in more or less at cost. I think it really is, ultimately -- if you look at the development pipeline today, the shadow pipeline, the builds that haven't yet started, the economics of that look a lot like economics look like on the deals that we've been starting over the last couple of years. I think a lot of it is how you would underwrite those would depend upon how you'd underrated market ultimately in terms of where redoing business and how you might underrates construction costs relative to market rent growth change over the next couple of years.

componenttext: And then -- just really back to the guidance though. Should we be assuming that if you are getting the 30 basis points beating on original underwriting, is that already kind of factored into your midpoint of your guidance or does that sort of gets you to the higher end of your guidance on FFO?

componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. That's helpful. And just one other question was on, you gave your outlook for U.S. job growth basically being similar to last year. If job growth were to be slowing here, which people are concerned about, where do you think -- which of your
componenttext: Okay. Got it. That's helpful. And just one other question was on, you gave your outlook for U.S. job growth basically being similar to last year. If job growth were to be slowing here, which people are concerned about, where do you think -- which of your markets have the most risk then from a fundamental standpoint?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nick, this is Sean. There's probably a couple of answers to that question, but I guess what I'd probably say, based on historical precedent in the market, is the sort of high beta markets, if you want to think about that way tend to be the technology mark
componenttext: Nick, this is Sean. There's probably a couple of answers to that question, but I guess what I'd probably say, based on historical precedent in the market, is the sort of high beta markets, if you want to think about that way tend to be the technology markets, so Northern California and Seattle, and to have a greater reaction in rent levels relative to given change in job growth in many of our other markets. So the technology markets are the ones you'd probably be most concerned about that's assuming of course that any reduction in job growth is somewhat proportional. In the past, we've had some losses in the energy sector. It has not had a direct effect on our markets, but there's certainly some indirect effects as it relates to reduced amount of capital investment on behalf of those companies kind of ripple through the economy. So those are the markets that are probably most concerned about given the reduction in job growth.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess just one last quick question and maybe it's for Kevin is that, I think the concern would be that you guys -- although you guys have a great balance sheet and you are mostly funded for the development pipeline today as you look out a year, you're t
componenttext: I guess just one last quick question and maybe it's for Kevin is that, I think the concern would be that you guys -- although you guys have a great balance sheet and you are mostly funded for the development pipeline today as you look out a year, you're then still starting more projects and people then worried about you guys having to raise capital a year from now, I mean what would be your sort of answer to that, that, that shouldn't be a concern for folks?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there's a few things, Nick, first of all, as we demonstrated in 2009, if we don't think we have reasonable access to capital, we don't have to start new projects, that would be one thing to keep in mind. We don't need to keep creating commitments if
componenttext: Well, there's a few things, Nick, first of all, as we demonstrated in 2009, if we don't think we have reasonable access to capital, we don't have to start new projects, that would be one thing to keep in mind. We don't need to keep creating commitments if we don't think cost-effective capital is available to us in one of our principal funding markets. And I guess the second thing to keep in mind is that we do keep a very strong balance sheet both from a match funding perspective, but also from another dimension, including having low leverage and the latter maturities, so that we have an awful lot of flexibility to deal with the sort of an air pocket that might exist where maybe disruption in capital markets before we've been able to sort and dial back on the starts. So I think fundamentally, we have great deal of flexibility in the commitments we create and the capital going to be able to source the deal with volatility in the capital markets and that's how we manage the balance sheet.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next we have Nick Joseph from Citi.
componenttext: And next we have Nick Joseph from Citi.

componenttext: You talked about the development rights pipeline and its current focus on suburbans of markets. Do you think that there's a difference in investor demand in terms of the transaction market between urban core assets and infill suburban assets? And then how do you think about that in terms of the IR differential between the 2?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nick, this is Matt. There's great demand for almost everything right now. I think there is a difference in cap rate. Clearly, urban core assets do tend to trade at a lower cap rate, much lower depends on what you're comparing it to. If you're comparing it
componenttext: Nick, this is Matt. There's great demand for almost everything right now. I think there is a difference in cap rate. Clearly, urban core assets do tend to trade at a lower cap rate, much lower depends on what you're comparing it to. If you're comparing it to here in D.C., D.C. versus Arlington is not going to be that different versus compared to say D.C. versus Tysons Corner, for example. So -- but we do reflect that in the target yields that we put out for deals. We look at where we think the cap rates would be on those assets, specific sites today and where we think long-term exit cap rates might be. So we try -- we do factor that in. Going forward, I don't know, it's speculative. There has been occurring capital that's probably preferred to stay mostly in the urban type of trophy assets, that's one reason the cap rates are a little bit lower on those. But we've got pretty strong healthy demand for both at this point.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if we were to enter into a recession, do you think there's more stickiness to the urban core cap rates versus the suburban? Or do you think they would move up together?
componenttext: Well, if we were to enter into a recession, do you think there's more stickiness to the urban core cap rates versus the suburban? Or do you think they would move up together?

componenttextpreview: Nick, there's probably liquidity premium for the urban core, the extent you get into of more significant capital dislocation, the probability to being able to move or to monetize an urban asset, I would say is probably greater than a suburban asset or. I
componenttext: Nick, there's probably liquidity premium for the urban core, the extent you get into of more significant capital dislocation, the probability to being able to move or to monetize an urban asset, I would say is probably greater than a suburban asset or. I think that's part of the premium valuation or discount cap rate is just that liquidity aspect of it.

componenttextpreview: And then in terms of rental affordability overall, are we at a point in the cycle where rental rate growth will more closely track which growth? Or is there still room to be able to increase rents at a higher pace than overall wage growth?
componenttext: And then in terms of rental affordability overall, are we at a point in the cycle where rental rate growth will more closely track which growth? Or is there still room to be able to increase rents at a higher pace than overall wage growth?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nick, this is Sean. We are at the sort of the upper end range on that metric, it's running around 22%, which is within the band of history, but certainly at the upper end of that band, so there's no question that we need to continue to see income growth t
componenttext: Nick, this is Sean. We are at the sort of the upper end range on that metric, it's running around 22%, which is within the band of history, but certainly at the upper end of that band, so there's no question that we need to continue to see income growth to support rental rate growth in the future. So if we had a sudden deceleration in income growth for whatever reason, which is not what's expected, I think we're seeing that front economy now in terms of pressure on wage growth then there would become greater constraints on pushing rents further in the future, no doubt about it.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Nick, just to add to that, when you look at wage growth, we talked about in the past, there is a bifurcated labor market, right, in terms of college grads and uncollege grads where you got 5% for the total population unemployment 2.5% for the college
componenttext: And Nick, just to add to that, when you look at wage growth, we talked about in the past, there is a bifurcated labor market, right, in terms of college grads and uncollege grads where you got 5% for the total population unemployment 2.5% for the college grads. The majority of our residents are college grads. And we are seeing that they're probably getting higher than average, maybe higher than average wage gains, which provides a little bit more support I think for our business in terms of continue to generate this rent growth.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Nick, just to give you a sense, on a year-over-year basis in the fourth quarter, lease income for new residents relative to last year was up more than 5%. So we're seeing that for our population of residence for sure.

componenttextpreview: This is Matt. If I can speak to that a little bit and then Sean can you chime in as well. The demographic trends are loan trends. I mean the great thing about it is you can see it coming 5, 10 years down the road, and so as we think about how we want to p
componenttext: This is Matt. If I can speak to that a little bit and then Sean can you chime in as well. The demographic trends are loan trends. I mean the great thing about it is you can see it coming 5, 10 years down the road, and so as we think about how we want to position our portfolio where we are seeing the best risk adjusted returns, opportunities to invest program communities pretty future, it's driven by some of those big macro trends. So I don't think a small movement in the homeownership rate on the margins is going to impact that when you look at just the raw numbers coming through [indiscernible] shift that's going to occur here. So I think people have changed a lot [indiscernible]

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess the only thing to add is, you're really starting to get the leading edge of that ecoboom. And you look back, lot of you don't realize this, but if you look back over the last 5 to 10 years, the drop in homeownership rates are most pronounced in th
componenttext: I guess the only thing to add is, you're really starting to get the leading edge of that ecoboom. And you look back, lot of you don't realize this, but if you look back over the last 5 to 10 years, the drop in homeownership rates are most pronounced in that 35 to 44 segment, more so than the 25 to 34 segment %. So you have a lot more people moving into that. They drop like 1,100 basis points something like that. And even it picks back up, you're talking about a lot more rental households over the next 10 years coming from that segment. And it's impacting how we're thinking about product right now in terms of providing I think we've talked about a signature package in terms of higher level of finish and some larger units that we may be been doing over the last few years and certain deals and it impacts how you think about amenities as well. So we do think it could be a pretty big source of demand and it represents that age cohort represents about 20% of our residents today whereas the under 35 cohorts maybe 40%, 45%.

So there's nothing material out there that we are aware of, but in the recent Facebook offering and we're not hearing about it in a way that since influencing day-to-day any form or fashion.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And it sounds like Northern California may decelerate in revenue growth this year. Can you comment on markets that you see have the best chance of accelerating growth this year?
componenttext: Okay. And it sounds like Northern California may decelerate in revenue growth this year. Can you comment on markets that you see have the best chance of accelerating growth this year?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Sean again. I guess what I'd say is, this point, you're probably identified Northern California as one of the markets where probably a little bit of concern about slowing, it come up a couple of different times. But in terms of markets that has some
componenttext: Sure. Sean again. I guess what I'd say is, this point, you're probably identified Northern California as one of the markets where probably a little bit of concern about slowing, it come up a couple of different times. But in terms of markets that has some upside, certainly the Mid-Atlantic is one that has some potential upside in terms of we're a point in the cycle where we know that supply is, it was about 2% last year, it's going to increase to about 2.5% this year. But more importantly, as we're getting pretty good job growth out of the Mid-Atlantic now [indiscernible] below 2% range and it's starting to have nice effect on occupancy and rent change across the markets here. So the expectation is that there's potential for some upside in the mid-Atlantic. I will not describe it as opportunistic in that there's significant upside. There still a fair mind amount of supply coming, and it's not a sort of high bidder market, as I described in the northern California and Pacific Northwest regions. So you tend to get a moderate recovery. And we are seeing that here in terms of recent trends where rent change is up about 100 basis points in the first quarter as compared to the first quarter '14, so there's nice momentum there. And then the other market that may have some upside I'd say is Boston. Boston has been performing well, job growth has been steady and supply is projected to decrease this year relative to 2015. So there's probably a little bit a potential upside in Boston and the Mid-Atlantic are the 2 that probably stand out the most, I'd say. Southern California has been increasing nicely, and we expect that to continue. But I wouldn't think it falls into the potential surprise category like the other 2 [indiscernible]

componenttext: You mentioned rent as a percent of income as kind of at the upper end of historical ranges. Any submarkets where you're above the prior peaks? And how do you think about maybe millennial budgets may not have a car?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good question. In terms of markets where it's, I guess, constrained, there's not necessarily any one market that's well beyond historical ranges. You've got certain markets that are more expensive but obviously, got people making substantial more income.
componenttext: Good question. In terms of markets where it's, I guess, constrained, there's not necessarily any one market that's well beyond historical ranges. You've got certain markets that are more expensive but obviously, got people making substantial more income. So there's nothing that's on the extreme outlier side, if you want to call it that. And we do try to take into account millennials and the choices and they make, so those numbers tend to be higher, some of those urban locations where people don't have cars using metro or subway or whatever might be. So we do find that in those cases, people are in a position where they can tend to spend a little bit more of their income on rent than in other geographies. So it's a fair point.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then maybe just on your outlook for your metro New York, New Jersey portfolio, can you maybe talk to the difference submarkets as certain submarkets are seeing much more supply than others?
componenttext: And then maybe just on your outlook for your metro New York, New Jersey portfolio, can you maybe talk to the difference submarkets as certain submarkets are seeing much more supply than others?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. In terms of the Greater New York and Jersey market, I mean, if you look at it across New York City, northern New Jersey, central New Jersey, Long Island, Westchester, it's a pretty diverse geography, a lot of the supply is concentrated in New York C
componenttext: Sure. In terms of the Greater New York and Jersey market, I mean, if you look at it across New York City, northern New Jersey, central New Jersey, Long Island, Westchester, it's a pretty diverse geography, a lot of the supply is concentrated in New York City and northern New Jersey. So if you look at Hudson County and you spread throughout the boroughs, you're going to see that. Supply as a percent of inventory still on Westchester, Long Island, central New Jersey is pretty insignificant. So even though you have greater demand in those markets that identify with greater supply, there's a lid and growth next it as a result of it. So there's not a wide variation for the most part. New York and Jersey is going to be probably in the mid to high 3% range. There's not one market that's in the low 2s and another one in the 5s, give you some perspective if that helps. It's a pretty tight range.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Sean, can you tie to more or less the same for the D.C. submarkets I mean in terms of fourth quarter performance, was there any bifurcation buys or terms of market in the D.C. Metro? And then in terms of your 2016 outlook, any material differential on expectations between D.C. proper, Northern Virginia, et cetera?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. As it relates to I'll call it sort of recent momentum, including the fourth quarter and spillover into early 2016, I say the laggard between across the metro area has been suburban Maryland. Job growth has been okay, but the supply has been heavy an
componenttext: Sure. As it relates to I'll call it sort of recent momentum, including the fourth quarter and spillover into early 2016, I say the laggard between across the metro area has been suburban Maryland. Job growth has been okay, but the supply has been heavy and steady throughout that region, particularly Rockville, North Bethesda, Chevy Chase has been supply. So it's been the softest. The strongest has been in and around D.C. So D.C. proper as well as the sort of corridor things like that, towns and submarkets of that are close in to D.C. and then I'd say the rest in Northern Virginia kind of falls into second place. So they call it the district and immediately adjacent submarkets, northern Virginia and suburban Maryland being the laggard kind of recent conditions. In terms of expected performance in '16, what we have is overall for the Mid-Atlantic, probably in the mid-1% range. And again, it's relatively tight, I'd say, we're talking about the suburban Maryland probably right at the midpoint there. We may see a little bit better performance at D.C. just given the nature of our specific assets in D.C., which is Gallery Place, Foxhall, stuff in the Northwest corridor that's older and rent-controlled. When you look at it from a market perspective, I would say the one thing to be cautious about is the greatest amount of supply to be delivered in 2016 is in the district. Because depending on the distribution of your portfolio within the district, really will dictate what your performance is going to be. So the way I think the market would probably look at it is D.C. people would probably expect to be a little bit softer given the nature of the deliveries. Infill suburban submarkets probably in Virginia performing better. And then Western Fairfax, I would say, and suburban Maryland probably being the laggard.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then can you also talk about expectations for the 3 main Southern California submarkets in 2016 and how you see that sort of shaping up? And any type of issues in any of the individual markets that you're worried about from our supply standpoint
componenttext: Okay. And then can you also talk about expectations for the 3 main Southern California submarkets in 2016 and how you see that sort of shaping up? And any type of issues in any of the individual markets that you're worried about from our supply standpoint?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Happy to talk about that. In terms of again recent performance rolling forward, sorry to keep it relatively brief without going on too long here, but where we started to see some supply impact is in Orange County. Orange County is softened a little
componenttext: Sure. Happy to talk about that. In terms of again recent performance rolling forward, sorry to keep it relatively brief without going on too long here, but where we started to see some supply impact is in Orange County. Orange County is softened a little bit of a fair amount of supply coming into Irvine, some in supply in Anaheim, there's been supply in Huntington Beach, little bit in Costa Mesa. So that's softened a little bit in our expectations for '16 for that market is for it to trail the other regions as well because of the same issues. San Diego and L.A., we expect a lead going into '16 and continue throughout the year. And for the most part, that's not only the nature of the markets but how our portfolio's positioned, which is for the most part it's B assets in suburban submarkets across San Diego, which is relatively small portfolio, but that's where the majority of our assets are located. And Los Angeles, same thing in terms of the distribution of the assets within those submarkets. We don't have any same-store assets in downtown L.A, as an example, which is getting supply now that's equal to double-digit percentages of existing inventory. So you're going to have softness in some of those submarkets like downtown L.A. where you're getting a heavy amount of new deliveries. So I'd say for '16, overall, you're probably going to see L.A., San Diego leading, and Orange County lagging, just given the nature of our portfolio, but also just from the market perspective in terms of where the supply is concentrated.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Chris. Obviously, you don't do a lot of acquisitions, can you talk a little bit about what motivated you to do the Avalon Hoboken? And what about -- what's the forward cap rate on that asset?
componenttext: This is Chris. Obviously, you don't do a lot of acquisitions, can you talk a little bit about what motivated you to do the Avalon Hoboken? And what about -- what's the forward cap rate on that asset?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Chris, this is Matt. You're right, we haven't done a lot of acquisitions historically in this cycle. So at this point what we are doing is we're trying to -- we are always looking for opportunities to improve our portfolio where we can, and that hap
componenttext: Sure. Chris, this is Matt. You're right, we haven't done a lot of acquisitions historically in this cycle. So at this point what we are doing is we're trying to -- we are always looking for opportunities to improve our portfolio where we can, and that happened to be a very unique opportunity there in Hoboken. We weren't per se adding New Jersey on a net basis, but we're always looking to improve our submarket exposure. It's a highly supply-protected submarkets, it's one of the few parts of New Jersey we have not been able to penetrate through new development. The cap rate is about 5, which is pretty attractive for an asset that's only 7 years old. The average unit size there is about 1,000 square feet, so it's actually more targeted at families and they're necessarily at young singles and that's what in that part of Hoboken, it's kind of interesting to see how it's evolving in that way as Hoboken kind of matures as a desirable location, not just for people trying to write out of school but for people, married couples, a little bit older as well, there's a supermarket right next door. With luscious a unique opportunity and we feel like we are able to based on some characteristics of the way the as it is marketed get it at a price that was more compelling than most of the acquisition opportunities we're seeing.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And maybe just add to that, maybe implicit your question, too. We're not looking at acquisitions as a growth platform right now, to be clear. But we are seeing a lot of volume, and we see it as an opportunity potentially upgrade the portfolio. And so we d
componenttext: And maybe just add to that, maybe implicit your question, too. We're not looking at acquisitions as a growth platform right now, to be clear. But we are seeing a lot of volume, and we see it as an opportunity potentially upgrade the portfolio. And so we do look at it sort of midcycle where we see a lot of volume. We're focused both on asset management and portfolio management to try to upgrade and improve the portfolio as we can. And as I mentioned earlier in one of the other questions, we are somewhat limited in terms of how much of this positions we can do before you can read in the capital anymore. But we do see that as -- we do have some assets we like to sell. And we are seeing an active transaction market where we see assets we'd prefer and so we are trying to do some fair trade along the way as well.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Tim. I would say we're probably looking at development yields around or we're looking at development mid-6s. There was a year or 2 where I think that came in around closer to 5 in terms of actual performance. Conversely, I would say, cap rate
componenttext: Yes. This is Tim. I would say we're probably looking at development yields around or we're looking at development mid-6s. There was a year or 2 where I think that came in around closer to 5 in terms of actual performance. Conversely, I would say, cap rates were probably in the mid-4s where they are today. And really as you know, hardly any trades at all, but due to the extent there were trade, it probably went north of 6 for a year or 2. But hopefully, that's helpful. If you look at the deals that we were building in 2009 and '10 that ended up stabilizing initially at 5, those are more like 6.5 and 7s today just to put in perspective. So they're fine assets. We're not going to make the same kind of returns that was made on deals that we started 2 years later for sure. But still a fine outcome given the kind of recession we went through.

That's the virtue of match funding, you're up into NAV growth right now at this point in time.

componenttext: Sure. This is Matt. I can take that a little bit. We are working on it. The program is getting set. So it's now mature to the point that have a pretty good definition know what of the offering is and we have been talking to folks and we'll keep you updated as we make progress on that.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Okay. Great. And then my second question is just what your thoughts are on 421A, whether that will be recessed stated or whether you think that will kind of severely curve development in New York?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's obviously too early to tell. It's a program that's been around for a long time and it is important for to make rental production work for the most part in the city in New York City. So I think our local folks would say probably there will be
componenttext: I think it's obviously too early to tell. It's a program that's been around for a long time and it is important for to make rental production work for the most part in the city in New York City. So I think our local folks would say probably there will be a program in some form or fashion that will come back at some point. These things get snagged in politics, and New York is kind of unique situation where it's not just a city but Albany is a Slate state legislator involved as well. So as it relates to our portfolio specifically, doesn't really have much impact. The deal we're just talking about at Columbus Circle, we are never intending to put that deal in the program. So our plan there is not have any affordable and not have a tax abatement from the start. And the other deals that we have going in New York, it's already been invested. So might impact on market on until things settle out, but it's too early to say what the impact might be going forward.

componenttextpreview: Dan, it's Tim. In terms of -- and I would talk to this in the past, every deal has a target yield that's impacted by what we think the projected growth profile, cash growth profile of that asset or that submarket will deliver. So something like a Columbus
componenttext: Dan, it's Tim. In terms of -- and I would talk to this in the past, every deal has a target yield that's impacted by what we think the projected growth profile, cash growth profile of that asset or that submarket will deliver. So something like a Columbus Circle we think would have a higher growth profile than the average deal in our portfolio. We would expect that to have a lower goal and yield then, that's pretty much how land markets and development market's price. So it's a fair point because we do have a couple large deals that in Hollywood deals as well which is an L.A. deal which usually California deals are lower cap rate and higher growth. So that will impact the projected initial yield, if you will, because we're expecting to get basically the same IRR but more of it through residual and cash flow growth.

componenttext: A couple of quick ones for you. The track record this cycle on development is clearly compelling as you laid [ph] out on '15. Thinking about it from the profit margin perspective that you laid out, what level of profit margins are you targeting on incremental starts?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Dave, as we mentioned, we typically do start with a cost of capital and add some accretion factor to that. I mean it ends up being in the 150 to 200 basis point range in terms of premium from a target perspective. And we've been able to meet or exce
componenttext: Well, Dave, as we mentioned, we typically do start with a cost of capital and add some accretion factor to that. I mean it ends up being in the 150 to 200 basis point range in terms of premium from a target perspective. And we've been able to meet or exceed that certainly this cycle. As we put the slide up there that shows the where the average deal is costing about 310,000, just using your data, if you just sort of extrapolate that out using the rent premium that those deals are getting, would suggest an average value of about $470,000 for that book of business. And when you look at the pipeline, the shadow pipeline, that has an estimated cost about 350 door today with honestly a bit more urban oriented products that probably has a little bit higher rent on average, slightly higher rent. So it's still pretty healthy looking margin based upon what we know today, which are today's rents and today's costs.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And Tim, you'd mentioned a couple of times or you've alluded to limit that surrounding your disposition potential in '16. Could you put a number around that?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It depends which assets you choose to sell at the end of the day. But it's not atypical. It's probably --  the assets we're looking to sell have more than a 50% [indiscernible] gain on the proceeds. So to the extent you got call it $200 million or $300 mi
componenttext: It depends which assets you choose to sell at the end of the day. But it's not atypical. It's probably --  the assets we're looking to sell have more than a 50% [indiscernible] gain on the proceeds. So to the extent you got call it $200 million or $300 million of capacity before you start getting into requirement just to distribute, you could sell 2x that . But it depends on the mix. Kevin, I don't if you got anything you want to add to that?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Just a couple of things, probably taxes will do a deep discussion on, to be sure, we probably can. Just really 2 issues. One is the special dividend obligation associated with the fact that we are a taxpaying entity both for the fact that we have a
componenttext: Sure. Just a couple of things, probably taxes will do a deep discussion on, to be sure, we probably can. Just really 2 issues. One is the special dividend obligation associated with the fact that we are a taxpaying entity both for the fact that we have a dividend paid deduction. But there's also excise tax considerations as well, so I think from our standpoint, when we look at using asset sales to fund development, we have a fair bit of running room in terms of being able to sell assets before we have to worry about a special dividend obligation. We would probably more likely in a kind of situation where we have to pay an excise tax, which is sort of a little bit of a 4% tax payment on excess income over distributions. And so it become sort of a kind of almost like a transaction cost if you will that gets added to selling assets to fund development. So we certainly have a reasonable amount of ability to continue to sell assets to fund development, but when you run in to first is probably having to pay an excise tax, which is just an extra transaction cost, if you will, which we'd rather not incur if we can avoid it, but it's something that's probably more road development.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. One last one for you, Kevin. You suggested that you'll lean on unsecured market as it relates to the sources of funds. What are your latest thoughts on 30-year money?
componenttext: All right. One last one for you, Kevin. You suggested that you'll lean on unsecured market as it relates to the sources of funds. What are your latest thoughts on 30-year money?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we don't really have 30 or unsecured money in the balance sheet today. We do have a fair bit of a about $1.1 billion of tax-exempt debt that's secured and has probably on average about 21 years left to run. So that's something we have done in the pa
componenttext: Well, we don't really have 30 or unsecured money in the balance sheet today. We do have a fair bit of a about $1.1 billion of tax-exempt debt that's secured and has probably on average about 21 years left to run. So that's something we have done in the past, and we like that form of capital, though it's far less available today. In terms of 30 or unsecured debt, since we don't have to have, since we don't currently have it, you have to ask yourself what's the substitution for. I think probably it's been a little bit more of a compelling equity substitute for those who want more leverage than a compelling substitute for 10 year debt when you do the breakevens. For us, we might be willing to entertain doing it. I guess probably one guiding principle would be, if we were to look at the total amount of debt we're going to issue in one year, there's only so much we want to issue in the form of 10-year unsecured debt before in the future period we have a more debt coming due than we would prefer, which as we've talked about before, we try to target having leveled maturities that are on balance less than or equal to projected amount of dividend. And so we felt going to be issuing a certain amount of debt in the unsecured markets in a given year, that might be more than we want to have come due in 10 years. We might think about doing the excess in the form of a 30-year note offering.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just curious, given on the market volatility concerning about the recession, are you seeing your tenants reacting any differently when you gave them new packing in January and where renewals would coming up with whether there being much more aggress
componenttext: I was just curious, given on the market volatility concerning about the recession, are you seeing your tenants reacting any differently when you gave them new packing in January and where renewals would coming up with whether there being much more aggressive about trying to get a rent cut or decline or some type of relief just kind of given the overall nervousness in the economic backdrop?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Sean. To answer that directly based on the data, the answer is no in terms of the actions they are taking, for example, rent increases to high and moving out, Motrin increase doesn't really move that much on average has a certain markets. And so I th
componenttext: It's Sean. To answer that directly based on the data, the answer is no in terms of the actions they are taking, for example, rent increases to high and moving out, Motrin increase doesn't really move that much on average has a certain markets. And so I think you probably have to go market by market to figure out where that's most pronounced. So there's certainly been pushback in northern California that's above historical averages. But that's a market where we are seeing pretty significant rent growth in the last 3 years. So you sort of expect that. When someone gets to a third 8%, 9%, 10% rent increase, wages have been growing but then they're not growing quickly, there's some pushback. But I'd say as part of a normal process, there's not a significant shift one direction or another that we're seeing across the portfolio.

componenttext: I was hoping you could talk about a couple of your larger developments out there, the Square or grow asset and more states in Boston and where those yield expectations stack up kind of relative to that 6 3 and what gives you confidence those assets in particular that the targeted yields will be achieved either from a cost control standpoint or market fundamentals?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure Drew, this is Matt, I can start on that and Sean if you want to chime in anything. Those are 2 big urban high-rises. And again, we think about the target returns starting out relative to kind of what the spot cap rate is -- would be on those assets i
componenttext: Sure Drew, this is Matt, I can start on that and Sean if you want to chime in anything. Those are 2 big urban high-rises. And again, we think about the target returns starting out relative to kind of what the spot cap rate is -- would be on those assets is one thing to look at as well as we project the growth profile would be to kind of get from different potential starting target yields to target IRR, which is more similar across different deals. Those 2 deals were underwritten in kind of the high 5s based on the rents that were in place when we started those deals. We had not marked either one to market yet. The will be square deal is a very large building, so it would be a while before we have kind of 20% lease which is typically when we would market to market, but I think we're feeling pretty good about the capital budget there and we're feeling pretty good that, based on what we're seeing so far, the market is certainly a little bit above where it was performing. And Sean.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Sean. As it relates to Willoughby, which is really as you may not know, it's 2 components to the building has an AVA component and then Avalon component. We have product in the AVA section of the building right now that delivered late in the fourt
componenttext: This is Sean. As it relates to Willoughby, which is really as you may not know, it's 2 components to the building has an AVA component and then Avalon component. We have product in the AVA section of the building right now that delivered late in the fourth quarter after a few delays with the MCA in their space. But early returns we have a market to market but face rents are in the $60 a foot range. I think pro forma was around 55. And that $60 a foot at the kind of slow leasing season, Christmas, January kind of rates. So feel pretty good about that in terms of how that product is positioned in Brooklyn. As we mentioned, we don't have the Avalon component yet, but it's -- those would be the nicer unit, the top of the building. So our expectations once we open those up probably midyear, we're going to see a nice pop in overall rates for the building.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andrew, this is Tim. Just to add, feel pretty good about the cost, we do act as our own GC sometimes with the CM, construction management firm, but we hold the contracts. And so we typically have better visibility than if we were working with a third-part
componenttext: Andrew, this is Tim. Just to add, feel pretty good about the cost, we do act as our own GC sometimes with the CM, construction management firm, but we hold the contracts. And so we typically have better visibility than if we were working with a third-party in terms of any cost pressures on deals. And we feel pretty good about, as Matt mentioned, pretty good about these deals now in terms of bringing those online and for the budget amounts of that we laid out on our schedule.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Great. That's helpful. One more, should there be slowing in employment growth in the Bay Area, how do you feel that the San Francisco MSA kind of stacks up against Silicon Valley against the East Bay area if supply standpoint or just where that dynamics on the ground in terms of setup if things get slow down?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, it's Sean. A couple of thoughts on that. In general, was in that market, when things often, the most expensive price point product tends to suffer first. So if you have the most expensive high-rise in the city, you're going to see some reaction to t
componenttext: Sure, it's Sean. A couple of thoughts on that. In general, was in that market, when things often, the most expensive price point product tends to suffer first. So if you have the most expensive high-rise in the city, you're going to see some reaction to that. If you just a macro comment, sort of depends on one end of the curve and what supplies being delivered. As we go into '16, there's more supply concentrated in San Jose than there is in East Bay or San Francisco, as an example. That's across San Jose, concentrated in Northeast San Jose. If you up in the Mountain View, certain submarkets, there's  about 3, 4 submarkets there. Southern San Francisco, fair amount of supply being delivered into soma if exposed to soma, you're probably going to hurt just as much. So it really depends on when in the cycle it occurs and what supply's being delivered at that point in time. But generally speaking, the higher price point assets tend to suffer first and which tend to see people will migrate if things become more affordable, they'll be able to migrate back towards the end of the safest city and the cycle then repeats itself. So hopefully, I'll provide some broad perspective about what happened to the market.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, it's Sean. One way to think about it is just how the portfolio eaves communities is performing relative to Avalon or AVA. It's typically a story of which market it's in, Northern California. Obviously, it's very strong versus say Westchester. But ge
componenttext: Rich, it's Sean. One way to think about it is just how the portfolio eaves communities is performing relative to Avalon or AVA. It's typically a story of which market it's in, Northern California. Obviously, it's very strong versus say Westchester. But generally speaking, right now, within the market footprint, our eaves communities are pretty synonymous with the communities as you referred to Axiometrics or transfer any of those. And eaves communities tend to be outperforming right now. To give you some perspective in the fourth quarter for our portfolio, the B assets or the eaves assets, which is for the most part B assets, were about 70 basis points ahead of how the a assets were performing. As you go look at Axiometrics, it's a pretty similar pattern there in terms of the outperformance. So this part of the cycle, well-positioned, value-oriented communities are outperforming. To the extent we are selling one of those communities, it typically is related to either submarket specific or asset specific. The issues we have or concerns about concentration in terms of other activity we might have in the region, that typically drives those disposition decisions as it relates to pretty much any community, but eaves as well.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then bigger picture on the development pipeline, in light of the fact you're projecting your land position to decline in 2016, 26 projects under development, about 10% of your asset base is tied up in development. Where do -- if you were to kind of ro
componenttext: And then bigger picture on the development pipeline, in light of the fact you're projecting your land position to decline in 2016, 26 projects under development, about 10% of your asset base is tied up in development. Where do -- if you were to kind of roll forward 3, 4 years from now, would that number -- would those numbers be materially lower than they are today if you had to hazard a guess?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, this is Tim. I guess is they'll be lower. How material, it really kind of depends a bit on the opportunity set. We've been a little surprised honestly over the last I'd say year, year and a half. But we continue to see we think pretty compelling opp
componenttext: Rich, this is Tim. I guess is they'll be lower. How material, it really kind of depends a bit on the opportunity set. We've been a little surprised honestly over the last I'd say year, year and a half. But we continue to see we think pretty compelling opportunities at reasonable rent prices. So to the extent that things get start getting too expensive or too distorted which they have on a limited basis for instance in the Bay Area where it's tough to make a numbers work in the Bay Area, so all the markets are looking like the Bay Area, it would deplete the development rights inventory pretty quickly. But that's not my guess. I mean, typically, the Northeast and Atlantic can be a little bit more stable. I would expect the expected case would be it would start to draw down a bit over the next 3 years.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And gentlemen, your final question of the day comes from Wes Golladay with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And gentlemen, your final question of the day comes from Wes Golladay with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually Neil on for Wes. Just a question on occupancy. It looked like this quarter saw a pretty strong drop in occupancy across the board, particularly in Northern California. Just wondering if you can comment on that a function of the seasonally we
componenttext: It's actually Neil on for Wes. Just a question on occupancy. It looked like this quarter saw a pretty strong drop in occupancy across the board, particularly in Northern California. Just wondering if you can comment on that a function of the seasonally weak or lower leasing, a function of you switching your expirations to the middle, higher volume, higher velocity of the year, pushing rent too hard. Could you comment on that?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure Neil, this is Sean. One thing to keep in mind is while occupancy was down on a year-over-year basis, if you look at it on a sequential basis, we were actually up 20 basis points. And there were a couple of markets at the end of 2014, particularly Nor
componenttext: Sure Neil, this is Sean. One thing to keep in mind is while occupancy was down on a year-over-year basis, if you look at it on a sequential basis, we were actually up 20 basis points. And there were a couple of markets at the end of 2014, particularly Northern California and the greater New York region, where frankly availability was lower than we had wanted from an idea perspective in terms of pushing pricing and occupancy drifted up a little heavy. So we are not so concerned about the year-over-year change, sequential change. We are perfectly fine with what we're well-positioned today in terms of where we sit we're basically mid-95s in terms of economic occupancy. It's down about 30, 40 basis points, but it's right about where we think we should be. As we look towards the spring, we want to try and put pricing as much as we can and availability is in the mid-5% range. It's up 30, 40 bps from last year at this point in time. But as I mentioned, we thought we're probably in the low side of this point last year. So we think we're in pretty good shape and you're just looking at a year-over-year comp that is creating that change in occupancy.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then lastly is, are you seeing any evidence that in the Bay Area, for some of your rentals on the higher end that people maybe are pushing back or maybe seeing some softness in renewals or new leases that would lead you to indicate that there ma
componenttext: Okay. And then lastly is, are you seeing any evidence that in the Bay Area, for some of your rentals on the higher end that people maybe are pushing back or maybe seeing some softness in renewals or new leases that would lead you to indicate that there may be something more than a temporary blip going on in that market?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Good question. I mean, obviously, Q4 is the typically the slower period. I would say it was a little beyond seasonal adjustment in the fourth quarter, whether it continues to soften a bit, just to be seen. But I think as we indicated earlier, we're e
componenttext: Yes. Good question. I mean, obviously, Q4 is the typically the slower period. I would say it was a little beyond seasonal adjustment in the fourth quarter, whether it continues to soften a bit, just to be seen. But I think as we indicated earlier, we're expecting job growth to slow in that region. Deliveries will be accelerating in that market. So we are expecting it to soften a bit as we move throughout the year, whether that first sign of it in the fourth quarter or not, just to be seen, but we did expect some softening. We realize that. And the question going forward here is with the pace of job growth since we know what supply is going to be. So my expectation is the market will moderate through 2016 given just the fundamentals that are in place.
