componenttext: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the AvalonBay Communities Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Your host for today's call is Mr. Jason Reilley, Senior Director of Investor Relations. Mr. Reilley, please go ahead.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you,Craig, and welcome to AvalonBay Communities fourth quarter 2015 earnings conference call. Before we begin, please note that forward-looking statements may be made during this discussion. There are a variety of risks and uncertainties associated
componenttext:
Thank you,Craig, and welcome to AvalonBay Communities fourth quarter 2015 earnings conference call. Before we begin, please note that forward-looking statements may be made during this discussion. There are a variety of risks and uncertainties associated with forward-looking statements and actual results may differ materially. There is a discussion of these risks and uncertainties in yesterday afternoon's press release as well as in the company's Form 10-K and Form 10-Q filed with the SEC. 
As always, this press release does include an attachment with definitions and reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures and other terms, which may be used in today's discussion. The attachment is also available on our website at www.avalonbay.com/earnings, and we encourage you to refer to this information during the review of our operating results and financial performance. 
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Tim Naughton, Chairman and CEO of AvalonBay Communities, for his remarks. Tim?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Jason, and welcome to our Q4 call. With me today are Kevin O'Shea, Sean Breslin and Matt Birenbaum. Kevin and I will provide commentary on the slides that we posted last night. And then the 4 of us will be available for Q&A afterward. Durin
componenttext:
Yes, thanks, Jason, and welcome to our Q4 call. With me today are Kevin O'Shea, Sean Breslin and Matt Birenbaum. Kevin and I will provide commentary on the slides that we posted last night. And then the 4 of us will be available for Q&A afterward. 
During our comments, we'll focus on providing a summary of Q4 and the full year results and then spend a good part of time talking about the outlook for 2016. I'll talk about the economy, apartment markets and operations and turn it over to Kevin, who will talk about development as well as capital and risk management as we move further into the cycle.
So let's start on Slide 4. Highlights for the quarter and year include core FFO growth in Q4 of 14.4% and 11.4% for the full year, which is about 300 basis points higher than our original outlook at the beginning of the year. And importantly, we continue to generate FFO growth this cycle toward the top of the sector, while having the lowest leverage. 
Q4 same-store revenue growth came in at 5.4% or 5.7% when you include redevelopment, as many of our peers do. And for the full year, same-store revenue growth came in at 5.0% or 5.2%, including redevelopment. Same-store NOI for the year came in at 5.8%. 
We completed about $500 million this quarter at right around a 7% yield and $1.3 billion for the full year, at an initial yield of 6.7%. We started another 4 communities totaling about $400 million in Q4, bringing our full year level starts to roughly $1.2 billion or roughly in line with completions this year.
And lastly, we raised $400 million in new capital in the quarter, principally through a $300 million unsecured debt offering. And for the year, we raised a total of $1.9 billion in capital to fund new investment and refinance maturing debt.
Turning now to Slide 5. The $1.3 billion of new development that we completed this year that I just referenced is contributing to healthy earnings and NAV accretion. Yields of 6.7% are roughly 250 basis points greater than our initial cost of external capital raised this year. And the cost basis of these completions at $310,000 per unit is more than 30% less than the value of our average stabilized asset on a per unit basis, with rents that are 12% to 13% higher, implying that value creation was around 50% over cost or roughly $650 million in net NAV created or $5 per share in 2015 alone.
Turning to Slide 6. In addition to strong financial results, we excelled another important aspects of our business in 2015, including customer satisfaction where we rank #1 nationally among all apartment operators for online reputation. Associate engagement, we are ranked #1 in our sector and #2 among all D.C. metro-based organizations on glassdoor. Corporate responsibility where our multiyear focus are on sustainability, that puts us towards the top of the sector in the U.S. and globally. And community recognition where a number of our newly developed communities are [indiscernible] awards from various industry groups. We probably don't talk enough about this with investors, but we know that achievement and survey, the needs of these important constituencies and our customers, our associates, the communities as well as the shareholders is critical to building the kind of culture and company that can be enduring and successful.
Shifting now to 2016, let's move to Slide 7. We're projecting a 9% core growth in core FFO per share this year, driven by about 2/3 internal operations from the almost 6%, thanks to NOI growth that was exactly at the midpoint. And about 1/3 from new investment activity once you net out the cost of new capital issuance, which is probably mostly from stabilizing new development.
The principal difference in growth between 2015 and '16 is that we expect less external growth from new investment activity, which in turn is being driven by the impact of fewer deliveries in 2015 that we will be stabilizing in '16 and some might even as in the timing of capital raising activity. 
When looking at the earnings impact of our development platform, it's probably more helpful to view it over a multiyear period. For example, if you look at it over the 2015, '16 timeframe here, new investment activity net of changes in capital cost is projected to deliver approximately $0.70 per share to core FFO or around 10% cumulative growth over the 2-year period.
Moving to Slide 8. Given our outlook for 2016, we announced a dividend increase of 8% this year. The dividend is now up by more than 50% over the last 5 years and importantly has grown by 5.5% on a compounded basis over the last 20 years. Dividends are an important component of total return. They represent almost 2/3 of the total return of roughly 1,800% that we've earned over the last 20 years. And that kind of growth really does underscore the accretion and growth embedded in our business model. I think sometimes it gets a little lost during the market volatility and rapid trading activity we're seeing in the sector today.
Turning to Slide 9. Our outlook is being driven in part by the prospect of stable economy continuing into 2016. And from our perspective, appears to have reached midcycle in terms of GDP and employment growth. An improving consumer should benefit from strong, stronger labor market in 2016. And then the public sector is expected to actually contribute to overall economic growth this year, although still at a lesser rate than the private sector after having been a drag for a number of years to overall economic growth.
Turning to Slide 10. Job growth in our markets is projected to outperform the U.S. again in 2016 as it did in '15 at just over 2%. The East Coast is expected to improve in '16, while the tech-heavy West Coast market should moderate off the blistering pace of the last couple of years, although it still remain at healthy levels around 2.5%. 
On Slide 11, total personal income growth, which combines job and per capita income growth is expected to accelerate in 2016 as wage growth gains traction, particularly for the younger millennial cohort most of whom continues to rent. 
Wage growth, as we discussed in the past, become an ever increasing important driver of our business as economic cycle matures and more supply starts to come online in 2016. 
Speaking that, moving to Slide 12 and supply. We do expect that completions in our markets will increase in 2016 by about 50 basis points to around 2% of stock or roughly in line with job growth suggesting pretty stable conditions overall. Of course, some submarkets, particularly in urban cores, we'll see higher levels of deliveries that may impact local markets as owners use concessions to stimulate absorption during lease up. This is particularly true in urban and high-rise product where inventories can build quickly and deliveries tend to occur over a more concentrated period of time. But overall, housing demand should continue to favor the apartment sector due to many of the things that we've been talking about over the last couple of years, including favorable demographics, pent-up demand as Millennials continue to unbundle and ultimately changing lifestyle trends with the late marriage and family formation. All these factors should help support another healthy year for apartment fundamentals in 2016.
And turning to Slide 13. That is reflected in our outlook for our same-store portfolio this year, where we're looking for same-store revenue growth of 4.25% to 5.5%, with modest improvement on the East Coast. While on the West Coast, we expect some moderation in Seattle and Northern California after exceptionally strong growth in 2015. 
Overall then, growth is expected to be healthy with performance between the East and West Coast narrowing a bit in 2016. 
And with that, I'll turn it to Kevin, who will discuss development and capital activity.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. Turning to development activity on Slide 14, we show [indiscernible] under construction in absolute terms and relative to our total enterprise value, both projected for year-end 2016 and historically going back to 2004. As you can see here, o
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. Turning to development activity on Slide 14, we show [indiscernible] under construction in absolute terms and relative to our total enterprise value, both projected for year-end 2016 and historically going back to 2004. As you can see here, ongoing development activity as a percentage of our total enterprise value has been relatively stable over the past few years at around 10%, which is at the low end of our target range. This reflects our continued discipline in allocating capital for this activity as we move further into the cycle.
Moving to Slide 15. Profit margins on our development activity have remained remarkably resilient and healthy in this cycle. Thanks to the underlying strength of apartment fundamentals, our sector-leading development and construction capabilities and the decisions we've made about which opportunities to pursue as the cycle matures. Since 2012, our development completions have increased from about $0.5 billion to more than $1 billion. During that time, development yields have been around 7%, while corresponding cap rates for those particular assets have been at or below 5%, resulting in stable profit margins on development in the low 30% range. 
As shown on Slide 16, communities currently in lease-up continue to provide healthy profit margins. For the 12 communities undergoing initial lease-up in 4Q '15, which represent $970 million in total capital cost, the current weighted average monthly rent per home is $115 above initial expectations. 
In terms of yield performance, the weighted average initial projected stabilized yield for these communities is currently 6.7%, or 30 basis points higher than our original projection of 6.4%.
Turning to Slide 17. I'd like to talk about how we manage risk associated with our development activity. The first way we do so is by maintaining a broadly diversified development pipeline, one that is diversified by geographic regions, by product type and by exposure to urban and suburban submarkets. 
As the chart on Slide 17 illustrate, while our development pipeline remains diversified across regions, future development lies a bias towards infill suburban markets and Midwest products, where rents, construction and land costs are more affordable, development economics are more favorable and the production cycle tend to be faster. Going forward, we expect our development rights pipeline will continue to be an important source of outsized growth in NAV and FFO per share.
Moving to Slide 18. Another way we manage development risk is how we source and structure new development opportunities, with the overwhelming majority being controlled through long-term purchase contracts with modest at-risk deposits and relatively few being controlled through land we purchased and hold on our balance sheet. At the end of 2015, our development rights pipeline consisted of 32 communities, representing $3.4 billion in projected total capital cost. Of these 32 communities, 25 are controlled through purchase contracts while we own the land in the remaining 7. 
In addition, of these 7 where we own the land, 2 account for approximately $420 million of the $485 million in land held for development on our balance sheet. We expect to begin construction on these 2 community Development Rights, Columbus Circle and Hollywood in 2016, which would reduce our projected land held for development by year-end 2016, the lowest level in more than a decade.
A third method which we use to manage development risk is substantially match funding new starts with long-term capital, a topic we've talked about a lot in the cycle. 
On Slide 19, we highlight our funding position against the total projected capital cost of development underway. As you can see, we only need to source about $500 million in long-term capital against the $3.4 billion in development under construction or recently completed, taking into account the $2.2 billion of capital already spent to date, $400 million of unrestricted cash on hand and $350 million of projected annual cash flow from operations after dividends. This means that about 85% of the value creation from ongoing development activity has already been locked in for our shareholders.
Turning to Slide 20. We show how being substantially match-funded significantly enhances our growth in EBITDA, while simultaneously enhancing our already sector-leading credit profile, essentially making us similar to an acquisition-oriented REIT from a funding-risk perspective, but with lower leverage and stronger built in earnings growth. Specifically, the projected EBITDA for recently completed development and from development under construction totals about $216 million, as shown on the chart on the left. This represents about 18% growth in annualized core EBITDA from the fourth quarter. 
Even in a worse case, if all the $480 million of unfunded commitments were funded with new debt, our net debt to core EBITDA would still decline from 4.8x to the mid-4s after taking into account the EBITDA from new development. Of course, our actual net debt to core EBITDA will move around a bit as we source new capital to fund incremental development activity. Therefore this slide isn't meant to communicate that our leverage is going to decrease 4.5x or our target leverage is 4.5x. 
In fact, our target range for this metric is to be roughly between 5x and 6x. Instead, the purpose in showing this slide is to convey that through our match funding strategy, we are optimally positioned to benefit from development activity, that is expected to be accretive both to earnings and balance sheet strength, and that our credit profile is actually enhanced by our profitable development capabilities given our funding strategy. 
And with that, I'll turn it back to Tim.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kevin. And just ending here on Slide 21 before opening up the call. In summary, 2015 was a very good year for the company and the industry. We're expecting 2016 to look a lot like 2015, once again benefiting from above trend growth. I think this o
componenttext:
Thanks, Kevin. And just ending here on Slide 21 before opening up the call. In summary, 2015 was a very good year for the company and the industry. We're expecting 2016 to look a lot like 2015, once again benefiting from above trend growth. I think this outlook is not surprising just given our view that we're midcycle with healthy apartment fundamentals continuing and then just a stable level of deliveries and healthy accretion coming from our developing pipeline. 
As we move further into the mature portion of the economic expansion, we are highly focused on managing the investment and funding risk of the business. And as Kevin mentioned in his remarks, we're doing this through managing the size and diversity of our pipeline, reducing land inventory, match funding new commitments and maintaining leverage at the low end of our target range. 
And with that,Craig, we'd be happy to open up the call for Q&A.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] First from UBS, we have Nick Yulico.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] First from UBS, we have Nick Yulico.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess my first question would be, you have talked a lot about how you've been able to deliver projects at higher yields they're underwriting for the past few years. You continue to do that. But as far as your guidance goes for this year, I mean, what
componenttext: So I guess my first question would be, you have talked a lot about how you've been able to deliver projects at higher yields they're underwriting for the past few years. You continue to do that. But as far as your guidance goes for this year, I mean, what is your -- is your assumption for the development pipeline that you're basically delivering at the yield that you gave on the development page and so that if you actually beat by 30 basis points at the high-end of your range? Or can you just put a little sensitivity around that?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nick, this is Tim, and Matt, feel free to jump in. In terms of the attachment that shows the development pipeline with the projected yield of 6 3, that is based upon current rents and rents marked to market once we start leasing and you get up to about 20
componenttext: Nick, this is Tim, and Matt, feel free to jump in. In terms of the attachment that shows the development pipeline with the projected yield of 6 3, that is based upon current rents and rents marked to market once we start leasing and you get up to about 20%,  25% occupancy. For those communities that have started construction where they may have been market rent growth and we haven't yet started leasing, we haven't marketed those to markets just to be clear. And I think you'd probably see over the last few years, we've totally been beating the initial pro forma yields by 30 to 50 or 60 basis points just because of a strong market rent growth and the fact that we've been able to bring deals in more or less at present cost. So I think it really is, ultimately -- and if you look at the development pipeline today, the shadow pipeline, the deals that haven't yet started, the economics of that look a lot like what the economics look like on the deals that we've been starting over the last couple of years. So I think a lot of it is going to -- how you would underwrite those would depend upon how you'd underwrite the market ultimately in terms of where we're doing business and how you might underwrite construction cost relative to market rent growth change over the next couple of years.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just -- I guess just related back to the guidance though, I mean, should we be assuming that if you are getting the 30 basis points beating on original underwriting, is that already kind of factored into your midpoint of your guidance? Or is that
componenttext: And then just -- I guess just related back to the guidance though, I mean, should we be assuming that if you are getting the 30 basis points beating on original underwriting, is that already kind of factored into your midpoint of your guidance? Or is that sort of gets you to the higher end of your guidance on FFO?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm sorry. In terms of FFO, reflects the budgets for each of those assets, which -- they would have some embedded level of market rent growth commensurate with the markets in which they reside.
componenttext: Yes, I'm sorry. In terms of FFO, reflects the budgets for each of those assets, which -- they would have some embedded level of market rent growth commensurate with the markets in which they reside.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. That's helpful. And just one other question was on, you gave your outlook for U.S. job growth basically being similar to last year. If job growth were to be slowing here, which people are concerned about, where do you think -- which of your
componenttext: Okay. Got it. That's helpful. And just one other question was on, you gave your outlook for U.S. job growth basically being similar to last year. If job growth were to be slowing here, which people are concerned about, where do you think -- which of your markets have the most risk then from a fundamental standpoint?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nick, this is Sean. There's probably a couple of answers to that question. But I guess what I'd probably say based on historical precedent in the markets is the sort of high beta markets, if you want to think about that way tend to be the technology
componenttext: Yes, Nick, this is Sean. There's probably a couple of answers to that question. But I guess what I'd probably say based on historical precedent in the markets is the sort of high beta markets, if you want to think about that way tend to be the technology markets, so Northern California and Seattle, and to have a greater reaction in rent levels relative to given change in job growth in many of our other markets. So the technology markets are the ones you'd probably be most concerned about that's assuming of course that any reduction in job growth is somewhat proportional. In the past, we've had some losses in the energy sector. It has not had a direct effect on our markets, but there's certainly some indirect effects as it relates to reduced amount of capital investment on behalf of those companies is going to ripple through the economy. So those are the markets I'm probably most concerned about given the reduction in job growth.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess just one last quick question and maybe it's for Kevin is that, I think the concern would be that you guys -- although you guys have a great balance sheet and you are mostly funded for the development pipeline today. As you look out a year, you're
componenttext: I guess just one last quick question and maybe it's for Kevin is that, I think the concern would be that you guys -- although you guys have a great balance sheet and you are mostly funded for the development pipeline today. As you look out a year, you're then still starting more projects and people then worried about you guys having to raise capital a year from now, I mean what would be your sort of answer to that, that, that shouldn't be a concern for folks?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there's a few things, Nick. And first of all, as we demonstrated in 2009, if we don't think we have regional access to capital, we don't have to start new projects, that would be one thing to keep in mind. We don't need to keep creating commitments
componenttext: Well, there's a few things, Nick. And first of all, as we demonstrated in 2009, if we don't think we have regional access to capital, we don't have to start new projects, that would be one thing to keep in mind. We don't need to keep creating commitments if we don't think cost-effective capital is available to us in one of our principal funding markets. And I guess the second thing to keep in mind is that we do keep a very strong balance sheet both from a match funding perspective, but also from another dimension, including having low leverage and latter maturities, so that we have an awful lot of flexibility to deal with sort of an air pocket that might exist where there maybe disruption in capital markets before we've been able to sort of just and dial back on new starts. So I think fundamentally, we have great deal of flexibility and the commitments we create and the capital we're going to be able to source from the deal with volatility in the capital markets and that's how we manage the balance sheet.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next we have Nick Joseph from Citi.
componenttext: And next we have Nick Joseph from Citi.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You talked about the development rights pipeline and its current focus on infill suburban submarkets. Do you think that there's a difference in investor demand in terms of the transaction market between urban core assets and infill suburban assets? And th
componenttext: You talked about the development rights pipeline and its current focus on infill suburban submarkets. Do you think that there's a difference in investor demand in terms of the transaction market between urban core assets and infill suburban assets? And then how do you think about that in terms of the IR differential between the two?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nick, this is Matt. There's great demand for almost everything right now. I think there is a difference in cap rates. Clearly, urban core assets do tend to trade at a lower cap rate, how much lower depends on what you're comparing it to. If you're co
componenttext: Yes, Nick, this is Matt. There's great demand for almost everything right now. I think there is a difference in cap rates. Clearly, urban core assets do tend to trade at a lower cap rate, how much lower depends on what you're comparing it to. If you're comparing it to here in D.C., D.C. versus Arlington is not going to be that different versus as compared to say D.C. versus Tysons Corner, for example. So -- but we do reflect that in the target yields that we put out for deals. We look at where we think the cap rates would be on those assets, specific sites today and where we think long-term exit cap rates might be. So we try -- we do factor that in. Going forward, I don't know, it's speculative. There has been foreign capital that's probably preferred to stay mostly in the urban-type of trophy assets, and that's one reason the cap rates are a little bit lower on those. But we've got pretty strong healthy demand for both at this point.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if we were to enter into a recession, do you think there's more stickiness to the urban core cap rates versus the suburban? Or do you think they would move up together?
componenttext: Well, if we were to enter into a recession, do you think there's more stickiness to the urban core cap rates versus the suburban? Or do you think they would move up together?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know, I think every cycle is different, it's hard to know.
componenttext: I don't know, I think every cycle is different, it's hard to know.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nick, I guess, I think, there's probably liquidity premium for the urban core stuff, so to the extent you get into a period of more significant capital dislocation, the probability to being able to move or to monetize an urban asset, I would say is probab
componenttext: Nick, I guess, I think, there's probably liquidity premium for the urban core stuff, so to the extent you get into a period of more significant capital dislocation, the probability to being able to move or to monetize an urban asset, I would say is probably greater than a suburban asset. Or -- and I think that's part of the premium valuation or discount cap, the discount for the cap rate is just that liquidity aspect of it.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of rental affordability overall, are we at a point in the cycle where rental rate growth will more closely track wage growth? Or is there still room to be able to increase rents at a higher pace than overall wage growth?
componenttext: And then in terms of rental affordability overall, are we at a point in the cycle where rental rate growth will more closely track wage growth? Or is there still room to be able to increase rents at a higher pace than overall wage growth?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nick, this is Sean. We are at sort of the upper end range on that metric, it's running around 22%, which is within the band of history, but certainly at the upper end of that band. So there's no question that we need to continue to see income growth
componenttext: Yes, Nick, this is Sean. We are at sort of the upper end range on that metric, it's running around 22%, which is within the band of history, but certainly at the upper end of that band. So there's no question that we need to continue to see income growth to support rental rate growth in the future. So if we had a sudden deceleration in income growth for whatever reason, which is not what's expected, and I think we're seeing that throughout the economy now in terms of pressure on wage growth then there would become greater constraints on pushing rents further in the future, no doubt about it.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nick, just to add to that, when you look at wage growth, we talked about in the past that there is a bifurcated labor market, right, in terms of college grads and non-college grads where you get 5% for the total population, unemployment 2.5% for college g
componenttext: Nick, just to add to that, when you look at wage growth, we talked about in the past that there is a bifurcated labor market, right, in terms of college grads and non-college grads where you get 5% for the total population, unemployment 2.5% for college grads. The majority of our residents are college grads. And we are seeing that they're probably getting higher than average, maybe higher than average wage gains, which provides a little bit more support I think for our business in terms of continue to generate decent rent growth.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nick, just to give you a sense on a year-over-year basis in the fourth quarter, lease income for new residents relative to last year was up more than 5%. So we're seeing that for our population of residence for sure.
componenttext: Nick, just to give you a sense on a year-over-year basis in the fourth quarter, lease income for new residents relative to last year was up more than 5%. So we're seeing that for our population of residence for sure.

componenttext: Gaurav, this is Kevin. As we laid out in our outlook, we anticipate sourcing about $1.1 billion in asset sales in unsecured debt. And I think in terms of the attractiveness of those markets today, both are highly attractive. And I'd say while we don't comment on the preciseness in part because the capital markets themselves can be volatile and the pricing can change over time, of that $1.1 billion, the majority of the capital and our plan is contemplated to come in the form of unsecured debt issuance.

componenttext: Yes, just I think to add to that, you are limited somewhat on how much you can sell from a tax perspective and retain the capital, don't have to do a special dividend just because of the tax gains that are embedded in a lot of the assets that would be on our disposition. componenttext: Yes, I mean, Austin, I mean we say we're primarily looking to rely on debt and asset sales. And we achieved debt deals this past year that we could probably issue debt at about the same pricing today on a 10-year basis, around in the mid-3 somewhere and cap rates are going to range depending upon which market you're selling in, probably from the low 4s to the mid-5s. So they make sense they were more weighted towards leverage, which will likely to be. This year, I think, it gets you probably in the low 4s again like we were in 2015.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's fair. And then just separately, given you guys focus a little bit more on increasing your development exposures in suburban markets. And you've talked a lot about the growth in 35 to 44-year-old age cohort. Just curious about your thoughts given we
componenttext: That's fair. And then just separately, given you guys focus a little bit more on increasing your development exposures in suburban markets. And you've talked a lot about the growth in 35 to 44-year-old age cohort. Just curious about your thoughts given we've kind of seen that homeownership break within that segment tick up here more recently and how you're thinking about that in terms of renter demand moving forward?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Matt. If I can speak to that a little bit and then Sean can you chime in as well. The demographic trends are long trends. I mean the great thing about it is you can see it coming 5, 10 years down the road. And so as we think about how we want to p
componenttext: This is Matt. If I can speak to that a little bit and then Sean can you chime in as well. The demographic trends are long trends. I mean the great thing about it is you can see it coming 5, 10 years down the road. And so as we think about how we want to position our portfolio where we are seeing the best risk adjusted returns, opportunities to invest, our program communities for the future, it's driven by some of those big macro trends. So I don't think a small movement in the homeownership rate on the margins is going to impact that when you look at just the raw numbers coming through pretty dramatic shift that's going to occur here. So I think people have to change a lot before probably changing our opinion on that.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess the only thing to add is, you're really starting to get the leading edge of that echo boom. And if you look back, a lot of you don't realize this, but if you look back over the last 5 to 10 years, the drop in homeownership rates are most pron
componenttext: Yes, I guess the only thing to add is, you're really starting to get the leading edge of that echo boom. And if you look back, a lot of you don't realize this, but if you look back over the last 5 to 10 years, the drop in homeownership rates are most pronounced in that 35 to 44 segment, more so than the 25 to 34 segment. So you have a lot more people moving into that. They drop like 1,100 basis points something like that. And even it picks back up, you're talking about a lot more rental households over the next 10 years coming from that segment. And it's impacting how we're thinking about product right now in terms of providing -- I think we've talked about a signature package in terms of higher level of finish and some larger units that we may be been doing over the last few years and certain deals and it impacts how you think about amenities as well. So we do think it could be a pretty big source of demand and it represents -- that age cohort represents about 20% of our residents today whereas the under 35 cohorts maybe 40%, 45%.

componenttext: John, this is Sean. We are not specifically aware of a, I guess, I'll call it a global offering like Facebook made. Obviously, there are other companies out there recruiting people across America that provide incentives for them to relocate. So -- but it really didn't attract that, it's very episodic in terms of how it occurs. It's just part of the normal [indiscernible] process on a daily basis. So there's nothing material out there that we are aware of other than the recent Facebook offering. And we're not hearing about it in a way that it's influencing our data in any form or fashion.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And it sounds like Northern California may decelerate in revenue growth this year. Can you comment on markets that you see may have the best chance of accelerating growth this year?
componenttext: Okay. And it sounds like Northern California may decelerate in revenue growth this year. Can you comment on markets that you see may have the best chance of accelerating growth this year?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Sean again. I guess what I'd say is, at this point, you properly identified Northern California as one of the markets where there is probably a little bit of concern about slowing, its come up a couple of different times. But in terms of markets tha
componenttext: Sure. Sean again. I guess what I'd say is, at this point, you properly identified Northern California as one of the markets where there is probably a little bit of concern about slowing, its come up a couple of different times. But in terms of markets that has some upside, certainly the Mid-Atlantic is one that has some potential upside in terms of -- we're at a point in the cycle where we know that supply is, it was about 2% last year, it's going to increase to about 2.5% this year. But more importantly, as we're getting pretty good job growth out of the Mid-Atlantic now up in the low 2% range. And it's starting to have nice effect on occupancy and rent change across the markets here. So the expectation is that there's potential for some upside in the Mid-Atlantic. I would not describe it as opportunistic and that there's significant upside. There is still a fair amount of supply coming. And it's not a sort of high bidder market, as I described in the Northern California and Pacific Northwest regions. So you tend to get a moderate recovery. And we are seeing that here in terms of recent trends where rent change is up about 100 basis points in the first quarter as compared to the first quarter of '14, so there's nice momentum there. And then the other market that may have some upside I'd say is Boston. Boston has been performing well, job growth has been steady and supply is projected to increase this year relative to 2015. So there's probably a little bit of potential upside in Boston and the Mid-Atlantic are the 2 that probably stand out the most, I'd say. Southern California has been increasing nicely and we expect that to continue. But I wouldn't think it falls into the potential surprise category like the other 2 did.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the AvalonBay Communities Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Your host for today's call is Mr. Jason Reilley, Senior Director of Investor Relations. Mr. Reilley, please go ahead.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you,Craig, and welcome to AvalonBay Communities fourth quarter 2015 earnings conference call. Before we begin, please note that forward-looking statements may be made during this discussion. There are a variety of risks and uncertainties associated
componenttext:
Thank you,Craig, and welcome to AvalonBay Communities fourth quarter 2015 earnings conference call. Before we begin, please note that forward-looking statements may be made during this discussion. There are a variety of risks and uncertainties associated with forward-looking statements and actual results may differ materially. There is a discussion of these risks and uncertainties in yesterday afternoon's press release as well as in the company's Form 10-K and Form 10-Q filed with the SEC. 
As always, this press release does include an attachment with definitions and reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures and other terms, which may be used in today's discussion. The attachment is also available on our website at www.avalonbay.com/earnings, and we encourage you to refer to this information during the review of our operating results and financial performance. 
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Tim Naughton, Chairman and CEO of AvalonBay Communities, for his remarks. Tim?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Jason, and welcome to our Q4 call. With me today are Kevin O'Shea, Sean Breslin and Matt Birenbaum. Kevin and I will provide commentary on the slides that we posted last night. And then the 4 of us will be available for Q&A afterward. Durin
componenttext:
Yes, thanks, Jason, and welcome to our Q4 call. With me today are Kevin O'Shea, Sean Breslin and Matt Birenbaum. Kevin and I will provide commentary on the slides that we posted last night. And then the 4 of us will be available for Q&A afterward. 
During our comments, we'll focus on providing a summary of Q4 and the full year results and then spend a good part of time talking about the outlook for 2016. I'll talk about the economy, apartment markets and operations and turn it over to Kevin, who will talk about development as well as capital and risk management as we move further into the cycle.
So let's start on Slide 4. Highlights for the quarter and year include core FFO growth in Q4 of 14.4% and 11.4% for the full year, which is about 300 basis points higher than our original outlook at the beginning of the year. And importantly, we continue to generate FFO growth this cycle toward the top of the sector, while having the lowest leverage. 
Q4 same-store revenue growth came in at 5.4% or 5.7% when you include redevelopment, as many of our peers do. And for the full year, same-store revenue growth came in at 5.0% or 5.2%, including redevelopment. Same-store NOI for the year came in at 5.8%. 
We completed about $500 million this quarter at right around a 7% yield and $1.3 billion for the full year, at an initial yield of 6.7%. We started another 4 communities totaling about $400 million in Q4, bringing our full year level starts to roughly $1.2 billion or roughly in line with completions this year.
And lastly, we raised $400 million in new capital in the quarter, principally through a $300 million unsecured debt offering. And for the year, we raised a total of $1.9 billion in capital to fund new investment and refinance maturing debt.
Turning now to Slide 5. The $1.3 billion of new development that we completed this year that I just referenced is contributing to healthy earnings and NAV accretion. Yields of 6.7% are roughly 250 basis points greater than our initial cost of external capital raised this year. And the cost basis of these completions at $310,000 per unit is more than 30% less than the value of our average stabilized asset on a per unit basis, with rents that are 12% to 13% higher, implying that value creation was around 50% over cost or roughly $650 million in net NAV created or $5 per share in 2015 alone.
Turning to Slide 6. In addition to strong financial results, we excelled another important aspects of our business in 2015, including customer satisfaction where we rank #1 nationally among all apartment operators for online reputation. Associate engagement, we are ranked #1 in our sector and #2 among all D.C. metro-based organizations on glassdoor. Corporate responsibility where our multiyear focus are on sustainability, that puts us towards the top of the sector in the U.S. and globally. And community recognition where a number of our newly developed communities are [indiscernible] awards from various industry groups. We probably don't talk enough about this with investors, but we know that achievement and survey, the needs of these important constituencies and our customers, our associates, the communities as well as the shareholders is critical to building the kind of culture and company that can be enduring and successful.
Shifting now to 2016, let's move to Slide 7. We're projecting a 9% core growth in core FFO per share this year, driven by about 2/3 internal operations from the almost 6%, thanks to NOI growth that was exactly at the midpoint. And about 1/3 from new investment activity once you net out the cost of new capital issuance, which is probably mostly from stabilizing new development.
The principal difference in growth between 2015 and '16 is that we expect less external growth from new investment activity, which in turn is being driven by the impact of fewer deliveries in 2015 that we will be stabilizing in '16 and some might even as in the timing of capital raising activity. 
When looking at the earnings impact of our development platform, it's probably more helpful to view it over a multiyear period. For example, if you look at it over the 2015, '16 timeframe here, new investment activity net of changes in capital cost is projected to deliver approximately $0.70 per share to core FFO or around 10% cumulative growth over the 2-year period.
Moving to Slide 8. Given our outlook for 2016, we announced a dividend increase of 8% this year. The dividend is now up by more than 50% over the last 5 years and importantly has grown by 5.5% on a compounded basis over the last 20 years. Dividends are an important component of total return. They represent almost 2/3 of the total return of roughly 1,800% that we've earned over the last 20 years. And that kind of growth really does underscore the accretion and growth embedded in our business model. I think sometimes it gets a little lost during the market volatility and rapid trading activity we're seeing in the sector today.
Turning to Slide 9. Our outlook is being driven in part by the prospect of stable economy continuing into 2016. And from our perspective, appears to have reached midcycle in terms of GDP and employment growth. An improving consumer should benefit from strong, stronger labor market in 2016. And then the public sector is expected to actually contribute to overall economic growth this year, although still at a lesser rate than the private sector after having been a drag for a number of years to overall economic growth.
Turning to Slide 10. Job growth in our markets is projected to outperform the U.S. again in 2016 as it did in '15 at just over 2%. The East Coast is expected to improve in '16, while the tech-heavy West Coast market should moderate off the blistering pace of the last couple of years, although it still remain at healthy levels around 2.5%. 
On Slide 11, total personal income growth, which combines job and per capita income growth is expected to accelerate in 2016 as wage growth gains traction, particularly for the younger millennial cohort most of whom continues to rent. 
Wage growth, as we discussed in the past, become an ever increasing important driver of our business as economic cycle matures and more supply starts to come online in 2016. 
Speaking that, moving to Slide 12 and supply. We do expect that completions in our markets will increase in 2016 by about 50 basis points to around 2% of stock or roughly in line with job growth suggesting pretty stable conditions overall. Of course, some submarkets, particularly in urban cores, we'll see higher levels of deliveries that may impact local markets as owners use concessions to stimulate absorption during lease up. This is particularly true in urban and high-rise product where inventories can build quickly and deliveries tend to occur over a more concentrated period of time. But overall, housing demand should continue to favor the apartment sector due to many of the things that we've been talking about over the last couple of years, including favorable demographics, pent-up demand as Millennials continue to unbundle and ultimately changing lifestyle trends with the late marriage and family formation. All these factors should help support another healthy year for apartment fundamentals in 2016.
And turning to Slide 13. That is reflected in our outlook for our same-store portfolio this year, where we're looking for same-store revenue growth of 4.25% to 5.5%, with modest improvement on the East Coast. While on the West Coast, we expect some moderation in Seattle and Northern California after exceptionally strong growth in 2015. 
Overall then, growth is expected to be healthy with performance between the East and West Coast narrowing a bit in 2016. 
And with that, I'll turn it to Kevin, who will discuss development and capital activity.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. Turning to development activity on Slide 14, we show [indiscernible] under construction in absolute terms and relative to our total enterprise value, both projected for year-end 2016 and historically going back to 2004. As you can see here, o
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. Turning to development activity on Slide 14, we show [indiscernible] under construction in absolute terms and relative to our total enterprise value, both projected for year-end 2016 and historically going back to 2004. As you can see here, ongoing development activity as a percentage of our total enterprise value has been relatively stable over the past few years at around 10%, which is at the low end of our target range. This reflects our continued discipline in allocating capital for this activity as we move further into the cycle.
Moving to Slide 15. Profit margins on our development activity have remained remarkably resilient and healthy in this cycle. Thanks to the underlying strength of apartment fundamentals, our sector-leading development and construction capabilities and the decisions we've made about which opportunities to pursue as the cycle matures. Since 2012, our development completions have increased from about $0.5 billion to more than $1 billion. During that time, development yields have been around 7%, while corresponding cap rates for those particular assets have been at or below 5%, resulting in stable profit margins on development in the low 30% range. 
As shown on Slide 16, communities currently in lease-up continue to provide healthy profit margins. For the 12 communities undergoing initial lease-up in 4Q '15, which represent $970 million in total capital cost, the current weighted average monthly rent per home is $115 above initial expectations. 
In terms of yield performance, the weighted average initial projected stabilized yield for these communities is currently 6.7%, or 30 basis points higher than our original projection of 6.4%.
Turning to Slide 17. I'd like to talk about how we manage risk associated with our development activity. The first way we do so is by maintaining a broadly diversified development pipeline, one that is diversified by geographic regions, by product type and by exposure to urban and suburban submarkets. 
As the chart on Slide 17 illustrate, while our development pipeline remains diversified across regions, future development lies a bias towards infill suburban markets and Midwest products, where rents, construction and land costs are more affordable, development economics are more favorable and the production cycle tend to be faster. Going forward, we expect our development rights pipeline will continue to be an important source of outsized growth in NAV and FFO per share.
Moving to Slide 18. Another way we manage development risk is how we source and structure new development opportunities, with the overwhelming majority being controlled through long-term purchase contracts with modest at-risk deposits and relatively few being controlled through land we purchased and hold on our balance sheet. At the end of 2015, our development rights pipeline consisted of 32 communities, representing $3.4 billion in projected total capital cost. Of these 32 communities, 25 are controlled through purchase contracts while we own the land in the remaining 7. 
In addition, of these 7 where we own the land, 2 account for approximately $420 million of the $485 million in land held for development on our balance sheet. We expect to begin construction on these 2 community Development Rights, Columbus Circle and Hollywood in 2016, which would reduce our projected land held for development by year-end 2016, the lowest level in more than a decade.
A third method which we use to manage development risk is substantially match funding new starts with long-term capital, a topic we've talked about a lot in the cycle. 
On Slide 19, we highlight our funding position against the total projected capital cost of development underway. As you can see, we only need to source about $500 million in long-term capital against the $3.4 billion in development under construction or recently completed, taking into account the $2.2 billion of capital already spent to date, $400 million of unrestricted cash on hand and $350 million of projected annual cash flow from operations after dividends. This means that about 85% of the value creation from ongoing development activity has already been locked in for our shareholders.
Turning to Slide 20. We show how being substantially match-funded significantly enhances our growth in EBITDA, while simultaneously enhancing our already sector-leading credit profile, essentially making us similar to an acquisition-oriented REIT from a funding-risk perspective, but with lower leverage and stronger built in earnings growth. Specifically, the projected EBITDA for recently completed development and from development under construction totals about $216 million, as shown on the chart on the left. This represents about 18% growth in annualized core EBITDA from the fourth quarter. 
Even in a worse case, if all the $480 million of unfunded commitments were funded with new debt, our net debt to core EBITDA would still decline from 4.8x to the mid-4s after taking into account the EBITDA from new development. Of course, our actual net debt to core EBITDA will move around a bit as we source new capital to fund incremental development activity. Therefore this slide isn't meant to communicate that our leverage is going to decrease 4.5x or our target leverage is 4.5x. 
In fact, our target range for this metric is to be roughly between 5x and 6x. Instead, the purpose in showing this slide is to convey that through our match funding strategy, we are optimally positioned to benefit from development activity, that is expected to be accretive both to earnings and balance sheet strength, and that our credit profile is actually enhanced by our profitable development capabilities given our funding strategy. 
And with that, I'll turn it back to Tim.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kevin. And just ending here on Slide 21 before opening up the call. In summary, 2015 was a very good year for the company and the industry. We're expecting 2016 to look a lot like 2015, once again benefiting from above trend growth. I think this o
componenttext:
Thanks, Kevin. And just ending here on Slide 21 before opening up the call. In summary, 2015 was a very good year for the company and the industry. We're expecting 2016 to look a lot like 2015, once again benefiting from above trend growth. I think this outlook is not surprising just given our view that we're midcycle with healthy apartment fundamentals continuing and then just a stable level of deliveries and healthy accretion coming from our developing pipeline. 
As we move further into the mature portion of the economic expansion, we are highly focused on managing the investment and funding risk of the business. And as Kevin mentioned in his remarks, we're doing this through managing the size and diversity of our pipeline, reducing land inventory, match funding new commitments and maintaining leverage at the low end of our target range. 
And with that,Craig, we'd be happy to open up the call for Q&A.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] First from UBS, we have Nick Yulico.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] First from UBS, we have Nick Yulico.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess my first question would be, you have talked a lot about how you've been able to deliver projects at higher yields they're underwriting for the past few years. You continue to do that. But as far as your guidance goes for this year, I mean, what
componenttext: So I guess my first question would be, you have talked a lot about how you've been able to deliver projects at higher yields they're underwriting for the past few years. You continue to do that. But as far as your guidance goes for this year, I mean, what is your -- is your assumption for the development pipeline that you're basically delivering at the yield that you gave on the development page and so that if you actually beat by 30 basis points at the high-end of your range? Or can you just put a little sensitivity around that?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nick, this is Tim, and Matt, feel free to jump in. In terms of the attachment that shows the development pipeline with the projected yield of 6 3, that is based upon current rents and rents marked to market once we start leasing and you get up to about 20
componenttext: Nick, this is Tim, and Matt, feel free to jump in. In terms of the attachment that shows the development pipeline with the projected yield of 6 3, that is based upon current rents and rents marked to market once we start leasing and you get up to about 20%,  25% occupancy. For those communities that have started construction where they may have been market rent growth and we haven't yet started leasing, we haven't marketed those to markets just to be clear. And I think you'd probably see over the last few years, we've totally been beating the initial pro forma yields by 30 to 50 or 60 basis points just because of a strong market rent growth and the fact that we've been able to bring deals in more or less at present cost. So I think it really is, ultimately -- and if you look at the development pipeline today, the shadow pipeline, the deals that haven't yet started, the economics of that look a lot like what the economics look like on the deals that we've been starting over the last couple of years. So I think a lot of it is going to -- how you would underwrite those would depend upon how you'd underwrite the market ultimately in terms of where we're doing business and how you might underwrite construction cost relative to market rent growth change over the next couple of years.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just -- I guess just related back to the guidance though, I mean, should we be assuming that if you are getting the 30 basis points beating on original underwriting, is that already kind of factored into your midpoint of your guidance? Or is that
componenttext: And then just -- I guess just related back to the guidance though, I mean, should we be assuming that if you are getting the 30 basis points beating on original underwriting, is that already kind of factored into your midpoint of your guidance? Or is that sort of gets you to the higher end of your guidance on FFO?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm sorry. In terms of FFO, reflects the budgets for each of those assets, which -- they would have some embedded level of market rent growth commensurate with the markets in which they reside.
componenttext: Yes, I'm sorry. In terms of FFO, reflects the budgets for each of those assets, which -- they would have some embedded level of market rent growth commensurate with the markets in which they reside.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. That's helpful. And just one other question was on, you gave your outlook for U.S. job growth basically being similar to last year. If job growth were to be slowing here, which people are concerned about, where do you think -- which of your
componenttext: Okay. Got it. That's helpful. And just one other question was on, you gave your outlook for U.S. job growth basically being similar to last year. If job growth were to be slowing here, which people are concerned about, where do you think -- which of your markets have the most risk then from a fundamental standpoint?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nick, this is Sean. There's probably a couple of answers to that question. But I guess what I'd probably say based on historical precedent in the markets is the sort of high beta markets, if you want to think about that way tend to be the technology
componenttext: Yes, Nick, this is Sean. There's probably a couple of answers to that question. But I guess what I'd probably say based on historical precedent in the markets is the sort of high beta markets, if you want to think about that way tend to be the technology markets, so Northern California and Seattle, and to have a greater reaction in rent levels relative to given change in job growth in many of our other markets. So the technology markets are the ones you'd probably be most concerned about that's assuming of course that any reduction in job growth is somewhat proportional. In the past, we've had some losses in the energy sector. It has not had a direct effect on our markets, but there's certainly some indirect effects as it relates to reduced amount of capital investment on behalf of those companies is going to ripple through the economy. So those are the markets I'm probably most concerned about given the reduction in job growth.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess just one last quick question and maybe it's for Kevin is that, I think the concern would be that you guys -- although you guys have a great balance sheet and you are mostly funded for the development pipeline today. As you look out a year, you're
componenttext: I guess just one last quick question and maybe it's for Kevin is that, I think the concern would be that you guys -- although you guys have a great balance sheet and you are mostly funded for the development pipeline today. As you look out a year, you're then still starting more projects and people then worried about you guys having to raise capital a year from now, I mean what would be your sort of answer to that, that, that shouldn't be a concern for folks?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there's a few things, Nick. And first of all, as we demonstrated in 2009, if we don't think we have regional access to capital, we don't have to start new projects, that would be one thing to keep in mind. We don't need to keep creating commitments
componenttext: Well, there's a few things, Nick. And first of all, as we demonstrated in 2009, if we don't think we have regional access to capital, we don't have to start new projects, that would be one thing to keep in mind. We don't need to keep creating commitments if we don't think cost-effective capital is available to us in one of our principal funding markets. And I guess the second thing to keep in mind is that we do keep a very strong balance sheet both from a match funding perspective, but also from another dimension, including having low leverage and latter maturities, so that we have an awful lot of flexibility to deal with sort of an air pocket that might exist where there maybe disruption in capital markets before we've been able to sort of just and dial back on new starts. So I think fundamentally, we have great deal of flexibility and the commitments we create and the capital we're going to be able to source from the deal with volatility in the capital markets and that's how we manage the balance sheet.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next we have Nick Joseph from Citi.
componenttext: And next we have Nick Joseph from Citi.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You talked about the development rights pipeline and its current focus on infill suburban submarkets. Do you think that there's a difference in investor demand in terms of the transaction market between urban core assets and infill suburban assets? And th
componenttext: You talked about the development rights pipeline and its current focus on infill suburban submarkets. Do you think that there's a difference in investor demand in terms of the transaction market between urban core assets and infill suburban assets? And then how do you think about that in terms of the IR differential between the two?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nick, this is Matt. There's great demand for almost everything right now. I think there is a difference in cap rates. Clearly, urban core assets do tend to trade at a lower cap rate, how much lower depends on what you're comparing it to. If you're co
componenttext: Yes, Nick, this is Matt. There's great demand for almost everything right now. I think there is a difference in cap rates. Clearly, urban core assets do tend to trade at a lower cap rate, how much lower depends on what you're comparing it to. If you're comparing it to here in D.C., D.C. versus Arlington is not going to be that different versus as compared to say D.C. versus Tysons Corner, for example. So -- but we do reflect that in the target yields that we put out for deals. We look at where we think the cap rates would be on those assets, specific sites today and where we think long-term exit cap rates might be. So we try -- we do factor that in. Going forward, I don't know, it's speculative. There has been foreign capital that's probably preferred to stay mostly in the urban-type of trophy assets, and that's one reason the cap rates are a little bit lower on those. But we've got pretty strong healthy demand for both at this point.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if we were to enter into a recession, do you think there's more stickiness to the urban core cap rates versus the suburban? Or do you think they would move up together?
componenttext: Well, if we were to enter into a recession, do you think there's more stickiness to the urban core cap rates versus the suburban? Or do you think they would move up together?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know, I think every cycle is different, it's hard to know.
componenttext: I don't know, I think every cycle is different, it's hard to know.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nick, I guess, I think, there's probably liquidity premium for the urban core stuff, so to the extent you get into a period of more significant capital dislocation, the probability to being able to move or to monetize an urban asset, I would say is probab
componenttext: Nick, I guess, I think, there's probably liquidity premium for the urban core stuff, so to the extent you get into a period of more significant capital dislocation, the probability to being able to move or to monetize an urban asset, I would say is probably greater than a suburban asset. Or -- and I think that's part of the premium valuation or discount cap, the discount for the cap rate is just that liquidity aspect of it.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of rental affordability overall, are we at a point in the cycle where rental rate growth will more closely track wage growth? Or is there still room to be able to increase rents at a higher pace than overall wage growth?
componenttext: And then in terms of rental affordability overall, are we at a point in the cycle where rental rate growth will more closely track wage growth? Or is there still room to be able to increase rents at a higher pace than overall wage growth?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nick, this is Sean. We are at sort of the upper end range on that metric, it's running around 22%, which is within the band of history, but certainly at the upper end of that band. So there's no question that we need to continue to see income growth
componenttext: Yes, Nick, this is Sean. We are at sort of the upper end range on that metric, it's running around 22%, which is within the band of history, but certainly at the upper end of that band. So there's no question that we need to continue to see income growth to support rental rate growth in the future. So if we had a sudden deceleration in income growth for whatever reason, which is not what's expected, and I think we're seeing that throughout the economy now in terms of pressure on wage growth then there would become greater constraints on pushing rents further in the future, no doubt about it.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nick, just to add to that, when you look at wage growth, we talked about in the past that there is a bifurcated labor market, right, in terms of college grads and non-college grads where you get 5% for the total population, unemployment 2.5% for college g
componenttext: Nick, just to add to that, when you look at wage growth, we talked about in the past that there is a bifurcated labor market, right, in terms of college grads and non-college grads where you get 5% for the total population, unemployment 2.5% for college grads. The majority of our residents are college grads. And we are seeing that they're probably getting higher than average, maybe higher than average wage gains, which provides a little bit more support I think for our business in terms of continue to generate decent rent growth.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nick, just to give you a sense on a year-over-year basis in the fourth quarter, lease income for new residents relative to last year was up more than 5%. So we're seeing that for our population of residence for sure.
componenttext: Nick, just to give you a sense on a year-over-year basis in the fourth quarter, lease income for new residents relative to last year was up more than 5%. So we're seeing that for our population of residence for sure.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next we'll go to Gaurav Mehta with Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: Next we'll go to Gaurav Mehta with Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Going back to your funding activity, can you talk about how you're thinking about asset sales versus capital markets today?
componenttext: Going back to your funding activity, can you talk about how you're thinking about asset sales versus capital markets today?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gaurav, this is Kevin. As we laid out in our outlook, we anticipate sourcing about $1.1 billion in asset sales in unsecured debt. And I think in terms of the attractiveness of those markets today, both are highly attractive. And I'd say while we don't com
componenttext: Gaurav, this is Kevin. As we laid out in our outlook, we anticipate sourcing about $1.1 billion in asset sales in unsecured debt. And I think in terms of the attractiveness of those markets today, both are highly attractive. And I'd say while we don't comment on the preciseness in part because the capital markets themselves can be volatile and the pricing can change over time, of that $1.1 billion, the majority of the capital and our plan is contemplated to come in the form of unsecured debt issuance.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So no -- not much asset sales this year?
componenttext: So no -- not much asset sales this year?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, $12.1 billion, so we haven't again precisely identified the actual mix. But a minority of that amount was coming through asset sales, the majority will come through unsecured debt is our current capital plan. Tim, you want to add to that?
componenttext: Well, $12.1 billion, so we haven't again precisely identified the actual mix. But a minority of that amount was coming through asset sales, the majority will come through unsecured debt is our current capital plan. Tim, you want to add to that?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just I think to add to that, you are limited somewhat on how much you can sell from a tax perspective and retain the capital, don't have to do a special dividend just because of the tax gains that are embedded in a lot of the assets that would be on
componenttext: Yes, just I think to add to that, you are limited somewhat on how much you can sell from a tax perspective and retain the capital, don't have to do a special dividend just because of the tax gains that are embedded in a lot of the assets that would be on our disposition. So that would impact at the margins in terms of how you might think about debt versus asset sales. So...

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the other point to bear in mind is that, with our leverage being a little bit -- currently being a little bit below our target level, we've got capacity for incremental debt, particularly when we give us taxes [ph] deleveraging impact of stabilizing d
componenttext: And the other point to bear in mind is that, with our leverage being a little bit -- currently being a little bit below our target level, we've got capacity for incremental debt, particularly when we give us taxes [ph] deleveraging impact of stabilizing development.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then lastly, on your development pipeline, the 6.3% average yield that you have on your current pipeline, is it possible to break it down between your expectations for just suburban versus urban assets?
componenttext: Okay. And then lastly, on your development pipeline, the 6.3% average yield that you have on your current pipeline, is it possible to break it down between your expectations for just suburban versus urban assets?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't really broken it down that way. It really varies by market. I mean, yields are lower in New York City, our cap rates are lower. So maybe they're a little lower on the urban stuff. Again, we think cap rates are 25 to 50 basis points lower on the
componenttext: We haven't really broken it down that way. It really varies by market. I mean, yields are lower in New York City, our cap rates are lower. So maybe they're a little lower on the urban stuff. Again, we think cap rates are 25 to 50 basis points lower on the existing assets. I don't know that there are urban yields are that much lower, but they're probably a little bit lower.
