componenttextpreview: Yes, I think probably in that ballpark.[indiscernible]
componenttext: Yes, I think probably in that ballpark.[indiscernible]

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, Austin, I mean we say we're primarily looking to rely on debt and asset sales. And we achieved debt deals this past year that we could probably issue debt at about the same pricing today on a 10-year basis, around in the mid-3 somewhere and c
componenttext: Yes, I mean, Austin, I mean we say we're primarily looking to rely on debt and asset sales. And we achieved debt deals this past year that we could probably issue debt at about the same pricing today on a 10-year basis, around in the mid-3 somewhere and cap rates are going to range depending upon which market you're selling in, probably from the low 4s to the mid-5s. So they make sense they were more weighted towards leverage, which will likely to be. This year, I think, it gets you probably in the low 4s again like we were in 2015.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's fair. And then just separately, given you guys focus a little bit more on increasing your development exposures in suburban markets. And you've talked a lot about the growth in 35 to 44-year-old age cohort. Just curious about your thoughts given we
componenttext: That's fair. And then just separately, given you guys focus a little bit more on increasing your development exposures in suburban markets. And you've talked a lot about the growth in 35 to 44-year-old age cohort. Just curious about your thoughts given we've kind of seen that homeownership break within that segment tick up here more recently and how you're thinking about that in terms of renter demand moving forward?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Matt. If I can speak to that a little bit and then Sean can you chime in as well. The demographic trends are long trends. I mean the great thing about it is you can see it coming 5, 10 years down the road. And so as we think about how we want to p
componenttext: This is Matt. If I can speak to that a little bit and then Sean can you chime in as well. The demographic trends are long trends. I mean the great thing about it is you can see it coming 5, 10 years down the road. And so as we think about how we want to position our portfolio where we are seeing the best risk adjusted returns, opportunities to invest, our program communities for the future, it's driven by some of those big macro trends. So I don't think a small movement in the homeownership rate on the margins is going to impact that when you look at just the raw numbers coming through pretty dramatic shift that's going to occur here. So I think people have to change a lot before probably changing our opinion on that.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess the only thing to add is, you're really starting to get the leading edge of that echo boom. And if you look back, a lot of you don't realize this, but if you look back over the last 5 to 10 years, the drop in homeownership rates are most pron
componenttext: Yes, I guess the only thing to add is, you're really starting to get the leading edge of that echo boom. And if you look back, a lot of you don't realize this, but if you look back over the last 5 to 10 years, the drop in homeownership rates are most pronounced in that 35 to 44 segment, more so than the 25 to 34 segment. So you have a lot more people moving into that. They drop like 1,100 basis points something like that. And even it picks back up, you're talking about a lot more rental households over the next 10 years coming from that segment. And it's impacting how we're thinking about product right now in terms of providing -- I think we've talked about a signature package in terms of higher level of finish and some larger units that we may be been doing over the last few years and certain deals and it impacts how you think about amenities as well. So we do think it could be a pretty big source of demand and it represents -- that age cohort represents about 20% of our residents today whereas the under 35 cohorts maybe 40%, 45%.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from John Kim with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from John Kim with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: There was a recent article that Facebook was offering employees $10,000 to $15,000 to move closer to its headquarters in Menlo Park. I'm wondering if you had heard other Silicon Valley companies doing this? Have you see any impacts in your properties?
componenttext: There was a recent article that Facebook was offering employees $10,000 to $15,000 to move closer to its headquarters in Menlo Park. I'm wondering if you had heard other Silicon Valley companies doing this? Have you see any impacts in your properties?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, this is Sean. We are not specifically aware of a, I guess, I'll call it a global offering like Facebook made. Obviously, there are other companies out there recruiting people across America that provide incentives for them to relocate. So -- but it
componenttext: John, this is Sean. We are not specifically aware of a, I guess, I'll call it a global offering like Facebook made. Obviously, there are other companies out there recruiting people across America that provide incentives for them to relocate. So -- but it really didn't attract that, it's very episodic in terms of how it occurs. It's just part of the normal [indiscernible] process on a daily basis. So there's nothing material out there that we are aware of other than the recent Facebook offering. And we're not hearing about it in a way that it's influencing our data in any form or fashion.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And it sounds like Northern California may decelerate in revenue growth this year. Can you comment on markets that you see may have the best chance of accelerating growth this year?
componenttext: Okay. And it sounds like Northern California may decelerate in revenue growth this year. Can you comment on markets that you see may have the best chance of accelerating growth this year?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Sean again. I guess what I'd say is, at this point, you properly identified Northern California as one of the markets where there is probably a little bit of concern about slowing, its come up a couple of different times. But in terms of markets tha
componenttext: Sure. Sean again. I guess what I'd say is, at this point, you properly identified Northern California as one of the markets where there is probably a little bit of concern about slowing, its come up a couple of different times. But in terms of markets that has some upside, certainly the Mid-Atlantic is one that has some potential upside in terms of -- we're at a point in the cycle where we know that supply is, it was about 2% last year, it's going to increase to about 2.5% this year. But more importantly, as we're getting pretty good job growth out of the Mid-Atlantic now up in the low 2% range. And it's starting to have nice effect on occupancy and rent change across the markets here. So the expectation is that there's potential for some upside in the Mid-Atlantic. I would not describe it as opportunistic and that there's significant upside. There is still a fair amount of supply coming. And it's not a sort of high bidder market, as I described in the Northern California and Pacific Northwest regions. So you tend to get a moderate recovery. And we are seeing that here in terms of recent trends where rent change is up about 100 basis points in the first quarter as compared to the first quarter of '14, so there's nice momentum there. And then the other market that may have some upside I'd say is Boston. Boston has been performing well, job growth has been steady and supply is projected to increase this year relative to 2015. So there's probably a little bit of potential upside in Boston and the Mid-Atlantic are the 2 that probably stand out the most, I'd say. Southern California has been increasing nicely and we expect that to continue. But I wouldn't think it falls into the potential surprise category like the other 2 did.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

And so essentially becomes a source of cash for us in 2016, and that's from a funding point of view, how we view it.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned rent as the percent of income is kind of at the upper end of historical ranges. Any submarkets where you're above the prior peaks? And how do you think about, maybe, millennial budgets where they might not have a car?
componenttext: You mentioned rent as the percent of income is kind of at the upper end of historical ranges. Any submarkets where you're above the prior peaks? And how do you think about, maybe, millennial budgets where they might not have a car?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jana. Good question. In terms of markets where it's, I guess, constrained, there's not necessarily any one market that's well beyond historical ranges. You've got -- certain markets are more expensive, but obviously you've got people making substanti
componenttext: Yes, Jana. Good question. In terms of markets where it's, I guess, constrained, there's not necessarily any one market that's well beyond historical ranges. You've got -- certain markets are more expensive, but obviously you've got people making substantially more income. So there's nothing that's on the extreme outlier side, if you want to call it that. And we do try to take into account millennials and the choices they make. So those numbers tend to be higher, and some of those urban locations where people don't have cars using metro or the subway or whatever it might be. So we do find that in those cases, people are in a position where they can tend to spend a little bit more of their income on rent than in other geographies. So it's a fair point.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then maybe just on your outlook for your metro New York, New Jersey portfolio. Can you maybe talk to the different submarkets, as certain submarkets are seeing much more supply than others?
componenttext: And then maybe just on your outlook for your metro New York, New Jersey portfolio. Can you maybe talk to the different submarkets, as certain submarkets are seeing much more supply than others?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. In terms of the Greater New York and Jersey market, I mean, if you look at it across the New York City, northern New Jersey, central New Jersey, Long Island and Westchester, it's a pretty diverse geography. A lot of the supply is concentrated in New
componenttext: Sure. In terms of the Greater New York and Jersey market, I mean, if you look at it across the New York City, northern New Jersey, central New Jersey, Long Island and Westchester, it's a pretty diverse geography. A lot of the supply is concentrated in New York City and northern New Jersey. So if you look at Hudson County and then you spread throughout the boroughs, you're going to see that. Supply as a percent of inventory still on Westchester, Long Island, central New Jersey is pretty insignificant. So even though you have greater demand in those markets that identify with greater supply, there's a lid on growth next year as a result of it. So it is not a wide variation for the most part. New York and Jersey is going to be probably in the mid to high 3% range. There's not one market that's in the low 2s and another one in the 5s, just to give you some perspective, if that helps. It's a pretty tight range.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next from Janney, we have Rob Stevenson.
componenttext: Next from Janney, we have Rob Stevenson.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sean, can you do more or less the same for the D.C. submarkets? I mean, in terms of fourth quarter performance, was there any bifurcation by sort of the submarket in the D.C. Metro? And then in terms of your 2016 outlook, any material differential on expe
componenttext: Sean, can you do more or less the same for the D.C. submarkets? I mean, in terms of fourth quarter performance, was there any bifurcation by sort of the submarket in the D.C. Metro? And then in terms of your 2016 outlook, any material differential on expectations between D.C. proper, Northern Virginia, et cetera?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. As it relates to the, I'll call it sort of recent momentum, including the fourth quarter and spillover into early 2016, I'd say the laggard across the metro area has been suburban Maryland. Job growth has been okay, but the supply has been heavy and
componenttext: Sure. As it relates to the, I'll call it sort of recent momentum, including the fourth quarter and spillover into early 2016, I'd say the laggard across the metro area has been suburban Maryland. Job growth has been okay, but the supply has been heavy and steady throughout that region, particularly Rockville, North Bethesda, Chevy Chase has been in [indiscernible] supply. So it's been the softest. The strongest has been in and around D.C. So D.C. proper as well as the close in sort of R.B. corridor and things like that, towns and submarkets that are close in to D.C. and then I'd say the rest in Northern Virginia kind of falls into the second place. So I think they call it the district and immediately adjacent submarkets, Northern Virginia and then suburban Maryland being the laggard just kind of recent conditions. In terms of expected performance in '16, what we have is overall for the Mid-Atlantic, probably in the mid-1% range. And again, it's relatively tight, I'd say. We're talking about the suburban Maryland probably right at the midpoint there. We may see a little bit better performance at D.C., just given the nature of our specific assets in D.C., which is the Gallery Place, Foxhall, stuff in the Northwest corridor that's older and rent-controlled. When you look at it from a market perspective, I would say the one thing to be cautious about is the greatest amount of supply to be delivered in 2016 is in the district. Because depending on the distribution of your portfolio within the district, really it'll dictate what your performance is going to be. So the way I think the market would probably look at it is D.C. people would probably expect to be a little bit softer given the nature of the deliveries. Infill suburban submarkets probably in Virginia performing better. And then Western Fairfax, I would say, and suburban Maryland probably being the laggard.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then can you also talk about the expectations for the 3 main Southern California submarkets in 2016? And how you see that sort of shaping up? And any type of issues in any of the individual markets that you're worried about from a supply standpo
componenttext: Okay. And then can you also talk about the expectations for the 3 main Southern California submarkets in 2016? And how you see that sort of shaping up? And any type of issues in any of the individual markets that you're worried about from a supply standpoint?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Happy to talk about that. In terms of again recent performance rolling forward -- I'm going to try to keep this relatively brief without going on too long here, but where we've started to see some supply impact is in Orange County. Orange County has
componenttext: Sure. Happy to talk about that. In terms of again recent performance rolling forward -- I'm going to try to keep this relatively brief without going on too long here, but where we've started to see some supply impact is in Orange County. Orange County has softened up a little bit with a fair amount of supply coming into Irvine, some in Laguna Hills, supply in Anaheim, there's been supply in Huntington Beach, little bit in Costa Mesa. So that's softened a little bit, and our expectation for '16 for that market is for it to trial the other regions as well because of the same issues. San Diego and L.A., we expect a lead going into '16 and continue throughout the year. And for the most part, that's not only the nature of the markets, but how our portfolio is positioned, which is for the most part it's B assets in suburban submarkets across San Diego, which is relatively small portfolio, but that's where the majority of our assets are located. And in Los Angeles, same thing in terms of distribution of the assets within those submarkets. We don't have any same-store assets in downtown L.A, as an example, which is getting supply now that's equal to double-digit percentages of existing inventory. So you're going to have softness in some of those submarkets, like downtown L.A., where you're getting a heavy amount of new deliveries. So I'd say for '16, overall, you're probably going to see L.A., San Diego leading, and Orange County lagging, just given the nature of our portfolio, but also just from the market perspective in terms of where the supply is concentrated.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next up, we have Ian Weissman with Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: And next up, we have Ian Weissman with Crdit Suisse.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Kris for Ian. Obviously, you don't do a lot of acquisitions. Can you talk a little bit about the -- what motivated you to do the Avalon Hoboken? And what about -- what's the forward cap rate on that asset?
componenttext: This is Kris for Ian. Obviously, you don't do a lot of acquisitions. Can you talk a little bit about the -- what motivated you to do the Avalon Hoboken? And what about -- what's the forward cap rate on that asset?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Chris, this is Matt. You're right. We haven't done a lot of acquisitions historically in this cycle. So at this point, what we are doing is we're trying to -- we are always looking for opportunities to improve our portfolio where we can, and that ha
componenttext: Sure. Chris, this is Matt. You're right. We haven't done a lot of acquisitions historically in this cycle. So at this point, what we are doing is we're trying to -- we are always looking for opportunities to improve our portfolio where we can, and that happened to be a very unique opportunity there in Hoboken. We weren't, per se, looking to adding New Jersey on a net basis, but we're always looking to improve our submarket exposure. It's a highly supply-protected submarkets. It's one of the few parts of New Jersey we have not been able to penetrate through new development. It's a -- the cap rate is about 5, which is pretty attractive for an asset that's only 7 years old. The average unit size there is about 1,000 square feet. So it's actually more targeted at families and -- than necessarily at young singles, and that's what -- in that part of Hoboken, it's kind of interesting to see how it's evolving in that way as Hoboken kind of matures as a desirable location, not just for people kind of right out of school, but for people, married couples, be a little bit older as well. There's a supermarket right next door. So it was just a unique opportunity, and we feel like we are able to, based on some unique characteristics of the way the asset was marketed, get it at a price that was more compelling than most of the acquisition opportunities we're seeing.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And maybe just to add to that, maybe implicating your question too, I mean, we're not looking at acquisitions as a growth platform right now, to be clear. But we are seeing a lot of volume, and we see it as an opportunity to potentially upgrade the portfo
componenttext: And maybe just to add to that, maybe implicating your question too, I mean, we're not looking at acquisitions as a growth platform right now, to be clear. But we are seeing a lot of volume, and we see it as an opportunity to potentially upgrade the portfolio. And so we do look at it sort of mid-cycle. We see a lot of volume. We're focused both on asset management and portfolio management to try to upgrade and improve the portfolio as we can. And as I mentioned earlier in one of the other questions, we are somewhat limited in terms of how much dispositions we can do before you can't retain a capital anymore. But we do see that as -- we do have some assets we like to sell. And we are seeing an active transaction market, where we see assets we'd prefer to own and so we are trying to do some fair trade along the way as well.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful. And then the 5 is, how much CapEx per unit is in there?
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And then the 5 is, how much CapEx per unit is in there?

componenttextpreview: Normally, when we call it cap rate, it's just kind of typical market convention. So I don't know the exact number, but this is again a fairly young asset, so my guess is something like 400, 500 units, something like that.
componenttext: Normally, when we call it cap rate, it's just kind of typical market convention. So I don't know the exact number, but this is again a fairly young asset, so my guess is something like 400, 500 units, something like that.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then, I appreciate all the color on the [indiscernible] you guys do on the development pipeline, but just wondering if you can give us some perspective of where cap rat spreads were on. News starts before the market entered a downturn las
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then, I appreciate all the color on the [indiscernible] you guys do on the development pipeline, but just wondering if you can give us some perspective of where cap rat spreads were on. News starts before the market entered a downturn last time around? And then, were those spreads ended up? And then I guess at the 250 basis point cap rates that you got now, is that enough cushion to kind of stay profitable, if things turn?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Tim. I would say we're probably looking at development yields around, where we're looking at today, in the mid-6s. There was a year or 2 where, I think, that came in around closer to 5 in terms of actual performance. Conversely, I would say,
componenttext: Yes. This is Tim. I would say we're probably looking at development yields around, where we're looking at today, in the mid-6s. There was a year or 2 where, I think, that came in around closer to 5 in terms of actual performance. Conversely, I would say, cap rates were probably in the mid-4s, where they are today. And really, as you know, there're hardly any trades at all, but to the extent there were trades, it probably went north of 6 for a year or 2. But hopefully, that's helpful. If you look at the deals that we were building in 2009 and '10 that ended up stabilizing initially at 5, those are more like 6.5 and 7s today, just to put a perspective. So they're fine assets. We're not going to make the same kind of returns that were made on deals that we started 2 years later for sure. But still a fine outcome given the kind of recession we went through.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chris, this is Kevin. Just to add to that, looking at some of the data that we have here internally in terms of original projected deals and initial stabilized deals by vintage of completion, and going back to that time period, yields fell about 100 basis
componenttext: Chris, this is Kevin. Just to add to that, looking at some of the data that we have here internally in terms of original projected deals and initial stabilized deals by vintage of completion, and going back to that time period, yields fell about 100 basis points, solid to their initial underwriting. And that's a great point that Matt is alluding to. The match funding is what's the most critical thing, because comparing sort of -- yet to really compare the yields on the deals that are started with the capital that is sourced in the same period of time. That's the virtue of match funding. You walk into any of the growth right now at this point in time.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from Ryan Peterson with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: And our next question is from Ryan Peterson with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on your Columbus Circle development, could you guys provide an update on any plans to monetize a portion of that through either retail or condominiums?
componenttext: Just on your Columbus Circle development, could you guys provide an update on any plans to monetize a portion of that through either retail or condominiums?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Matt. I can fix that a little bit. We are working on it. The program is getting set. As an example, I think when we first bought the land, we thought we were going to do about 50,000 or 55,000 square feet of retail there. The program that we
componenttext: Sure. This is Matt. I can fix that a little bit. We are working on it. The program is getting set. As an example, I think when we first bought the land, we thought we were going to do about 50,000 or 55,000 square feet of retail there. The program that we have now is more like 67,000 or 70,000 square feet of retail. We were able to add some retail in a cellar level and a sub-cellar level. So it's now matured to the point we have a pretty good definition of what the offering is and we have been talking to folks, and we'll keep you updated as we make progress on that.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then my second question is just what your thoughts are on 421-a? Whether that will be resuscitated or whether you think that will kind of severely curb development in New York?
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then my second question is just what your thoughts are on 421-a? Whether that will be resuscitated or whether you think that will kind of severely curb development in New York?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's obviously too early to tell. It is a program that's been around for a long, long time, and it is important for -- to make rental production work for the most part in the city -- in New York City. So I think our local folks would say probably
componenttext: I think it's obviously too early to tell. It is a program that's been around for a long, long time, and it is important for -- to make rental production work for the most part in the city -- in New York City. So I think our local folks would say probably there will be a program in some form or fashion that will come back at some point. These things get snagged in politics, and then New York is kind of a unique situation, where it's not just a city, but Albany is a state legislator involved as well. So as it relates to our portfolio specifically, doesn't really have much impact. The deal we're just talking about at Columbus Circle, we are never intending to put that deal in the program. So our plan there is not have any affordable and not have a tax abatement from the start. And the other deals that we have going in New York, it's already been invested. So might impact the land market on -- until things settle out, but it's too early to say what this impact might be going forward.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next from Zelman & Associates, we have Dan Oppenheim.
componenttext: Next from Zelman & Associates, we have Dan Oppenheim.

componenttext: Was wondering just if you can talk a little bit in terms of what you think about for -- you said that you'll start Columbus Circle here in 2016. Any thought in terms of timing for that or just sort of finalizing in terms of the retail offering and overall plans?

componenttextpreview: I think our current expectation is we could start in the second half of the year. I think we're starting demolition right now. So we've got some work to do there and -- as we are just finalizing the plans, but within the plan for the back half of the year
componenttext: I think our current expectation is we could start in the second half of the year. I think we're starting demolition right now. So we've got some work to do there and -- as we are just finalizing the plans, but within the plan for the back half of the year.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And I guess, relatedly, on Page 5 of the slide, you talked to -- basically showed the what you're getting in terms of the rent and the capital cost for the development projects that are completed in 2015, basically showing some of the, call it, a
componenttext: Got it. And I guess, relatedly, on Page 5 of the slide, you talked to -- basically showed the what you're getting in terms of the rent and the capital cost for the development projects that are completed in 2015, basically showing some of the, call it, a higher growth yield relative to the stabilized portfolio. How do you think about that in terms of the growth rates? We didn't mention anything about Columbus Circle. When we look at that a couple of years from now, it's almost going to look the reverse in terms of probably lower yield, but likely thinking about a higher long-term growth rate. And so wondering how you think about the growth on this, or what you've started in 2015?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, it's Tim. I mean, in terms of -- and I would talk to this in the past, every deal has a target yield that's impacted by what we think the projected growth profile, cash growth profile of that asset or that submarket will deliver. So something like a
componenttext: Dan, it's Tim. I mean, in terms of -- and I would talk to this in the past, every deal has a target yield that's impacted by what we think the projected growth profile, cash growth profile of that asset or that submarket will deliver. So something like a Columbus Circle, we think, would have a higher growth profile than the average deal in our portfolio. We would expect that to have a lower goal and yield then. That's pretty much how land markets and development market's price. So it's a fair point because we do have a couple large deals that -- and a Hollywood deal as well, which is and L.A. deal, which usually California deals are lower cap rate and higher growth. So that will impact the projected initial yield, if you will, because we're expecting to get basically the same IRR, but more of it through residual and cash flow growth.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next we'll go to Vincent Chao from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Next we'll go to Vincent Chao from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: I just want to go back to some of your job growth outlook, specifically the New York, Metro New Jersey area, just hearing some other forecasts calling for some deceleration there. Looks like you're looking for things to pick up in '16 versus 2015. I was just curious if any comment on what's driving that? That's really your expectations in New York City or if it's some of the suburbs?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We really rely on third parties for our job forecast. So I guess, I would start there. There is some chat, I guess -- I think partly what's been going on in the equity markets whether some of the economists and consensus was going to drift down a little b
componenttext: We really rely on third parties for our job forecast. So I guess, I would start there. There is some chat, I guess -- I think partly what's been going on in the equity markets whether some of the economists and consensus was going to drift down a little bit, in terms of GDP and job forecast in general, to the extent that they change it related to the equity markets. So I guess, it would be logical that maybe New York, New Jersey might be more impacted than the average market. But now we have -- we use some judgment. But when we're quoting job growth, we are relying on third parties that we have found to be most helpful in the past.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Okay. That makes sense. And just one other question, just in terms of L.A. It sounds like expectations for Southern California overall are going to be for continued acceleration, but it did seem like same-store revenue growth here in L.A. slowed a little bit, and I was just wondering if there was something specifically that kind of weighed on growth here this quarter, understanding it's still 6%, which is good, but...?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Vin, this is Sean. There's nothing specific that we are concerned about as it relates to L.A. I mean, every aspect has different characteristics in terms of lease expiration profile and things of that sort. We're trying to push rate in some cases and
componenttext: Yes, Vin, this is Sean. There's nothing specific that we are concerned about as it relates to L.A. I mean, every aspect has different characteristics in terms of lease expiration profile and things of that sort. We're trying to push rate in some cases and then on another case, just trying to gain occupancy. So you're just kind to get in the quarter-to-quarter noise, I don't think there's any concern about L.A. at this point at all.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next we'll go to Dave Bragg from Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: Next we'll go to Dave Bragg from Green Street Advisors.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of quick ones for you. The track record this cycle on development is clearly compelling as you laid out in '15. Thinking about it from the profit margin perspective that you laid out, what level of profit margins are you targeting on incremental
componenttext: A couple of quick ones for you. The track record this cycle on development is clearly compelling as you laid out in '15. Thinking about it from the profit margin perspective that you laid out, what level of profit margins are you targeting on incremental starts?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Dave, as we mentioned, we typically do start with a cost of capital and add some accretion factor to that. I mean, it ends up being in the 150 to 200 basis point range in terms of premium from a target perspective. But -- and we've been able to meet
componenttext: Well, Dave, as we mentioned, we typically do start with a cost of capital and add some accretion factor to that. I mean, it ends up being in the 150 to 200 basis point range in terms of premium from a target perspective. But -- and we've been able to meet or exceed that certainly this cycle. As we put the slide up there that showed the -- and where the average deal was costing about 310,000, just using your data, if you just sort of extrapolate that out using the rent premium that those deals are getting, that would suggest an average value of about $470,000 for that book of business. And when you look at the pipeline, the shadow pipeline, that has an estimated cost about 350 a door today with honestly a bit more urban-oriented product, which probably has a little bit higher rent on average, slightly higher rent. So it's still pretty healthy looking margin based upon what we know today, which are today's rents and today's costs.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And Tim, you'd mentioned a couple of times or you've alluded to limit surrounding your disposition potential in '16. Could you put a number around that?
componenttext: Okay. And Tim, you'd mentioned a couple of times or you've alluded to limit surrounding your disposition potential in '16. Could you put a number around that?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, depends -- that depends which assets you choose to sell at the end of the day, but it's not atypical. It's probably --  the assets we're looking to sell have more than a 50% embedded gain on the proceeds. So to the extent you've got, call it, $200 m
componenttext: Well, depends -- that depends which assets you choose to sell at the end of the day, but it's not atypical. It's probably --  the assets we're looking to sell have more than a 50% embedded gain on the proceeds. So to the extent you've got, call it, $200 million or $300 million of capacity before you start getting into requirement just to distribute, you could sell 2x that. But it depends on the mix. Kevin, I don't know if you got anything you want to add to that?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Just a couple of things, and probably tax is not an area people are overly eager to get into a deep discussion on, to be sure; we probably can. Just really 2 issues: One is just the special dividend obligation associated with the fact that we are a
componenttext: Sure. Just a couple of things, and probably tax is not an area people are overly eager to get into a deep discussion on, to be sure; we probably can. Just really 2 issues: One is just the special dividend obligation associated with the fact that we are a taxpaying entity, both for the fact that we have a dividend paid deduction. But there's also excise tax considerations as well, so I think from our standpoint, when we look at using asset sales to fund development, we have a fair bit of running room in terms of being able to sell assets before we have to worry about a special dividend obligation. We would probably more likely in a kind of situation where we wanted to pay an excise tax, which is sort of a little bit of a 4% tax payment on excess income over distributions. And so it becomes sort of a -- kind of almost like a transaction cost if you will that gets added to selling assets to fund development. So we certainly have a reasonable amount of ability to continue to sell assets to fund development, but what we went into first is probably having to pay an excise tax, which is just an extra transaction cost, if you will, which we'd rather not incur if we can avoid it, but it's something that's probably more relevant.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. One last one for you, Kevin. You suggested that you'll lean on the unsecured market as it relates to the sources of funds. What are your latest thoughts on 30-year money?
componenttext: All right. One last one for you, Kevin. You suggested that you'll lean on the unsecured market as it relates to the sources of funds. What are your latest thoughts on 30-year money?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we don't really have 30-year unsecured money in the balance sheet today. We do have a fair bit of about $1.1 billion of tax-exempt debt that's secured and has probably on an average about 21 years left to run. So that's something we had done in the
componenttext: Well, we don't really have 30-year unsecured money in the balance sheet today. We do have a fair bit of about $1.1 billion of tax-exempt debt that's secured and has probably on an average about 21 years left to run. So that's something we had done in the past, and we like that form of capital, though it's far less available today. In terms of 30-year unsecured debt, since we don't have to have, we simply don't currently have it. You have to ask yourself what's it in substitution for? I think probably it's been a little bit more of a compelling equity substitute for those who want more leverage than a compelling substitute for 10-year debt when you do the breakevens. For us, we might be willing to entertain doing it. I guess, probably one guiding principle would be -- if we were to look at the total amount of debt we're going to issue in one year, there's only so much we'd want to issue in the form of 10-year unsecured debt before in a future period we'd have a more debt coming due, then we would prefer, which as we've talked about before, we tried to target having leveled maturities that are on balance less than or equal to our projected amount of dividend. And so if we felt we're going to be issuing a certain amount of debt in the unsecured markets in a given year, that might be more than we want to have coming due in 10 years. We might think about doing the excess in the form of a 30-year note offering.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just curious that just given all the market volatility, concerning about a recession, are you seeing that your tenants reacting any differently when you gave them new [indiscernible] in January and were renewals were coming up whether there being mu
componenttext: I was just curious that just given all the market volatility, concerning about a recession, are you seeing that your tenants reacting any differently when you gave them new [indiscernible] in January and were renewals were coming up whether there being much more aggressive about trying to get a rent cut or decline in or some type of relief, just kind of given the overall nervousness in the economic backdrop?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tayo, it's Sean. I mean, to answer that directly based on the data, the answer is no, in terms of the actions they are taking; for example, rent increases too high and moving out. Move out to rent increase doesn't really move that much on average, and it
componenttext: Tayo, it's Sean. I mean, to answer that directly based on the data, the answer is no, in terms of the actions they are taking; for example, rent increases too high and moving out. Move out to rent increase doesn't really move that much on average, and it has the certain markets. And so I think you probably have to go market by market to figure out where that's most pronounced. So there's certainly been pushback in Northern California that's above historical averages. But that's a market where we are seeing pretty significant rent growth in the last 3 years. So you sort of expect that. When someone gets a third 8%, 9%, 10% rent increase, wages have been growing, but then they're not growing that quickly. There's some pushback. But I'd say, as part of the normal process, there's not a significant shift to one direction or another that we're seeing across the portfolio.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And from Robert W. Baird, we have Drew Babin.
componenttext: And from Robert W. Baird, we have Drew Babin.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could talk about a couple of your larger developments out there, the Willoughby Square/AVA DoBro asset and North Station in Boston, I mean, where those yield expectations stack up kind of relative to that 6.3% and what gives you confidenc
componenttext: I was hoping you could talk about a couple of your larger developments out there, the Willoughby Square/AVA DoBro asset and North Station in Boston, I mean, where those yield expectations stack up kind of relative to that 6.3% and what gives you confidence those assets in particular that the targeted yield could be achieved, either from a cost control standpoint or market fundamentals?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Drew, this is Matt. I can start on that and Sean, if you want to chime in anything. Those are 2 big urban high-rises. And again, we think about the target returns starting out relative to kind of what the spot cap rate is -- would be on those assets
componenttext: Sure. Drew, this is Matt. I can start on that and Sean, if you want to chime in anything. Those are 2 big urban high-rises. And again, we think about the target returns starting out relative to kind of what the spot cap rate is -- would be on those assets, is one thing we look at, as well as where we can project the growth profile would be, to kind of get from different potential starting target yields to target IRR, which is more similar across different deals. Those 2 deals were underwritten in kind of the high-5s based on the rents that were in place when we started those deals. We had not marked either one to market yet. The will be square deal, is a very large building. So it will be a while before we have kind of 20% lease, which is typically when we would market to market, but I think we're feeling pretty good about the capital budget there and we're feeling pretty good that based on what we're seeing so far, the market is certainly a little bit above where it was performing. And Sean?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Drew, this is Sean. As it relates to Willoughby/AVA DoBro, which is really -- as you may not know, it's 2 components to the building, has an AVA component and then an Avalon component. We have product in the AVA section of the building right now that
componenttext: Yes. Drew, this is Sean. As it relates to Willoughby/AVA DoBro, which is really -- as you may not know, it's 2 components to the building, has an AVA component and then an Avalon component. We have product in the AVA section of the building right now that's delivered late in the fourth quarter after a few delays with the MCA in their space. But early returns are good. We have a market to market, but face rents are in the $60 foot range. I think pro forma was around 55. And that $60 a foot at the kind of slow leasing season, Christmas, January kind of rates. So feel pretty good about that in terms of how that product is positioned in Brooklyn. As I mentioned, we don't have the Avalon component yet, but it's -- those will be the nicer unit at the top of the building. So our expectations once we open those up probably midyear, we're going to see a nice pop in overall rates for the building.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Drew, this is Tim. Just to add maybe on the cost side, so we feel pretty good about the cost. I mean, we do act as our own GC sometimes with the CM, a construction management firm, but we hold the contracts. And so we typically have better visibility than
componenttext: Drew, this is Tim. Just to add maybe on the cost side, so we feel pretty good about the cost. I mean, we do act as our own GC sometimes with the CM, a construction management firm, but we hold the contracts. And so we typically have better visibility than if we were working with a third party in terms of any cost pressures on deals. And we feel pretty good about -- as Matt mentioned, feel pretty good about these deals right now in terms of bringing those online and the -- for the budget amounts that we laid out on our schedule.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Great. That's helpful. And one more, should there be any slowing in employment growth in the Bay Area? How do you feel that the San Francisco MSA kind of stacks up against Silicon Valley against the East Bay area, either from a supply standpoint or just where that dynamics on the ground in terms of setup, if things get slow down?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Drew, it's Sean. A couple of thoughts on that. I mean, in general, across that market, when things often, the most expensive price point product tends to suffer first. So if you have the most expensive high-rise in the city, you're going to see some
componenttext: Sure. Drew, it's Sean. A couple of thoughts on that. I mean, in general, across that market, when things often, the most expensive price point product tends to suffer first. So if you have the most expensive high-rise in the city, you're going to see some reaction to that. If you -- that's just a macro comment. It sort of depends on when it occurs and what supply is being delivered. As we go into '16, there's more supply concentrated in San Jose than there is in either East Bay or San Francisco, as an example. That's across San Jose, and that's concentrated in Northeast San Jose. If you bleed up in the Mountain View, certain submarkets; there's about 3 or 4 submarkets there. Up in San Francisco, there's a fair amount of supply being delivered into SoMa. So if you're exposed to SoMa, you're probably going to hurt just as much. So it sort of depends on when in the cycle it occurs and what supply is being delivered at that point in time. But generally speaking in the higher price point, assets tend to suffer first and which tendencies people will migrate. If things become more affordable, they'll migrate back towards the end of the city and the cycle kind of repeats itself. So hopefully, I've provided some broad perspective about what happens in the market.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, it's Sean. One way to think about it is just how the portfolio eaves communities just performing relative to Avalon or AVA. That typically is story of which market it's actually in. It's in Northern California. Obviously, it's been very strong versu
componenttext: Rich, it's Sean. One way to think about it is just how the portfolio eaves communities just performing relative to Avalon or AVA. That typically is story of which market it's actually in. It's in Northern California. Obviously, it's been very strong versus, say, Westchester. But generally speaking, right now, within the market footprint, our Eaves communities are pretty synonymous with B communities as you referred to Axiometrics or Reis or any of those. And Eaves communities tend to be outperforming right now. To give you some perspective in the fourth quarter for our portfolio, the B assets or the eaves assets, which is for the most part B assets, were about 70 basis points ahead of how the A assets were performing. As you go look at Axiometrics, it's a pretty similar pattern there in terms of the outperformance. So this part of the cycle, well-positioned, value-oriented communities are outperforming. To the extent we are selling one of those communities, it typically is related to either submarket specific or asset specific. The issues we have or concerns about concentration in terms of other activity we might have in the region, that typically drives those disposition decisions as it relates to pretty much any community, but eaves as well.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then bigger picture on the development pipeline, in light of the fact that you're projecting your land position to decline in 2016, 26 projects under development, about 10% of your asset base is tied up in development. Where do -- if you were to kind
componenttext: And then bigger picture on the development pipeline, in light of the fact that you're projecting your land position to decline in 2016, 26 projects under development, about 10% of your asset base is tied up in development. Where do -- if you were to kind of roll forward 3, 4 years from now, would that number -- would those numbers be materially lower than they are today, if you had to hazard a guess?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, this is Tim. My guess is they'll be lower. How materially, it really kind of depends a bit on the opportunity set. We've been a little surprised, honestly, over the last, I'd say, year to year and a half that we continued to see, we think, pretty co
componenttext: Rich, this is Tim. My guess is they'll be lower. How materially, it really kind of depends a bit on the opportunity set. We've been a little surprised, honestly, over the last, I'd say, year to year and a half that we continued to see, we think, pretty compelling opportunities at reasonable land prices. So to the extent that things get -- start getting too expensive or too distorted, which they have on a limited basis, for instance, in the Bay Area, where it's tough to make the numbers work in the Bay Area. So all the markets started looking like the Bay Area. It would deplete the development rights inventory pretty quickly. But that's not my guess. I mean, typically, the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic can be a little bit more stable. And I would expect the case would be, it would start to draw down a bit over the next 3 years.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: And gentlemen, your final question of the day comes from Wes Golladay with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually Neil on for Wes. Just a question on occupancy. It looked like this quarter saw pretty strong drop in occupancy across the board, particularly in Northern California. Just wondering if you can comment on that, a function of just seasonally we
componenttext: It's actually Neil on for Wes. Just a question on occupancy. It looked like this quarter saw pretty strong drop in occupancy across the board, particularly in Northern California. Just wondering if you can comment on that, a function of just seasonally weak or lower leasing, a function of you switching your expirations to the middle, higher volume, higher velocity times of the year, pushing rent too hard. Can you comment on that?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Neil, this is Sean. I mean, one thing to keep in mind is while occupancy was down on a year-over-year basis, if you look at it on a sequential basis, we were actually up 20 basis points. And there were a couple of markets at the end of 2014, particu
componenttext: Sure. Neil, this is Sean. I mean, one thing to keep in mind is while occupancy was down on a year-over-year basis, if you look at it on a sequential basis, we were actually up 20 basis points. And there were a couple of markets at the end of 2014, particularly Northern California and the greater New York region, where frankly availability was a little lower than we had wanted it from an ideal perspective in terms of pushing pricing and occupancy drifted up a little heavy. So we are not too concerned about the year-over-year change -- sequential change. We are perfectly fine with -- we're well positioned today in terms of where we sit. We're basically mid-95s in terms of economic occupancy. It's down about 30, 40 basis points, but it's right about where we think we should be. As we look towards the spring, we want to try and push pricing as much as we can, and availability is in the mid-5% range. It's up 30, 40 bps from last year at this point in time. But as I mentioned, we thought we're probably a little bit on the low side at this point last year. So we think we're in pretty good shape and you're just looking at a year-over-year comp that was creating that change in occupancy.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then lastly, are you seeing any evidence that in the Bay Area, for some of your rentals on the higher end that people maybe are pushing back or maybe seeing some softness in renewals or new leases that would lead you to indicate that there may b
componenttext: Okay. And then lastly, are you seeing any evidence that in the Bay Area, for some of your rentals on the higher end that people maybe are pushing back or maybe seeing some softness in renewals or new leases that would lead you to indicate that there may be something more than a temporary blip going on in that market?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Good question. I mean, obviously, Q4 is typically the slower period. I would say, it was a little beyond seasonal adjustment in the fourth quarter, whether it continues to soften a bit is yet to be seen. But I think as we indicated earlier, we're exp
componenttext: Yes. Good question. I mean, obviously, Q4 is typically the slower period. I would say, it was a little beyond seasonal adjustment in the fourth quarter, whether it continues to soften a bit is yet to be seen. But I think as we indicated earlier, we're expecting job growth to slow in that region. Deliveries will be accelerating in that market. So we are expecting it to soften a bit as we move throughout the year, whether that -- it was first sign of it in the fourth quarter or not is yet to be seen, but we did expect some softening. We realize that. And then the question going forward here is with the pace of job growth since we know what supply is going to be. So our expectation is the market will moderate through 2016, given just the fundamentals that are in place.
