componenttext: I was wondering just if you can talk a little bit in terms of what you think about for -- you said that you'll start Columbus Circle here in 2016, any thought in terms of timing for that where it's -- or it's just sort of finalizing in terms of the retail offering and overall plans?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think our current expectation is we could start in the second half of the year. I think we're starting demolition right now. So we've got some work to do there and -- as we are just finalizing the plans, but within the plan for the back half of the year
componenttext: I think our current expectation is we could start in the second half of the year. I think we're starting demolition right now. So we've got some work to do there and -- as we are just finalizing the plans, but within the plan for the back half of the year.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And I guess relatedly, on Page 5 of the slide, you talked to -- basically showed the what you're getting in terms of the rent and the capital cost for the development projects that are completed in 2015, basically showing some of the, call it, a h
componenttext: Got it. And I guess relatedly, on Page 5 of the slide, you talked to -- basically showed the what you're getting in terms of the rent and the capital cost for the development projects that are completed in 2015, basically showing some of the, call it, a higher growth yield relative to the stabilized portfolio. How do you think about that in terms of the growth rates? We didn't mention anything about Columbus Circle. When we look at that a couple of years from now, it's almost going to look the reverse in terms of probably lower yield, but likely thinking about a higher long-term growth rate. And so wondering how you think about the growth on this, or what you've started in 2015?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, it's Tim. I mean, in terms of -- and I would talk to this in the past, every deal has a target yield that's impacted by what we think the projected growth profile, cash growth profile, of that asset or that submarket will deliver. So something like a
componenttext: Dan, it's Tim. I mean, in terms of -- and I would talk to this in the past, every deal has a target yield that's impacted by what we think the projected growth profile, cash growth profile, of that asset or that submarket will deliver. So something like a Columbus Circle, what we'd think would have a higher growth profile than the average deal in our portfolio, we would expect that to have a lower goal and yield then. That's pretty much how land markets and development markets price. So it's a fair point because we do have a couple large deals that -- and a Hollywood deal as well, which is an L.A. deal, which usually California deals are lower cap rate and higher growth. So that will impact the projected initial yield, if you will, because we're expecting to get basically the same IRR, but more of it through residual and cash flow growth.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next we'll go to Vincent Chao from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Next we'll go to Vincent Chao from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to go back to some of your job growth outlook, specifically the New York, Metro New Jersey area, just hearing some other forecasts calling for some deceleration there. Looks like you're looking for things to pick up in '16 versus 2015. I was j
componenttext: I just want to go back to some of your job growth outlook, specifically the New York, Metro New Jersey area, just hearing some other forecasts calling for some deceleration there. Looks like you're looking for things to pick up in '16 versus 2015. I was just curious if any comment on what's driving that? That's really your expectations in New York City or if it's some of the suburbs?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we really rely on third parties for our job forecast. So I guess, I would start there. There is some chatter, I guess -- I think partly what's been going on in the equity markets whether some of the economists and consensus was going to drift down a
componenttext: Well, we really rely on third parties for our job forecast. So I guess, I would start there. There is some chatter, I guess -- I think partly what's been going on in the equity markets whether some of the economists and consensus was going to drift down a little bit, in terms of GDP and job forecasts in general. To the extent that they change it related to the equity markets, I guess it would be logical that maybe New York, New Jersey might be more impacted than the average market. But now we have -- we use some judgment. But when we're quoting job growth, we are relying on third parties that we have found to be most helpful in the past.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That makes sense. And just one other question, just in terms of L.A. It sounds like expectations for Southern California overall are going to be for continued acceleration, but it did seem like same-store revenue growth here in L.A. slowed a little
componenttext: Okay. That makes sense. And just one other question, just in terms of L.A. It sounds like expectations for Southern California overall are going to be for continued acceleration, but it did seem like same-store revenue growth here in L.A. slowed a little bit, and I was just wondering if there was something specifically that kind of weighed on growth here this quarter, understanding it's still 6%, which is good, but...?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, Vin, this is Sean. There's nothing specific that we are concerned about as it relates to L.A. I mean, every aspect has different characteristics in terms of lease expiration profile and things of that sort. You're trying to push rate in some case
componenttext: Yes. No, Vin, this is Sean. There's nothing specific that we are concerned about as it relates to L.A. I mean, every aspect has different characteristics in terms of lease expiration profile and things of that sort. You're trying to push rate in some cases and then in other cases, you're just trying to gain occupancy. So if you're just kind to get in the quarter-to-quarter noise, I don't think there's any concern about L.A. at this point at all.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next we'll go to Dave Bragg from Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: Next we'll go to Dave Bragg from Green Street Advisors.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of quick ones for you. The track record this cycle on development is clearly compelling as you laid out on '15. Thinking about it from the profit margin perspective that you laid out, what level of profit margins are you targeting on incremental
componenttext: A couple of quick ones for you. The track record this cycle on development is clearly compelling as you laid out on '15. Thinking about it from the profit margin perspective that you laid out, what level of profit margins are you targeting on incremental starts?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Dave, as we mentioned, we typically do start with a cost of capital and add some accretion factor to that. I mean, it ends up being in the 150 to 200 basis point range in terms of premium from a target perspective. But -- and we've been able to meet
componenttext: Well, Dave, as we mentioned, we typically do start with a cost of capital and add some accretion factor to that. I mean, it ends up being in the 150 to 200 basis point range in terms of premium from a target perspective. But -- and we've been able to meet or exceed that certainly this cycle. As we put the slide up there that showed the -- where the average deal was costing about $310,000, just using your data, if you just sort of extrapolated that out using the rent premium that those deals are getting, that would suggest an average value of about $470,000 for that book of business. And when you look at the pipeline, the shadow pipeline, that has an estimated cost of about $350,000 a door today with honestly a bit more urban-oriented product, which probably has a little bit higher rent on average, slightly higher rents. So it's still pretty healthy looking margin based upon what we know today, which are today's rents and today's costs.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And, Tim, you'd mentioned a couple of times or you've alluded to limit surrounding your disposition potential in '16. Could you put a number around that?
componenttext: Okay. And, Tim, you'd mentioned a couple of times or you've alluded to limit surrounding your disposition potential in '16. Could you put a number around that?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it depends which assets you choose to sell at the end of the day, but it's not atypical. It's probably --  the assets we're looking to sell have more than a 50% embedded gain on the proceeds. So to the extent you've got, call it, $200 million or $30
componenttext: Well, it depends which assets you choose to sell at the end of the day, but it's not atypical. It's probably --  the assets we're looking to sell have more than a 50% embedded gain on the proceeds. So to the extent you've got, call it, $200 million or $300 million of capacity before you start getting into a requirement just to distribute, you could sell 2x that. But it depends on the mix. Kevin, I don't know if you've got anything you want to add to that?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Just a couple of things, and probably tax is not an area people are overly eager to get into a deep discussion on, to be sure; we probably can't. There's really 2 issues: One is there's a special dividend obligation associated with the fact that we
componenttext: Sure. Just a couple of things, and probably tax is not an area people are overly eager to get into a deep discussion on, to be sure; we probably can't. There's really 2 issues: One is there's a special dividend obligation associated with the fact that we are a taxpaying entity but for the fact that we have a dividend pay deduction. But there's also excise tax considerations as well. So I think from our standpoint, when we look at using asset sales to fund development, we have a fair bit of running room in terms of being able to sell assets before we have to worry about a special dividend obligation. We would probably more likely encounter a situation where we might have to pay an excise tax, which is sort of a -- a little bit of a 4% tax payment on excess income over distributions. And so it becomes sort of a -- kind of almost like a transaction cost, if you will, that gets added to selling assets to fund development. So we certainly have a reasonable amount of ability to continue to sell assets to fund development, but what we run into first is probably having to pay an excise tax, which is just an extra transaction cost, if you will, which we'd rather not incur if we can avoid it, but it's something that's probably more relevant.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. One last one for you, Kevin. You suggested that you'll lean on unsecured market as it relates to the sources of funds. What are your latest thoughts on 30-year money?
componenttext: All right. One last one for you, Kevin. You suggested that you'll lean on unsecured market as it relates to the sources of funds. What are your latest thoughts on 30-year money?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we don't really have 30-year unsecured money in the balance sheet today. We do have a fair bit of -- about $1.1 billion of tax-exempt debt that's secured and has probably on an average about 21 years left to run. So that's something we have done in
componenttext: Well, we don't really have 30-year unsecured money in the balance sheet today. We do have a fair bit of -- about $1.1 billion of tax-exempt debt that's secured and has probably on an average about 21 years left to run. So that's something we have done in the past, and we like that form of capital, though it's far less available today. In terms of 30-year unsecured debt, since we don't have to have -- since we don't currently have it, you have to ask yourself what's it in substitution for? I think probably it's been a little bit more of a compelling equity substitute for those who want more leverage than a compelling substitute for 10-year debt when you do the breakevens. For us, we might be willing to entertain doing it. I guess probably one guiding principle would be if we were to look at the total amount of debt we're going to issue in one year, there's only so much we'd want to issue in the form of 10-year unsecured debt. Before, in a future period, we'd have a more debt coming due than we would prefer, which as we've talked about before, we tried to target having leveled maturities that are on balance less than or equal to our projected amount of dividends. And so if we felt we're going to be issuing a certain amount of debt in the unsecured markets in a given year, that might be more than we want to have coming due in 10 years. We might think about doing the excess in the form of a 30-year note offering.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next from Jefferies, we have Tayo Okusanya.
componenttext: And next from Jefferies, we have Tayo Okusanya.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just curious just given all the market volatility, concerning about a recession, are you seeing that your tenants reacting any differently when you gave them new asking rents in January and where renewals were coming up, whether they're being much m
componenttext: I was just curious just given all the market volatility, concerning about a recession, are you seeing that your tenants reacting any differently when you gave them new asking rents in January and where renewals were coming up, whether they're being much more aggressive about trying to get a rent cut or decline in or some type of relief, just kind of given the overall nervousness in the economic backdrop?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tayo, it's Sean. I mean, to answer that directly based on the data, the answer is no, in terms of the actions they are taking, for example, the rent increase is too high, I'm moving out. Move out to rent increase doesn't really move that much on average,
componenttext: Tayo, it's Sean. I mean, to answer that directly based on the data, the answer is no, in terms of the actions they are taking, for example, the rent increase is too high, I'm moving out. Move out to rent increase doesn't really move that much on average, and it has the certain markets. And so I think you probably have to go market by market to figure out where that's most pronounced. So there's certainly been pushback in Northern California that's above historical averages. But that's a market where we are seeing pretty significant rent growth in the last 3 years. So you sort of expect that. When someone gets their third 8%, 9%, 10% rent increase, wages have been growing, but then they're not growing that quickly, there's some pushback. But I'd say, as part of the normal process, there's not a significant shift to one direction or another that we're seeing across the portfolio.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And from Robert W. Baird, we have Drew Babin.
componenttext: And from Robert W. Baird, we have Drew Babin.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could talk about a couple of your larger developments out there, the Willoughby Square/AVA DoBro asset and North Station in Boston, and where those yield expectations stack up kind of relative to that 6.3% and what gives you confidence in
componenttext: I was hoping you could talk about a couple of your larger developments out there, the Willoughby Square/AVA DoBro asset and North Station in Boston, and where those yield expectations stack up kind of relative to that 6.3% and what gives you confidence in those assets in particular that the targeted yield could be achieved, either from a cost control standpoint or market fundamentals?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Drew, this is Matt. I can start on that and Sean, if you want to chime in on anything. Those are 2 big urban high-rises. And again, we think about the target returns starting out relative to kind of what the spot cap rate is -- would be on those ass
componenttext: Sure. Drew, this is Matt. I can start on that and Sean, if you want to chime in on anything. Those are 2 big urban high-rises. And again, we think about the target returns starting out relative to kind of what the spot cap rate is -- would be on those assets, is one thing we look at, as well as where we can project the growth profile would be, to kind of get from different potential starting target yields to target IRR, which is more similar across different deals. Those 2 deals were underwritten in kind of the high-5s based on the rents that were in place when we started those deals. We had not marked either one to market yet. The Willoughby Square deal, is a very large building. So it will be a while before we have kind of 20% lease, which is typically when we would market to market, but I think we're feeling pretty good about the capital budget there and we're feeling pretty good that based on what we've seen so far, the market is certainly a little bit above where it was performing. And, Sean?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Drew, this is Sean. As it relates to Willoughby/AVA DoBro, which is really -- as you may not know, it's 2 components to the building. There's an AVA component and then an Avalon component. We have product in the AVA section of the building right now
componenttext: Yes. Drew, this is Sean. As it relates to Willoughby/AVA DoBro, which is really -- as you may not know, it's 2 components to the building. There's an AVA component and then an Avalon component. We have product in the AVA section of the building right now that's delivered late in the fourth quarter after a few delays with the MTA in their space. But early returns are good. We have a market to market, but face rents are in the $60 a foot range. I think pro forma was around $55. And that's $60 a foot at the kind of slow-leasing season, Christmas, January kind of rates. So feel pretty good about that in terms of how that product is positioned in Brooklyn. As I mentioned, we don't have the Avalon component yet, but it's -- those will be the nicer units at the top of the building. So our expectations once we open those up probably midyear, we're going to see a nice pop in overall rates for the building.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Drew, this is Tim. Just to add maybe on the cost side, so we feel pretty good about the cost. I mean, we do act as our own GC, sometimes with the CM, a construction management firm, but we hold the contracts. And so we typically have better visibility tha
componenttext: Drew, this is Tim. Just to add maybe on the cost side, so we feel pretty good about the cost. I mean, we do act as our own GC, sometimes with the CM, a construction management firm, but we hold the contracts. And so we typically have better visibility than if we were working with a third party in terms of any cost pressures on deals. And we feel pretty good about -- as Matt mentioned, we feel pretty good about these deals right now in terms of bringing those online and the -- for the budget amounts that we laid out on our schedule.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. That's helpful. And one more, should there be any slowing in employment growth in the Bay Area, how do you feel that the San Francisco MSA kind of stacks up against Silicon Valley against the East Bay area, either from a supply standpoint or just w
componenttext: Great. That's helpful. And one more, should there be any slowing in employment growth in the Bay Area, how do you feel that the San Francisco MSA kind of stacks up against Silicon Valley against the East Bay area, either from a supply standpoint or just what are the dynamics on the ground in terms of setup if things get slow down?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Drew, it's Sean. A couple of thoughts on that. I mean, in general, across that market, when things often, the most expensive price point product tends to suffer first. So if you have the most expensive high-rise in the city, you're going to see some
componenttext: Sure. Drew, it's Sean. A couple of thoughts on that. I mean, in general, across that market, when things often, the most expensive price point product tends to suffer first. So if you have the most expensive high-rise in the city, you're going to see some reaction to that. If you -- that's just a macro comment. It sort of depends on when it occurs and what supply is being delivered. As we go into '16, there's more supply concentrated in San Jose than there is in either the East Bay or San Francisco, as an example. That's across San Jose. Now it's concentrated in Northeast San Jose, if you bleed up into Mountain View, certain submarkets; there's about 3 or 4 submarkets there. Up in San Francisco, there's a fair amount of supply being delivered into SoMa. So if you're exposed to SoMa, you're probably going to hurt just as much. So it sort of depends on when in the cycle it occurs and what supply is being delivered at that point in time. But generally speaking in the higher price point, assets tend to suffer first and which tendencies people will migrate as things become more affordable? They'll migrate back towards the end of the city and the cycle kind of repeats itself. So hopefully that provides some broad perspective about what happens in the market.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next we have Rich Anderson with Mizuho Securities.
componenttext: And next we have Rich Anderson with Mizuho Securities.

componenttext: Sorry to keep it going here, but I just had this question. Looking at the development pipeline, do you develop Eve's product or are they all just kind of retrofit from current assets?

componenttextpreview: Rich, this is Matt. I wish we could, but no. Those are all renovations or refunctionings.
componenttext: Rich, this is Matt. I wish we could, but no. Those are all renovations or refunctionings.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I get it. I thought so, because there's none listed there, but -- and it's in my recollection, but then I noticed you also have been selling some of these product. I'm just curious how that brand is doing relative to AVA?
componenttext: Yes, I get it. I thought so, because there's none listed there, but -- and it's in my recollection, but then I noticed you also have been selling some of these product. I'm just curious how that brand is doing relative to AVA?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, it's Sean. One way to think about it is just how the portfolio eaves communities is performing relative to Avalon or AVA. That typically is a story of which market it's actually in. It's in Northern California. Obviously, it's been very strong versu
componenttext: Rich, it's Sean. One way to think about it is just how the portfolio eaves communities is performing relative to Avalon or AVA. That typically is a story of which market it's actually in. It's in Northern California. Obviously, it's been very strong versus, say, Westchester. But generally speaking, right now, within the market footprint, our eaves communities are pretty synonymous with B communities as you referred to Axiometrics or Reis or any of those. And eaves communities tend to be outperforming right now. To give you some perspective, in the fourth quarter for our portfolio, the B assets or the eaves assets, which is, for the most part, B assets, were about 70 basis points ahead of how the A assets were performing. As you go look at Axiometrics, it's a pretty similar pattern there in terms of the outperformance. So this part of the cycle, well-positioned, value-oriented communities are outperforming. To the extent we are selling one of those communities, it typically is related to either submarket specific or asset specific, either issues we have or concerns about concentration in terms of other activity we might have in the region, that typically drives those disposition decisions as it relates to pretty much any community, but eaves as well.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then bigger picture on the development pipeline, in light of the fact that you're projecting your land position to decline in 2016, 26 projects under development, about 10% of your asset base is tied up in development. Where do -- if you were to kind
componenttext: And then bigger picture on the development pipeline, in light of the fact that you're projecting your land position to decline in 2016, 26 projects under development, about 10% of your asset base is tied up in development. Where do -- if you were to kind of roll forward 3, 4 years from now, would that number -- would those numbers be materially lower than they are today, if you had to hazard a guess?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, this is Tim. My guess is they'll be lower. How materially, it really kind of depends a bit on the opportunity set. We've been a little surprised, honestly, over the last, I'd say, 1 or 1.5 years that we continued to see, we think, are pretty compell
componenttext: Rich, this is Tim. My guess is they'll be lower. How materially, it really kind of depends a bit on the opportunity set. We've been a little surprised, honestly, over the last, I'd say, 1 or 1.5 years that we continued to see, we think, are pretty compelling opportunities at reasonable land prices. So to the extent that things get -- start getting too expensive or too distorted, which they have on a limited basis, for instance, in the Bay Area, where it's tough to make the numbers work in the Bay Area. So if all the markets started looking like the Bay Area, it would -- we would deplete the development rights inventory pretty quickly. But that's not my guess. I mean, typically, the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic can be a little bit more stable. And I would expect -- the expected case would be, it would start to draw down a bit over the next 3 years.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, gentlemen, your final question of the day comes from Wes Golladay with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And, gentlemen, your final question of the day comes from Wes Golladay with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually Neil on for Wes. Just a question on occupancy. It looked like this quarter, you saw pretty strong drop in occupancies across the board, particularly in Northern California. Just wondering if you can comment on that. Is it a function of just
componenttext: It's actually Neil on for Wes. Just a question on occupancy. It looked like this quarter, you saw pretty strong drop in occupancies across the board, particularly in Northern California. Just wondering if you can comment on that. Is it a function of just seasonally weak or lower leasing, a function of you switching your expirations to the middle, higher volume, higher velocity times of the year, pushing rent too hard? Can you comment on that?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Neil, this is Sean. I mean, one thing to keep in mind is while occupancy was down on a year-over-year basis, if you look at it on a sequential basis, we were actually up 20 basis points. And there were a couple of markets at the end of 2014, particu
componenttext: Sure. Neil, this is Sean. I mean, one thing to keep in mind is while occupancy was down on a year-over-year basis, if you look at it on a sequential basis, we were actually up 20 basis points. And there were a couple of markets at the end of 2014, particularly Northern California and the greater New York region, where frankly availability was a little lower than we had wanted it from an ideal perspective in terms of pushing pricing and occupancy drifted up a little heavy. So we are not too concerned about the year-over-year change -- sequential change. We are perfectly fine with -- we're well positioned today in terms of where we sit. We're basically mid-95s in terms of economic occupancy. It's down about 30, 40 basis points, but it's right about where we think we should be. As we look towards the spring, we want to try and push pricing as much as we can, and availability is in the mid-5% range. It's up 30, 40 bps from last year at this point in time. But as I mentioned, we thought we were probably a little bit on the low side at this point last year. So we think we're in pretty good shape. And you're just looking at a year-over-year comp that was creating that change in occupancy.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then lastly, are you seeing any evidence that in the Bay Area, for some of your rentals on the higher end that people maybe are pushing back or maybe seeing some softness in renewals or new leases that would lead you to indicate that there may b
componenttext: Okay. And then lastly, are you seeing any evidence that in the Bay Area, for some of your rentals on the higher end that people maybe are pushing back or maybe seeing some softness in renewals or new leases that would lead you to indicate that there may be something more than a temporary blip going on in that market?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, good question. I mean, obviously, Q4 is typically the slower period. I would say it was a little beyond seasonal adjustment in the fourth quarter, whether it continues to soften a bit is yet to be seen. But I think, as we indicated earlier, we're
componenttext: Yes. No, good question. I mean, obviously, Q4 is typically the slower period. I would say it was a little beyond seasonal adjustment in the fourth quarter, whether it continues to soften a bit is yet to be seen. But I think, as we indicated earlier, we're expecting job growth to slow in that region. Deliveries will be accelerating in that market. So we are expecting it to soften a bit as we move throughout the year, whether that was a first sign of it in the fourth quarter or not is yet to be seen, but we did expect some softening. We realize that. And then the question going forward here is with the pace of job growth since we know what supply is going to be. So our expectation is the market will moderate through 2016, given just the fundamentals that are in place.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Aaron, and welcome to AvalonBay Communities First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call.Before we begin, please note that forward-looking statements may be made during this discussion.There are a variety of risks and uncertainties ass
componenttext:
Well, thank you, Aaron, and welcome to AvalonBay Communities First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call.
Before we begin, please note that forward-looking statements may be made during this discussion.
There are a variety of risks and uncertainties associated with forward-looking statements, and actual results may differ materially.
There's a discussion of these risks and uncertainties in yesterday afternoon's press release as well as in the company's Form 10-K and Form 10-Q filed with the SEC.
As usual, this press release does include an attachment with definitions and reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures and other terms, which may be used in today's discussion.
The attachment is also available on our website at www.avalonbay.com/earnings, and we encourage you to refer to this information during the review of our operating results and financial performance.
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Tim Naughton, Chairman and CEO of AvalonBay Communities, for his remarks. Tim?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Jason, and welcome to our Q1 call. With me today are Kevin O'Shea, Sean Breslin and Matt Birenbaum. I'll be providing management commentary on the slides that were posted yesterday afternoon, and all of us will be available for Q&A afterwards
componenttext:
Yes, thanks, Jason, and welcome to our Q1 call. With me today are Kevin O'Shea, Sean Breslin and Matt Birenbaum. I'll be providing management commentary on the slides that were posted yesterday afternoon, and all of us will be available for Q&A afterwards. 
My comments will focus on providing summary of Q1 results, talk about trends in the apartment market and our portfolio, and lastly, I'll share some thoughts on capital allocation and portfolio management. 
So starting on Slide 4, it was a strong quarter this past quarter, where we achieved core FFO growth of more than 12.5%, fueled by healthy same-store revenue growth of 5.5% and same-store NOI growth of almost 8% as well as contributions coming from our lease-up portfolio from our $2.7 billion development pipeline. As we mentioned last quarter, external growth from investment activities has contributed roughly 45% of core FFO growth over the last 2 years, and it continues to add meaningfully to FFO growth in 2016. We were active on the portfolio management front as well this past quarter, closing at $240 million in acquisitions and almost $0.5 billion in dispositions. 
Turning now to Slide 5. Recent market trends reflect shifting patterns across our footprint. This chart shows year-over-year changes in effective rent for each of our 6 regions for the full market as reported by Axiometrics. A few trends worth noting include first, effective rent growth on the West Coast continues to outpace the East Coast by about 400 basis points, running around 6% in the West and roughly 2% in the East during the quarter. 
Second, the New York, Northern California regions are seeing some deceleration while our other regions remain stable or are improving. New York has been impacted by new supply while Northern California's performance is being driven by a combination of supply, slower job growth than last year at this time and tough year-over-year comps. Southern California, Seattle continue to post strong gains while D.C. is beginning to show modest improvement. 
The last point worth mentioning is that these charts really do demonstrate the apartment cyclical can ebb and flow, similar to what we experienced in the '90s. With deliveries beginning to stabilize, rent growth is likely to bounce around a bit, driven more by the demand side of the equation, including demographic shifts, growth and employment and wages and the pace of household formation. 
Turning to Slide 6. Looking at our portfolio, we can see that the average rent change in the market is consistent with our portfolio, and the overall market trends, it remains healthy in the 4% range. This rate of growth is down from last year but is consistent with our expectations as more supply is coming online this year. In addition, similar to the prior set of charts, our portfolio reflects markets that can be somewhat choppy across the cycle. In fact, just in this cycle, we have seen 3 periods when rent growth has been above the average and 3 when it's been below the average during a time span of less than 6 years. 
Turning to Slide 7. After having trailed in rent growth versus urban submarkets earlier this cycle, suburban submarkets began to outperform over the last couple of years. This trend has been driven by expanding development pipelines in inventory that began to build in many urban submarkets across our region starting in 2013, outpacing suburban deliveries during this time. We believe that this trend of suburban outperformance is likely to continue over the next 2 to 3 years, given that urban deliveries should be about 2x that of the suburbs through 2017. 
As capital allocators and active developers, we've been talking about this over the last couple of years. We began shifting our focus 2 to 3 years ago toward suburban submarkets, particularly in fill areas, where we saw better values and less supply. But, however, just as I mentioned, our market performance can ebb and flow across the cycle by region, the same is true for some markets. As capital flows shift in response to these trends, we'll continue to be opportunistic in search of the most compelling risk-adjusted returns whether they'd be in target suburban or urban submarkets. 
In fact, over our 20-plus year history, we've achieved similar returns in urban and suburban submarkets across our regions. We've been able to do this by taking a fine grain approach to capital allocation, directing new investments to the highest risk-adjusted returns at any particular point in time. 
Now turning to Slide 8. Another capital allocation topic I'd like to touch on relates to our level of development as the cycle matures. This slide depicts realized and estimated unrealized IRRs of development completions sorted by completion dates through 2013. 
Last quarter, we discussed strategies we are deploying to mitigate risk posed by our development efforts, including pipeline diversification, managing land inventory and match funding new commitments. This quarter, we thought it might be helpful to look at how development has performed historically based upon cycle timing and timing of delivery. 
As you can see and might expect, development generates its highest returns during periods of economic expansion, particularly in the early years of expansion, where projects may have been started during the prior downturn or in the early recovery portion of the current cycle. What perhaps is less intuitive is our history of generating healthy returns for projects that delivered during the contraction phase of the cycle and that were most likely started during the latter portion of the prior cycle, a point in time when land and construction costs are generally peaking. 
Across all parts of the cycle, we've been able to comfortably clear our cost of capital and deliver NAV to shareholders through development. My point here is not that development always makes sense but rather, that we can continue to create value through this capability during downturns if deployed in a skillful, rigorous and disciplined way that focuses our efforts and resources on the most compelling opportunities in our markets.
Turning to Slide 9. It stands to reason that as we pursue development in a disciplined manner as the cycle matures, it ought to result in a diminished opportunity set as fewer deals meet required hurdle rates. And in fact, this is the case. Since 2013 while our development pipeline is measured by total capital investment has more or less leveled off, we measured it as a percent of total enterprise value or even by the number of projects, it's declined by roughly 25% to 30%. So we believe that we can continue to create shareholder value through new development at this point in the cycle, albeit at a lesser rate perhaps than earlier in the cycle. 
Lastly, turning to Slide 10. We've been active in the transaction market recently, and I wanted to share a couple of thoughts with respect to our activities in this area of our business. Over the last few months, we've purchased or cleared due diligence on 3 communities totaling over $300 million of total investment. Each of these communities are high-quality assets with high walk scores and great submarkets located in Alexandria and Arlington, Virginia and Hoboken, New Jersey. 
With many merchant built development deals completing and some investment funds unwinding, we are seeing some excellent assets come to market, much of it unencumbered by long-term debt and expensive prepayment penalties. These acquisitions are being funded and turned through asset sale proceeds from fund and wholly-owned dispositions, some of which will trade as 1031 exchanges with the acquisitions. 
As a result, our level of asset sales will be dependent on acquisition volume. As we identify acquisitions that we believe can improve the risk-adjusted returns for our portfolio, we'll pair them with the sale of noncore assets. But overall, we do plan on being a net seller of assets this year. We're just taking advantage of an active market to improve the portfolio. 
So in summary, before opening it up to Q&A, I just like to say that Q1 was another strong quarter for AVB, achieving double-digit growth in core FFO for the fourth consecutive quarter. While we are seeing some moderation in fundamentals and operating trends, they remain healthy. The sector will continue to benefit from favorable demographics and living patterns of millenials and Gen X while new deliveries should begin to stabilize in 2016 at levels that are at or below the structural demand for our apartment housing. As we move into the mature portion of the economic expansion, we'll remain disciplined capital allocators and risk managers, recognizing that we can continue to create meaningful value for shareholders through new development, employing the talent and rigor that we've demonstrated over the several cycles during the last 20-plus years. 
And with that, Aaron, we'd be happy to open up the call for questions.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Nick Joseph with Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Nick Joseph with Citi.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering in terms of operations if you could talk about how the first quarter trended relative to where you thought it would at the beginning of the year, which markets are ahead of expectations so far and maybe which are behind.
componenttext: I'm wondering in terms of operations if you could talk about how the first quarter trended relative to where you thought it would at the beginning of the year, which markets are ahead of expectations so far and maybe which are behind.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nick, it's Sean. Happy to do that. Overall, based on performance in the first quarter and what we know about the second quarter thus far, we're basically in line with our overall expectations for revenue. New York is a little bit behind, but Southern
componenttext: Yes, Nick, it's Sean. Happy to do that. Overall, based on performance in the first quarter and what we know about the second quarter thus far, we're basically in line with our overall expectations for revenue. New York is a little bit behind, but Southern Cal, Pacific Northwest and the Mid-Atlantic are a little bit ahead, more than offsetting New York. And then the other 2 major regions, Boston and the Northern California region are basically in line with our original budget. In terms of -- to provide a little more color maybe on where we are in terms of recent trends in the first quarter, rent change was 3.7%. It's trended up in April to 4.2%, which is renewals in the mid-5s and move into the high 2s, getting to that 4.2%. And to provide some context when we plan for the year, our expectation is that rent change throughout the year would average about 4.5%, which is down about 120 basis points from what we realized in rent change in 2015. So based on where we are now, moving into the second quarter of the stronger leasing season when rents really start to ramp up, our expectation is pretty consistent with what's happening in the portfolio and particularly if you look towards the stronger season and renewal offers, I think we're in pretty good shape. May and June renewal offers are out in the high 6% range, and that's basically a blend of call it, 5% in the Mid-Atlantic and New York, about 6.5% in Boston, about 8% in Northern Cal and Southern Cal and about 10% in Seattle. So overall, we think we're in pretty good shape. Things are unfolding sort of as we expected, and as we look forward into the rest of the second quarter, we're pretty good position occupancy wise. We're 95 7 at this point, which is about 20 basis points below this point last year, and availability is in the low 5s, about 10 basis points lower over last year. So those numbers we're comfortable with taking on slightly lower occupancy, availability's about right as we start to push rents harder going into the spring season.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of supply in urban versus suburban, the presentation shows suburban supply decreasing in '17 against urban, but the commentary from the other apartment peers that have reported earnings so far is focused on supply moving out of the urban
componenttext: And then in terms of supply in urban versus suburban, the presentation shows suburban supply decreasing in '17 against urban, but the commentary from the other apartment peers that have reported earnings so far is focused on supply moving out of the urban core and more back into the suburbs. So I'm wondering if you expect that to occur after 2017 or if you think supply will continue to impact the urban core more so at this point in the cycle.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nick, this is Tim. The slide that we showed, I guess, Slide 7, to be clear, that really is focused on deliveries as we get out to '16 and '17. Our peers may have been -- I didn't listen to their calls, they may have been focused more in starts, which were
componenttext: Nick, this is Tim. The slide that we showed, I guess, Slide 7, to be clear, that really is focused on deliveries as we get out to '16 and '17. Our peers may have been -- I didn't listen to their calls, they may have been focused more in starts, which were obviously would impact maybe '18, '19. And as I mentioned before, I mean, it's not -- we're relatively agnostic between urban and suburban and in terms of just even how we're focusing our efforts if we start to see market value in the urban submarkets, we're going to -- because of some of the trends we're seeing now, we're likely to maybe double back there. So they may be right. You might see some falloff in '18 or '19 if starts in '16 or '17 come down in the urban areas. But certainly, in terms of deliveries, we don't see that at all over the next couple of years.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nick, just to give you some specific name numbers based on our ground-up view of supply, which is a blend of the development team and our operations team and our market research team working together with own knowledge as well as third-party informat
componenttext: Yes, Nick, just to give you some specific name numbers based on our ground-up view of supply, which is a blend of the development team and our operations team and our market research team working together with own knowledge as well as third-party information, those numbers in '16 are about 2.8% of inventory in the urban submarkets in terms of deliveries and about 1.9% in suburban. And the projections for '17 based on pretty much what we know right now in the ground, et cetera. So it can move a little bit but given the time line get things entitled and built, it's not going to move a lot. Some stuff maybe delayed from 1 year to the next but in aggregate, probably not going to move a lot. For '17 deliveries in the urban submarkets around 3%, suburban around 1.4%. That's based on what we know today. The other thing that's out there we probably need to be mindful of just in terms of total supply is there are some things happening both from hard cost perspective as well as the construction lending environment that may constrain that a little bit just universally. So that's something to keep in mind.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Jana Galan with Bank of America.
componenttext: We'll go next to Jana Galan with Bank of America.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Public-private partnership development right added in this quarter looks very unique. Is that something you're going to look to do more of in the future?
componenttext: Public-private partnership development right added in this quarter looks very unique. Is that something you're going to look to do more of in the future?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jana, it's Matt. I'll speak to that one. It has been a part of our business for a long time, and we had a lot of success in public-private partnerships at certain points in the cycle, including in New York, we have some very successful deals in Queens, in
componenttext: Jana, it's Matt. I'll speak to that one. It has been a part of our business for a long time, and we had a lot of success in public-private partnerships at certain points in the cycle, including in New York, we have some very successful deals in Queens, in Long Island City Last decade that were somewhat similar. We've done some public-private deals on the West Coast at some transit stations. So it does play well to our competitive advantages, we think, and to some of our strengths, and that deal's actually a good example because we were able to be selective there as a developer even though others may have offered a higher land value because the public authority recognized and respected that given our reputation, given our scale, our balance sheet strength, everything else that we can deliver on our promises. And for them, it's as much about certainty of execution. There are some schools to be built there on that site as well as the project we would own and -- by dealing with and selecting us, they don't have to deal with a private developer who's going to have a separate equity partner or separate lender, separate general contractor. It's an integrated solution. So we have -- we like those deals. That particular deal, it's a pretty exciting location, 96th Street and Second Avenue. It's a full city block. It's right on top of the new Second Avenue subway line, which is, I think, the first new line in the city in many, many, many years. And the timing on that one is such that given the approvals process that's in front of us the regulatory process, that deal actually may well start kind of early into the next cycle, which is based on some of the slide that Tim had shown before, are frequently deals that have very strong returns.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if there any updates for your Upper West Side New York development in terms of the retail component?
componenttext: And if there any updates for your Upper West Side New York development in terms of the retail component?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jana, this is Tim. I think you're referring to the Columbus Circle site that we own. Currently, we actually are doing some work on the site. We're doing some enabling work in terms of abatement and demolition. I think as we mentioned before, we still anti
componenttext: Jana, this is Tim. I think you're referring to the Columbus Circle site that we own. Currently, we actually are doing some work on the site. We're doing some enabling work in terms of abatement and demolition. I think as we mentioned before, we still anticipate starting the deal some time mid this year, probably sometime in Q3, late Q3. We are continuing to evaluate different strategies. There are some risks there, including one way that you mentioned by bringing in a retail partner. We still have people who are registered despite some softness on the sides so people are interested in wholesaling some of the building for residential condo as well. The reality is we've been spending time really trying to nail down performance obligations for both sides, and it's ultimately got to work, ultimately for there to be a deal because to the extent we bring in a retail partner, they would have essentially be taking title at the time which we can deliver a cold dark shelf to them. We want to make sure they're going to be there, and they're going to want to make sure we can meet certain performance obligations. And until in effect we're almost ready to start the building, the vertical building construction, we're not going to really be in a position to finalize the deal there. Another strategy -- I mean, in part given the East 96th Street site, we are considering potentially bringing a financial partner to lay off some -- as another way to lay off some risk. The deal that Matt just talked about, it's a large deal, which is over $500 million, excluding the land lease itself, and so and as we think about New York City concentration you may look at either joint venture in Columbus circle or potentially even other avenues to lay off some of the concentration risk in a pretty short investment time period in the city. So just stay tuned. We are exploring a number of sort of risk management strategies with respect to this deal in the overall portfolio there, and we'll keep you people informed as it makes most sense.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Gaurav Mehta with Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: We'll go next to Gaurav Mehta with Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Following up on New York. You cited supply as one of the reasons for softness in the market. I was wondering if you could also comment on what you're seeing on the demand side.
componenttext: Following up on New York. You cited supply as one of the reasons for softness in the market. I was wondering if you could also comment on what you're seeing on the demand side.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Gaurav. This is Sean. I mean, if you think about it in New York, for the most part, we do think it is supply issue. It's about -- our expectation for this year is about 2% of inventory, but in New York city proper, it's about 3.5% direct supply and
componenttext: Sure, Gaurav. This is Sean. I mean, if you think about it in New York, for the most part, we do think it is supply issue. It's about -- our expectation for this year is about 2% of inventory, but in New York city proper, it's about 3.5% direct supply and then if you toss in some shadow supply from condos and things like that, that number might be a little bit higher. The demand side, demand has actually been pretty healthy. Job growth has been steady across the region, and in the, I think, mid-1% range. It's been up in the mid-2s in terms of the city itself. So demand has been there. But what you have to keep in mind related to the supply is it's all coming in it's pretty high end, for the most part. And if you think about New York City and even parts of Northern New Jersey, what's going to be delivered this year is about 10,000 units. So there's plenty of demand. The demand may not look the same as what it has in the last cycle in terms of either percentage from the financial sector a very, very high paying levels. So there is probably more diversity of the job growth than what we've experienced in the past, but there has been steady absorption and steady demand in that market.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, and then following up on suburban versus urban that Slide #7 that you have in your presentation suburban outperforming urban. But if I look at your New York suburban portfolio it by then underperforming the urban market. So I was wondering if you c
componenttext: Great, and then following up on suburban versus urban that Slide #7 that you have in your presentation suburban outperforming urban. But if I look at your New York suburban portfolio it by then underperforming the urban market. So I was wondering if you could provide more details as to what's going on in New York suburban.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So in terms of the New York, one thing to keep in mind there is the suburban submarkets in the Northeast in general, including New York and then moving up into New England, are more seasonal. So you tend to see more softness in late Q4 and Q1 in the
componenttext: Yes. So in terms of the New York, one thing to keep in mind there is the suburban submarkets in the Northeast in general, including New York and then moving up into New England, are more seasonal. So you tend to see more softness in late Q4 and Q1 in the suburban submarkets. So that's not a surprise to us in terms of where we ended the first quarter as well as the fourth quarter. But as you look forward and the impact on supply to give you a sense where it's headed, for our portfolio, if you look at renewal offers as we move in through the second quarter, they're in the low 5% range. The weakest is New York City at about 4%. But Long Island's at 6%, Northern New Jersey is at 7%, Central New Jersey is 5.5%. So we do expect those suburban submarkets to pick up steam as we move through the second and third quarter relative to New York City purely just as a function of supply, for the most part. So we expect it'll play out that way in New York overall based on what we know today.

So rates holding a little bit above what we expected, around $60 a foot, and it has been good. So our expectation is for that to continue the DoBro product is a pretty unique product. It's been accepted quite well by the target demographic, and so we're pleased with early results.

componenttextpreview: Great. That's helpful. Just more sticking New York City submarket specifically despite the supply during sort of typically slower season, occupancy was up 50 basis points during the quarter, and I was just curious what was driving that if it was tactical
componenttext: Great. That's helpful. Just more sticking New York City submarket specifically despite the supply during sort of typically slower season, occupancy was up 50 basis points during the quarter, and I was just curious what was driving that if it was tactical and just some detail there.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as you might know from previous commentary for us, we don't necessarily target a very specific rate of occupancy for each and every market submarket. Our objective is optimize revenue, and so sometimes you're going to get back occupancy to get rate a
componenttext: Yes, as you might know from previous commentary for us, we don't necessarily target a very specific rate of occupancy for each and every market submarket. Our objective is optimize revenue, and so sometimes you're going to get back occupancy to get rate and/or vice versa to try and optimize revenues. So I wouldn't read too much into occupancy changes from quarter-to-quarter or even year-over-year. The only global statement I'd say is over the last couple of years given market conditions, we're more aggressive on rate, all things being equal, at the expense of occupancy across our footprint. And every submarkets a little bit different, but I wouldn't read too much into the sequential quarter or even the year-over-year numbers other than the trend over the last couple of years being more aggressive on the rate side and yielding a little bit more on occupancy has been okay.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then just switching and last one for me to the portfolio management comments. I guess, what are you guys really trying to accomplish as you see acquisitions come to market? And where exactly are you seeing the best opportunities?
componenttext: That's helpful. And then just switching and last one for me to the portfolio management comments. I guess, what are you guys really trying to accomplish as you see acquisitions come to market? And where exactly are you seeing the best opportunities?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, maybe I'll start and ask Matt to follow up in terms of where we're seeing the best opportunities. There's a lot of transaction volume right now, and there's a lot of really, as I mentioned in my prepared remarks, a lot of really fine assets oftentime
componenttext: Yes, maybe I'll start and ask Matt to follow up in terms of where we're seeing the best opportunities. There's a lot of transaction volume right now, and there's a lot of really, as I mentioned in my prepared remarks, a lot of really fine assets oftentimes built by the merchant builders coming off construction loans, they don't have permanent loans in place that have hefty prepayment penalties, and therefore sometimes sort of doesn't make it attractive for us in terms of assuming secured debt. So it's an opportunity to take advantage of the fact we have a lot of unencumbered assets, some of which are noncore that we like to -- we like to trade, and there's a point in time in which there's a really attractive assets that we think we can improve the overall quality of the portfolio by turning a little bit of it. So it's a little bit of a unique moment in time, we think. But in terms of where we're seeing some of the best opportunities maybe you just elaborate a little bit there.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I guess, I'd start by saying on the macro level regionally, the 2 regions where we would seek to redeploy capital the most would be the Mid-Atlantic and Southern California for different reasons, but those were actually kind of more or less on targe
componenttext: Sure. I guess, I'd start by saying on the macro level regionally, the 2 regions where we would seek to redeploy capital the most would be the Mid-Atlantic and Southern California for different reasons, but those were actually kind of more or less on target for our long-term portfolio, geographical allocation goals, but if we're under underallocated anywhere, it's probably those 2 regions. And some of that was, frankly, deliberate. In the case of Mid-Atlantic we sold quite a bit earlier in the cycle kind of in front of what we saw a lot of supply coming relative to the Mid-Atlantic's history. So we think it's a pretty good time to be buying in the Mid-Atlantic. Values haven't increased all that much relative to all of the other geographies in our portfolio, which makes sense because obviously, rents have been relatively flat here for quite a while. So we see just better value in terms of just total relative to replacement cost, relative to cost per foot, cost per unit. In Southern Cal, it's always difficult there. Archstone really was a transformative event for us in terms of growing our Southern California portfolio, but we're still looking to grow there, where we can. In terms of submarket locations, we are looking to upgrade the quality of the portfolio a little bit as Tim mention. So you look at the 3 that we mentioned so far, they are all infill, high-quality, high density infill suburbs we would look in the urban cores as well based on pricing, where we see the best relative value but higher walk scores. And then we have been looking at younger assets, which is a little different for us. We do find sometimes we're a very successful buyer for assets that maybe somebody else has just renovated, 12-, 15-year-old assets, where the value-add players aren't going to bid those up to the same extent. So we look at those types of assets too, but -- and arguably Market Common fit that description a little bit, but we're always looking for ways, where if we can leverage what advantages we have into sometimes it's a unique deal structure that may drive us to get a little bit better value on the buy-side. But typically we would probably be looking for assets that are a little bit younger than what you may have seen us buying in the past. And again...

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Jeffrey Pell with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll go next to Jeffrey Pell with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just looking back at the Archstone acquisition in late 2012, the largest component of the purchase was in Southern California. How do you believe those assets are performing today versus the original expectations?
componenttext: Just looking back at the Archstone acquisition in late 2012, the largest component of the purchase was in Southern California. How do you believe those assets are performing today versus the original expectations?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeff, it's Sean Breslin. In terms of overall performance, I think it's fair to say that the assets have outperformed our expectations in terms of a period of ownership here. And then on top of that, the other thing I would add is probably more opport
componenttext: Yes, Jeff, it's Sean Breslin. In terms of overall performance, I think it's fair to say that the assets have outperformed our expectations in terms of a period of ownership here. And then on top of that, the other thing I would add is probably more opportunity in the portfolio in terms of redevelopment, repositioning those assets than we probably expected going in. Did a fine job maintaining the assets but given the balance sheet they had and the position they were with Lehman just didn't necessarily have capital to invest assets reposition them. So we're trying to advantage of that opportunity across the footprint, including significant concentration that we did acquire in Southern California. So net-net, I'd say we're pleased with our results from Archstone, and values have grown considerably during the last couple of years.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just as a follow-up to that, do you believe your Southern California portfolio could potentially outperform Northern California over next few years?
componenttext: And just as a follow-up to that, do you believe your Southern California portfolio could potentially outperform Northern California over next few years?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Sean again. It's always a possibility given underlying demand drivers in Southern California combined with the very low levels of supply, the low of our regions currently in terms of our expectation sort of in the mid-1% range, it's a possibility. It
componenttext: It's Sean again. It's always a possibility given underlying demand drivers in Southern California combined with the very low levels of supply, the low of our regions currently in terms of our expectation sort of in the mid-1% range, it's a possibility. It tends to be market that over the long run has been an outperformer with far less volatility than some of the tech markets like Northern California and Seattle. So it could certainly a period of time where it does outperform that would not be out of reason, be beyond reason.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: We'll go next Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just first, you mentioned in some prior questions ago about the bank regulation on lending. As you guys have seen it so far in the banks be impacted by the Basel III coming down on construction lending, has your experience, what you've seen in the field,
componenttext: Just first, you mentioned in some prior questions ago about the bank regulation on lending. As you guys have seen it so far in the banks be impacted by the Basel III coming down on construction lending, has your experience, what you've seen in the field, has it been a material cut back on the part of developers and their inability to get construction lending? Or is this really sort of an issue on the edges and most developers that you see in the market are still able to get construction lending as they historically have been able to?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alex, this is Sean. Maybe Tim or Matt want to jump in. At this point, we're aware of what's been communicated to the banks, and some of the risk retention issues as well as incremental oversight in multifamily loans. For the most part, what we're hearing
componenttext: Alex, this is Sean. Maybe Tim or Matt want to jump in. At this point, we're aware of what's been communicated to the banks, and some of the risk retention issues as well as incremental oversight in multifamily loans. For the most part, what we're hearing is somewhat anecdotal in terms of more pressure on the underwriting banks putting out targets that are, I'd say, either even or less than volume they produced last year in terms of construction lending for multifamily specifically. So I'd say it's still early in the game as to the eventual outcome, but there are certain signs of tightening that will put more pressure on bring in either additional equity to the table to get deals done probably is the likely answer but different pricing as well, and Kevin may want to comment on that as well from a bank perspective.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, sure, Alex. We're not directly in the market, but from what we've been able to learn from being active in our dialogue with banks who do these kind of construction financing and certainly what we have heard is construction financing has become tou
componenttext: I mean, sure, Alex. We're not directly in the market, but from what we've been able to learn from being active in our dialogue with banks who do these kind of construction financing and certainly what we have heard is construction financing has become tough to obtain as you point out especially for small as well as capitalized developers. Pricing, for example, has moved beyond 300 bps over LIBOR. In order to get better terms, often these developers are needing to partial recourse and sometimes make a commitment to provide permanent financing to the bank. So construction provide higher levels of deposits. So across the board, this has just been a little bit of tightening that we've seen in that end market.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, maybe a last point on this. I think sort of initially manifest itself you start to see a little more deal flow on the land side. So private sponsors are maybe not getting the terms or hearing what they want to hear from banks or even potentially new
componenttext: Yes, maybe a last point on this. I think sort of initially manifest itself you start to see a little more deal flow on the land side. So private sponsors are maybe not getting the terms or hearing what they want to hear from banks or even potentially new equity partners. Those deals gets sort of softly marketed back in the market, and we're seeing that right now on some on a couple of particularly attractive opportunities, where the landowner thought they're going to develop it themselves, and certainly, there's many different story to the market that they've got a lot in their plate they need to sell some what they got. So I think that's it we're likely to see it manifest itself at least initially here over the next 3 to 6 months, but I think it'll probably just have to keep a watch out and see as it really having an impact today on total start volume.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: But the point you guys are likely to see some more attractively priced land?
componenttext: But the point you guys are likely to see some more attractively priced land?

componenttextpreview: And on the condo side on the bay project, where you have a condo partner in there, what's the -- can you just given all the talk about condo concern in New York, can you just as far as the financial risk to AvalonBay, if the entity doesn't revise soon you
componenttext: And on the condo side on the bay project, where you have a condo partner in there, what's the -- can you just given all the talk about condo concern in New York, can you just as far as the financial risk to AvalonBay, if the entity doesn't revise soon you guys just automatically take over their spot? Or is there some financial liability to you if they run into something to difficulty on their own?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alex, this is Matt. I guess, I can take a shot on that one. Tim want to chime in as well. Equity deal we are providing construction financing really to facilitate the deal because we're building the whole building. And so if they were to default on the lo
componenttext: Alex, this is Matt. I guess, I can take a shot on that one. Tim want to chime in as well. Equity deal we are providing construction financing really to facilitate the deal because we're building the whole building. And so if they were to default on the loan, they would walk away from their equity, and we would wind up with their units, and there's some guarantee support as well. I don't remember exactly how deep that goes, and we have looked at that as a downside scenario. We could take their units back and rent them, and we don't think it would be a material change to the economics of that deal. I will also say that it's a very different location. There's no -- you talk about there's a lot of condo supply in New York. It's not in bay. It's not in Brighton Beach. It's not in that part of Brooklyn at also. That market is until little micro pocket there that I really think is hardly at all impacted by what's going on across the city.

componenttext: Okay. And then just final question. The $0.14 land gain in the second quarter, what's that related to?

componenttext: Sure, Alex. This is Kevin. That relates to second phase development that we anticipate contributing to venture with our existing partners and, in doing so, recognize a gain on that sale of the land about $20 million.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sean, can you talk a little bit about what you're seeing in your various D.C. submarkets performance wise, stronger versus weaker and what's likely to the trend over the remainder of the year as leasing continues?
componenttext: Sean, can you talk a little bit about what you're seeing in your various D.C. submarkets performance wise, stronger versus weaker and what's likely to the trend over the remainder of the year as leasing continues?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure Rob, happy to. In terms of the Mid-Atlantic, based on where we are today in terms of performance, and I'll talk mainly from a rent change perspective in terms of where we're getting traction, D.C. is actually holding up the best right at the mom
componenttext: Yes, sure Rob, happy to. In terms of the Mid-Atlantic, based on where we are today in terms of performance, and I'll talk mainly from a rent change perspective in terms of where we're getting traction, D.C. is actually holding up the best right at the moment, kind of mid-2% range versus a 1.5% or so for suburban Maryland and Northern Virginia. That's up roughly about 75 basis points over last year. I mean, our expectation going forward is that it's probably going to continue to be the softest in the suburban Maryland submarket based on the supply that's being delivered across Rockville and North Bethesda, et cetera, Northern Virginia, probably will be sort of second position, if you want to call it, in terms of performance and then D.C. based on asset mix that we have, we will probably be the leading submarket in terms of performance. And keep in mind what's in our same-store bucket is Northwest, value-oriented assets, a deal tied to American university, et cetera. So it's a very different kind of same-store relative to many others. The majority of the supply is actually going to be delivered in the district. So if you look at it from an entire market perspective, D.C. probably will continue to be soft and potentially as soft as suburban Maryland, but in terms of our specific portfolio and the way it's positioned, the D.C. assets are leading and probably will continue to.
