componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I wouldn't say so. I mean, if I think about it from New York perspective, the highest rent deal we have very is in at $80 a foot or so, and it's performing quite well. There's little supply there. So again, for the most part, it really does d
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I wouldn't say so. I mean, if I think about it from New York perspective, the highest rent deal we have very is in at $80 a foot or so, and it's performing quite well. There's little supply there. So again, for the most part, it really does depend where your assets are positioned relative to new supply. So we've got $50, $60 a foot assets in Midtown West, more value-oriented, but there's more supply there. So they're struggling more as an example. But when you go to Long Island City and it's $50 a foot, $55 a foot, and it's doing 6% year-over-year, and so I wouldn't say there's a common thread to higher-end units underperforming across any of the markets at this point in time, it's really more direct function of supply in submarket that you're in.

componenttextpreview: A question on New York. Is there -- can we get a comment about how things trended over the course of the quarter? Did you notice anything improving as the quarter went on? Was March better than January? Was nothing discernible there in terms of trend line
componenttext: A question on New York. Is there -- can we get a comment about how things trended over the course of the quarter? Did you notice anything improving as the quarter went on? Was March better than January? Was nothing discernible there in terms of trend line?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, Rich, this is Sean. It's picking up steam a little bit. I mean, if you look at the region overall, rent change in the first quarter is about 2%, which was 1% in New York City, about 4% in Long Island and 2.5% to 3.5% in New Jersey markets. It
componenttext: Yes, I mean, Rich, this is Sean. It's picking up steam a little bit. I mean, if you look at the region overall, rent change in the first quarter is about 2%, which was 1% in New York City, about 4% in Long Island and 2.5% to 3.5% in New Jersey markets. It has picked up steam a little bit, where we are doing around 3% now instead of 2%, which is around low 4s on renewables and 1%, 1.5% on move ins. But as I mentioned earlier, when you look at renewals, I'd say they started to pick up a little more speed, particularly in the suburban submarkets. As I mentioned, New York City still gets around 4%, but it was up quite nicely when you get into the suburban submarkets 5.5%, 6%, 7% depending on where you are. So I'd say the momentum is positive probably most positive in the suburban submarkets as compared to the city.

componenttext: Rich, this is Matt. Yes, no. We are planning on doing some of our disposition acquisition activity as 1031 exchanges. But I wouldn't say that we have tax protection issues beyond the fact that we can only sell so much with average deploying the proceeds into acquisitions or paying special dividend. So I mean, we have an overall company limits on that volume, but I don't know...

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, this is Kevin. To add on that, we tend, as you know, to use dispositions as a means of funding development activity, and that certainly is our plan this year. The component of our external capital that we raised a fund development will be in the for
componenttext: Rich, this is Kevin. To add on that, we tend, as you know, to use dispositions as a means of funding development activity, and that certainly is our plan this year. The component of our external capital that we raised a fund development will be in the form of dispositions at some level beyond a certain point when we sell additional assets and trigger additional gains, and you could see some very robust gains reflected in what we sold so far. You do run into a situation where from a retax point of view, we need special distribution in order to retain the capital. So if we want to buy assets to reposition the portfolio and fund that with dispositions beyond what we would needs to self-fund development, then it at some point, just makes sense to do that incremental portfolio repositioning through 1031 activity.

componenttext: As it relates to our portfolio in your concentration more suburban as well as Class B and you think about the inventories how tight they are for resale and the benefit that your tenants may not be able to find something want to move out or afford it or get mortgage financing and some of the challenges, how do you think about going forward some of the dynamics that incrementally on floor sale side that might loosen up or more inventory will come, and which markets are you going to be the most vulnerable or may see more pressure to move out to buy within your footprint just first question then I have a follow-up.

componenttext: General commentary on that trend maybe. I mean, move outstanding purchased have remained has remained well below historical averages for our essentially this entire cycle. It's only 11% this quarter as an example, which is down about 150 basis points year-over-year, and typically we're probably both sensitive to it in terms of either existing assets or new opportunities is in those markets, where home prices are somewhat more affordable, which is typically be Seattle and the Mid-Atlantic, maybe a bit in Central Jersey. And based on everything that we see, production has certainly started to increase some, but it remains well below just sort of structural demand given the level of household formations either expected, which probably better than all of us. So in terms of near-term pressure, I don't think that's likely to be a real issue for us based on what we know today.

componenttext: No, it does move around by market. The only market that basically was at its long-term average 1 point last year was New England, which was around 20%, 21% strip down since is that time. So at this point, every market is running well below its long-term average.

So -- and there's probably more significant even in this submarkets that are experiencing a lot of supply.

componenttext: Yes, Drew, this is Sean. First maybe set some context Northern California when we provided guidance earlier this year, and Tim alluded to it on today's prepared remarks for the call as well. We did have an expectation that given the increase in supply across the region, which is basically around 3% today as compared to 1.5% last year combined with a somewhat softening in demand, if you remember at this point, last year, job growth across the Bay Area was running around 4% at a pretty blistering pace as compared to about 2% today that we would see softening in performance throughout the year that's pretty much on track. As I mentioned earlier, we're basically our budget in that market. In terms of the performance of the specific some markets, where you're seeing a stronger or weaker results what I'd say is in general, more value-oriented assets are outperforming the higher-end assets across the footprint to the footprint in the Bay Area region overall. In terms of specific some markets, San Francisco, the supplies pretty much Mission Bay kind of SoMa submarket right there and that tends to be a little bit weaker right now. Our assets value-oriented assets Daley City, Pacifica, they're all outperforming versus the higher end Mission bay and SoMa is underperforming. San Jose the supplies Northeast San Jose a little bit of San Jose and then stretches up really into Mountain View is all in terms of supply and then on the east bay, there's not a lot of supply really in the East bay a little bit Dublin and Pleasanton and some product, and online up towards public market Berkeley in that area, but it's de minimis relative to what you're seeing in San Francisco and San Jose. So hopefully that provides some context for where the supplies coming online.

componenttext: Sure, Tayo, this is Kevin. As you may recall, we sort of do not provide updated guidance for the full year on our first quarter call. We provide initial outlook obviously for our fourth quarter call in January, and then we provide a midyear update after intentionally our second quarter call. That's the plan. So we don't have a further update, particularly given that we've got leasing season in front of us, and we are only a few months from having done a full budget. So no new news on that front. This was the first quarter that we provided guidance on second quarter, and as you can see from our release, our guidance for the REIT FFO is $2.10 per share and for core FFO is $2 per share. So that's -- and then in terms of what we did in the first quarter as you know from our release, we beat our initial expectation by $0.06, which is probably the largest beat on our expectations in a quarterly basis in recent memory. So quite strong performance was about probably $0.04 of that $0.06 beat likely to be permanent and $0.02 likely to reverse at some point over the course of the year.

We don't provide that level of guidance is essentially that would be as you recall when we provided our outlook for 2016, we indicated that we intended sourcing external capital of about $1.1 billion. At the time we indicated that, that would likely come through unsecured debt an asset sales with unsecured debt hopefully and likely comprising the majority of that $1.1 billion. So really, it's the $1.1 billion less whatever we do in unsecured debt that would represent the net disposition activity, but it certainly represents a minority of that $1.1 billion. In terms of what we've done so far, as you can see, essentially, the acquisitions that we completed in the first quarter were basically funded through fund in wholly-owned asset sales and the assumed the debt in Hoboken so going forward, for the balance of the year, we expect that just sort of still about $1.1 billion, and again these expectation is predominantly in the form of unsecured debt with a balance through net disposition activity.

componenttext: This is Matt. We do have a couple of deals, which are mixed-use deals in our pipeline, including one that we expect to start here later this year in Northern California in Emeryville, which also we think plays to our strengths not dissimilar to the deal we did within here in Northern Virginia assembly up in Boston, which we did with federal. componenttext: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the AvalonBay Communities First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Your host for today's conference call is Mr. Jason Reilley, Senior Director of Investor Relations. Mr. Reilley, you may begin your conference.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Aaron, and welcome to AvalonBay Communities First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Before we begin, please note that forward-looking statements may be made during this discussion. There are a variety of risks and uncertainties assoc
componenttext:
Well, thank you, Aaron, and welcome to AvalonBay Communities First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Before we begin, please note that forward-looking statements may be made during this discussion. There are a variety of risks and uncertainties associated with forward-looking statements, and actual results may differ materially.
There's a discussion of these risks and uncertainties in yesterday afternoon's press release as well as in the company's Form 10-K and Form 10-Q filed with the SEC.
As usual, this press release does include an attachment with definitions and reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures and other terms, which may be used in today's discussion.
The attachment is also available on our website at www.avalonbay.com/earnings, and we encourage you to refer to this information during the review of our operating results and financial performance.
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Tim Naughton, Chairman and CEO of AvalonBay Communities, for his remarks. Tim?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Jason, and welcome to our Q1 call. With me today are Kevin O'Shea, Sean Breslin and Matt Birenbaum. I'll be providing management commentary on the slides that were posted yesterday afternoon, and all of us will be available for Q&A afterwards
componenttext:
Yes, thanks, Jason, and welcome to our Q1 call. With me today are Kevin O'Shea, Sean Breslin and Matt Birenbaum. I'll be providing management commentary on the slides that were posted yesterday afternoon, and all of us will be available for Q&A afterwards. 
My comments will focus on providing summary of Q1 results, talk about trends in the apartment market and our portfolio, and lastly, I'll share some thoughts on capital allocation and portfolio management. 
So starting on Slide 4, it was a strong quarter this past quarter, where we achieved core FFO growth of more than 12.5%, fueled by healthy same-store revenue growth of 5.5% and same-store NOI growth of almost 8%, as well as contributions coming from our lease-up portfolio from our $2.7 billion development pipeline. As we mentioned last quarter, external growth from investment activity has contributed roughly 45% of core FFO growth over the last 2 years, and it continues to add meaningfully to FFO growth in 2016. We were active on the portfolio management front as well this past quarter, closing at $240 million in acquisitions and almost $0.5 billion in dispositions. 
Turning now to Slide 5. Recent market trends reflect shifting patterns across our footprint. This chart shows year-over-year changes in effective rent for each of our 6 regions for the full market as reported by Axiometrics. A few trends worth noting include first, effective rent growth on the West Coast continues to outpace the East Coast by about 400 basis points, running around 6% in the West and roughly 2% in the East during the quarter. 
Second, the New York, Northern California regions are seeing some deceleration, while our other regions remain stable or are improving. New York has been impacted by new supply, while Northern California's performance is being driven by a combination of supply, slower job growth than last year this time and tough year-over-year comps. Southern California, Seattle continue to post strong gains while D.C. is beginning to show modest improvement. 
The last point worth mentioning is that these charts really do demonstrate the apartment cycle can ebb and flow, similar to what we experienced in the '90s. With deliveries beginning to stabilize, rent growth is likely to bounce around a bit, driven more by the demand side of the equation, including demographic shifts, growth in employment and wages and the pace of household formation. 
Turning to Slide 6. Looking at our portfolio, we can see that the average rent change in the market is consistent with our portfolio, and the overall market trends and remains healthy in the 4% range. This rate of growth is down from last year but is consistent with our expectations as more supply is coming online this year. In addition, similar to the prior set of charts, our portfolio reflects markets that can be somewhat choppy across the cycle. In fact, just in this cycle, we have seen 3 periods when rent growth has been above the average and 3 when it's been below the average during a time span of less than 6 years. 
Turning to Slide 7. After having trailed in rent growth versus urban submarkets earlier this cycle, suburban submarkets began to outperform over the last couple of years. This trend has been driven by expanding development pipelines in inventory that began to build in many urban submarkets across our region starting in 2013, outpacing suburban deliveries during this time. We believe that this trend of suburban outperformance is likely to continue over the next 2 to 3 years, given that urban deliveries should be about 2x that of the suburbs through 2017. 
As capital allocators and active developers, we've been talking about this over the last couple of years. We began shifting our focus 2 to 3 years ago toward suburban submarkets, particularly infill areas, where we saw better values and less supply. But, however, just as I mentioned, our market performance can ebb and flow across the cycle by region, the same is true for some markets. As capital flow shift the response to these trends, we'll continue to be opportunistic in search of the most compelling risk-adjusted returns whether they'd be in target suburban or urban submarkets. 
And in fact, over our 20-plus year history, we've achieved similar returns in urban and suburban submarkets across our regions. We've been able to do this by taking a fine grain approach to capital allocation, directing new investments to the highest risk-adjusted returns at any particular point in time. 
Now turning to Slide 8. Another capital allocation topic I'd like to touch on relates to our level of development as the cycle matures. This slide depicts realized and estimated unrealized IRRs of development completions sorted by completion dates through 2013. 
Last quarter, we discussed strategies we are deploying to mitigate risk posed by development efforts, and including pipeline diversification, managing land inventory and match funding new commitments. This quarter, we thought it might be helpful to look at how development has performed historically based upon cycle timing and timing of delivery. 
As you can see and might expect, development generates its highest returns during periods of economic expansion, particularly in the earlier years of expansion, where projects may have been started during the prior downturn or in the early recovery portion of the current cycle. What perhaps is less intuitive is our history of generating healthy returns for projects that delivered during the contraction phase of the cycle and that were most likely started during the latter portion of the prior cycle, a point in time when land and construction costs are generally peaking. 
Across all parts of the cycle, we've been able to comfortably clear our cost of capital and deliver NAV to shareholders through development. My point here is not that development always makes sense but rather, that we can continue to create value through this capability during downturns if deployed in a skillful, rigorous and disciplined way that focuses our efforts and resources on the most compelling opportunities in our markets.
Turning to Slide 9. It stands a reason that as we pursue development in a disciplined manner as the cycle matures, it ought to result in a diminished opportunity set as fewer deals meet required hurdle rates. And in fact, this is the case. Since 2013, while our development pipeline is measured by total capital investment has more or less leveled off, we measure it as a percent of total enterprise value or even by the number of projects, it's declined by roughly 25% to 30%. So we believe that we can continue to create shareholder value through new development at this point in the cycle, albeit at a lesser rate perhaps than earlier in the cycle. 
Lastly, turning to Slide 10. We've been active in the transaction market recently, and I wanted to share a couple of thoughts with respect to our activities in this area of our business. Over the last few months, we've purchased or cleared due diligence on 3 communities totaling over $300 million of total investment. Each of these communities are high-quality assets with high walk scores in great submarkets located in Alexandria and Arlington, Virginia and Hoboken, New Jersey. 
With many merchant built development deals completing and some investment funds unwinding, we are seeing some excellent assets come to market, much of it unencumbered by long-term debt and expensive prepayment penalties. These acquisitions are being funded and turned through asset sale proceeds from fund and wholly-owned dispositions, some of which will trade as 1031 exchanges with acquisitions. 
As a result, our level of asset sales will be dependent on acquisition volume. As we identify acquisitions that we believe can improve the risk-adjusted returns for our portfolio, we'll pair them with the sale of noncore assets. But overall, we do plan on being a net seller of assets this year. We're just taking advantage of an active market to improve the portfolio. 
So in summary, before opening it up to Q&A, I just like to say that Q1 was another strong quarter for AVB, achieving double-digit growth in core FFO for the fourth consecutive quarter. While we are seeing some moderation in fundamentals and operating trends, they remain healthy. The sector will continue to benefit from favorable demographics and living patterns of millenials and Gen X, while new deliveries should begin to stabilize in 2016 at levels that are at or below the structural demand for apartment housing. As we move into the mature portion of the economic expansion, we'll remain disciplined capital allocators and risk managers, recognizing that we can continue to create meaningful value for shareholders through new development, employing the talent and rigor that we've demonstrated over the several cycles during the past 20-plus years. 
And with that, Aaron, we'd be happy to open up the call for questions.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Nick Joseph with Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Nick Joseph with Citi.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering in terms of operations if you can talk about how the first quarter trended relative to where you thought it would at the beginning of the year, which markets are ahead of expectations so far and maybe which are behind.
componenttext: I'm wondering in terms of operations if you can talk about how the first quarter trended relative to where you thought it would at the beginning of the year, which markets are ahead of expectations so far and maybe which are behind.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nick, it's Sean. Happy to do that. Overall, based on performance in the first quarter and what we know about the second quarter thus far, we're basically in line with our overall expectations for revenue. New York is a little bit behind, but Southern
componenttext: Yes, Nick, it's Sean. Happy to do that. Overall, based on performance in the first quarter and what we know about the second quarter thus far, we're basically in line with our overall expectations for revenue. New York is a little bit behind, but Southern Cal, Pacific Northwest and the Mid-Atlantic are a little bit ahead, more than offsetting New York. And then the other 2 major regions, Boston and the Northern California region are basically in line with our original budget. In terms of -- to provide a little more color maybe on where we are in terms of recent trends in the first quarter, rent change was 3.7%. It's trended up in April to 4.2%, which is renewals in the mid-5s and move-ins in the high 2s, getting to that 4.2%. And to provide some context when we plan for the year, our expectation is that rent change throughout the year would average about 4.5%, which is down about 120 basis points from what we realized in rent change in 2015. So based on where we are now, moving into the second quarter of the stronger leasing season when rents really start to ramp up, our expectation is pretty consistent with what's happening in the portfolio, and particularly if you look towards the stronger season and renewal offers, we think we're in pretty good shape. May and June renewal offers are out in the high 6% range, and that's basically a blend of call it, 5% in the Mid-Atlantic and New York, about 6.5% in Boston, about 8% in Northern Cal and Southern Cal and about 10% in Seattle. So overall, we think we're in pretty good shape. Things are unfolding sort of as we expected. And as we look forward into the rest of the second quarter, we're pretty good position occupancy wise. We're 95 7 at this point, which is about 20 basis points below this point last year, and availability is in the low 5s, about 10 basis points lower over last year. So those are numbers we're comfortable with taking on slightly lower occupancy, availability is about right as we start to push rents harder as going into the spring season.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of supply in urban versus suburban, the presentation shows suburban supply decreasing in '17 against urban, but the commentary from the other apartment peers that have reported earnings so far is focused on supply moving out of the urban
componenttext: And then in terms of supply in urban versus suburban, the presentation shows suburban supply decreasing in '17 against urban, but the commentary from the other apartment peers that have reported earnings so far is focused on supply moving out of the urban core and more back into the suburbs. So I'm wondering if you expect that to occur after 2017 or if you think supply will continue to impact the urban core more so at this point in the cycle.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nick, this is Tim. The slide that we showed, I guess, it's Slide 7, to be clear, that really is focused on deliveries as we get out to '16 and '17. Our peers may have been -- I didn't listen to their calls, but may have been focused more on starts, which
componenttext: Nick, this is Tim. The slide that we showed, I guess, it's Slide 7, to be clear, that really is focused on deliveries as we get out to '16 and '17. Our peers may have been -- I didn't listen to their calls, but may have been focused more on starts, which will obviously would impact maybe '18, '19. And as I mentioned before, I mean, it's not -- we're relatively agnostic between urban and suburban and in terms of just even how we're focusing our efforts if we start to see more value in the urban submarkets, we're going to -- because of some of the trends we're seeing now, we're likely to maybe double back there. So they may be right. You might see some falloff in '18 or '19 if starts in '16 or '17 come down in the urban areas. But certainly, in terms of deliveries, we don't see that at all over the next couple of years.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nick, just to give you some specific numbers based on our sort of ground-up view of supply, which is a blend of the development team and our operations team and our market research team working together, both with our own knowledge as well as third-p
componenttext: Yes, Nick, just to give you some specific numbers based on our sort of ground-up view of supply, which is a blend of the development team and our operations team and our market research team working together, both with our own knowledge as well as third-party information, those numbers in '16 are about 2.8% of inventory in the urban submarkets in terms of deliveries and about 1.9% in suburban. And the projections for '17 based on pretty much what we know right now shovels in the ground, et cetera. So it can move a little bit, but given the time line to get things entitled and built, price is not going to move a lot. Some stuff maybe delayed from 1 year to the next but in aggregate, probably not going to move a lot. For '17 deliveries in the urban submarkets around 3%, and suburban about 1.4%. So that's based on what we know today. The other thing that's out there we probably need to be mindful of just in terms of total supply is there are some things happening both from a hard cost perspective as well as the construction lending environment that may constrain that a little bit just universally. So that's something to keep in mind.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Jana Galan with Bank of America.
componenttext: We'll go next to Jana Galan with Bank of America.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I thought the public-private partnership development right added in this quarter looks very unique. Is that something that you're going to look to do more of in the future?
componenttext: I thought the public-private partnership development right added in this quarter looks very unique. Is that something that you're going to look to do more of in the future?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jana, it's Matt. I guess, I'll speak to that one. It has been a part of our business for a long time, and we had a lot of success in public-private partnerships at certain points in the cycle, including in New York, we have some very successful deals in Q
componenttext: Jana, it's Matt. I guess, I'll speak to that one. It has been a part of our business for a long time, and we had a lot of success in public-private partnerships at certain points in the cycle, including in New York, we have some very successful deals in Queens, in Long Island City. Last decade they were somewhat similar. We've done some public-private deals on the West Coast at some transit stations. So it does play well to our competitive advantages, we think, and to some of our strengths, and that deal is actually a good example because we were able to be selective there as a developer, even though others may have offered a higher land value because the public authority recognized and respected that given our reputation, given our scale, our balance sheet strength, everything else that we can deliver on our promises. And for them, it's as much about certainty of execution. There are some schools to be built there on that site as well as the project we would own and -- by dealing with and selecting us, they don't have to deal with a private developer who's going to have a separate equity partner or separate lender, separate general contractor. It's an integrated solution. So we have -- we like those deals. That particular deal, it's a pretty exciting location, 96th Street and Second Avenue. It's a full city block. It's right on top of the new Second Avenue subway line, which is, I think, the first new line in the city in many, many, many years. And the timing on that one is such that given the approvals process that's in front of us the regulatory process, that deal actually may well start kind of early into the next cycle, which is based on some of the slides that Tim mentioned before, frequently deals that have very strong returns.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if there are any updates for your upper west side New York development in terms of a retail component?
componenttext: And if there are any updates for your upper west side New York development in terms of a retail component?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jana, this is Tim. I think you're referring to the Columbus Circle site that we own. Currently, we actually are doing some work on the site. We're doing some enabling work in terms of abatement and demolition. I think as we mentioned before, we still anti
componenttext: Jana, this is Tim. I think you're referring to the Columbus Circle site that we own. Currently, we actually are doing some work on the site. We're doing some enabling work in terms of abatement and demolition. I think as we mentioned before, we still anticipate starting the deal some time mid this year, probably sometime in Q3, late Q3. We are continuing to evaluate different strategies, layoff some risks there, including one way that you mentioned by bringing in a retail partner. We still have people registered despite some softness on the condos side. Some people registered in wholesaling some of the building for residential condo as well. The reality is we've been spending time really trying to nail down performance obligations for both sides, and it's ultimately got to work, ultimately for there to be a deal because to the extent we bring in a retail partner, they would essentially be taking title at the time at which we can deliver a cold dark shelf to them. And we want to make sure they're going to be there, and they're going to want to make sure that we can meet certain performance obligations. And until in effect we're almost ready to start the building, the vertical building construction, we're not going to really be in a position to finalize the deal there. Another strategy -- I mean, in part given the East 96th Street site, we are considering potentially in bringing a financial partner to lay off some -- as another way to lay off some risk. The deal that Matt just talked about, it's a large deal, which is over $500 million, excluding the land lease itself, and so and as we think about New York City concentration we may look at either joint venture in Columbus circle or potentially even other avenues to lay off some of the concentration risk in a pretty short investment time period in the city. So just stay tuned. We are exploring a number of sort of risk management strategies with respect to this deal and their overall portfolio there, and we'll keep you people informed as it makes most sense.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Gaurav Mehta with Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: We'll go next to Gaurav Mehta with Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Following up on New York. You cited supply as one of the reasons for softness in the market. I was wondering if you could also comment on what you're seeing on a demand side.
componenttext: Following up on New York. You cited supply as one of the reasons for softness in the market. I was wondering if you could also comment on what you're seeing on a demand side.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Gaurav. This is Sean. I mean, you think about it in New York, for the most part, we do think it is a supply issue. It's about -- our expectation for this year is about 2% of inventory, but in New York city proper, it's about 3.5% direct supply. And
componenttext: Sure, Gaurav. This is Sean. I mean, you think about it in New York, for the most part, we do think it is a supply issue. It's about -- our expectation for this year is about 2% of inventory, but in New York city proper, it's about 3.5% direct supply. And then if you toss in some shadow supply from condos and things like that, that number might be a little bit higher. The demand side, demand has actually been pretty healthy. Job growth has been steady across the region, and in the, I think, mid-1% range. It's been up in the mid-2s in terms of the city itself. So demand has been there. But what you have to keep in mind related to the supply is it's all coming in at the pretty high end, for the most part. And if you think about New York City and even parts of Northern New Jersey, what's going to be delivered this year is about 10,000 units. So there's plenty of demand. The demand might not look the same as what it has in last cycles in terms of the percentage from the financial sector a very, very high paying levels. So there is probably more diversity of the job growth than what we've experienced in the past. But there has been steady absorption and steady demand in that market.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, and then following up on suburban versus urban that chart number -- Slide #7 that you have in your presentation suburban outperforming urban. But if I look at your New York suburban portfolio it -- by rent growth is underperforming the urban market
componenttext: Great, and then following up on suburban versus urban that chart number -- Slide #7 that you have in your presentation suburban outperforming urban. But if I look at your New York suburban portfolio it -- by rent growth is underperforming the urban market. So I was wondering if you could provide more details as to what's going on in New York suburban.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So in terms of New York, one thing to keep in mind there is the suburban submarkets in the Northeast in general, including New York and then moving up into New England, are more seasonal. So you tend to see more softness in late Q4 and Q1 in the subu
componenttext: Yes. So in terms of New York, one thing to keep in mind there is the suburban submarkets in the Northeast in general, including New York and then moving up into New England, are more seasonal. So you tend to see more softness in late Q4 and Q1 in the suburban submarkets. So that's not a surprise to us in terms of where we ended the first quarter as well as the fourth quarter. But as you look forward and the impact on supply to give you a sense where it's headed, for our portfolio, if you look at renewal offers as we move in through the second quarter, they're in the low 5% range. The weakest is New York City at about 4%. But Long Island is at 6%, Northern New Jersey is at 7%, Central New Jersey is 5.5%. So we do expect those suburban submarkets to pick up steam as we move through the second and third quarter relative to New York City, purely just as a function of supply for the most part. So we expect it'll play out that way in New York overall based on what we know today.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Jordan Sadler with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll go next to Jordan Sadler with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Austin Wurschmidt here with Jordan. Just sticking with New York a little bit, could you provide a little bit of color on what you're seeing at your AVA DoBro project in terms of lease-up pace relative to the expectations as well as the rents you're a
componenttext: It's Austin Wurschmidt here with Jordan. Just sticking with New York a little bit, could you provide a little bit of color on what you're seeing at your AVA DoBro project in terms of lease-up pace relative to the expectations as well as the rents you're achieving there?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. It's Sean again. Yes, lease-up volume has been quite good there. We average 39 a month through the quarter, which is quite healthy considering it tends to be one of the lower volume quarters of the year. It typically ramps up in the second quarter a
componenttext: Sure. It's Sean again. Yes, lease-up volume has been quite good there. We average 39 a month through the quarter, which is quite healthy considering it tends to be one of the lower volume quarters of the year. It typically ramps up in the second quarter and third quarter. There is some supply being delivered in that submarket now. There'll be a little bit more as we get further into the year, but velocity and rate have both been quite healthy. So rates holding a little bit above what we expected, around $60 a foot, and velocity has been good. So our expectation is for that to continue. The DoBro product is pretty unique product. It's been accepted quite well by the target demographic, and so we're pleased with the early results.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Austin, this is Matt. Just to clarify a little bit, we have marked the AVA DoBro piece of that to market, and that's the number that you see updated in the earnings release because the Avalon piece, which is the upper floors of the building, we have n
componenttext: And Austin, this is Matt. Just to clarify a little bit, we have marked the AVA DoBro piece of that to market, and that's the number that you see updated in the earnings release because the Avalon piece, which is the upper floors of the building, we have not yet started to lease there. Those rents are not yet mark to market.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And what percent in the units there are part of the AVA DoBro?
componenttext: And what percent in the units there are part of the AVA DoBro?

componenttextpreview: I think it's about 300 Avalon and 500 AVA?
componenttext: I think it's about 300 Avalon and 500 AVA?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so 500. So 5 8 -- 60% or so is AVA.
componenttext: Yes, so 500. So 5 8 -- 60% or so is AVA.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. That's helpful. And then just more sticking on the New York City submarket specifically despite the supply during sort of the typically slower season, occupancy was up 50 basis points during the quarter, and I was just curious what was driving that
componenttext: Great. That's helpful. And then just more sticking on the New York City submarket specifically despite the supply during sort of the typically slower season, occupancy was up 50 basis points during the quarter, and I was just curious what was driving that if it was tactical and just some detail there.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean as you might know from previous commentary for us, we don't necessarily target a very specific rate of occupancy for each and every market and submarket. Our objective is to optimize revenue, and so sometimes you're going to get back occupancy
componenttext: Yes, I mean as you might know from previous commentary for us, we don't necessarily target a very specific rate of occupancy for each and every market and submarket. Our objective is to optimize revenue, and so sometimes you're going to get back occupancy to get rate and/or vice versa to try and optimize revenues. So I wouldn't read too much into occupancy changes from quarter-to-quarter or even year-over-year. The only global statement I'd say is over the last couple of years given market conditions, we're more aggressive on rate, all things being equal, at the expense of occupancy across our footprint. And every submarket is a little bit different, but I wouldn't read too much into the sequential quarter or even the year-over-year numbers other than the trend over the last couple of years being more aggressive on the rate side and yielding a little bit more on occupancy has been okay.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then just switching, and last one for me to the portfolio management comments. I guess, what are you guys really trying to accomplish as you see acquisitions come to market? And where exactly are you seeing the best opportunities?
componenttext: That's helpful. And then just switching, and last one for me to the portfolio management comments. I guess, what are you guys really trying to accomplish as you see acquisitions come to market? And where exactly are you seeing the best opportunities?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, maybe I'll start and then ask Matt to follow up in terms of where we're seeing the best opportunities. There's just lot of transaction volume right now, and there's a lot of really, as I mentioned in my prepared remarks, a lot of really fine assets o
componenttext: Yes, maybe I'll start and then ask Matt to follow up in terms of where we're seeing the best opportunities. There's just lot of transaction volume right now, and there's a lot of really, as I mentioned in my prepared remarks, a lot of really fine assets oftentimes built by the merchant builders coming off construction loans, so they don't have permanent loans in place that have hefty prepayment penalties, and therefore sometimes sort of doesn't make it attractive for us in terms of assuming secured debt. So it's an opportunity to take advantage of the fact we have a lot of unencumbered assets, some of which are noncore that we like to trade, and there's a point in time in which there's some really attractive assets that we think we can improve the overall quality of the portfolio by turning a little bit of it. So it's a little bit of a unique moment in time, we think. But in terms of -- Matt, in terms of where we're seeing some of the best opportunities, maybe you can just elaborate a little bit there.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I guess, I'd start by saying on the macro level regionally, the 2 regions where we would seek to redeploy capital the most would be the Mid-Atlantic and Southern California for different reasons, but those were actually kind of more or less on targe
componenttext: Sure. I guess, I'd start by saying on the macro level regionally, the 2 regions where we would seek to redeploy capital the most would be the Mid-Atlantic and Southern California for different reasons, but those were actually kind of more or less on target for our long-term portfolio, geographical allocation goals, but if we're under underallocated anywhere, it's probably in those 2 regions. And some of that was, frankly, deliberate. In the case of Mid-Atlantic we sold quite a bit here earlier in this cycle kind of in front of what we saw is lot of supply coming relative to the Mid-Atlantic's history. So we think it's a pretty good time to be buying in the Mid-Atlantic. Values haven't increased all that much relative to all of the other geographies in our portfolio, which makes sense because obviously, rents have been relatively flat here for quite a while. So we see just better value in terms of just total relative to replacement cost, relative to cost per foot, cost per unit. And Southern Cal, it's always difficult there. Archstone really was a transformative event for us in terms of growing our Southern California portfolio, but we're still looking to grow there, where we can. In terms of submarket locations, we are looking to upgrade the quality of the portfolio a little bit as Tim mention. So you look at the 3 that we mentioned so far, they are all infill, high-quality, high density infill suburbs we would look in the urban cores as well based on pricing where we see the best relative value, but higher walk scores. And then we have been looking at younger assets, which is a little different for us. We do find sometimes we're a very successful buyer for assets that maybe somebody else has just renovated, 12-, 15-year-old assets, where the value-add players aren't going to bid those up to the same extent. So we look at those types of assets too, but -- and arguably mark your comment fits that description a little bit, but we're always looking for ways where if we can leverage what advantages we have into sometimes its unique deal structure that may drive us to get a little bit better value on the buy-side. But typically we would probably be looking for assets that are a little bit younger than what you may have seen us buying in the past. And again...

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Jeffrey Pehl with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll go next to Jeffrey Pehl with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just looking back at the Archstone acquisition in late 2012, the largest component of the purchase was in Southern California. How do you believe those assets are performing today versus your original expectations?
componenttext: Just looking back at the Archstone acquisition in late 2012, the largest component of the purchase was in Southern California. How do you believe those assets are performing today versus your original expectations?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeff, it's Sean Breslin. In terms of overall performance, I think it's fair to say that the assets have outperformed our expectations in terms of a period of ownership here. And then on top of that, the other thing I would add is there's probably mor
componenttext: Yes, Jeff, it's Sean Breslin. In terms of overall performance, I think it's fair to say that the assets have outperformed our expectations in terms of a period of ownership here. And then on top of that, the other thing I would add is there's probably more opportunity in the portfolio in terms of redevelopment, repositioning those assets than we probably expected going in. Archstone did a fine job maintaining the assets, but given the balance sheet they had and the position they were tied into with Lehman, just didn't necessarily have the capital to invest in the assets to reposition them. So we're trying to take advantage of that opportunity across the footprint, including significant concentration that we did acquire in Southern California. So net-net, I'd say we're pleased with our results from Archstone, and values have grown considerably during the last couple of years.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just as a follow-up to that, do you believe your Southern California portfolio could potentially outperform Northern California over the next few years?
componenttext: And just as a follow-up to that, do you believe your Southern California portfolio could potentially outperform Northern California over the next few years?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Sean again. I mean it's always a possibility given underlying demand drivers in Southern California combined with the very low levels of supply, the lowest of any of our regions currently in terms of our expectation sort of in the mid-1% range, it's
componenttext: It's Sean again. I mean it's always a possibility given underlying demand drivers in Southern California combined with the very low levels of supply, the lowest of any of our regions currently in terms of our expectation sort of in the mid-1% range, it's a possibility. It tends to be a market that over the long run has been an outperformer with far less volatility than some of the tech markets like Northern California and Seattle. So it could certainly be a period of time where it does outperform that would not be on reason, be beyond reason.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: We'll go next to Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just first, you mentioned in some prior questions ago about the bank regulation on lending. As you guys have seen it so far in the banks be impacted by the Basel III coming down on construction lending, has your experience what you've seen in the field, h
componenttext: Just first, you mentioned in some prior questions ago about the bank regulation on lending. As you guys have seen it so far in the banks be impacted by the Basel III coming down on construction lending, has your experience what you've seen in the field, has it been a material cut back on the part of developers and their inability to get construction lending? Or is this really sort of an issue on the edges and most developers that you see in the market are still able to get construction lending as they historically have been able to?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alex, this is Sean. Maybe Tim or Matt want to jump in. I mean at this point, we're aware of what's been communicated to the banks, and some of the risk retention issues as well as the incremental oversight of multifamily loans. For the most part, what we'
componenttext: Alex, this is Sean. Maybe Tim or Matt want to jump in. I mean at this point, we're aware of what's been communicated to the banks, and some of the risk retention issues as well as the incremental oversight of multifamily loans. For the most part, what we're hear anyhow is somewhat anecdotal in terms of more pressure on the underwriting banks putting out targets that are, I'd say, either even or less than volume they produced last year in terms of construction lending for multifamily specifically. So I'd say it's still early in the game as to the eventual outcome, but there are certain signs of tightening that will put more pressure on bring in either additional equity to the table to get deals done probably is the likely answer, but different pricing as well, and Kevin may want to comment on that as well from a bank perspective.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, sure, Alex. I mean as you know, we're not directly in the market, but from what we've been able to learn from being active in our dialogue with banks who do this kind of construction financing and certainly what we have heard is that construction
componenttext: I mean, sure, Alex. I mean as you know, we're not directly in the market, but from what we've been able to learn from being active in our dialogue with banks who do this kind of construction financing and certainly what we have heard is that construction financing has become tough to obtain as you point out, especially for small as well as capitalized developers. Pricing, for example, has moved beyond 300 bps over LIBOR. In order to get better terms, often these developers are needing to provide partial recourse and sometimes make a commitment to provide permanent financing to the bank post construction, and sometimes provide higher levels of deposits. So across the board, there's just been a little bit of tightening that we've seen in that end market.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would just -- maybe the last point on this. I think the way it sort of initially manifest itself you start to see a little more deal flow on the land side. So as private sponsors are maybe not getting the terms or hearing what they want to hear fro
componenttext: Yes, I would just -- maybe the last point on this. I think the way it sort of initially manifest itself you start to see a little more deal flow on the land side. So as private sponsors are maybe not getting the terms or hearing what they want to hear from banks or even potentially new equity partners. Those deals sort of get sort of softly marketed back in the market, and we're seeing that right now on some -- on a couple of particularly attractive opportunities, where the landowner thought that they're going to develop it themselves, and suddenly they're spinning a different story to the market that they've got a lot in their plate, they need to sell some what they got. So I think that's the way you'll likely to see it manifest or at least initially here over the next 3 to 6 months, but I think we'll probably just hope -- kind of have to keep a watch out and see is it really having an impact at the end of the day on total start volume.

componenttext: Okay. And on the condo side on the Sheepshead Bay project, where you have a condo partner in there, what's the -- can you just given all the uptalk about condo concern in New York, can you just as far as the financial risk to AvalonBay, if the entity doesn't perform, I assume you guys just automatically take over their spot? Or is there some financial liability to you if they run into some financial difficulty on their own?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alex, this is Matt. I guess, I can take a shot at that one. And I don't know if Tim wants to chime in as well. They have equity in the deal, we are providing construction financing really to facilitate the deal because we're building the whole building. A
componenttext: Alex, this is Matt. I guess, I can take a shot at that one. And I don't know if Tim wants to chime in as well. They have equity in the deal, we are providing construction financing really to facilitate the deal because we're building the whole building. And so if they were to default on the loan, they would walk away from their equity, and we would wind up with their units, and we -- there's some guarantee support as well. Although I don't remember exactly how deep that goes, and we have looked at that as a downside scenario. We could take their units back and rent them, and we don't think it would be a material change to the economics of that deal. I will also say that it's a very different location. There's no -- you talk about there's a lot of condo supply in New York. It's not in Sheepshead Bay. It's not in Brighton Beach. It's not in that part of Brooklyn at also. So that market is in turn little micro pocket there that I really think is hardly at all impacted by what's going on across the city.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sean, can you talk a little bit about the -- what you're seeing in your various D.C. submarkets performance wise, stronger versus weaker and what's likely to be the trend over the remainder of the year as leasing continues?
componenttext: Sean, can you talk a little bit about the -- what you're seeing in your various D.C. submarkets performance wise, stronger versus weaker and what's likely to be the trend over the remainder of the year as leasing continues?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure Rob, happy to. In terms of the Mid-Atlantic, based on where we are today in terms of performance, and I'll talk mainly from a rent change perspective in terms of where we're getting traction, D.C. is actually holding up the best right at the mom
componenttext: Yes, sure Rob, happy to. In terms of the Mid-Atlantic, based on where we are today in terms of performance, and I'll talk mainly from a rent change perspective in terms of where we're getting traction, D.C. is actually holding up the best right at the moment, kind of mid-2% range versus, say 1.5% or so for suburban Maryland and Northern Virginia. That's up roughly about 75 basis points over last year. I mean, our expectation going forward is that it's probably going to continue to be the softest in the suburban Maryland submarket based on the supply that's being delivered across Rockville and North Bethesda, et cetera, Northern Virginia, probably will be sort of second position, if you want to call it, in terms of performance, and then D.C. based on asset mix that we have, we think will probably be the leading submarket in terms of performance. And keep in mind, what's in our same-store bucket is Northwest, some value-oriented assets, a deal tied to American university, et cetera. So it's a very different kind of same-store math relative to many others. The majority of the supply is actually going to be delivered in the district. So if you looked at it from an entire market perspective, D.C. probably will continue to be soft and potentially as soft as suburban Maryland, but in terms of our specific portfolio and the way it's positioned, the D.C. assets are leading and probably will continue to.

componenttext: Yes, I mean, I wouldn't say so. I mean, if I think about it like from New York perspective, the highest rent deal we have is in the barrier at $85 per foot or so, and it's performing quite well. There's very little supply there that could beat again, so I think for the most part, it really does depend on where your assets are positioned relative to new supply. So we've got $50, $60 a foot assets in Midtown West, more value-oriented, but there's more supply there. So they're struggling more as an example. But then you go to Long Island City and it's $50 a foot, $55 a foot, and it's doing 6% year-over-year, and so I wouldn't say there's a common threat to higher-end units underperforming across any of the markets at this point in time, it's really more a direct function of supply in the submarket that you're in.

componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, Rich, this is Sean. It's certainly picking up steam a little bit. I mean, if you look at the region overall, rent change in the first quarter is about 2%, which was 1% in New York City, about 4% in Long Island and 2.5% to 3.5% in New Jersey m
componenttext: Yes, I mean, Rich, this is Sean. It's certainly picking up steam a little bit. I mean, if you look at the region overall, rent change in the first quarter is about 2%, which was 1% in New York City, about 4% in Long Island and 2.5% to 3.5% in New Jersey markets. It has picked up steam a little bit, where we are doing around 3% now instead of 2%, which is around low 4s on renewables and 1%, 1.5% on move-ins. But as I mentioned earlier, when you look at renewals, I'd say they started to pick up a little more speed, particularly in the suburban submarkets. As I mentioned, New York City so it gets around 4%, but it moves up quite nicely when you get into the suburban submarkets 5.5%, 6%, 7% depending on where you are. So I'd say the momentum is positive, probably most positive in the suburban submarkets as compared to the city.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Rich, this is Matt. Yes, no. We are planning on doing some of our disposition acquisition activity at 1031 exchanges. But I wouldn't say that we have tax protection issues beyond the fact that we can only sell so much without redeploying the proceeds into acquisitions or paying special dividend. So I mean, we have an overall company limit on that volume, but I don't know...

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, this is Kevin. To add on that, I mean we tend, as you know, to use dispositions as a means of funding development activity, and that certainly is our plan this year. The component of our external capital that we raised, fund development will be in t
componenttext: Rich, this is Kevin. To add on that, I mean we tend, as you know, to use dispositions as a means of funding development activity, and that certainly is our plan this year. The component of our external capital that we raised, fund development will be in the form of dispositions at some level beyond a certain point when we sell additional assets and trigger additional gains, and you can see some very robust gains here reflected in what we sold so far. You do run into a situation where from a retax point of view, we would need to make special distribution and would have retained that capital. So if we want to buy assets to reposition the portfolio and fund that with dispositions beyond what we would needs to self-fund development, then it's at some point, it just makes sense to do that incremental portfolio repositioning through 1031 activity.

componenttext: As it relates to our portfolio and your concentration is more suburban as well as Class B, and you think about the inventories how tight they are for resale and the benefit that your tenants may not be able to find something either they want to move out or afford it or get mortgage financing and some of the challenges, how do you think about going forward some of the dynamics that incrementally on the floor sale side that might loosen up or more inventory will come, and which markets are you going to be the most vulnerable or may see more pressure for move out to buy within your footprint? Just first question, then I have to come up with a follow-up.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ivy, just on general commentary on that trend maybe. I mean, move out to home purchases have remained -- has remained well below historical averages for essentially this entire cycle. It's only 11% this quarter as an example, which is down about 150 basis
componenttext: Ivy, just on general commentary on that trend maybe. I mean, move out to home purchases have remained -- has remained well below historical averages for essentially this entire cycle. It's only 11% this quarter as an example, which is down about 150 basis points year-over-year, and typically we're probably both sensitive to it in terms of either existing assets or new opportunities is in those markets, where home prices are somewhat more affordable, which would typically be Seattle and the Mid-Atlantic, maybe a little bit in Central Jersey. And based on everything that we see, production has certainly started to increase some, but it remains well below just sort of structural demand given the level of household formations you expected, which you know probably better than all of us. So in terms of near-term pressure, I don't think that's likely to be a real issue for us based on what we know today.

componenttext: No, it does move around by market. As I mentioned, those 2 markets, Mid-Atlantic and Seattle and then New England tend to be at the higher end of the range as compared to New York, Southern Cal, Northern Cal, very expensive markets, tends to be quite low. The only market that basically was at its long-term average from one point last year was New England, which was around 20%, 21%, it stripped it down since that time. So at this point, every market is running well below its long-term average.

And if I may ask one more follow-up as it relates to supply in the markets where you see new better position that you're not in the New York sort of tougher areas where are the supply is being delivered. What historically has the trickle-down effect been into Class B assets, where you're seeing rents under pressure or more concessions being offered in Class A? Can you go back historically and look at what the impact has been, if any in the Class B suburban or within the urban Class B?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ivy, this is Tim. Yes, certainly wherever there's any supply introduced into a market it's going to have some impact on all rental housing, and I sort of think of it as sort of concentric circles, if you will. So the stuff that's new, more recently delive
componenttext: Ivy, this is Tim. Yes, certainly wherever there's any supply introduced into a market it's going to have some impact on all rental housing, and I sort of think of it as sort of concentric circles, if you will. So the stuff that's new, more recently delivered is kind of right in bull's eye. And as you kind of go down the price, the price ladder, there are obviously, less impacted. And I mean, I think right now in our portfolio we're seeing just to give you an example, I think we're seeing Class B roughly outperforming Class A by over 100 basis points, 150 basis points in terms of rent growth. So -- and there's a -- it's probably more significant even in submarkets that are experiencing a lot of supply.

componenttext: I was hoping to take the discussion of the Bay Area a little deeper and talk about specific towns, specific areas on what are the urban, suburban Class A versus Class B? And can you talk about which areas are most impacted by new supply, and which areas are most impacted by any marginal slackening of demand?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure Drew, this is Sean. First maybe to set some context for Northern California when we provided guidance earlier this year, and Tim alluded to it on today's prepared remarks for the call as well. We did have an expectation that given the increase i
componenttext: Yes, sure Drew, this is Sean. First maybe to set some context for Northern California when we provided guidance earlier this year, and Tim alluded to it on today's prepared remarks for the call as well. We did have an expectation that given the increase in supply across the region, which is basically around 3% today as compared to 1.5% last year combined with a somewhat softening in demand, if you remember at this point, last year, job growth across the Bay Area was running around 4%, a pretty blistering pace as compared to about 2% today that we would see softening in performance throughout the year and that's pretty much on track. As I mentioned earlier, we're basically are budget in that market. In terms of the performance of the specific submarkets, where you're seeing stronger or weaker results what I'd say is in general, more value-oriented assets are outperforming the higher-end assets across the footprint. The footprint being the Bay Area region overall. In terms of specific submarkets, San Francisco, the supply is pretty much Mission Bay kind of the SoMa submarket right there. That tends to be a little bit weaker right now. Our assets is value-oriented assets Daly City, Pacifica, [indiscernible] they're all outperforming versus the higher-end day assets Mission Bay and SoMa is underperforming. San Jose that supplies Northeast San Jose a little bit of San Jose and then stretches up really into Mountain View as well in terms of supply. And then on the East Bay, there's not a whole lot of supply really in the East Bay, you have a little bit in Dublin and Pleasanton and some product coming online up towards public market Berkeley in that area, but it's de minimis relative to what you're seeing in San Francisco and San Jose. So hopefully that provides some context for where the supplies coming online.

componenttextpreview: Sure, Tayo, this is Kevin. As you may recall, we sort of we do not provide updated guidance for the full year on our first quarter call. We provide initial outlook, obviously for our fourth quarter call in January, and then we provide a fulsome midyear up
componenttext: Sure, Tayo, this is Kevin. As you may recall, we sort of we do not provide updated guidance for the full year on our first quarter call. We provide initial outlook, obviously for our fourth quarter call in January, and then we provide a fulsome midyear update after our intentionally our second quarter call. So that's the plan. So we don't have a further update, particularly given that we've got the leasing season in front of us, and we are only a few months from having done a full budget. So no new news on that front. This was the first quarter that we provided guidance on second quarter, and as you can see from our release, at this point of our guidance for NAREIT FFO is $2.10 per share and for core FFO is $2 per share. So that's -- and then in terms of what we did in the first quarter as you know from our release, we beat our initial expectation by $0.06, which is probably the largest beat on our expectations in a quarterly basis in recent memory. So quite strong performance, it was about probably $0.04 of that $0.06 beat likely to be permanent and $0.02 likely to reverse at some point over the course of the year.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Conor, this is Kevin. I guess essentially what you're asking for is what's our net disposition activity. We don't provide that level of guidance, because essentially that would be, as you recall when we provided our outlook for 2016, we indicated that
componenttext: So Conor, this is Kevin. I guess essentially what you're asking for is what's our net disposition activity. We don't provide that level of guidance, because essentially that would be, as you recall when we provided our outlook for 2016, we indicated that we anticipated sourcing external capital of about $1.1 billion. At the time we indicated that, that would likely come through unsecured debt an asset sales with unsecured debt hopefully and likely comprising the majority of that $1.1 billion. So really, it's the $1.1 billion less whatever we do in unsecured debt that would represent the net disposition activity, but it certainly represents a minority of that $1.1 billion. In terms of what we've done so far, as you can see, essentially, the acquisitions that we completed in the first quarter were basically funded through fund in wholly-owned asset sales and the assumed debt in Hoboken. So going forward, for the balance of the year, we expect that just sort of still about $1.1 billion, and again the expectation is predominantly in the form of unsecured debt with the balance through net disposition activity.

componenttext: Conor, it's Matt. Actually, we've been working on that deal for 3 years already. So I would say it's indicative in the sense that we've said for a while now that doing straight up land deals in New York is very, very difficult at today's economics. So if we were to source new opportunities, it would be more likely be deals like this, but I wouldn't say that this -- we are generally in the market for these types of opportunities. They're infrequent, and they are complex, and they tend to take a lot of time to get done, but there are opportunities that we see -- we saw throughout different points in the cycle over the years.

componenttext: Greg, this is Kevin. Just to be clear, we're not providing guidance for that set of comments. So that's an example, but the other $0.01 was related to redevelopment OpEx, which was largely due to slight delays in start of some renovation programs that we expect to start, so that will probably reverse ratably over the course of the next 3 quarters.

A lot of people are looking to buy property right now.

componenttext: Okay, great. And then last one here. headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, it's Sean. Rent income ratios are still running around 22%. It's been that way for a couple of years now, and it's at the higher end of the range from an historical perspective, but has remained relatively constant. So one thing we have said is that
componenttext: Greg, it's Sean. Rent income ratios are still running around 22%. It's been that way for a couple of years now, and it's at the higher end of the range from an historical perspective, but has remained relatively constant. So one thing we have said is that we continue to expect wage growth to help support rent growth going forward, and we've seen that so far beating last year in particular and our expectation for this year. So overall, I think we're in pretty good shape. In terms of move outs due to rent increases, it's down about 100 basis points last year. Some markets were down than others, but in general comfortable with where we are.

componenttext: Yes, Wes, this is Sean. First, in terms of commentary about traffic, one thing to be cautious about on traffic is we sort of influence that number as well depending on our level of availability. We may be driving the marketing harder or softer to generate traffic. So it is a bit of a manufactured number in terms of it's based on not only organic demand, but how much of that demand we're trying to capture. In terms of overall traffic though, it was up about 3% as I recall year-over-year in the first quarter. And if you looked at sort of per available apartment home, I think it was down about 100 basis points. So not a significant movement one way or another, and I would just be careful about how you think about using that information as well.

componenttextpreview: This is Matt. I guess, in terms of -- I think a lot of them are deals that probably are more well-suited to our competitive advantages than others, not necessarily because of it's complexity. A lot of those are deals in New Jersey, where we have an abilit
componenttext: This is Matt. I guess, in terms of -- I think a lot of them are deals that probably are more well-suited to our competitive advantages than others, not necessarily because of it's complexity. A lot of those are deals in New Jersey, where we have an ability to crack entitlements that a lot of others don't, for example. So they all have a different story in suburban Boston, too, where we have an incredibly deep franchise that's been moving that for years. So a lot of them are those types of deals. We do have a couple of deals, which are mixed-use deals in our pipeline, including one that we expect to start here later this year in Northern California in Emeryville, which also we think plays to our strengths not dissimilar to the deal we did within here in Northern Virginia assembly rail up in Boston, which we did with federal. So we have a few deals like that in the pipeline, but it's really -- it's pretty diverse. It's diverse by region. It's diverse by deal type. They all have different reasons why kind of -- from an economic point of view we thought that we had some kind of an advantage there.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
