componenttext: Yes, Wes, this is Sean. First, in terms of commentary about traffic, one thing to be cautious about on traffic is we sort of influence that number as well depending on our level of availability. We may be driving the marketing harder or softer to generate traffic. So it is a bit of a manufactured number in terms of it's based on not only organic demand, but how much of that demand we're trying to capture. In terms of overall traffic though, it was up about 3% as I recall year-over-year in the first quarter. And if you looked at sort of per available apartment home, I think it was down about 100 basis points. So not a significant movement one way or another, and I would just be careful about how you think about using that information as well.

componenttext: This is Matt. I guess, in terms of -- I think a lot of them are deals that probably are more well suited to our competitive advantages than others, not necessarily because of its complexity. A lot of those are deals in New Jersey, where we have an ability to crack entitlements that a lot of others don't, for example. So they all have a different story in suburban Boston, too, where we have an incredibly deep franchise that's been moving that for years. So a lot of them are those types of deals. We do have a couple of deals, which are mixed-use deals in our pipeline, including one that we expect to start here later this year in Northern California in Emeryville, which also we think plays to our strengths not dissimilar to the deal we did within here in Northern Virginia, Assembly Rail up in Boston, which we did with federal. So we have a few deals like that in the pipeline, but it's really -- it's pretty diverse. It's diverse by region. It's diverse by deal type. They all have different reasons why kind of -- from an economic point of view we thought that we had some kind of an advantage there.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Avalonbay Communities Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Your host for today's conference call is Mr. Jason Reilley, Senior Director of Investor Relations. Mr. Reill
componenttext: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Avalonbay Communities Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Your host for today's conference call is Mr. Jason Reilley, Senior Director of Investor Relations. Mr. Reilley, you may begin your conference.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Augusta, and welcome to Avalonbay Communities second quarter 2016 earnings conference call. Before we begin, please note that forward-looking statements may be made during this discussion. There are a variety of risks and uncertainties associat
componenttext:
Thank you, Augusta, and welcome to Avalonbay Communities second quarter 2016 earnings conference call. Before we begin, please note that forward-looking statements may be made during this discussion. There are a variety of risks and uncertainties associated with forward-looking statements, and actual results may differ materially. There's a discussion of these risks and uncertainties in yesterday afternoon's press release as well as in the company's Form 10-K and Form 10-Q filed with the SEC. 
As usual, this press release does include an attachment with definitions and reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures and other terms which may be used in today's discussion. The attachment is also available on our website at www.avalonbay.com/earnings, and we encourage you to refer to this information during the review of our operating results and financial performance. 
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Tim Naughton, Chairman and CEO of Avalonbay Communities for his remarks. Tim?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Jason, and welcome to our second quarter call. With me today is Kevin O'Shea, Sean Breslin and Matt Birenbaum. I'll provide commentary on the slides that we posted last night, then all of us will be available for Q&A afterwards. My comments
componenttext:
Yes. Thanks, Jason, and welcome to our second quarter call. With me today is Kevin O'Shea, Sean Breslin and Matt Birenbaum. I'll provide commentary on the slides that we posted last night, then all of us will be available for Q&A afterwards. 
My comments will focus on providing a summary of Q2 and year-to-date results, our revised midyear outlook for 2016, our view regarding the trajectory and durability of the current apartment cycle and, lastly, a look at how current development activity is contributing to our earnings growth. 
So starting on Slide 4. It was a solid quarter, where we achieved core FFO growth greater than 8.5% from a combination of healthy same-store revenue and NOI growth of 5% and contributions from new lease-ups as we completed almost $200 million at a projected yield of just under 7%. Year-to-date core FFO is up over 10%, again driven by a combination of internal growth from the stabilized portfolio and external growth from stabilizing development. For the first half of the year, our same-store portfolio performs in line with budget although a bit ahead in Q1 and a little behind in Q2. I'll discuss this trend a little more in a couple of minutes. 
Turning to Slide 5 and our  updated outlook for the year. In short, overall expectations for core FFO are in line with our original outlook, which call for core FFO growth of 9%. Our projection for same-store NOI growth has been trimmed by about 40 basis points or approximately $0.03 per share for the full year but is offset by contributions from other categories such as our full year outlook for core FFO remains unchanged. Our projected investment and funding activity for the year remains more or less in line with our original expectations with some minor variances. 
Turning now to Slide 6. We thought we'd provide a little more color regarding our outlook for the same-store portfolio in the second half of the year. As I mentioned earlier, we performed in line with expectations for the first half of the year, although in Q2, we did experience the -- we did not experience the seasonal strain and effective rent growth that we're accustomed to seeing. This trend appears to be largely demand-driven as economic and job growth fell short of expectations for the first half of the year, and declining business confidence in investment no doubt was a contributing factor as recent uncertainty in global events have left businesses hesitant to make new commitments. 
Turning to Slide 7. Slower economic growth impacts corporate and transient demands, which helps fuel seasonal strength in the second and third quarters for our business. The weaker corporate and transient demand affects us in 2 ways: first, a reduction in premium income, which typically runs 50% to 60% higher per lease; and secondly, an effective increase in market vacancy as, in fact, inventories are essentially added back to the market. 
Turning to Slide 8. As economic conditions have moderated over the last 2 or 3 quarters, effective rent growth in our same-store portfolio, expressed as like term rent change, has remained in the 4% range over the last 6 to 7 months. And while like term rent change did improve modestly in Q2, we did not see the same seasonal lift we've seen in prior years so far this cycle. 
And turning to Slide 9, of course, performance does vary across our regions. Effective rent growth has moderated, most notably, in Northern California and the Northeast while Seattle and the Mid-Atlantic have been trending up. Rent growth in Southern California remains healthy in the 6% range. 
Turning to Slide 10. As you might expect, these trends are impacting our outlook for portfolio performance for the year. Again, in the Northeast and Northern California has fallen short of projected budget, while in Seattle and D.C. are expected to outperform. Overall, the net impact is resulting in a reduction of same-store revenue of almost 40 basis points for the full year with all of that expect the shortfall to occur in the second half of the year. 
Now turning now to Slide 11. Just given trends in the operating environment, we thought we'd just revisit where we think we are in the cycle. We still believe that fundamentals point mostly in favor of an extended cycle much like we saw in the 1990s. As you see on this chart, consumer confidence remains on solid footing at cyclically higher levels, and young adults are doing their best in leading the way. 
Turning to Slide 12. Consumer confidence is being shaped in large part by an improved employment picture with jobless claims continuing their fall since the cycle began and job openings now outpacing hiring activities. And as you can see on Slide 13, the growing strength in the labor market seems to finally be putting pressure on wages as evidenced by recent AVP reports. And combined with reduced debt burdens and stronger balance sheet you see on Chart 2, the consumer's in good shape and getting stronger which bodes well for continued economic growth given their contribution to GDP. 
Turning to Slide 14. In addition, renter demand should continue to be supported by favorable demographics with the largest segment of millennials in the early to mid-20s still moving into their prime household formation and renting years. Obviously, demographics have been a major driver of renter demand this past cycle, and they should continue to support healthy rental demand over the next 5-plus years even if homeownerships begin to stabilize -- I'm sorry homeownership rates begin to stabilize as the leading-edge millennials begin to consider buying a home. 
Turning to Slide 15. The supply side of the equation is currently as well. Apartment deliveries are expected to beat nationally in 2016 and '17 as permitting for new projects has slowed down over the last 2 to 3 quarters from the cyclical highs in 2015. This is due in part to tightening credit for multifamily construction, which has become much more pronounced over the last couple of quarters. 
Turning to Slide 16. In addition to the apartment sector remaining in balance, the picture for the overall housing market looks positive as well. Projections for new housing production are in line with household formation over the next 4 years, but it's important to note that, first, these figures -- these supply figures ignore obsolescence or destruction of roughly 400,000 units per year, and they also assume that housing production over the next 4 years increases by 30% from its current level and roughly doubles what we've seen so far on average this cycle. 
So overall, while we may be seeing economic growth moderate a bit, we don't see any real tangible sign that the apartment or housing cycle was nearing its end. Rather, we are still seeing solid demand growth matched by what we believe is greenfield levels of new supply to meet that demand. 
Turning to Slide 17. Within this operating environment, one where demand and supply are expected to remain in balance, we believe that we are well positioned to continue to deliver outsized growth from our development platform. So far, this cycle, we've completed over $4 billion of new development and initial stabilized yields on average of around 7% are well in excess of our marginal cost of capital during this time, which has contributed to strong core FFO growth over the last few years. 
And finally turning to Slide 18. Development should continue to drive solid external growth going forward as development underway, along with non-stabilized recent completions, should generate another $200 million of NOI with less than $400 million of capital required to complete this basket of $3.3 billion of assets. With these assets projected to yield low above our marginal cost of capital, most of which has already been raised, we're positioned to deliver industry-leading external growth over the next 2 to 3 years. 
So in summary, 2016 is shaping up to be another strong year for Avalonbay, and we believe that the company is very well positioned from an investment and funding perspective to outperform going forward. 
And with that, Augusta, we'd like to open the call for questions.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to Nick Joseph with Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to Nick Joseph with Citi.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Given the more muted near-term 2016 operating outlook, does it give you any positive in terms of development starts in the back half of the year?
componenttext: Given the more muted near-term 2016 operating outlook, does it give you any positive in terms of development starts in the back half of the year?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nick, this is Tim. No not really. I mean I would try to point to the last few charts and talking about where we think we are in the cycle. We think the cycle still has been around the economic cycle and, more broadly, the housing cycle and the apartment c
componenttext: Nick, this is Tim. No not really. I mean I would try to point to the last few charts and talking about where we think we are in the cycle. We think the cycle still has been around the economic cycle and, more broadly, the housing cycle and the apartment cycle. So when we give response [ph] if we thought the cycle was maybe nearing its end, then the cost of capital was we needed in order to fund those commitments changed dramatically. But in terms of the expected yields on that basket in the communities relative to what we think we can fund them at, we think it still provides an attractive accretive growth. So at this point, I'd say no.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just in terms of markets, maybe one that's priced on the negative and one on the positive, can you talk about what you're seeing in New England and then in the Pacific Northwest?
componenttext: And then just in terms of markets, maybe one that's priced on the negative and one on the positive, can you talk about what you're seeing in New England and then in the Pacific Northwest?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, Nick. It's Sean, happy to talk about that. In terms of New England, first, it's typically more seasonal than most of our markets. And if you look at what's happened throughout the year, rent change started in the year in the mid-2% range and it
componenttext: Yes, sure, Nick. It's Sean, happy to talk about that. In terms of New England, first, it's typically more seasonal than most of our markets. And if you look at what's happened throughout the year, rent change started in the year in the mid-2% range and it's trended up to about 3.5%, but it's running well below both last year's rate of about 5% and our initial expectations. I think it's largely a result of 2 things. One is job growth, and the first 5 or 6 months of the year has been somewhat disappointing at an annualized rate of about 1.5 points relative to expectations closer to about 2% for the full year. And also the transient demand that Tim referred to has been pretty weak in Boston this year, which put downward pressure on rental rates in the late spring and the early summer. So in terms of New England, that's kind of what's happening there. And then as it relates to Seattle, Seattle, for the most part, is all about demand. And the first half of the year, job growth is running in the mid-4% range. I think most forecasters that we rely on had projected a slowdown in hiring in the Seattle market and it has not slowed down. There's still plenty of supply, about 3.5% of inventory, but the surprise has been on the demand side in terms of job growth. There's still softness in the sort of urban poor of Seattle. We don't have many assets there. We only have 2 operating assets in those submarkets. But if you move out to the north end and you moved to [indiscernible] and you move to Bellevue, revenue growth is still relatively robust. And I think the difference between Seattle and Northern California in terms of what you're seeing in performance is you really have some well-established, large well-capitalized companies driving the hiring in the tech sector in Seattle as compared to allow the small businesses to make up the greater share of employment in Northern California that are more to susceptible to changes in funding [indiscernible] the D.C. market and what's happening with IPO, valuations, et cetera. So that's really what's been helping Seattle is really the job growth.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just finally. It looks like bad debt increased. Can you talk about what drove that increase, if it was in any specific markets?
componenttext: And just finally. It looks like bad debt increased. Can you talk about what drove that increase, if it was in any specific markets?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, did you say bad debt, Nick, just so I hear you clearly?
componenttext: Yes, did you say bad debt, Nick, just so I hear you clearly?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the bad debt was up about 15 basis points year-over-year. We are seeing elevated levels of bad debt across 4 of the 6 regions. About 60% of it, though, is coming from a combination of factors in the New York region. Really 3 things that I could point
componenttext: Yes, the bad debt was up about 15 basis points year-over-year. We are seeing elevated levels of bad debt across 4 of the 6 regions. About 60% of it, though, is coming from a combination of factors in the New York region. Really 3 things that I could point to. One is the core process has slowed considerably in 2016 relative to 2015. So it's taking a lot longer to get sort of judgment, if you want to call it that. And our policy is to write things off after a certain period of time. If we collect it later, it'll be an offset but we're running things off more rapidly. And then secondly, we're just not getting the same level of judgment but what we were seeing just based on some new judgments in certain courts. And then thirdly is we did have one corporate housing provider kind of go belly up on us. There's only 15 homes that have represented a couple of months of rent. The underlying client was actually still paying, so it's sort of an anomaly in the system I guess I would say. But New York is about 60% of the total increase, so that was anticipated.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Rich Hightower [ph] with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Rich Hightower [ph] with Evercore ISI.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a quick question here on the New York, New Jersey region. It does seem that the revised projection is not meaningfully below the original projection but somewhat below. So could you break down what you're seeing in the different submarkets whether it's
componenttext: So a quick question here on the New York, New Jersey region. It does seem that the revised projection is not meaningfully below the original projection but somewhat below. So could you break down what you're seeing in the different submarkets whether it's in Manhattan, Brooklyn or even the outlying suburbs and just where you're seeing pockets of strength and weakness on either the supply or demand side there?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Rich, this is Sean again, happy to do so. First, overall, for our New York, New Jersey, just to give you a sense of how it strengthened throughout the years across the portfolio, rent change increased from about 1.5% in Q1 to roughly 3% for Q2. And
componenttext: Sure, Rich, this is Sean again, happy to do so. First, overall, for our New York, New Jersey, just to give you a sense of how it strengthened throughout the years across the portfolio, rent change increased from about 1.5% in Q1 to roughly 3% for Q2. And while we've had good progress on renewal rent change, which is in the low 4% range, it moved in. Rent change remains pretty stubbornly low at around 1.5 points. It hasn't really improved much through the second quarter or into July. And I think what you're seeing there, particularly in New York City, which I'm including Northern New Jersey and kind of this general description of the geography at this point, is while there's been steady job growth, there's just not enough high paying jobs being created to absorb all the new supply. It's all being delivered at the high end of the market. And if you look at the performance, particularly recent performance of the suburban markets in and around New York are performing better than the City. we're seeing rent growth in New York City to sort of in the mid-2% range. But as you move into Long Island and Northern and Central New Jersey, we get up to the 3%, 4% even 5% in Central Jersey over the last quarter. So in general, I'd say the supply is weighing most heavily on the New York City market so including the boroughs and Northern New Jersey and we're seeing better performance on our suburban submarkets.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, Sean, that's helpful. And then one also final question on property tax increases. I know that they were around [ph] 9% for the quarter. I guess if you could pinpoint this, when can we expect that trend to sort of taper off a little bit? Or do y
componenttext: All right, Sean, that's helpful. And then one also final question on property tax increases. I know that they were around [ph] 9% for the quarter. I guess if you could pinpoint this, when can we expect that trend to sort of taper off a little bit? Or do you think we're sort of just in for consistent mid- to high single-digit growth for a while here?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, really, the fact is the second quarter and the first half are really a reflection of prior year activity for the most part. About 2/3 of the increase in taxes relates to a supplemental assessment that were reversed last year in the second quarter. Ou
componenttext: Yes, really, the fact is the second quarter and the first half are really a reflection of prior year activity for the most part. About 2/3 of the increase in taxes relates to a supplemental assessment that were reversed last year in the second quarter. Our expectation is that by the time we get to year-end, taxes would probably be growing on a year-over-year basis in the 4% range, 3.5% to 4% range. So there's a lot of noise in there in terms of the appeal. We achieved something this quarter what we received in the same quarter last year, et cetera, sort of [indiscernible] the comps a little bit, but call it, 3.5% to 4% is the expected growth rate in taxes for calendar year '16.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

componenttext: The go next to Dennis McGill with Zelman & Associates.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, was hoping it looked like turnover for the whole portfolio is up a little bit. Hoping you could put a little color behind the markets, if you're seeing any markets vary materially from that trend.
componenttext: First question, was hoping it looked like turnover for the whole portfolio is up a little bit. Hoping you could put a little color behind the markets, if you're seeing any markets vary materially from that trend.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean if you look at it, it's a little bit of around -- I would say basically it's 61% this year and last year in the same quarter. And if you look at turnover as a percentage of expiration because expirations do move around a little bit, turnover
componenttext: Sure. I mean if you look at it, it's a little bit of around -- I would say basically it's 61% this year and last year in the same quarter. And if you look at turnover as a percentage of expiration because expirations do move around a little bit, turnover was actually down around 100 basis points. So the only market where there's anything to note is that Pacific Northwest is up about 300 basis points year-over-year. Sort of the expected given the nature of the rent increase that we're achieving in that market, the turnover is up. So other than that, for the most part, relatively benign change in turnover on a year-over-year basis.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then how about the concessions? Are you seeing any shift in concessions and particularly, I guess, in Northern California or in the New York City, any prevalence -- increased prevalence of concessions?
componenttext: Okay. And then how about the concessions? Are you seeing any shift in concessions and particularly, I guess, in Northern California or in the New York City, any prevalence -- increased prevalence of concessions?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. There definitely is -- I'd say it's a trend to increased concessions primarily in the New York City market and in San Francisco. Those are probably the 2 places that you're seeing it. And for the most part, I think it's the direct reflection of the j
componenttext: Yes. There definitely is -- I'd say it's a trend to increased concessions primarily in the New York City market and in San Francisco. Those are probably the 2 places that you're seeing it. And for the most part, I think it's the direct reflection of the just the lease-up activity that we're seeing in those markets. So in both San Francisco and particularly in Manhattan, there's a fair amount of concessions. I believe that communities on the stabilized assets do tend to compete based on those price points. So in many cases, market to market rents, but in some cases, where you think it might be an aberration for a short period of time, you might use a concession as opposed to reducing the rent. Particularly in New York, when you're faced with communities that have legal rent caps and things like that, you're trying to manage that.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just lastly, as you look at your second half outlook, and I believe the 3% to 4% revenue growth outlook, what would the pace look like through the year? Do you see third and fourth quarter relatively similar? Do you see a shift in momentum
componenttext: Okay. And then just lastly, as you look at your second half outlook, and I believe the 3% to 4% revenue growth outlook, what would the pace look like through the year? Do you see third and fourth quarter relatively similar? Do you see a shift in momentum as you exit the year?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean what's implied by the revised outlook is high 3% range in terms of revenue growth in the second half expected to be slightly above that in the third quarter and slightly below that in the fourth quarter.
componenttext: Yes, I mean what's implied by the revised outlook is high 3% range in terms of revenue growth in the second half expected to be slightly above that in the third quarter and slightly below that in the fourth quarter.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Jordan Sadler with Keybanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll go next to Jordan Sadler with Keybanc Capital Markets.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Alstom [ph] [indiscernible] here with Jordan. Just up to this point, really the weakness that we've talked about has really been supply-driven and this is one of the first references at our call being more on the demand side. So I guess I'm just curi
componenttext: It's Alstom [ph] [indiscernible] here with Jordan. Just up to this point, really the weakness that we've talked about has really been supply-driven and this is one of the first references at our call being more on the demand side. So I guess I'm just curious, aside from you mentioned New England being one of the markets where job growth has come in below expectations, what other markets are you seeing demand sort of weaker than you initially expected? And then what gives you the confidence with, I guess, greater uncertainty of the world and the election upcoming that this things can reaccelerate or level out?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think I could speak to maybe some of the maybe the near-term things, and Tim might want to speak to sort of the broader cycle, which I think is what he referenced in his prepared remarks in terms of acceleration, deceleration. But in terms of curre
componenttext: Yes, I think I could speak to maybe some of the maybe the near-term things, and Tim might want to speak to sort of the broader cycle, which I think is what he referenced in his prepared remarks in terms of acceleration, deceleration. But in terms of current trends, as Tim mentioned, job growth overall is running below expectation across the country. I'd say with the exception of what we're seeing in terms of acceleration in the Mid-Atlantic and the Pacific Northwest, most of the other markets are slightly below expectations in terms of job growth for this year. So given the level of supply which was anticipated and reduced job growth, that's where you see us falling short a little bit in terms of our expectations for revenue growth in the second half of the year. But in terms of the broader outlook, Tim could reference some thoughts on that.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just to be clear, I wasn't calling for an acceleration of fundamentals. What I was saying is we believe that the cycle is not done and we're not as lean as the continued deceleration. We've been at -- I think the one chart showed we're seeing like re
componenttext: Yes. Just to be clear, I wasn't calling for an acceleration of fundamentals. What I was saying is we believe that the cycle is not done and we're not as lean as the continued deceleration. We've been at -- I think the one chart showed we're seeing like rent -- like term rent change to be right in the 4% range now for the last 6 or 7 months. That's the period of time when we have seen weaker economic activity than we had anticipated. Job growth has been off about 50 basis points from what we had projected. I just think [indiscernible] this economic activity and job growth, we're going to have a little less household formation. But having said that, as we said in our management letter, we do expect rent change to be in the 3% to 4% range through the balance of the year. That is at or above trend, long-term trend. That's still very healthy rent growth for our business. So we're not necessarily calling for a reacceleration to cyclical highs, but we're not -- we don't think it's over yet. And again, it's one of the reasons why we compare it to the '90s. If you go back to the '90s, you just sort of chart what rent growth and revenue growth look like. It moved around from year to year based upon what was happening in that particular year from an economic activity standpoint. It does ebb and flow a bit and that's just the way the economies work. We don't see the kind of distortions that you might expect to see -- you see some weakness but you don't see the kind of distortion that you might expect to see that results in a lot of dislocation and ultimately leads to negative economic growth and recession.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Appreciate the detail there. And then you kind of touched a little bit on Southern California and I was just curious, that was a market that was sort of trending ahead of expectations earlier in the year. And now you're calling for things to soften into t
componenttext: Appreciate the detail there. And then you kind of touched a little bit on Southern California and I was just curious, that was a market that was sort of trending ahead of expectations earlier in the year. And now you're calling for things to soften into the second half and next year and didn't really highlight it as an outperformer versus the initial projections. Can you just give a little detail as to what's driving some of that softness into the second half of the year? And then maybe a little detail by submarket would be helpful.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, this is Sean. On that topic, basically, Northern California, as you pointed out, slightly ahead in the first half. It's basically slightly behind in the second half as a function of the macroeconomic things that we spoke about in terms of job growth
componenttext: Sure, this is Sean. On that topic, basically, Northern California, as you pointed out, slightly ahead in the first half. It's basically slightly behind in the second half as a function of the macroeconomic things that we spoke about in terms of job growth, et cetera. The supply is pretty much as expected. And so I don't know that there's a great story in Southern California in terms of whether there's a deceleration other than the job environment. If you look at it, we had a little bit of a boost in the Los Angeles region, particularly Samford and Novelli in the first half of the year as a result of some one-off issue, which was a gas leak in that area that drove some initial demand in the first quarter. It boosted occupancy but we've given that back in the second quarter. So there's a little bit of a lift in the first quarter and first half as a result of that. So that's partly reflected in a deceleration, I guess, if you want to call it as you look to the second half relative to the first half. But it's basically performing on plan. Los Angeles is healthy. Orange County has been slightly choppy but still relatively healthy. We've got some supply coming in to Anaheim, Irvine and Huntington Beach, a little bit of choppiness but for the most part, the product is being absorbed. And then San Diego just continues to perform quite well. So I don't know that there's any unusual story coming out of Southern California other than slightly lower job growth and then the sort of one-time business the we we received in the first half of the year from the gas leak that occurred.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Kris Trafton with Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: We'll go next to Kris Trafton with Crdit Suisse.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just following up on Jordan's question. Given that we're expecting deliveries to peak this year in markets outside New York and job growth continues around 150 [indiscernible] for a month. Not looking for 2017 guidance, but is your thought revenue gro
componenttext: I'm just following up on Jordan's question. Given that we're expecting deliveries to peak this year in markets outside New York and job growth continues around 150 [indiscernible] for a month. Not looking for 2017 guidance, but is your thought revenue growth could potentially bottom at the end of this year?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let's go back to my earlier comments. I think revenue growth can move around for the balance of the cycle. I don't think -- it's very different than what we saw in the 2000s, where rents went out, and when they stopped going up, they went down. So f
componenttext: Well, let's go back to my earlier comments. I think revenue growth can move around for the balance of the cycle. I don't think -- it's very different than what we saw in the 2000s, where rents went out, and when they stopped going up, they went down. So far in this cycle, I think you even saw in these 2 charts that we put up, one that showed the entire portfolio and one that showed the 6 regions, even after you sort of neutralize for seasonality, rent is moving around a bit even in this cycle. And we're saying we think that we're going to continue to see that a bit. Having said all that, we do see demand and supply becoming more in balance, which means we think we're going to get -- we're basically moderating towards trend right now a little bit above trend.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, perfect. And then just going back to one of your slides on the job openings versus the job hire slide, I mean given like the protection sentiment kind of in the United States and less likely to import [indiscernible] labor and the skills gap that we
componenttext: Okay, perfect. And then just going back to one of your slides on the job openings versus the job hire slide, I mean given like the protection sentiment kind of in the United States and less likely to import [indiscernible] labor and the skills gap that we have here in the United States, do you think that, that gap between openings and hires may kind of stick around for a while? And then did you give it any thought in terms of how that may affect demand in kind of your major markets?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's a fair question. I mean particularly given the college grads and highly skilled positions, as you mentioned, that there could be a shortage. But what that does is it creates more income growth for a big part of our resident population, w
componenttext: Yes, I think it's a fair question. I mean particularly given the college grads and highly skilled positions, as you mentioned, that there could be a shortage. But what that does is it creates more income growth for a big part of our resident population, which is one of the things that we said we really need to have, and as the cycle gets longer to help continue to kind of support the kind of rent growth that we've been seeing. I think potentially it's a favorable trend for our business maybe not for more broadly for the economy but for the apartment business in the kind of markets that we're in.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Jeff Spector with Bank of America.
componenttext: We'll go next to Jeff Spector with Bank of America.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think this question was addressed, but if it was, please let me know. On the supply points you mentioned in your management letter, you talk about supply averaging approximately 2% of your markets in '16 and '17. When we look at different sources
componenttext: I don't think this question was addressed, but if it was, please let me know. On the supply points you mentioned in your management letter, you talk about supply averaging approximately 2% of your markets in '16 and '17. When we look at different sources of supply, I know it's still hard to figure out for '17, it seemed like there's some differentiation between, let's say, San Fran and New York City. But based on your comment, I wasn't sure if you'd feel like San Fran is going to stay elevated into '17 because I think we were looking at [indiscernible] that's showing a drop-off in, let's say, the Northern California area in '17 versus New York. It's going to persist at least through '17.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeff. This is Sean. Fair comment. I think if you look at it based on the way we look at our markets, which is different from the U.S. overall, we're not as heavily involved in scrutinizing suppliers in those markets. But in our footprint, we're expec
componenttext: Yes, Jeff. This is Sean. Fair comment. I think if you look at it based on the way we look at our markets, which is different from the U.S. overall, we're not as heavily involved in scrutinizing suppliers in those markets. But in our footprint, we're expecting the Northern California region decelerate slightly from '16 to '17 from about 2.5% to 2.2%. But if you look at San Francisco specifically, we're expecting it to increase again in 2017 from 3.1% of inventory in '16 to 3.4% in 2017. So you didn't even look at the composition of the different markets within that region to determine what's happening. And as it relates to New York, we are expecting that to continue to be an issue through '17. As you may know, in New York, 15 [ph] deliveries were about 1.5 points of inventory. It does about 3% [ph] now. And but when you get to 2017, it's expected to peak closer to about 3.5% of inventory in the New York market.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. So in San Fran, you are expecting in '17 an increase. What's the disconnect, let's say, between what you're projecting versus, let's say, I believe you guys look at the -- I think Axiometrics is projecting a decrease. Is it just more of the s
componenttext: Okay, great. So in San Fran, you are expecting in '17 an increase. What's the disconnect, let's say, between what you're projecting versus, let's say, I believe you guys look at the -- I think Axiometrics is projecting a decrease. Is it just more of the submarket?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can speak to our process for the most part. And the way we do the process is a little bit top-down and bottoms-up to sort of meet in the middle of our forecast. The top-down sort of comes from other sources, whether it'd be REITs, Axiometrics or certain
componenttext: I can speak to our process for the most part. And the way we do the process is a little bit top-down and bottoms-up to sort of meet in the middle of our forecast. The top-down sort of comes from other sources, whether it'd be REITs, Axiometrics or certain local market providers like Delta Associates as an example here in D.C. or others in other markets. So we take that, but then we also do sort of a ground-up assessment. We have a market research team here in Arlington that scrubs all the local websites [indiscernible] municipalities in our market to understand where certain deals are in the processing for entitlement and what the expected delivery dates are. In addition to that, our local development team, where we have a 3 to 4 people per office around the country, is tracking all the development in their markets as they're competing for sites and expected opportunities in their markets. And in addition for the development teams, the last growth in our process is through the operations team where they now [indiscernible] beginning to pre-lease to better predict when deliveries are expected to arrive in certain submarkets and if we need to alter our revenue management strategy ahead of deliveries coming. So it's a pretty thorough process from a top-down and a bottom-up -- bottoms-up perspective as compared to just looking at the risk data and saying that's what we expect. So I think our process is probably more robust than average, but given our capability and development, how important it is to our business, we just give a lot of scrutiny.

componenttext: Correct, in your presentation, talk about the development yields for 2Q.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We completed 3 communities in the quarter and the number is going to move around based on the specific communities per geography each quarter. And the 3 we completed this past quarter all will perform pretty handily. One of them was Capitol Hill in S
componenttext: Yes. We completed 3 communities in the quarter and the number is going to move around based on the specific communities per geography each quarter. And the 3 we completed this past quarter all will perform pretty handily. One of them was Capitol Hill in Seattle, which is our first asset in that submarket, which has just exceeded expectations, obviously, with a big run off in rent since we started that deal 2-plus years ago. Another one was the deal in Northern New Jersey, in Union, which yes, we haven't seen any new supply in many years. And frequently, we find deposit price on rents when we serve in communities like that. And the third one was in Irvine. So the basket moves around from quarter-to-quarter, but I think year-to-date it's in the kind of 6 3-ish range. So obviously, the [indiscernible] in the prior quarter, a little bit lower yielding. Some of those were in one of those deal in Southern Cal, which tends to have lower yields. So it's going to generally move around, but we're continuing to see yields obviously big initial underwriting on the strength of good rent.

componenttext: This is Jeff on with Andrew. Just to turn to Slide 8 of the presentation, it looks like mush of the setup is like 2013 where your same-store slowed but bottomed at 3.5%. But I'm just curious, if you take this chart, what would it look like in 2001 or 2008 when things were about to fall off a cliff?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think I've referenced it. Look, I don't know if we have this exact data. It's a time series for certainly for 2001. But if you recall, I mean you have a big run-up [ph] in 2000 in the apartment world. So you really had a rent spike that was driving
componenttext: Yes. I think I've referenced it. Look, I don't know if we have this exact data. It's a time series for certainly for 2001. But if you recall, I mean you have a big run-up [ph] in 2000 in the apartment world. So you really had a rent spike that was driving pretty phenomenal performance in 2000. And then with the [indiscernible] rack in the elimination of -- you had 2 things going on, the elimination, obviously, of a lot of technology jobs, and you had a pretty much more dramatic expansion of [indiscernible] bolsters impact on interest rates. So you had a lot more -- home ownership rates went up in the face of a recession which was unusual. So you had a lot more demand disruption in the case of rental housing than you did actually in the 2000s when you have job losses that were actually 3x than we had in the early 2000s. But we saw sort of the typical pattern where renter ownership rates actually went up during recession. So it's a little more -- as I mentioned earlier, the 2000s is a little bit more of a kind of a straight up and then straight down curve to rent growth. It kind of kept going up and then until it hit. And after about 2006 and to 2007, rent started to decelerate until 2008 hit us.

componenttext: This is Matt. I guess I'll speak to that one. Lowest capital rates are still probably Manhattan kind of core. Best locations in Manhattan are probably still 3 caps. But outside of that, I would say, generally speaking, the lowest cap rates are across Southern California right now. I don't think a lot has been trading in Northern California recently just because of the changes on the ground there. So we've been trying to buy in Southern California and it's been a little bit frustrating. Good newer product in Southern Cal in some markets is definitely trading sub4 cap rates. And then the rest of the markets are kind of low to mid-4s up to the mid-5s depending on where you are.

componenttext: If I look at Page 9 of your slides where you give the rent change by market, why do your markets seem like they were sort of fluctuating over a 5-year average? But it's hard to look scarier there as Northern California which looks like it's in sort of freefall since last year but maybe reaching a bottom on your 5-year history. So what was the first half of this year like-term rent change in San Francisco? And what are you assuming for the second half of the year? And maybe you can break down the performance of the markets a bit between San Francisco versus the East Bay and San Jose.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nick this is Sean. I'm going to try to address some of those comments and then we can just follow up in greater detail if you're interested. Wanting to give the a sense, in Northern California, first, to give you some perspective from an overall stan
componenttext: Yes, Nick this is Sean. I'm going to try to address some of those comments and then we can just follow up in greater detail if you're interested. Wanting to give the a sense, in Northern California, first, to give you some perspective from an overall standpoint, rent change started the year around 6% but it's continued to decelerate and it's currently running around 4%. And that's made up of about 2.2% in San Francisco, 6% in the East Bay and the low 4% range in San Jose. So that's kind of where we are now. If you look at -- if you want to kind of decompose that even more into the [indiscernible] and like-term rent change by market, wanted to get that to you separately, so we're going to spend a lot of time on that. But I think it's fair to say that San Francisco is [indiscernible] at this point so just to address that one. Rent change at this point on move-ins is essentially just barely positive, 50 basis points to 100 basis points kind of range. We continue to hold renewals sort of in the low and mid-4% range. So you're talking about anywhere from 2.5% to 3.5% sort of numbers on a blended basis in San Francisco. Those numbers are certainly better in the East Bay and San Jose as I mentioned currently. But in terms of it reaching the bottom and flattening out, as I mentioned in response to a prior question, we still expect continued deliveries, pretty heavy level in San Francisco throughout this year and then even increasing into next year. So performance -- really rent change is going to depend on the level of demand, and job growth has been decelerating there. So to the extent that we see job growth level off, that would certainly help. But I think really your forecast for job growth is going to dictate performance in 2017 and where that levels off or not. Certainly as you get beyond '17, given the nature of the product that's constructed in San Francisco, supply should start to fall off, but we do expect it to be somewhat challenging through 2017 in San Francisco specifically.

Any changes as to how you think about concessions there and the ultimate yield on the entire project?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Sean again. Willoughby and Avalon -- [indiscernible] has been performing quite well. As you indicated, we're just starting the lease-up on the Willoughby component. But if you look at performance through the second quarter, which represents
componenttext: Sure. This is Sean again. Willoughby and Avalon -- [indiscernible] has been performing quite well. As you indicated, we're just starting the lease-up on the Willoughby component. But if you look at performance through the second quarter, which represents mainly AVA DoBro, we leased and occupied 65, 60 a month, which is quite strong and up from the first quarter which is around 39. So leasing velocity has been healthy. As I indicated, it's a little too early probably to give you great guidance about the Willoughby component. We did mark the rents up this quarter, but our expectation is that, hopefully, there will be some additional lift as we move through the second of of the year. The views are pretty spectacular on top of that building so I'm not sure that we had seen exactly where the rents are going to settle out. But I think it's fair to say the overall project has performed quite well. In terms of the impact on yield, the only negative I can speak to is that we have had a little bit of a surprise on the property tax that may offset some of the rent lift, but our expectation is that the yield will be essentially on par with original expectations, hopefully slightly above.

componenttext: I was hoping to talk about L.A. In my understanding in your portfolio was that you have very good exposure to downtown L.A. where there's quite a bit of the supply coming over the next couple of years. I was hoping you could speak to whether at least tangentially there was any impact from downtown L.A. supply in some of your submarkets in the second quarter?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Drew, this is Sean. You're correct. We have one operating asset in downtown L.A. It's in Little Tokyo, a community we constructed at the earlier part of this cycle. We actually have great basis there, but yes, there's a significant amount of supply b
componenttext: Yes, Drew, this is Sean. You're correct. We have one operating asset in downtown L.A. It's in Little Tokyo, a community we constructed at the earlier part of this cycle. We actually have great basis there, but yes, there's a significant amount of supply being delivered into L.A. I think it's upwards of 15% of inventory. You have to put that number in context with the fact that they're trying to create a whole new environment in downtown and it's spread across multiple submarkets within downtown L.A. But in terms of any indirect effect on the rest of the portfolio from that supply, we have not seen that. Most of the product that we own in that market is a mix of some of newer communities but also a fair amount of older communities and terrific suburban locations that are performing quite well.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean L.A. and Orange County if you look at the supply that's coming online, for the most part, we do expect continued elevated deliveries in downtown L.A. It's like 14%, 15% this year and it stays at that level through 2017. Yes, there are a couple
componenttext: Yes, I mean L.A. and Orange County if you look at the supply that's coming online, for the most part, we do expect continued elevated deliveries in downtown L.A. It's like 14%, 15% this year and it stays at that level through 2017. Yes, there are a couple of pockets that you're seeing in supply in L.A. is [indiscernible] Delray. In particular, it's one large development there that's quite a bit that's delivering right now, and then a couple of other submarkets. As you move down into Orange County, you do see supply fall off a little bit in Anaheim from 16 to '17. And as it relates to Irvine, Irvine is actually projected to increase as you move in to '17 as a result of some deliveries by a handful of developers but, in particular, a couple of large projects that will be delivered by the Irvine company, so increase there and then a modest reduction in Huntington Beach. And then Huntington Beach is kind of 2 anchors on the supply. There's a fair amount of product being delivered right at the mall at Beach Boulevard and 405, but there's other communities, up a couple of communities under development down at South Pacific city which is down along down Pacific Coast Highway there in Huntington Beach. So there's not much sort of in between there, but those are the 2 sort of anchors of supply in that market. If you look at it, overall, one thing to keep in mind for Southern California is we're still talking about deliveries that are low 1% range of inventory overall. So you do have to be careful about which submarkets you're in. But if you look at it, the region is pretty supply constrained.

componenttext: Yes, let me just [indiscernible] speak. I mean what happened in the first half of the year is what's really going to impact portfolio performance in the second half of the year. And you'll usually see about a 2-quarter lag impact in terms of what's happening in terms of the direction of the job growth relative to the portfolio.

componenttext: And then just another question, just looking at the like-term rent effective rent changes around 4% so far this year expected to maybe moderate a little bit in the back half. But if we look at the first have same-store revenue growth, that's been a bit higher, maybe 100 basis points higher than that. And it looks like the July data, there's a narrowing of that gap, and I'm just curious if there's anything specific that's driving that is that folks are trading down or is it just different lease term lengths than you've seen typically, just any color you have on that.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean what comes to mind is really comps in the second half of the year, assuming we really have more challenging comps. And it's really played out in terms of -- if you look at on a granular level it really comes down to the monthly sequential chan
componenttext: Yes, I mean what comes to mind is really comps in the second half of the year, assuming we really have more challenging comps. And it's really played out in terms of -- if you look at on a granular level it really comes down to the monthly sequential change in GDP. And what we've seen in both like-term rent change, as well as the transient and corporate component, is it's just not compounding as great a rate as it was at this time last year. So to give you some perspective as an example, if you looked at the change in GP on a monthly basis last year, we're talking about for the second quarter on a monthly basis moving up at 60 basis points in April, 100 basis points in May and about 110 basis points in June versus this year, those numbers were 30 basis points, 60 basis points and 90 basis points. Some of that is a reflection of the transient demand that we mentioned earlier, Tim alluded to in his prepared remarks, which sort of turbocharge GDP growth in the late second quarter and early third quarter that we're not seeing this year. So that's certainly part of it.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick ones for me. First, on the outperformance that obviously helped this year's guidance number has sort of been a hallmark for you guys, the 30 basis points, as fundamentals moderate, how should we be thinking about that outperformance? Is that
componenttext: Just 2 quick ones for me. First, on the outperformance that obviously helped this year's guidance number has sort of been a hallmark for you guys, the 30 basis points, as fundamentals moderate, how should we be thinking about that outperformance? Is that something that you expect to continue or eventually maybe it's not in the next 6, maybe in the next 12 months where trend is going just be delivering at your underwriting rather than exceeding?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean as you know, I mean we do underwrite base upon current rents in place. As long as rents are -- continue to rise at some level, we would expect yields continue to go up, all those things being constant, which, for the most part, they are, whic
componenttext: Well, I mean as you know, I mean we do underwrite base upon current rents in place. As long as rents are -- continue to rise at some level, we would expect yields continue to go up, all those things being constant, which, for the most part, they are, which [indiscernible] bring development in close to budget. So yes, you would expect that lift to moderate as rents might moderate. Now 30 basis points is a little misleading. If you took out the impact of Willoughby, well, Willoughby's rents went up pretty specifically, so did the taxes, as Sean had mentioned. So that actually muted the impact in terms of the yield impact. If you neutralized Willoughby, the other deals on average went up -- have gone up by 70 basis points, so almost a 10% lift in terms of -- about a 10% lift in terms of the projected yield. So you got to look at the actual basket and some different things that may be happening with individual assets.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

componenttext: That's helpful, Tim. And then the second is, maybe Kevin, can you just provide a little bit color -- I don't think you addressed it earlier, but in the guidance provision, you're getting a lift from capital markets and transaction activity a $0.02 positive variance versus your original outlook. Can you just provide a little bit more color on what's going in there, what's changed in your thinking of those 2 items to give you that positive benefit?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Alex, this is Kevin. The $0.02 lift in expected core FFO per share is coming from capital markets and transaction activity as you'd expect. It's a mix of things going on there. It's the impact of net acquisition and disposition activity both in terms
componenttext: Yes, Alex, this is Kevin. The $0.02 lift in expected core FFO per share is coming from capital markets and transaction activity as you'd expect. It's a mix of things going on there. It's the impact of net acquisition and disposition activity both in terms of the amount and the timing as well as some changes to JV income -- I'm sorry, some changes to the debt assumptions that we got. We did pay off a piece of debt in the second quarter and had some benefit from lower interest rate being woven into the next year.

componenttext: Okay, it's not as if -- because you guys haven't historically drawn your line -- I can't remember actually the last time [indiscernible] you draw on your line. But you intended to use a more line of your credit. It's just timing of other activities, correct?

componenttext: It's timing of activity, primarily acquisition and disposition activity, both the amount and the timing of it. So yes, we don't expect to be a significant user of our line of credit that we haven't done throughout the year.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, john this is Matt. We do index our target investment returns to our weighted average cost of capital assuming a 30% to 70% debt-to-equity mix. So as the cost of debt goes down, it does at the margin reduce our WAC [ph] a little bit, but frankly, it's
componenttext: Hey, john this is Matt. We do index our target investment returns to our weighted average cost of capital assuming a 30% to 70% debt-to-equity mix. So as the cost of debt goes down, it does at the margin reduce our WAC [ph] a little bit, but frankly, it's a more impacted by the equity. And we don't adjust it on a day-to-day basis. We'll adjust it maybe twice a year. What we've seen is that it's actually pretty darn sticky over the last 4 or 5 years really through this entire cycle. So I would not -- I would say no in general. Our target returns in general has not moved in any material way over the last really couple of years. We're still looking at -- and when you look at where the underwriting returns are on the development rate side, they've been very consistent in that kind of mid-6 range.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And John, this is Kevin, just to add to that, while treasury rates had certainly gone down, you can certainly look at our cost of debt for 10-year unsecured debts, last year, we averaged around 3.4%, 3.5%. As you know, [indiscernible] offering we executed
componenttext: And John, this is Kevin, just to add to that, while treasury rates had certainly gone down, you can certainly look at our cost of debt for 10-year unsecured debts, last year, we averaged around 3.4%, 3.5%. As you know, [indiscernible] offering we executed just under 3%. If we were to raise the 10-year [indiscernible] offering today, we're probably around 3% because while treasuries have fallen, spreads have widened, actually neutralizing the treasury chain. So even over the last year, there's only been maybe a 40, 50 basis point decrease in our overall cost of debt. So we [indiscernible] that through on a blended basis, the 30% leverage [indiscernible] and Matt alluded to is a pretty modest impact.

componenttextpreview: I'm not sure if I follow. We underwrite yield on a [indiscernible] basis. And so what we do is we -- in our yield matrix, the component that Matt was alluding that ties to our short-term cost of capital looks like our levered initial short-term cost to ca
componenttext: I'm not sure if I follow. We underwrite yield on a [indiscernible] basis. And so what we do is we -- in our yield matrix, the component that Matt was alluding that ties to our short-term cost of capital looks like our levered initial short-term cost to capital, which ascribes 30% [ph] weighted -- 7% [ph] weighting to equity. So we end up [indiscernible] essentially an unlevered or neutralized number from a leverage point of view. So we don't look at yields on a levered basis.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Quick question for me on the development side of the equation. I'm curious how much of the job occupancy, sort of job openings that you're seeing are driven by construction and that's having any pressures on construction costs and then that would ultimate
componenttext: Quick question for me on the development side of the equation. I'm curious how much of the job occupancy, sort of job openings that you're seeing are driven by construction and that's having any pressures on construction costs and then that would ultimately impact development yields? I know you mentioned development yields were probably going to be stable, but I'm curious if you're seeing rising construction costs regarding -- driven primarily by wage growth on that side.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it has been driven mostly by labor not by materials for sure, and that's been a mix, I would imagine, above profitability and labor costs. If you look at the different sort of wage you see out there, construction labor is towards the top, if not at
componenttext: Well, it has been driven mostly by labor not by materials for sure, and that's been a mix, I would imagine, above profitability and labor costs. If you look at the different sort of wage you see out there, construction labor is towards the top, if not at the very top in terms of year-over-year wage growth. So it's an industry that has seen a lot of skilled labor over the last cycle or 2, and it's a challenge to get skilled labor in a lot of these sites compared -- and when you think about the production level not just the department's but just the housing and kind of all real estate categories, the level of construction is still not that high, and yes, it's a real challenge for the industry right now. I think a lot of that has to do with the shortage in skilled labor.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And you're pretty comfortable that development yields will remain stable despite that?
componenttext: Got it. And you're pretty comfortable that development yields will remain stable despite that?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we continue to -- whenever we look at new opportunities as well as existing opportunities, we continue to sort of reunderwrite them as we continue to invest [indiscernible] cost of capital and make sure you want to continue to invest what we think i
componenttext: Well, we continue to -- whenever we look at new opportunities as well as existing opportunities, we continue to sort of reunderwrite them as we continue to invest [indiscernible] cost of capital and make sure you want to continue to invest what we think is sort of the highest risk capital of any deal, which is that entitlement and design -- that pursued cost capital, if you will. So the kind of yields that you see on the schedule and the release, they're consistent with the kind of yields we see in the development pipeline.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's clearly -- I mean part of why we've been able to replenish our development right pipeline I think is connected to that. We are seeing more deal flow. I think if a developer has 3 or 4 deals, they may be looking to lay off one of them in terms of l
componenttext: There's clearly -- I mean part of why we've been able to replenish our development right pipeline I think is connected to that. We are seeing more deal flow. I think if a developer has 3 or 4 deals, they may be looking to lay off one of them in terms of land and it's probably a function somewhat kind of the reception that they're getting with some of their key lending partners. But across the board, you're definitely hearing from both banks the suppliers of capital as well as the consumers of capital developers that construction financing is less wonderful.

componenttextpreview: Just a quick question. Could you talk about rent to income ratio in many of your key markets, and if you think that's a contributing factor to -- or rent fatigue is a contributing factor to some of the slowdown in the rent growth we're seeing? Just wanted
componenttext: Just a quick question. Could you talk about rent to income ratio in many of your key markets, and if you think that's a contributing factor to -- or rent fatigue is a contributing factor to some of the slowdown in the rent growth we're seeing? Just wanted to get a sense how much of this stuff really is supply related versus how much is demand-related.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Tayo it's Sean. Yes, resident income ratios are running around 23% right now. That's certainly at the higher end of long-term average as [indiscernible] to think of it that way. We are seeing income growth. Income growth In the portfolio and househo
componenttext: Sure, Tayo it's Sean. Yes, resident income ratios are running around 23% right now. That's certainly at the higher end of long-term average as [indiscernible] to think of it that way. We are seeing income growth. Income growth In the portfolio and household move-in in the second quarter was up a couple of hundred basis points year-over-year. In terms of rent fatigue, if you look at the portfolio in terms of reasons for move-out, it's actually come down. If you look at rent increases as a percentage of move-outs, it was running closer to 20% last year. It's running about 17% right now. And as you might imagine, it's come down a fair bit in markets like New York and Northern California. So we're starting to see pretty good signs of wage growth across the economy and in our portfolio. And as you've seen some deceleration in rental growth in some of these markets, there's just not as much pressure there as there was during 2015 as an example.

Rent increases, as I mentioned, is running around 17% and then the home purchases are running at [ph] 13%. It's actually down 50 basis points year-over-year and still well below long-term averages. So just a little bit of movement upward in a couple of markets, but it's not really moving much in terms of home purchases.

componenttext: Yes, Wes, it's a little hard to quantify, I'll tell you why. It's easy to quantify some of the direct effect on the short-term component in particular. So to give you an example, if the percentage of leases that are short term is down, say, 50 basis points specifically give it 50% premium on that, plus about 25 incremental basis points of GDP growth during that period of time, what's hard to quantify is the indirect effect of having that inventory back in the market. So it's hard to say exactly what the impact is for the full year because of those various assumptions you have to make. So it's fairly quantify the 3 or 4 months which we could certainly talk to you about offline but the broader impact is hard to quantify.

I'm curious, just looking at Slide 7, as you think about -- I don't know whether you track this or not, but was any change in sort of Airbnb type rentals, were renters in your apartments accelerating the listing of their apartments or scaling that back as a way to maybe generate income to offset some of the rent expenses? componenttextpreview: Not necessarily, Michael. I mean we do stay connected with Airbnb and they provided some information on leasing activity in our apartment homes. Based on the last report that I have, there was not a material shift. Some of the stuff that we see is really
componenttext: Not necessarily, Michael. I mean we do stay connected with Airbnb and they provided some information on leasing activity in our apartment homes. Based on the last report that I have, there was not a material shift. Some of the stuff that we see is really -- you have to dissect it at a very granular level to understand that. For example, in New England, [indiscernible] specifically, there were some pretty good winter storms the last couple of years. When we underwrite things, we sort of look at an average year, this year was a better-than-average year, so there was less transit demand from insurance claims where people had damage in their homes during the winter. It gets to that level of granularity in terms of understanding that demand. So I've not seen anything regarding Airbnb at this point.

componenttext: And then when you think about -- so this captures about 6% of the lease volume of your rent roll between the corporate leasing and the short term, so the balance call it, about 94%. componenttextpreview: Yes we do dissect the data in terms of that percentage they're single, single with children, married, married with kids, [indiscernible] et cetera. There's not been a significant movement in those numbers. It's a large population, so you really have to se
componenttext: Yes we do dissect the data in terms of that percentage they're single, single with children, married, married with kids, [indiscernible] et cetera. There's not been a significant movement in those numbers. It's a large population, so you really have to see, so that was quite a bit of movement to move the needle here. The reason we brought this up is the premiums are so significant on the short-term leases that it can have an impact. Again, when you're talking about a 50% premium, even if it's 1% of your leases or 50 basis points or 0.5% [ph] of your leases, then it can have a significant impact on GP in any given month. So that's why we highlighted this one in particular and the same thing in corporate.
