headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Augusta, and welcome to Avalonbay Communities Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Before we begin, please note that forward-looking statements may be made during this discussion. There are a variety of risks and uncertainties associat
componenttext:
Thank you, Augusta, and welcome to Avalonbay Communities Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Before we begin, please note that forward-looking statements may be made during this discussion. There are a variety of risks and uncertainties associated with forward-looking statements, and actual results may differ materially. There's a discussion of these risks and uncertainties in yesterday afternoon's press release as well as in the company's Form 10-K and Form 10-Q filed with the SEC. 
As usual, this press release does include an attachment with definitions and reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures and other terms, which may be used in today's discussion. The attachment is also available on our website at www.avalonbay.com/earnings, and we encourage you to refer to this information during the review of our operating results and financial performance. 
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Tim Naughton, Chairman and CEO of Avalonbay Communities for his remarks. Tim?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Jason, and welcome to our second quarter call. With me today is Kevin O'Shea, Sean Breslin and Matt Birenbaum. I'll provide commentary on the slides that we posted last night, then all of us will be available for Q&A afterwards. My comments
componenttext:
Yes. Thanks, Jason, and welcome to our second quarter call. With me today is Kevin O'Shea, Sean Breslin and Matt Birenbaum. I'll provide commentary on the slides that we posted last night, then all of us will be available for Q&A afterwards. 
My comments will focus on providing a summary of Q2 and year-to-date results, our revised midyear outlook for 2016, our view regarding the trajectory and durability of the current apartment cycle, and lastly, a look at how current development activity is contributing to our earnings growth. 
So starting on Slide 4. It was a solid quarter, where we achieved core FFO growth greater than 8.5% from a combination of healthy same-store revenue and NOI growth of 5% and contributions from new lease-ups, as we completed almost $200 million at a projected yield of just under 7%. Year-to-date, core FFO was up over 10%, again driven by a combination of internal growth from the stabilized portfolio and external growth from stabilizing development. For the first half of the year, our same-store portfolio performs in line with budget, although a bit ahead of budget in Q1 and a little behind in Q2. I'll discuss this trend a little more in a couple of minutes. 
Turning to Slide 5 and our updated outlook for the year. In short, overall expectations for core FFO are in line with our original outlook, which call for core FFO growth of 9%. Our projection for same-store NOI growth has been trimmed by about 40 basis points or approximately $0.03 per share for the full year, but is offset by contributions from other categories, such that our full year outlook for core FFO remains unchanged. Our projected investment and funding activity for the year remains more or less in line with our original expectation with some minor variances. 
Turning now to Slide 6. We thought we'd provide a little more color regarding our outlook for the same-store portfolio in the second half of the year. As I mentioned earlier, we performed in line with expectations for the first half of the year, although in Q2, we did experience the -- we did not experience the seasonal strength and effective rent growth that we're accustomed to seeing. This trend appears to be largely demand-driven, as economic and job growth fell short of expectations for the first half of the year, and declining business confidence in investment, no doubt, was a contributing factor as recent uncertainty in global events have left businesses hesitant to make new commitments. 
Turning to Slide 7. Slower economic growth impacts corporate and transient demand, which helps fuel seasonal strength in the second and third quarters for our business. A weaker corporate and transient demand affects us in 2 ways: first, a reduction in premium income, which typically runs 50% to 60% higher per lease; and secondly, an effective increase in market vacancy as, in fact, inventories essentially added back to the market. 
Turning to Slide 8. As economic conditions have moderated over the last 2 or 3 quarters, effective rent growth in our same-store portfolio, expressed as like-term rent change, has remained in the 4% range over the last 6 to 7 months. And while like-term rent change did improve modestly in Q2, we did not see the same seasonal lift we've seen in prior years so far this cycle. 
And turning to Slide 9, of course, performance does vary across our regions. Effective rent growth has moderated, most notably, in Northern California and the Northeast, while Seattle and the Mid-Atlantic have been trending up. Rent growth in Southern California remains healthy in the 6% range. 
Turning to Slide 10. As you might expect, these trends are impacting our outlook for portfolio performance for the year. Again, the Northeast and Northern California fallen short of projected budget, while in Seattle and D.C. are expected to outperform. Overall, the net impact is resulting in a reduction of same-store revenue of almost 40 basis points for the full year with all of that expect a shortfall to occur in the second half of the year. 
Now turning now to Slide 11. Just given trends in the operating environment, we thought we'd just revisit where we think we are in the cycle. We still believe that fundamentals point mostly in favor of an extended cycle much like we saw in the 1990s. As you see on this chart, consumer confidence remains on solid footing at cyclically high levels, and young adults are feeling the best and leading the way. 
Turning to Slide 12. Consumer confidence is being shaped in large part by an improved employment picture with jobless claims continuing their fall since the cycle began and job openings now outpacing hiring activities. And as you can see on Slide 13, the growing strength in the labor market seems to finally be putting pressure on wages as evidenced by recent ADP reports. And combined with reduced debt burdens and stronger balance sheets you see on Chart 2, the consumer are in good shape and getting stronger, which bodes well for continued economic growth given their contribution to the GP. 
Turning to Slide 14. In addition, renter demand should continue to be supported by favorable demographics with the largest segment of millennials in the early to mid-20s still moving into their prime household formation and renting years. Obviously, demographics have been a major driver of renter demand this past cycle, and they should continue to support healthy rental demand over the next 5-plus years, even if homeownerships begin to stabilize -- I'm sorry, homeownership rates begin to stabilize, as the leading-edge of millennials begin to consider buying a home. 
Turning to Slide 15. The supply side of the equation is encouraging as well. Apartment deliveries are expected to peak nationally in 2016 and '17, as permitting for new projects has slowed down over the last 2 to 3 quarters from the cyclical highs in 2015. This is due in part to tightening credit for multifamily construction, which has become much more pronounced over the last couple of quarters. 
Turning to Slide 16. In addition to the apartment sector remaining in balance, the picture for the overall housing market looks positive as well. Projections for new housing production are in line with household formation over the next 4 years, but it's important to note that, first, these figures -- these supply figures ignore obsolescence or destruction of roughly 400,000 units per year, and they also assume that housing production over the next 4 years increases by 30% from its current level and roughly doubles what we've seen so far on average this cycle. 
So overall, while we may be seeing economic growth moderate a bit, we don't see any real tangible signs that the apartment or housing cycle was nearing its end. Rather, we are still seeing solid demand growth matched by what we believe is reasonable levels of new supply to meet that demand. 
Turning to Slide 17. Within this operating environment, one, where demand and supply are expected to remain in balance, we believe that we are well positioned to continue to deliver outsized growth from our development platform. So far, this cycle, we've completed over $4 billion of new development and initial stabilized yields on average of around 7% are well in excess of our marginal cost of capital during this time, which has contributed to strong core FFO growth over the last few years. 
And finally turning to Slide 18. Development should continue to drive solid external growth going forward as development underway, along with nonstabilized recent completions, should generate another $200 million of NOI with less than $400 million of capital required to complete this basket of $3.3 billion of assets. With these assets projected to yield low above our marginal cost of capital, most of which has already been raised, we are positioned to deliver industry-leading external growth over the next 2 to 3 years. 
So in summary, 2016 is shaping up to be another strong year for Avalonbay, and we believe that the company is very well positioned from an investment and funding perspective to outperform going forward. 
And with that, Augusta, we'd like to open the call for questions.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to Nick Joseph with Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to Nick Joseph with Citi.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Given the more muted near-term 2016 operating outlook, does it give you any pause in terms of development starts in the back half of the year?
componenttext: Given the more muted near-term 2016 operating outlook, does it give you any pause in terms of development starts in the back half of the year?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nick, this is Tim. No, not really. I mean, that was a kind of the point to the last few charts and talking about where we think we are in the cycle. We think the cycle still has -- lives around the economic cycle, and more broadly, the housing cycle and t
componenttext: Nick, this is Tim. No, not really. I mean, that was a kind of the point to the last few charts and talking about where we think we are in the cycle. We think the cycle still has -- lives around the economic cycle, and more broadly, the housing cycle and the apartment cycle. So when we give as pause if we thought the cycle was maybe nearing its end, then the cost of capital was -- that we need in order to fund those commitments changed dramatically. But in terms of the expected yields on that basket of communities relative to what we think we can fund them at, we think it still provides an attractive accretive growth. So at this point, I'd say, no.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just in terms of markets, maybe one that's priced on the negative and one on the positive. Can you talk about what you're seeing in New England and then in the Pacific Northwest?
componenttext: And then just in terms of markets, maybe one that's priced on the negative and one on the positive. Can you talk about what you're seeing in New England and then in the Pacific Northwest?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, Nick. It's Sean, happy to talk about that. In terms of New England, first, it's typically more seasonal than most of our markets. And if you look at what's happened throughout the year, rent change started the year in the mid-2% range and it's
componenttext: Yes, sure, Nick. It's Sean, happy to talk about that. In terms of New England, first, it's typically more seasonal than most of our markets. And if you look at what's happened throughout the year, rent change started the year in the mid-2% range and it's trended up to about 3.5%, but it's running well below both last year's rate of about 5% and our initial expectations. I think, it's largely a result of 2 things. One is job growth, and the first 5 or 6 months of the year has been somewhat disappointing at an annualized rate of about 1.5 points relative to expectations closer to about 2% for the full year. And then also the transient demand that Tim referred to has been pretty weak in Boston this year, which put downward pressure on rental rates in the late spring and the early summer. So in terms of New England, that's kind of what's happening there. And then as it relates to Seattle, Seattle, for the most part, it's all about demand. And the first half of the year, job growth is running in the mid-4% range. I think most forecasters that we rely on had projected a slowdown in hiring in the Seattle market and it has not slowed down. There's still plenty of supply, about 3.5% of inventory, but the surprise has been on the demand side in terms of job growth. There's still softness in the sort of urban core of Seattle. We don't have many assets there. We really have 2 operating assets in those submarkets. But if you move out to the Northern, you move to Redmond, you move to Bellevue, revenue growth is still relatively robust. And I think the difference between Seattle and Northern California in terms of what you're seeing in performance is, you really have some well-established, large, well-capitalized companies driving the hiring in the tech sector in Seattle as compared to allow the smaller businesses that make up a greater share of employment in Northern California that are more susceptible to changes in funding tied to the VC market and what's happening with IPO, evaluations, et cetera. So that's really what's been helping Seattle is really the job growth.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just finally, it looks like bad debt increased. Can you talk about what drove that increase? If it was in any specific markets?
componenttext: And then just finally, it looks like bad debt increased. Can you talk about what drove that increase? If it was in any specific markets?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, did you say bad debt, Nick, just so I got you clearly?
componenttext: Yes, did you say bad debt, Nick, just so I got you clearly?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the bad debt was up about 15 basis points year-over-year. We are seeing elevated levels of bad debt across 4 of the 6 regions. About 60% of it, though, is coming from a combination of factors in the New York region. Really 3 things that I could point
componenttext: Yes, the bad debt was up about 15 basis points year-over-year. We are seeing elevated levels of bad debt across 4 of the 6 regions. About 60% of it, though, is coming from a combination of factors in the New York region. Really 3 things that I could point to. One is the core process has slowed considerably in 2016 relative to 2015. So it's taking a lot longer to get sort of judgment, if you want to call it that. And our policy is to write things off after a certain period of time. If we collect it later, it'll be an offset, but we're writing things off more rapidly. And then secondly is, we're just not getting the same level of judgments that we were seeing just based on some new judges in certain courts. And then thirdly is, we did have one corporate housing provider kind of go belly up on us. There's only 15 homes that have represented a couple of months of rent. The underlying client was actually still paying, so it's sort of an anomaly in the system, I guess, I would say, but New York is about 60% of the total increase, so that was unanticipated.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Rich Hightower with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Rich Hightower with Evercore ISI.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a quick question here on the New York, New Jersey region. It does seem that the revised projection is not meaningfully below the original projection but somewhat below. So could you break down what you're seeing in the different submarkets, whether it'
componenttext: So a quick question here on the New York, New Jersey region. It does seem that the revised projection is not meaningfully below the original projection but somewhat below. So could you break down what you're seeing in the different submarkets, whether it's Manhattan or Brooklyn or even the outlying suburbs and just where you're seeing pockets of strength and weakness on either of the supply or demand side there?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Rich, this is Sean again, happy to do so. First, overall, for our New York, New Jersey, just to give you a sense of how it trended throughout the year across that portfolio. Rent change increased from about 1.5% in Q1 to roughly 3% for Q2. And while
componenttext: Sure, Rich, this is Sean again, happy to do so. First, overall, for our New York, New Jersey, just to give you a sense of how it trended throughout the year across that portfolio. Rent change increased from about 1.5% in Q1 to roughly 3% for Q2. And while we've had a good progress on renewal rent change, which is in the low 4% range, move-in rent change remains pretty stubbornly low at around 1.5%. It hasn't really improved much through the second quarter or into July. And I think what you're seeing there, particularly in New York City, which I'm including Northern New Jersey and kind of this general description of the geography at this point, is while there's been steady job growth, there is just not enough high paying jobs being created to absorb all the new supply. It's all being delivered at the high end of the market. And if you look at the performance, particularly recent performance of the suburban markets in and around New York are performing better than the City. We're seeing rent growth in New York City to sort of in the mid-2% range. But as you move into Long Island and Northern and Central New Jersey, we get up to the 3% to 4% and even 5% in Central Jersey over the last quarter. So, in general, I'd say the supply is weighing most heavily on the New York City market so, including the boroughs and Northern New Jersey, and we're seeing better performance out of the suburban submarkets.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, Sean, that's helpful. And then one, also, final question on property tax increases. I know that they were up 9% for the quarter. I guess, if you could pinpoint this, when can we expect that trend to sort of taper off a little bit? Or do you thi
componenttext: All right, Sean, that's helpful. And then one, also, final question on property tax increases. I know that they were up 9% for the quarter. I guess, if you could pinpoint this, when can we expect that trend to sort of taper off a little bit? Or do you think we're sort of just in for consistent mid- to high single-digit growth for a little while here?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, really, the taxes -- the second quarter and the first half are really a reflection of prior year activity for the most part. About 2/3 of the increase in taxes relates to supplemental assessments that were reversed last year in the second quarter. Ou
componenttext: Yes, really, the taxes -- the second quarter and the first half are really a reflection of prior year activity for the most part. About 2/3 of the increase in taxes relates to supplemental assessments that were reversed last year in the second quarter. Our expectation is that by the time we get to year-end, taxes are probably be growing on a year-over-year basis in the 4% range -- 3.5% to 4% range. So there's a lot of noise in there in terms of the appeal for that we achieve something this quarter, what we received in the same quarter last year, et cetera, sort of [indiscernible] comps a little bit, but call it, 3.5% to 4% is the expected growth rate in taxes for the calendar year '16.

componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, if you look at it, it's a little bit of rounding out, I would say. It's basically 61% this year and last year in the same quarter. And if you look at turnover as a percentage of expirations because expirations do move around a little bit, tu
componenttext: Sure. I mean, if you look at it, it's a little bit of rounding out, I would say. It's basically 61% this year and last year in the same quarter. And if you look at turnover as a percentage of expirations because expirations do move around a little bit, turnover was actually down about 100 basis points. So the only market where there's anything to note is that Pacific Northwest was up about 300 basis points year-over-year, sort of the expected given the nature of the rent increase that we're achieving in that market, the turnover is up. So other than that, for the most part, relatively benign change in turnover on a year-over-year basis.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then how about the concessions? Are you seeing any shift in concessions in, particularly, I guess, in Northern California, in the New York City or any prevalence -- increased prevalence of concessions?
componenttext: Okay. And then how about the concessions? Are you seeing any shift in concessions in, particularly, I guess, in Northern California, in the New York City or any prevalence -- increased prevalence of concessions?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. There definitely is, I'd say, a trend of increased concessions primarily in the New York City market and in San Francisco. Those are probably the 2 places that you are seeing it. And for the most part, I think, it's the direct reflection of just the
componenttext: Yes. There definitely is, I'd say, a trend of increased concessions primarily in the New York City market and in San Francisco. Those are probably the 2 places that you are seeing it. And for the most part, I think, it's the direct reflection of just the lease-up activity that we're seeing in those markets. So in both San Francisco, and particularly in Manhattan, there is a fair amount of concessions of the lease-up communities and then the stabilized assets do tend to compete based on those price points. So in many cases, we're marking the market rents, but in some cases, where you think it might be an aberration for a short period of time, you might use a concession as opposed to reducing the rent. Particularly in New York, when you're faced with communities that have legal rent caps and things like that, you're trying to manage both.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just lastly, as you look at your second half outlook, and I believe the 3% to 4% revenue growth outlook, what would the pace look like through the year? Do you see the third and fourth quarter relatively similar? Do you see a shift in momen
componenttext: Okay. And then just lastly, as you look at your second half outlook, and I believe the 3% to 4% revenue growth outlook, what would the pace look like through the year? Do you see the third and fourth quarter relatively similar? Do you see a shift in momentum as you exit the year?

componenttext: Yes, I mean, what's implied by the revised outlook is high 3% range in terms of revenue growth in the second half expected to be slightly above that in the third quarter and slightly below that in the fourth quarter.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Austin Wurschmidt here with Jordan. Just up into this point, really the weakness that we've talked about has really been supply-driven and this is one of the first references at our call being more on the demand side. So, I guess, I'm just curious, a
componenttext: It's Austin Wurschmidt here with Jordan. Just up into this point, really the weakness that we've talked about has really been supply-driven and this is one of the first references at our call being more on the demand side. So, I guess, I'm just curious, aside from you mentioned New England being one of the markets where job growth has come in below expectations. What other markets are you seeing demand sort of weaker than you initially expected? And then what gives you the confidence with, I guess, greater uncertainty of the world and the election upcoming that things could reaccelerate or level out?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the -- I could speak to, maybe, some of the -- maybe the near-term things, and Tim might want to speak to sort of the broader cycle, which I think is what he referenced in his prepared remarks in terms of acceleration, deceleration. But in te
componenttext: Yes, I think the -- I could speak to, maybe, some of the -- maybe the near-term things, and Tim might want to speak to sort of the broader cycle, which I think is what he referenced in his prepared remarks in terms of acceleration, deceleration. But in terms of current trends, as Tim mentioned, job growth overall is running below expectations across the country. I'd say with the exception of what we're seeing in terms of acceleration in the Mid-Atlantic and the Pacific Northwest, most of the other markets are slightly below expectations in terms of job growth for this year. So given the level of supply which was anticipated and reduced job growth, that's where you see us falling short a little bit in terms of our expectations for revenue growth in the second half of the year. But in terms of the broader outlook, Tim could provide a reference -- some thoughts on that.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just to be clear, I wasn't calling for an acceleration of fundamentals. What I was saying is, we believe that the cycle is not done, and we're not actually going to see continued deceleration. We've been -- I think, the one chart showed we've been --
componenttext: Yes. Just to be clear, I wasn't calling for an acceleration of fundamentals. What I was saying is, we believe that the cycle is not done, and we're not actually going to see continued deceleration. We've been -- I think, the one chart showed we've been -- we've seen like-rent -- like-term rent change to be right in the 4% range now for the last 6 or 7 months, that's a period of time when we have seen weaker economic activity than we had anticipated. Job growth has been off about 50 basis points from what we have projected. I just think this is less economic activity and job growth, you have a little less household formation. But having said that, as we said in our management letter, we do expect rent change to be in the 3% to 4% range through the balance of the year. That is at or above trend, long-term trend. That's still very healthy rent growth for our business. So we're not necessarily calling for a reacceleration to cyclical highs, but we are not -- we don't think it's over yet. And again, it's one of the reasons why we compare it to the '90s. If you go back to the '90s and you just sort of chart what rent growth and revenue growth look like, it moved around from year-to-year based upon what was happening in that particular year from an economic activity standpoint. It does ebb and flow a bit and that's just the way economies work. We don't see the kind of distortions that you might expect to see. You see some weakness, but you don't see the kind of distortions that you might expect to see that results in a lot of dislocation and ultimately leads to negative economic growth and recession.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Appreciate the detail there. And then you kind of touched a little bit on Southern California, and I was just curious that was a market that was sort of trending ahead of the expectations earlier in the year and now you're calling for things to soften int
componenttext: Appreciate the detail there. And then you kind of touched a little bit on Southern California, and I was just curious that was a market that was sort of trending ahead of the expectations earlier in the year and now you're calling for things to soften into the second half of next year and didn't really highlight it as an outperformer versus your initial projections. Can you just give a little detail as to what's driving some of that softness into the second half of the year? And then maybe a little detail by submarket would be helpful.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, this is Sean. On that topic, basically, Southern California, as you pointed out, slightly ahead in the first half. It's basically slightly behind in the second half as a function of the macroeconomic things that we spoke about in terms of job growth
componenttext: Sure, this is Sean. On that topic, basically, Southern California, as you pointed out, slightly ahead in the first half. It's basically slightly behind in the second half as a function of the macroeconomic things that we spoke about in terms of job growth, et cetera. The supply is pretty much as expected. And so, I don't know that there is a great story in Southern California in terms of whether it's a deceleration other than the job environment. l mean, if you look at it, we had a little bit of a boost in the Los Angeles region, particularly, Stamford and [indiscernible] in the first half of the year as a result of just some one-off issue, which was a gas leak in that area that drove some initial demand in the first quarter. It boosted occupancy, but we've given that back in the second quarter. So there was a little bit of a lift in the first quarter and first half as a result of that. So that's partly reflected in a deceleration, I guess, if you want to call it, as you look to the second half relative to the first half, but it's basically performing on plan. Los Angeles is healthy. Orange County has been slightly choppy but still relatively healthy. You've got some supply coming in to Anaheim, Irvine and Huntington Beach, creates a little bit of choppiness, but for the most part, the product is being absorbed. And then san Diego just continues to perform quite well. So I don't know that there is any unusual story coming out of Southern California other than slightly lower job growth and then the sort of one-time boost that we received in the first half of the year from the gas leak that occurred.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Kris Trafton with Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: We'll go next to Kris Trafton with Crdit Suisse.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

componenttext: I'm just following up on Jordan's question. Given that we are expecting deliveries to peak this year in markets outside New York if job growth continues around 150k pays a month. Not looking for 2017 guidance, what is your thought that revenue growth could potentially bottom at the end of this year?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, just go back to my earlier comments. I think, revenue growth can move around for the balance of the cycle. I don't think -- it's very different than what we saw in 2000s, where rents went up, and then when they stopped going up, they went down. So f
componenttext: Well, just go back to my earlier comments. I think, revenue growth can move around for the balance of the cycle. I don't think -- it's very different than what we saw in 2000s, where rents went up, and then when they stopped going up, they went down. So far this cycle -- I think, you even saw in those 2 charts that we put up, one that showed the entire portfolio and one that showed the 6 regions, even after you sort of neutralize for seasonality, rents are moving around a bit even this cycle. And we're saying we think that's we're going to continue to see that a bit. Having said all that, we do see demand and supply becoming more in balance, which means we think we're going to get -- we're basically moderating -- we're moderating towards trend right now a little bit above trend.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, perfect. And then just going back to one of your slides on the job openings versus job hire slide. I mean, given the length of protection of sentiment kind of in the United States and less likely to import foreign labor and the skills gap that we ha
componenttext: Okay, perfect. And then just going back to one of your slides on the job openings versus job hire slide. I mean, given the length of protection of sentiment kind of in the United States and less likely to import foreign labor and the skills gap that we have here in the United States, do you think that, that gap between openings and hires may kind of stick around for a while? And then did you give it any thought in terms of how that may affect demand in kind of your major markets?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, it's a fair question. I mean, particularly as you get into college grads and highly skilled positions, as you mentioned, that there could be a shortage and what that does is it creates more income growth for a big part of our resident popula
componenttext: Yes. I think, it's a fair question. I mean, particularly as you get into college grads and highly skilled positions, as you mentioned, that there could be a shortage and what that does is it creates more income growth for a big part of our resident population, which is one of the things that we said we really need to have, and as the cycle gets longer that -- to help continue to kind of support, kind of rent growth that we've been seeing. So I think it's -- potentially it's a favorable trend for our business, maybe not for more broadly for the economy, but for the apartment business and the kind of markets that we're in.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Jeff Spector with Bank of America.
componenttext: We'll go next to Jeff Spector with Bank of America.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think this question was addressed, but if it was, please let me know. On the supply points you mentioned in your management letter, you talk about supply averaging approximately 2% in your markets in '16 and '17. When we look at different sources
componenttext: I don't think this question was addressed, but if it was, please let me know. On the supply points you mentioned in your management letter, you talk about supply averaging approximately 2% in your markets in '16 and '17. When we look at different sources of supply, I know it's still hard to figure out for '17, it seem like there is some differentiation between, let's say, San Fran and New York City. But based on your comment, I wasn't sure if you'd feel like San Fran is going to stay elevated into '17 because I think we were looking at stats that were showing a drop-off in, let's say, the Northern California area in '17 versus New York, it's going to persist at least through '17.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeff, this is Sean. Fair comment. I think, if you look at it based on the way we look at our markets, which is different from the U.S. overall, we are not as heavily involved in scrutinizing suppliers in those markets. But in our footprint, we are ex
componenttext: Yes, Jeff, this is Sean. Fair comment. I think, if you look at it based on the way we look at our markets, which is different from the U.S. overall, we are not as heavily involved in scrutinizing suppliers in those markets. But in our footprint, we are expecting the Northern California region decelerate slightly from '16 to '17 from about 2.5% to 2.2%. But if you look at San Francisco specifically, we're expecting it to increase again in 2017 from 3.1% of inventory in '16 to 3.4% in 2017. So you do need to look at the composition of the different markets within that region to determine what's happening. And as it relates to New York, we are expecting that to continue to be an issue through '17. As you may know, in New York, 15 deliveries were about 1.5% of inventory, it's up to about 3% now. And when you get to 2017, it's expected to peak closer to about 3.5% of inventory in the New York market.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. So in San Fran, you are expecting in '17 an increase. What's the disconnect, let's say, between what you're projecting versus, let's say, I believe you guys look at the -- I think, Axiometrics is projecting a decrease. Is it just more of the
componenttext: Okay, great. So in San Fran, you are expecting in '17 an increase. What's the disconnect, let's say, between what you're projecting versus, let's say, I believe you guys look at the -- I think, Axiometrics is projecting a decrease. Is it just more of the submarket?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think -- I can speak to as our process for the most part. And the way we do the process is a little bit top-down and bottoms-up to sort of meet in the middle with our forecast. The top-down sort of comes from other sources, whether it'd be REITs, A
componenttext: Yes, I think -- I can speak to as our process for the most part. And the way we do the process is a little bit top-down and bottoms-up to sort of meet in the middle with our forecast. The top-down sort of comes from other sources, whether it'd be REITs, Axiometrics or certain local market providers, like Delta Associates as an example here in D.C. or others in other markets. So we take that, but then we also do sort of a ground-up assessment. We have a market research team here in Arlington that scrubs all the local websites through the municipalities in our market to understand where certain deals are in their processing for entitlements and what the expected delivery dates are. In addition to that, our local development team, where we have 3 to 4 people per office around the country, is tracking all the development in their markets, as they are competing for sites and expected opportunities in their markets. And then in addition to the development teams, the last growth in our process is through the operations team where they know what's beginning to pre-lease to better predict when deliveries are expected to arrive in certain submarkets, and if we need to alter our revenue management strategy ahead of deliveries coming. So it's a pretty thorough process from a top-down and a bottoms-up perspective, as compared to just looking at the REITs data and saying that's what we expect. So I think our process is probably more robust than average, but given our capability and development, how important it is to our business, we just give a lot of scrutiny.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We completed 3 communities in the quarter and the number is going to move around based on the specific communities with geography each quarter. And the 3 we completed this past quarter, all of them performed pretty handily. One of them was on Capitol
componenttext: Yes. We completed 3 communities in the quarter and the number is going to move around based on the specific communities with geography each quarter. And the 3 we completed this past quarter, all of them performed pretty handily. One of them was on Capitol Hill in Seattle, which is our first asset in that submarket, which has just exceeded expectations, obviously, with a big runoff in rents since we started that deal 2-plus years ago. Another one was the deal in Northern New Jersey, in Union, which hadn't seen any new supply in many years. And frequently, we find a positive surprise on rents when we lease-up in communities like that. And the third one was in Irvine. So the basket moves around from quarter-to-quarter, but I think year-to-date, it's in the kind of 6.3%-ish range. So, obviously, completed the prior quarter little bit lower yielding, some of those were in -- one of those is large deal in Southern Cal, which tends to have lower yields. So it's going to generally move around, but we are continuing to see yields, obviously, beat the initial underwriting on the strength of good rent growth.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Jeff on with Andrew. Just to turn to Slide 8 of the presentation, it looks like much of the setup is like 2013 where your same-store slowed, but bottomed at 3.5%. But I'm just curious, if you take this chart, what would it look like in 2001 or 200
componenttext: This is Jeff on with Andrew. Just to turn to Slide 8 of the presentation, it looks like much of the setup is like 2013 where your same-store slowed, but bottomed at 3.5%. But I'm just curious, if you take this chart, what would it look like in 2001 or 2008 when things were about to fall off a cliff?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, I'd referenced it. They looked -- I don't know if we have this exact data series, time series certainly for 2001. But if you recall, I mean, you had a big run-up in 2000 in the apartment world. So you really had a rent spike that was driving
componenttext: Yes. I think, I'd referenced it. They looked -- I don't know if we have this exact data series, time series certainly for 2001. But if you recall, I mean, you had a big run-up in 2000 in the apartment world. So you really had a rent spike that was driving pretty phenomenal performance in 2000. And then with the [indiscernible] the elimination of -- you had 2 things going, you had elimination, obviously, of lot of technology jobs, and you had a pretty, much more dramatic expansion of monetary policy in terms of the impact on interest rates. So you had a lot more -- home ownership rates went up in the phase of recession which was unusual. So you had a lot more demand destruction in the case of rental housing than you did actually in the 2000s where you have job losses that were actually 3x what we had in the early 2000s. But we saw sort of the typical pattern where rentership rates actually went up during recession. So it's a little more -- as I mentioned earlier -- and the 2000s has little bit more of a kind of a straight up and then straight down curve to rent growth. It kind of kept going up and then until it did, and then after about 2006 into 2007, rents started to decelerate until 2008 hit us.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

componenttext: This is Matt. I guess, I'll speak to that one. Lowest cap rates are still probably Manhattan kind of core, best locations in Manhattan are probably still 3 caps. But outside of that, I would say, generally speaking, the lowest cap rates are across the Southern California right now. I don't think a lot's been trading in Northern California recently just because of the changes on the ground there. So we've been trying to buy in Southern California and it's been a little bit frustrating. Good newer product in Southern Cal into submarkets is definitely trading sub-4 cap rate. And then the rest of the markets are kind of low to mid-4s up to the mid-5s depending on where you are.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

componenttext: If I look at Page 9 of your slides where you give the rent change by market, while your markets seem like are just sort of fluctuating over a 5-year average, but the chart to look scarier there as Northern California, which looks like it's in sort of freefall since last year, but maybe reaching a bottom on your 5-year history. So what was the first half of this year like-term rent change in San Francisco? And what are you assuming for the second half of the year? And maybe you can break down the performance of the markets a bit between San Francisco versus the East Bay and San Jose.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nick, this is Sean. I waned to try to address some of those comments and we can always follow up with greater detail if you're interested. Wanting to give you a sense that in Northern California, first, give you some perspective from an overall stand
componenttext: Yes, Nick, this is Sean. I waned to try to address some of those comments and we can always follow up with greater detail if you're interested. Wanting to give you a sense that in Northern California, first, give you some perspective from an overall standpoint, rent change started the year around 6%, but it's continued to decelerate and it's currently running around 4%. And that's made up of about 2.5% in San Francisco, 6% in the East Bay and the low 4% range in San Jose. So that's kind of where we are now. If you look at -- if you want to kind of decompose that even more into the new move-ins and like-term rent change by market, wanted to get that to you separately, so we're not going to consume a lot of time on that. But I think it's fair to say that San Francisco is probably the softest at this point, so just to address that one. Rent change at this point on move-ins is essentially just barely positive, 50 basis points to 100 basis points kind of range. We continue to hold renewals sort of in the low- to mid-4% range. So you're talking about anywhere from 2.5% to 3.5% sort of numbers on a blended basis in San Francisco. Those numbers are certainly better in the East Bay and San Jose, as I mentioned currently. But in terms of it reaching the bottom and flattening out, as I mentioned in a response to a prior question, we still expect continued deliveries at a pretty heavy level in San Francisco throughout this year and then even increasing into next year. So performance -- really rent change is going to depend on the level of demand and job growth has been decelerating there. So to the extent that we see job growth level off, that would certainly help. But I think really your forecast for job growth is going to dictate performance in 2017 and whether that levels off or not. Certainly as you get beyond '17, given the nature of the product that's constructed in San Francisco, supply should start to fall off, but we do expect it to be somewhat challenging through 2017 in San Francisco specifically.

The 4% I mentioned was more kind of where we are currently, got a current market [indiscernible].

componenttext: So going back to the East Coast be in the Brooklyn development project that's underway, how is the lease-up doing? Particularly, I'm interested in the Avalon component, which I know just started leasing as the higher rent piece of the project. Any change as to how you think about concessions there and the ultimate yield on the entire project?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Sean again. Willoughby and Avalon Willoughby and Ava DoBro has been performing quite well. As you indicated, we're just starting to lease-up on the Willoughby component. But if you look at performance through the second quarter, which repres
componenttext: Sure. This is Sean again. Willoughby and Avalon Willoughby and Ava DoBro has been performing quite well. As you indicated, we're just starting to lease-up on the Willoughby component. But if you look at performance through the second quarter, which represents mainly AVA DoBro. We leased and occupied 65, 60 a month, which is quite strong and up from the first quarter which was around 39. So leasing velocity has been healthy. As I indicated, it's a little too early probably to give you great guidance about the Willoughby component. We did mark the rents up this quarter, but our expectation is that, hopefully, there will be some additional lift as we move through the second half of the year. The views are pretty spectacular at top of that building, so I'm not sure that we had seen exactly where the rents are going to settle out. But I think it's fair to say the overall project has performed quite well. In terms of the impact on yield, the only negative I can speak to is that we have had a little bit of a surprise on the property tax side that may offset some of the rent lift, but our expectation is that the yield will be essentially on par with original expectation, so hopefully slightly above.

componenttextpreview: I was hoping to talk about L.A. In my understanding of your portfolio was that you have very little exposure to downtown L.A. where there i a quite a bit of supply coming over the next couple of years. I was hoping you could speak to whether at least tang
componenttext: I was hoping to talk about L.A. In my understanding of your portfolio was that you have very little exposure to downtown L.A. where there i a quite a bit of supply coming over the next couple of years. I was hoping you could speak to whether at least tangentially there was any impact from downtown L.A. supply in some of your submarkets in the second quarter.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Drew, this is Sean. You're correct. We have one operating asset in downtown L.A. It's in Little Tokyo, a community we constructed at the earlier part of this cycle and actually have great basis there. But, yes, there is a significant amount of supply
componenttext: Yes, Drew, this is Sean. You're correct. We have one operating asset in downtown L.A. It's in Little Tokyo, a community we constructed at the earlier part of this cycle and actually have great basis there. But, yes, there is a significant amount of supply being delivered into L.A. I think it's upwards of 15% of inventory. You have to put that number in context with the fact that they're trying to create a whole new environment in downtown and it's spread across multiple submarkets within downtown L.A. But in terms of any indirect effect on the rest of the portfolio from that supply, we have not seen that. Most of the product that we own in that market is a mix of some of newer communities but also a fair amount of older communities and terrific suburban locations that are performing quite well.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

componenttext: Okay. You also mentioned markets like, I think, Huntington Beach and Irvine, for instance, that are seeing reduced amount of supply just in Southern California. What does that supply growth trajectory look like going to next year? Is there a fairly sizable deceleration of new supply? Or do you expect some continued pressure there?

componenttextpreview: L.A. and Orange County generally.
componenttext: L.A. and Orange County generally.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, L.A. and Orange County, if you look at the supply that's coming online, for the most part, we do expect continued elevated deliveries in downtown L.A. It's like 14%, 15% this year and it stays at that level through 2017. Yes, there are a coup
componenttext: Yes. I mean, L.A. and Orange County, if you look at the supply that's coming online, for the most part, we do expect continued elevated deliveries in downtown L.A. It's like 14%, 15% this year and it stays at that level through 2017. Yes, there are a couple of pockets that you're seeing in supply in L.A. is Marina Del Rey. In particular, it's one large development there at [indiscernible] bit that's delivering right now and then a couple of other submarkets. As you move down into Orange County, you do see supply fall off a little bit in Anaheim from 16 to '17. And as it relates to Irvine, Irvine is actually projected to increase as you move in to '17 as a result of some deliveries by a handful of developers but, in particular, couple of large projects that will be delivered by the Irvine company, so increase there and then a modest reduction in Huntington Beach. And then Huntington Beach is kind of 2 anchors to the supply. There is a fair amount of product being delivered right at the mall at Beach Boulevard and the 405, but there's other communities, couple of communities under development down at Pacific City which is down along down Pacific Coast Highway there in Huntington Beach. So there is not much sort of in between there, but those are the 2 sort of anchors of supply in that market. So if you look at it, overall, one thing to keep in mind for Southern California is, we're still talking about deliveries that are low 1% range of inventory overall. So you do have to be careful about which submarkets you're in. But if you look at it, the region is pretty supply constrained.

componenttext: Yes, Vince, let me just finish the speech. I mean, what happened in the first half of the year is what's really going to impact portfolio performance in the second half of the year. So that's why we're not really all that -- we are not as focused in terms of the job. What happened in the second half of the year in terms of job growth, it really played more into our 2017 outlook than the back half of 2016. You'll usually see about a 2-quarter lag impact in terms of what's happening in terms of the direction of the job growth relative to the portfolio.

componenttext: And then just another question. Just in terms of looking at the like-term effective rent changes around 4% so far this year expected to, maybe, moderate a little bit in the back half. But if we look at the first half same-store revenue growth, that's been a bit higher, maybe 100 basis points higher than that. And it looks like the July data, there is a narrowing of that gap, and I'm just curious if there is anything specific that's driving that is that folks trading down or just different lease term lengths than you've seen typically, and just any color you have on that?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, what comes to mind is really comps. I mean, the second half of the year, assuming we have more challenging comps, and it's really played out in terms of -- if you look at granular level, it really comes down to the monthly sequential change i
componenttext: Yes, I mean, what comes to mind is really comps. I mean, the second half of the year, assuming we have more challenging comps, and it's really played out in terms of -- if you look at granular level, it really comes down to the monthly sequential change in GP. And what we've seen in both like-term rent change as well as the transient and corporate component, is it's just not compounding as greater rate as it was at this time last year. So to give you some perspective as an example, if you looked at the change in GP on a monthly basis last year, we're talking about though the second quarter on a monthly basis moving up at 60 basis points in April, 100 basis points in May and about 110 basis points in June versus this year, those numbers were 30 basis points, 60 basis points and 90 basis points. Some of that is a reflection of the transient demand that we mentioned earlier, Tim alluded to in his prepared remarks, which does sort of turbocharge GP growth in the late second quarter and early third quarter that we're not seeing this year, so that's certainly part of it.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick ones for me. First, on the outperformance that's obviously helped this year's guidance number sort have been a hallmark for you guys, the 30 basis points. As fundamentals moderate, how should we be thinking about that outperformance? Is that
componenttext: Just 2 quick ones for me. First, on the outperformance that's obviously helped this year's guidance number sort have been a hallmark for you guys, the 30 basis points. As fundamentals moderate, how should we be thinking about that outperformance? Is that something that you expect to continue or eventually maybe it's not in the next 6, maybe in the next 12 months where trend is going just be delivering at your underwriting rather than exceeding?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's -- I mean, as you know, I mean, we do underwrite based upon current rents in place. As long as rents are -- continue to rise at some level, we would expect yields to continue to go up, all other things being constant, which for the most part, t
componenttext: Well, it's -- I mean, as you know, I mean, we do underwrite based upon current rents in place. As long as rents are -- continue to rise at some level, we would expect yields to continue to go up, all other things being constant, which for the most part, they are, which [indiscernible] able to bring development in close to budget. So, yes, you would expect that lift to moderate as rents might moderate. Now the 30 basis points is a little misleading. There was -- if you took out the impact of Willoughby, while Willoughby's rents went up pretty significantly, so did the taxes, as Sean had mentioned, so that actually muted the impact in terms of the yield impact. If you neutralize Willoughby, the other deals on average went up -- have gone up by 70 basis points. So almost a 10% of lift in terms of -- about a 10% lift in terms of the projected yield. So you got to look at the actual basket and some different things that may be happening with individual assets.

componenttext: Yes, Alex, this is Kevin. The $0.02 lift in expected core FFO per share coming from capital markets and transaction activity as you'd expect. It's a mix of things going on there. It's the impact of net acquisition and disposition activity both in terms of the amount and the timing as well as some changes to JV income -- I'm sorry, some changes to the debt assumptions that we got. We did pay off a piece of debt in the second quarter and had some benefit from lower interest rates being woven into the next year.

componenttext: Okay, but it's not as though -- because you guys haven't historically drawn your line -- I can't remember actually the last time you had -- you drawn on your line, but it's now that as you intended to use a more your line of credit, it's just timing of other activities, correct?

componenttext: It's timing of other activity, primarily acquisition and disposition activity, both the amount and the timing of it. So, yes, we don't expect to be a significant user of our line of credit and we haven't been throughout the year.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, John, this is Matt. We do index our target investment returns to our weighted average cost of capital assuming a 30% to 70% debt-to-equity mix. So as the cost of debt goes down, it does at the margin reduce our WACC a little bit, but frankly, it's a
componenttext: Hey, John, this is Matt. We do index our target investment returns to our weighted average cost of capital assuming a 30% to 70% debt-to-equity mix. So as the cost of debt goes down, it does at the margin reduce our WACC a little bit, but frankly, it's a lot more impacted by the equity. And we don't adjust it on a day-to-day basis. We'll adjust it maybe twice a year. What we've seen is that it's actually been pretty darn sticky over the last 4 or 5 years really through this entire cycle. So I would not -- I would say, no. In general, our target returns on development has not moved in any material way over the last, really, couple of years. We're still looking at -- and when you look at where the underwriting returns on the development rate side, they've been very consistent in that kind of mid-6 range.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And John, this is Kevin. Just to add to that, while treasury rates had certainly gone down, if you sort of look at our cost of debt for 10-year unsecured debt, last year, we averaged around 3.4%, 3.5% as you know in our May offering we executed just under
componenttext: And John, this is Kevin. Just to add to that, while treasury rates had certainly gone down, if you sort of look at our cost of debt for 10-year unsecured debt, last year, we averaged around 3.4%, 3.5% as you know in our May offering we executed just under 3%. If we were to raise due 10-year bond offering today, we'd probably be around 3% because while treasuries have fallen, spreads have widened, essentially neutralizing the treasury chain. So even over the last year, there's only been maybe a 40, 50 basis point decrease in our overall cost of debt. So when you wheel that through on a blended basis, it's 30% leverage for what Matt alluded to in the underwriting, it's a pretty modest potential impact.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Seems like it would be in a higher levered return on your development, is that a fair assessment?
componenttext: Seems like it would be in a higher levered return on your development, is that a fair assessment?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure if I followed. We underwrite yields on an unlevered basis. And so what we do is we -- in our yield matrix, the component that Matt was alluding that ties to our short-term cost of capital looks at our unlevered initial short-term cost to capi
componenttext: I'm not sure if I followed. We underwrite yields on an unlevered basis. And so what we do is we -- in our yield matrix, the component that Matt was alluding that ties to our short-term cost of capital looks at our unlevered initial short-term cost to capital, which describes 30% weighting to debt, 70% weighting to equity. And so we end up as having essentially an unlevered or neutralized number there from a leverage point of view. So we don't look at yields on a levered basis.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Quick question for me on the development side of the equation. I'm curious how much of the job occupancy, sort of job openings that you're seeing are driven by construction? And if that's having any pressures on construction costs and then that would ulti
componenttext: Quick question for me on the development side of the equation. I'm curious how much of the job occupancy, sort of job openings that you're seeing are driven by construction? And if that's having any pressures on construction costs and then that would ultimately impact development yields? I know you mentioned development yields were probably going to be stable, but I'm curious if you're seeing rising construction costs regarding -- driven primarily by wage growth on that side.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it has been driven mostly by labor, not by materials for sure and that's been a mix, I would imagine of both profitability and labor costs. If you look at the different sort of wage indices out there, construction labor is towards the top, if not at
componenttext: Well, it has been driven mostly by labor, not by materials for sure and that's been a mix, I would imagine of both profitability and labor costs. If you look at the different sort of wage indices out there, construction labor is towards the top, if not at the very top in terms of year-over-year wage growth. So it's an industry that has seen a lot of skilled labor leave over the last cycle or 2. And it's a challenge to get skilled labor in lot of these sites. And when you think about the production level, not just of apartments, but just housing and all -- kind of all real estate categories, the level of construction is still not that high, and yes, it's a real challenge for the industry right now. I think a lot of that just has to do with the shortage of skilled labor.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And you're pretty comfortable that development yields will remain stable despite that?
componenttext: Got it. And you're pretty comfortable that development yields will remain stable despite that?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we continue to -- whenever we look at new opportunities as well as existing opportunities, we continue to sort of reunderwrite them, as we continue to invest pursued cost of capital and make sure it's something we want to continue to invest what we
componenttext: Well, we continue to -- whenever we look at new opportunities as well as existing opportunities, we continue to sort of reunderwrite them, as we continue to invest pursued cost of capital and make sure it's something we want to continue to invest what we think is sort of the highest risk capital of any deal, which is that entitlement and design that pursued cost capital, if you will. So the kind of yields that you see on the schedule and the release  that's -- they're consistent with the kind of yields we see in the Development Right pipeline.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's clearly -- I mean, part of why we've been able to replenish our Development Right pipeline, I think, is connected to that. We are seeing more deal flow. I think there are -- if a developer has 3 or 4 deals, they may be looking to lay off one of th
componenttext: There's clearly -- I mean, part of why we've been able to replenish our Development Right pipeline, I think, is connected to that. We are seeing more deal flow. I think there are -- if a developer has 3 or 4 deals, they may be looking to lay off one of them in terms of land and that's probably a function somewhat of the kind of the reception that they're getting with some of their key lending partners. But across the board, you're definitely hearing from both banks, the suppliers of capital as well as the consumers of capital developers that construction financing is less plentiful.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

componenttext: Just a quick question. Could you talk about rent to income ratios in many of your key markets, and if you think that's a contributing factor to -- or rent fatigue is a contributing factor to some of the slowdown in the rent growth we're seeing. Just wanted to get a sense of how much of this stuff really is supply related versus how much is demand-related?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Tayo, it's Sean. Yes, rent to income ratios are running around 23% right now, so certainly at the higher end of long-term averages, if you to think of it that way. We are seeing income growth. Income growth In the portfolio and households that moved
componenttext: Sure, Tayo, it's Sean. Yes, rent to income ratios are running around 23% right now, so certainly at the higher end of long-term averages, if you to think of it that way. We are seeing income growth. Income growth In the portfolio and households that moved-in in the second quarter was up a couple of hundred basis points year-over-year. In terms of rent fatigue, if you look at the portfolio in terms of reasons for move-out, it's actually come down. If you look at rent increases as a percentage of move-outs, it was running closer to 20% last year. It's running about 17% right now. And as you might have imagined, it's come down a fair bit in markets like New York and Northern California. So we are starting to see pretty good signs of wage growth across the economy and in our portfolio. And as you've seen some deceleration in rental rate growth in some of these markets, there is just not as much pressure there as there was during 2015, as an example.

componenttext: No, not really. It is -- what I mentioned is it relates to rent increases being down year-over-year, for the most part, it's been pretty stable at the portfolio level. And I wouldn't say there is any significant highlights even at the regional level at this point. So what should expect for the most part, relocation and stoplist about 23% to 25% of move-outs. Rent increases, as I mentioned, running around 17% and then the home purchases are running at 13%,  actually down 50 basis points year-over-year and still well below long-term averages, so just a little bit of movement upward in a couple of markets, but it's not really moving much in terms of home purchases.

componenttext: Yes, Wes, it's a little hard to quantify and I'll tell you why. It's easy to quantify some of the direct effects on the short-term component, in particular, so to give you an example. If the percentage of leases that are short term is down, say, 50 basis points specifically could indiscernible] 50% premium on that, plus about 25 incremental basis points of GP growth during that period of time, what's hard to quantify is the indirect effect of having that inventory back into the market. So it's hard to say exactly what the impact is for the full year because of those various assumptions you'd have to make. So it's fairly easy to quantify the 3 or 4 months, which we could certainly talk to you about offline but the broader impact is hard to quantify.

Is there anything there that you've been able to discern on the Airbnb front within your portfolio?

componenttext: Not necessarily, Michael. I mean, we do stay connected with Airbnb and they provide us information on leasing activity in our apartment homes. Based on the last report that I saw, there was not a material shift. Some of the stuff that we see is really -- you have to dissect it at a very granular level to understand it. So, for example, in New England, Boston, specifically, there were some pretty good winter storms last couple of years. When we underwrite things, we sort of look at an average year, this year was a better-than-average year, so there was less transient demand from insurance claims where people that had damage in their homes during the winter. It gets to that level of granularity in terms of understanding that demand. So I've not seen anything regarding Airbnb at this point so.

componenttext: And then when you think about the -- so this captures about 6% of the lease volume of your rent roll between the corporate leasing in the short term, so the balance, call it about 94%. I'm just curious whether you can share any light on the 94% relative to the 6% you show here.

componenttextpreview: Yes, we do dissect the data in terms of percentage that are single, single with children, married, married with kids, roommates, et cetera. There's not been a significant movement in those numbers. It's a large population, so you'd really have to see in a
componenttext: Yes, we do dissect the data in terms of percentage that are single, single with children, married, married with kids, roommates, et cetera. There's not been a significant movement in those numbers. It's a large population, so you'd really have to see in absolute sense, quite a bit of movement to move the needle here. The reason we brought this up is the premiums are so significant on the short-term leases that it can have an impact. Again, when you're talking about a 50% premium, even if it's 1% of your leases or 50 basis points or 0.5% of your leases, then it can have a significant impact on GP in any given month. So that's why we highlighted this one in particular and the same thing in the corporates.
