componenttext: Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill has the next question.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick ones from me. First, on the outperformance that's obviously helped this year's guidance number, sort have been a hallmark for you guys, the 30 basis points. As fundamentals moderate, how should we be thinking about that outperformance? Is tha
componenttext: Just 2 quick ones from me. First, on the outperformance that's obviously helped this year's guidance number, sort have been a hallmark for you guys, the 30 basis points. As fundamentals moderate, how should we be thinking about that outperformance? Is that something that you expect to continue or eventually, maybe if not in the next 6, maybe in the next 12 months where trend is going you'll just be delivering at your underwriting rather than exceeding?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's -- I mean, as you know, I mean, we do underwrite based upon current rents in place. As long as rents are -- continue to rise at some level, we would expect yields to continue to go up, all other things being constant, which for the most part, t
componenttext: Well, it's -- I mean, as you know, I mean, we do underwrite based upon current rents in place. As long as rents are -- continue to rise at some level, we would expect yields to continue to go up, all other things being constant, which for the most part, they are, we've generally been able to bring development in close to budget. So, yes, you would expect that lift to moderate as rents might moderate. Now the 30 basis points is a little misleading. There was -- if you took out the impact of Willoughby, while Willoughby's rents went up pretty significantly, so did the taxes, as Sean had mentioned, so that actually muted the impact in terms of the yield impact. If you neutralize Willoughby, the other deals on average went up -- have gone up by 70 basis points. So almost a 10% lift in terms of -- about a 10% lift in terms of the projected yield. So you got to look at the actual basket and some different things that may be happening with individual assets.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful, Tim. And then the second is, maybe Kevin, can you just provide a little bit color. I don't think you addressed it earlier, but in the guidance provision, you're getting a lift from capital markets and transaction activity at $0.02 positive
componenttext: That's helpful, Tim. And then the second is, maybe Kevin, can you just provide a little bit color. I don't think you addressed it earlier, but in the guidance provision, you're getting a lift from capital markets and transaction activity at $0.02 positive variance versus your original outlook. Can you just provide a little bit more color on what's going in there, what's changed in your thinking of those 2 items to give you that positive benefit?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Alex, this is Kevin. The $0.02 lift in expected core FFO per share coming from capital markets and transaction activity is, as you'd expect, it's a mix of things going on there. It's the impact of net acquisition and disposition activity both in term
componenttext: Yes, Alex, this is Kevin. The $0.02 lift in expected core FFO per share coming from capital markets and transaction activity is, as you'd expect, it's a mix of things going on there. It's the impact of net acquisition and disposition activity both in terms of the amount and the timing as well as some changes to JV income -- I'm sorry, some changes to the debt assumptions that we've got. We did pay off a piece of debt in the second quarter and had some benefit from lower interest rates being woven into the mix here.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, but it's not as though -- because you guys haven't historically drawn your line -- I can't remember actually the last time you had something drawn on your line, but it's now that you intended to use more of your line of credit, it's just timing of o
componenttext: Okay, but it's not as though -- because you guys haven't historically drawn your line -- I can't remember actually the last time you had something drawn on your line, but it's now that you intended to use more of your line of credit, it's just timing of other activities, correct?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's timing of other activity, primarily acquisition and disposition activity, both the amount and the timing of it. So, yes, we don't expect to be a significant user of our line of credit, and we haven't been throughout the year.
componenttext: It's timing of other activity, primarily acquisition and disposition activity, both the amount and the timing of it. So, yes, we don't expect to be a significant user of our line of credit, and we haven't been throughout the year.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to John Kim with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll go next to John Kim with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up on commentary of concessions on stabilized assets. Can you just quantify what percentage of your stabilized portfolio you're offering 3 months rent and maybe compare that to last year?
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up on commentary of concessions on stabilized assets. Can you just quantify what percentage of your stabilized portfolio you're offering 3 months rent and maybe compare that to last year?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Percentage of the portfolio offering free rent, I'm not sure I have that. I think we can certainly get that back to you. But to give you some sense in terms of absolute dollars on a year-over-year basis in the second quarter, cash concessions in the secon
componenttext: Percentage of the portfolio offering free rent, I'm not sure I have that. I think we can certainly get that back to you. But to give you some sense in terms of absolute dollars on a year-over-year basis in the second quarter, cash concessions in the second quarter of '15 were about $75,000 versus the second quarter of this year were around $300,000 and the greatest increases were in the New England, New York and Northern California markets.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And when you discussed 3% to 4% like-term rental growth in the second half of this year, is that on an effective or nominal basis?
componenttext: And when you discussed 3% to 4% like-term rental growth in the second half of this year, is that on an effective or nominal basis?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's effective. That's a net effective number.
componenttext: It's effective. That's a net effective number.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. With your cost of debt declining, have you changed your underwriting hurdles at all on your development pipeline as far as deals or IRR?
componenttext: Okay. With your cost of debt declining, have you changed your underwriting hurdles at all on your development pipeline as far as deals or IRR?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, John, this is Matt. We do index our target investment returns to our weighted average cost of capital assuming a 30% to 70% debt-to-equity mix. So as the cost of debt goes down, it does, at the margin, reduce our WACC a little bit, but frankly, it's
componenttext: Hey, John, this is Matt. We do index our target investment returns to our weighted average cost of capital assuming a 30% to 70% debt-to-equity mix. So as the cost of debt goes down, it does, at the margin, reduce our WACC a little bit, but frankly, it's a lot more impacted by the equity. And we don't adjust it on a day-to-day basis. We'll adjust it maybe twice a year. What we've seen is that it's actually been pretty darn sticky over the last 4 or 5 years really through this entire cycle. So I would not -- I would say no, in general, our target returns on development has not moved in any material way over the last, really, couple of years. We're still looking at -- and when you look at where the underwriting returns on the development rights are, they've been very consistent in that kind of mid-6 range.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And John, this is Kevin. Just to add to that, while treasury rates have certainly gone down, if you sort of look at our cost of debt for 10-year unsecured debt, last year, we averaged around 3.4%, 3.5%. As you know in our May offering we executed just und
componenttext: And John, this is Kevin. Just to add to that, while treasury rates have certainly gone down, if you sort of look at our cost of debt for 10-year unsecured debt, last year, we averaged around 3.4%, 3.5%. As you know in our May offering we executed just under 3%. If we were to raise -- do a 10-year bond offering today, we'd probably be around 3%, because while treasuries have fallen, spreads have widened, essentially neutralizing the treasury chain. So even over the last year, there's only been maybe a 40, 50 basis point decrease in our overall cost of debt. So when you weave that through on a blended basis, it's 30% leverage for what Matt alluded to in the underwriting, it's a pretty modest potential impact.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Seems like it would be in a higher levered return though on your development, is that a fair assessment?
componenttext: Seems like it would be in a higher levered return though on your development, is that a fair assessment?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure if I follow. We underwrite yields on an unlevered basis. And so what we do is we -- in our yield matrix, the component that Matt was alluding to that ties to our short-term cost of capital looks at our unlevered initial short-term cost to cap
componenttext: I'm not sure if I follow. We underwrite yields on an unlevered basis. And so what we do is we -- in our yield matrix, the component that Matt was alluding to that ties to our short-term cost of capital looks at our unlevered initial short-term cost to capital, which ascribes 30% weighting to debt, 70% weighting to equity. And so we end up as having essentially an unlevered or a neutralized number there from a leverage point of view. So we don't look at yields on a levered basis.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Richard Hill with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll go next to Richard Hill with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Quick question for me on the development side of the equation. I'm curious how much of the job occupancy, sort of job openings that you're seeing are driven by construction? And if that's having any pressures on construction costs and then that would ulti
componenttext: Quick question for me on the development side of the equation. I'm curious how much of the job occupancy, sort of job openings that you're seeing are driven by construction? And if that's having any pressures on construction costs and then that would ultimately impact development yields? I know you mentioned development yields were probably going to be stable, but I'm curious if you're seeing rising construction costs regarding -- driven primarily by wage growth on that side.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it has been driven mostly by labor, not by materials for sure and that's been a mix, I would imagine, of both profitability and labor costs. If you look at the different sort of wage indices out there, construction labor is towards the top, if not a
componenttext: Well, it has been driven mostly by labor, not by materials for sure and that's been a mix, I would imagine, of both profitability and labor costs. If you look at the different sort of wage indices out there, construction labor is towards the top, if not at the very top in terms of year-over-year wage growth. So it's an industry that has seen a lot of skilled labor leave over the last cycle or 2. And it's a challenge to get good skilled labor at lot of these sites. And when you think about the production level, not just of apartments, but just housing and all -- kind of all real estate categories, the level of construction is still not that high, and yes, it's a real challenge for the industry right now. I think a lot of that just has to do with a shortage of skilled labor.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And you're pretty comfortable that development yields will remain stable despite that?
componenttext: Got it. And you're pretty comfortable that development yields will remain stable despite that?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we continue to -- whenever we look at new opportunities as well as existing opportunities, we continue to sort of reunderwrite them, as we continue to invest pursued cost of capital and make sure it's something we want to continue to invest what we
componenttext: Well, we continue to -- whenever we look at new opportunities as well as existing opportunities, we continue to sort of reunderwrite them, as we continue to invest pursued cost of capital and make sure it's something we want to continue to invest what we think is sort of the highest risk capital of any deal, which is that entitlement and design, that pursuit cost capital, if you will. So the kind of yields that you see on the schedule and the release  that's -- they're consistent with the kind of yields we see in the Development Right pipeline.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just one more quick question on the financing side. Are you actually seeing guys pull back or developers pull back because they haven't been able to get the construction financing that they see or that they used to see?
componenttext: Great. And then just one more quick question on the financing side. Are you actually seeing guys pull back or developers pull back because they haven't been able to get the construction financing that they see or that they used to see?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's clearly -- I mean, part of why we've been able to replenish our Development Right pipeline, I think, is connected to that. We are seeing more deal flow. I think there are -- if a developer has 3 or 4 deals, they may be looking to lay off one of th
componenttext: There's clearly -- I mean, part of why we've been able to replenish our Development Right pipeline, I think, is connected to that. We are seeing more deal flow. I think there are -- if a developer has 3 or 4 deals, they may be looking to lay off one of them in terms of land and that's probably a function somewhat of the kind of the reception that they're getting with some of their key lending partners. But across the board, you're definitely hearing from both banks, the suppliers of capital as well as the consumers of capital developers, that construction financing is less plentiful.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Tayo Okusanya with Jefferies.
componenttext: We'll go next to Tayo Okusanya with Jefferies.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question. Could you talk about rent to income ratios in many of your key markets, and if you think that's a contributing factor to -- or rent fatigue is a contributing factor to some of the slowdown in rent growth we're seeing. Just wanted to
componenttext: Just a quick question. Could you talk about rent to income ratios in many of your key markets, and if you think that's a contributing factor to -- or rent fatigue is a contributing factor to some of the slowdown in rent growth we're seeing. Just wanted to get a sense of how much of this stuff really is supply related versus how much is demand-related?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Tayo, it's Sean. Yes, rent to income ratios are running around 23% right now, so certainly at the higher end of long-term averages, if you to think of it that way. We are seeing income growth. Income growth In the portfolio and households that moved
componenttext: Sure, Tayo, it's Sean. Yes, rent to income ratios are running around 23% right now, so certainly at the higher end of long-term averages, if you to think of it that way. We are seeing income growth. Income growth In the portfolio and households that moved-in in the second quarter was up a couple of hundred basis points year-over-year. In terms of rent fatigue, if you look at the portfolio in terms of reasons for move-outs, it's actually come down. If you look at rent increases as a percentage of move-outs, it was running closer to 20% last year. It's running about 17% right now. And as you might have imagined, it's come down a fair bit in markets like New York and Northern California. So we are starting to see pretty good signs of wage growth across the economy and in our portfolio. And as you've seen some deceleration in rental rate growth in some of these markets, there is just not as much pressure there as there was during 2015, as an example.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll go next to Wes Golladay with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go next to Wes Golladay with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Looking at the reasons to move out, have you noticed any changes that are material?
componenttext: Looking at the reasons to move out, have you noticed any changes that are material?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, not really. It is -- what I mentioned is it relates to rent increases being down year-over-year. For the most part it's been pretty stable at the portfolio level, and I wouldn't say there is any significant highlights even at the regional level at thi
componenttext: No, not really. It is -- what I mentioned is it relates to rent increases being down year-over-year. For the most part it's been pretty stable at the portfolio level, and I wouldn't say there is any significant highlights even at the regional level at this point. So it's what you should expect for the most part, relocation tends to top the list, about 23% to 25% of move-outs. Rent increases, as I mentioned, running around 17% and then home purchases are running at 13%, so actually down about 50 basis points year-over-year and still well below long-term averages, so just a little bit of movement upward in a couple of markets, but it's not really moving much in terms of home purchases.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and looking at Exhibit 7, how much did that impact or the lower corporate and transient demand impact the overall same-store number for the year when we factor in 2Q and 3Q?
componenttext: Okay, and looking at Exhibit 7, how much did that impact or the lower corporate and transient demand impact the overall same-store number for the year when we factor in 2Q and 3Q?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Wes, it's a little hard to quantify and I'll tell you why. It's easy to quantify some of the direct effect on the short-term component, in particular, so to give you an example: If the percentage of leases that are short term is down, say, 50 basis p
componenttext: Yes, Wes, it's a little hard to quantify and I'll tell you why. It's easy to quantify some of the direct effect on the short-term component, in particular, so to give you an example: If the percentage of leases that are short term is down, say, 50 basis points specifically could, get a 50% premium on that, you lost about 25 incremental basis points of GP growth during that period of time. What's hard to quantify is the indirect effect of having that inventory back into the market. So it's hard to say exactly what the impact is for the full year because of those various assumptions you'd have to make. So it's fairly easy to quantify the 3 or 4 months, which we could certainly talk to you about offline but the broader impact is hard to quantify.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And was that pretty broad based by region, both the corporate and transient? Or is it just isolated to the East Coast where leasing was a little bit softer?
componenttext: Okay. And was that pretty broad based by region, both the corporate and transient? Or is it just isolated to the East Coast where leasing was a little bit softer?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, the corporate component was pretty widespread, probably slightly more pronounced in New York, as an example. And then on the transient piece, also relatively widespread, but more acute in New England.
componenttext: No, the corporate component was pretty widespread, probably slightly more pronounced in New York, as an example. And then on the transient piece, also relatively widespread, but more acute in New England.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Nick Joseph with Citi.
componenttext: We'll go next to Nick Joseph with Citi.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Michael Bilerman with Nick. I'm curious, just sticking with that Slide 7, as you think about -- I don't know whether you track this or not, but were there any change in sort of Airbnb type rentals? Were renters in your apartments accelerating the lis
componenttext: It's Michael Bilerman with Nick. I'm curious, just sticking with that Slide 7, as you think about -- I don't know whether you track this or not, but were there any change in sort of Airbnb type rentals? Were renters in your apartments accelerating the listing of their apartments or scaling that back as a way to maybe generate income to offset some of the rent expense? Is there anything there that you've been able to discern on the Airbnb front within your portfolio?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not necessarily, Michael. I mean, we do stay connected with Airbnb and they provide us information on leasing activity in our apartment homes. Based on the last report that I saw, there was not a material shift. Some of the stuff that we see is really --
componenttext: Not necessarily, Michael. I mean, we do stay connected with Airbnb and they provide us information on leasing activity in our apartment homes. Based on the last report that I saw, there was not a material shift. Some of the stuff that we see is really -- you have to dissect it at a very granular level to understand it. So, for example, in New England, Boston, specifically, there were some pretty good winter storms last couple of years. When we underwrite things, we sort of look at an average year, this year was a better-than-average year, so there was less transient demand from insurance claims for people that had damage in their homes during the winter. It gets to that level of granularity in terms of understanding that demand. So I've not seen anything regarding Airbnb at this point though.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then when you think about the -- so this captures about 6% of the lease volume of your rent roll between the corporate leasing in the short term, so the balance, call it about 94%. Is there other categories that we should be you mindful of that are ei
componenttext: And then when you think about the -- so this captures about 6% of the lease volume of your rent roll between the corporate leasing in the short term, so the balance, call it about 94%. Is there other categories that we should be you mindful of that are either accelerating or deceleration? I don't know how granular you get between students, singles, couples, couples with children and how you dissect all of the data. I'm just curious whether you can share any light on the 94% relative to the 6% you show here.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we do dissect the data in terms of percentage that are single, single with children, married, married with kids, roommates, et cetera. There's not been a significant movement in those numbers. It's a large population, so you'd really have to see, in
componenttext: Yes, we do dissect the data in terms of percentage that are single, single with children, married, married with kids, roommates, et cetera. There's not been a significant movement in those numbers. It's a large population, so you'd really have to see, in absolute sense, quite a bit of movement to move the needle here. The reason we brought this up is the premiums are so significant on the short-term leases that it can have an impact. Again, when you're talking about a 50% premium, even if it's 1% of your leases or 50 basis points or 0.5% of your leases, then it can have a significant impact on GP in any given month. So that's why we highlighted this one in particular and the same thing in the corporates.

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And is there any change in terms of the number of people occupying a home over time that may indicate any shift in terms of affordability that would be noticeable?
componenttext: And is there any change in terms of the number of people occupying a home over time that may indicate any shift in terms of affordability that would be noticeable?

headline: Avalonbay Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have not seen that today, no.
componenttext: We have not seen that today, no.

componenttext: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to AvalonBay Communities Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] Your host for today's conference call is Mr. Jason Reilley, Senior Director of Investor Relations. Mr. Reilley, you may begin your conference.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jessica, and welcome to AvalonBay Communities Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Before we begin, please note that forward-looking statements may be made during this discussion. There are a variety of risks and uncertainties associated w
componenttext: Thanks, Jessica, and welcome to AvalonBay Communities Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Before we begin, please note that forward-looking statements may be made during this discussion. There are a variety of risks and uncertainties associated with the forward-looking statements, and actual results may differ materially. There is a discussion of these risks and uncertainties in yesterday afternoon's press release, as well as in the company's Form 10-K and Form 10-Q filed with the SEC. As usual, this press release does include an attachment with definitions and reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures and other terms which may be used in today's discussion. The attachment is also available on our website at www.avalonbay.com/earnings. And we encourage you to refer to this information during the review of our operating results and financial performance. And with that, I'll turn the call over to Tim Naughton, Chairman and CEO of AvalonBay Communities, for his remarks. Tim?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Jason. And welcome to our third quarter call. With me today are Kevin O'Shea, Sean Breslin and Matt Birenbaum. I will be providing management commentary in the slides that we posted yesterday after the market closed, and all of this will be a
componenttext:
Yes. Thanks, Jason. And welcome to our third quarter call. With me today are Kevin O'Shea, Sean Breslin and Matt Birenbaum. I will be providing management commentary in the slides that we posted yesterday after the market closed, and all of this will be available for Q&A afterwards. 
My comments will focus on providing a summary of Q3, year-to-date results, our outlook for 2016, a look at fundamentals, and lastly, an update on investment activity and a look back on our capital allocation track record. 
So let's start on Slide 4. 
It was a solid quarter, where we achieved quite core FFO growth of 7.3% from a combination of same store NOI growth of over 4% and healthy contributions continuing from new lease-ups. Year-to-date core FFO per share is up over 9%. And in Q3, we raised over $1 billion in new capital, including the October bond deal and disposition activity, to fund ongoing, and the upcoming development and to pay off maturing debt. 
Turning to Slide 5 in our updated outlook for the year. 
We have updated our outlook for FFO and same-store metrics. Our core FFO per share has been reduced by $0.05 per share or 70 basis points for the full year to 8.3%, due to a combination of factors, including same-store revenue growth being trimmed by around 12 basis points from our midyear forecast from a mix of lower projected occupancy and rate for Q4. Secondly, a higher same-store operating expenses, related primarily to higher utility costs and delayed resolution of several tax appeals. Thirdly, lower redevelopment NOI. And lastly, a higher interest rate -- a higher interest related costs in connection with our recent $650 million bond deal that we completed earlier this month. 
Turning now to Slide 6. We thought we'd spend a couple of minutes on fundamentals that are shaping portfolio performance and the overall outlook for the apartment sector. 
GDP and job growth, as many of you know, continued to decelerate. GDP growth has been below 1.5% now for the last 3 quarters, while job growth is running more than 20% less than its cyclical peak and well off last year's pace so far year-to-date. Lower corporate profits and business confidence is resulting in less investment in labor and capital as businesses appear reluctant to make new commitments. 
Turning to Slide 7. 
While businesses are slowing down, the consumer appears to still be in good shape, and the labor market continues to tighten with more job openings helping to contribute to an improved wage picture. Consumers balance sheets are in the best space in many years. And these trends are contributing to a cyclically high consumer confidence, which in turn is helping to drive stronger household formation, which is running north of 1 million per year after lingering at generational lows earlier this cycle. 
Turning to Slide 8. 
Longer-term, secular trends should continue to support apartment demand. You adult job growth is outpacing the U.S. average, driven obviously by a strong growth in this. This generation is marrying and having children later. And unsurprisingly, we have seen a strongest household formation for singles and couples as one and 2-person households have been responsible for more than 80% of all net new households formed so far this cycle. 
Homeownership rates have in turn continued to fall through the segment, helping to stimulate healthy apartment demand in this cycle. While the leading edge of millennials are now in their mid-30s, the largest part of this generation are still in their mid-20s and are expected to stimulate renter demand for several years. 
So overall, despite slower economic activity, demand fundamentals are still healthy for the housing market in general and for the apartment sector specifically. 
Turning to Slide 9. Let's take a look at what the these trends mean for our market. 
So far this cycle, from 2010 to 2015, we have benefited from a significant imbalance between demand and supply. This slide looks at this in a couple of ways. On the left, we look at the broader housing picture as household formation specifically outpace housing starts during this period. And on the right, job growth outpaced new apartment deliveries by roughly 2x. So in the first part of the cycle, through 2015, demand has run well above supply and apartment rents have grown well above the long-term trend. 
Going forward, over the next 2 to 3 years, and you see from the right-hand side of both of these charts, through 2018, we expect demand and supply to be more imbalanced, reflecting an industry moving toward equilibrium after years of significant outperformance. 
Turning to Slide 10. 
That notion is certainly reflected in recent rent performance across our markets and in our same-store portfolio. Overall, market rent growth according to Axiometrics has declined from around 5% to 2% to 3% over the last 4 to 5 quarters. Similarly, in our same-store portfolio, we've seen same unit rent growth declined from over 6% to 3% to 4% range during that same time, where the levels that are closer to historical average. 
Turning to Slide 11. And double clicking through on our portfolio a bit here, you can see a couple of other trends. 
First, we are seeing convergence in performance between East and West, as the differentials and rent growth have narrowed by around 300 basis points over the last year, driven mainly by a deceleration in Northern California and some improvement in the mid-Atlantic. And second, and as we've been discussing in recent quarters, rent growth in the suburbs continues to outpace that in urban submarkets by around 200 basis points given this concentration of the new supply in urban centers. 
Let's turn now to investment activity and to Slide 12. 
Lease up performance continues to be strong as rents are roughly 200 basis points above[ph]  pro forma and yields are 30 basis points higher. And if yields are well above prevailing cap rates and our marginal cost of capital, new development is contributing meaningfully to NAV and earnings growth well into the current cycle.
Turning to Slide 13. 
And as discussed a couple of quarters ago, this really has been the case during our life as a public company. This slide depicts development performance across various phases of the cycles since 1995. The strongest performance generally occurs during the expansion phase for sure, but has been healthy even when new development has delivered into the downturn. We believe this speaks to our capability in this area and our disciplined approach to allocating capital to this activity. 
Turning now to Slide 14. 
In addition, we continued to be disciplined in how we capitalize new development commitments. Excluding the benefit of any free cash flow or retained earnings we may enjoy, we are still currently 85% match funded against our $3.1 billion pipeline, that is we've already raised most of the permanent capital for this bucket of assets well in advance of it producing operating cash flow. So as this development stabilizes, it will add meaningfully to future growth and free cash flow. 
Turning to Slide 15, and shifting gears a bit. We thought it might be helpful to briefly review our capital allocation track record over our life as a public company. 
What we understand that there's a lot of focus right now in moderating fundamentals and the impacts on portfolio performance. We are investing in long-lived assets with an aim to deliver outside total returns over the long run. 
As you can see on this chart, over the last 20-plus years, we've been able to generate strong investment and returns with an unlevered IRRs of around 13%. A few points worth noting here. First, we've been able to deliver healthy returns, double-digit IRRs across all of our regions. Second, we generated strong IRRs across both urban and the suburban submarkets. Third, we generated the highest returns in markets where we have the longest tenure, the mid-Atlantic and Northern California. And our business tenure matters in terms of market intelligence, experience, reputation and relationships. And lastly, while these returns represent a mix of unrealized or projected returns and realized returns, the average is consistent with what has been realized through our dispositions over the last 10 years, as shown on the Attachment 12 of this release. 
Now lastly, turning to Slide 16. 
This long-term track record has certainly extended to the current cycle. So far, this cycle, we have delivered around $4.5 billion of new development at yields that have generated initial NAV accretion of around $2 billion and healthier earnings accretion, contributing to annual compounded growth and core FFO of almost 13% over the last 6 years, a period of time when core FFO per share has more than doubled and dividends have grown by more than 50%. 
So in summary, while we are seeing some moderation in fundamentals, it appears that we are settling into a period of equilibrium as the economic expansion plays out. Of course, the submarkets and some markets will outperform, while others might lag, but overall, demand and supply seemed to be roughly in balance and projected to remain that way over the next 2 to 3 years. And as we move into the later stages of a very healthy apartment cycle, we continued to exercise a disciplined approach to capital allocation, both in how we raise and deploy capital. And that should allow us to generate solid earnings and NAV growth that will help us outperform. 
And with that, Jessica, we'd be happy to open the call for some questions.

componenttext: And then my final question here concerns development. And just a general question I guess, how are you guys feeling about the development pipeline today? And has any of your assumptions changed in terms of how you're underwriting the projected yields on the overall pipeline or the things that you're starting in the near term?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, this is Matt. Yes, no, we are expecting a lot of historic volume here in the fourth quarter. It was always really in the plan that the starts were going to be backloaded this year. And it's really just a function of when those deals work their way t
componenttext: Rich, this is Matt. Yes, no, we are expecting a lot of historic volume here in the fourth quarter. It was always really in the plan that the starts were going to be backloaded this year. And it's really just a function of when those deals work their way through the system and are ready to start, so we haven't -- I wouldn't say our view has changed in any material way in terms of the attractiveness or the profitability of the development platform. We're still adding new development rights through the course of the year. They're still kind at the same current economics. Again, we underwrite the kind of today's rents and costs and expenses that don't really trend, but we're still seeing, on average, our development rights pipeline underwriting to about a mid 6s[ph] yield, some variation by region, but that's been pretty consistent really for the last several years. The only thing that's really potentially changed is just different deals will move around quarter-to-quarter. So whether we wind up with this historic volume through the total unit that we expected at the beginning of the year, probably just depends on what happens with the Columbus Circle deal and whether that starts this quarter or it may slip into the first quarter of next year.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. I guess I mean one follow-up there. Just simply to the extent that the current environment has deteriorated over the course of 2016, I think where we might be a little bit confused is just how some of the assumptions haven't changed much. I mea
componenttext: All right. I guess I mean one follow-up there. Just simply to the extent that the current environment has deteriorated over the course of 2016, I think where we might be a little bit confused is just how some of the assumptions haven't changed much. I mean is that just a function of underwriting rents versus the basis that you guys have locked in, or is it -- are we misinterpreting kind of the way the numbers move there?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Rich, this is Tim. I mean rents are continuing to increase in our markets generally, and it's a function of how it interplays with construction costs for sure. We are seeing some moderation in some market on construction costs now. Land costs, as yo
componenttext: Well, Rich, this is Tim. I mean rents are continuing to increase in our markets generally, and it's a function of how it interplays with construction costs for sure. We are seeing some moderation in some market on construction costs now. Land costs, as you know, has locked in. So in terms of overall economics on a current basis, as Matt mentioned, we haven't seen a big change. We probably the deals that completed this quarter that stabilizes in 6[ph] core [indiscernible] we've got about $2.5 billion there under construction that we still estimate 6 core and that's what most of that pipeline not remarked to market yet, which we would anticipate that would graph and then just the deals we've been putting under our contract in 2016, which probably has been a little bit of a surprise that they have been as attractive as we -- from an economic standpoint as they've been are kind of consistent with those kinds of returns. So the assumptions are always based upon what we're seeing in the markets today. And I think that's what Matt in terms of our underlying assumptions haven't changed in terms of how they're derived.

componenttext: Sean, you mentioned the increase to same-store expense growth is driven by utilities and the delay in tax appeals. Could you talk about what's driving the growth of the more controllable expenses? It looks like payroll, R&M and office operations were up this quarter.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Nick, this is Sean. Why don't I give you an overview of the change from the mid-year guidance that we provided as compared to what we provided last night, if that's helpful. But the growth has changed, if you look at, call it the combined third quart
componenttext: Yes. Nick, this is Sean. Why don't I give you an overview of the change from the mid-year guidance that we provided as compared to what we provided last night, if that's helpful. But the growth has changed, if you look at, call it the combined third quarter and fourth quarter or back half of the year, it represents around $2.6 million, $2.7 million. About 1/3 of that is timing related. And the majority of that ties to the 3 tax appeals in L.A. County that were scheduled and anticipated to occur in Q4 that looks like they're going to slip into Q1 and in the balance of the timing related component related to the startup of a coach facility at one of our New York high-rise asset that's been delayed a little bit. So about 1/3 of it, we'll get. We're just going to get a prior closer to Q1 as opposed to Q4. But in terms of the absolute amount of the change, it's about 70 basis points. If you look at the midyear guidance we provided, basically, around 2 4, that where we're at 3 1 today. The major components are the utilities, it's about $1.8 million, taxes, around $700,000, and there's a couple of hundred thousand related to insurance and payroll. Again, that's sort of comparing back half of 2016 as compared to our midyear re-forecast, so a big chunk of it again is timing related, but those are the primary drivers of a difference as compared to what we had said earlier at midyear.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then you said concessions. Can you talk about if you're using concessions under your stabilized properties today. What markets you're doing that? And if it's free rent or gift cards or maybe any other details you can provide on that.
componenttext: And then you said concessions. Can you talk about if you're using concessions under your stabilized properties today. What markets you're doing that? And if it's free rent or gift cards or maybe any other details you can provide on that.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. For the most part, we don't get a lot of concessions, but we do use them in certain markets. And I'd say it depends on a couple of things, Nick. Obviously, in New York, you probably see a greater use of concession given some of the legal rent i
componenttext: Yes, sure. For the most part, we don't get a lot of concessions, but we do use them in certain markets. And I'd say it depends on a couple of things, Nick. Obviously, in New York, you probably see a greater use of concession given some of the legal rent issues that surround that market. And then in certain situations where we think there may be just the bulk of deliveries that's coming through in a particular quarter or 2 that sort of impacts the then current environment and we want to take sort of a temporary hit as opposed to the full 12 months in reducing the rent when it comes to lease renewal for those customers, that we tend to use. But in terms of the concessions that we granted in the third quarter, it's about 440,000, about 50% of it is in San Francisco, a better than the 25% is in the Pacific Northwest, which is in a healthy market, but it tends to be a market where there is just a greater use of concessions. So we have concessions last year, we use concessions this year. It's just the sort of the nature of the barter in Seattle. But if you look at the year-over-year change, about 85% of the year-over-year increase is really in San Francisco, and that's primarily concentrated at the Mission Bay assets, a little bit of 55 9[ph], a little bit at Ocean Avenue, which are competing with more the new deliveries.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Nick Yulico with UBS.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Nick Yulico with UBS.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. A couple of ones. First on a couple of markets like if you think about New York, San Francisco, I mean if you look at Axiometrics data showing that year-over-year has been no rent growth or slightly negative net rent growth in the market. What point
componenttext: Yes. A couple of ones. First on a couple of markets like if you think about New York, San Francisco, I mean if you look at Axiometrics data showing that year-over-year has been no rent growth or slightly negative net rent growth in the market. What point does that flow into your portfolio more so where if market rents just aren't moving, I mean how do you still keep up, let's say, positive renewals in both markets?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Dave, this is Sean. In terms of a bleeding through the portfolio, I mean it's the softer market environment this year obviously has already started to bleed through the portfolio, which was our original expectations at the beginning of the year in th
componenttext: Yes. Dave, this is Sean. In terms of a bleeding through the portfolio, I mean it's the softer market environment this year obviously has already started to bleed through the portfolio, which was our original expectations at the beginning of the year in the guidance that we provided. The rate at which at least the portfolio really is a function of a couple of different things. For the most part, it really does depend on turnover rates, because if you're turning over say a 54% or a 55% of the portfolio every year, that's going to get mark-to-market to some degree, and then the balance of it really is in renewals. And historically, we had seen more pricing power with renewals relative to new move ins because of switching costs and things of that sort. So it takes a period of time for that to happen. So obviously, in some markets we are seeing rents go down relative to this point last year, I'd say, particularly in the markets like San Francisco or a little bit in New York City, but we're seeing overall positive rent change currently in those markets, I'd say, due to 2 reasons. One is we probably are performing slightly better than the market average in those markets. And secondly, it's just a function of the renewals versus the move ins that I described previously.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. Just second question, maybe for Tim. Are you seeing any change in cap rates for where multifamilies assets are trading in the private market? I mean if we think about how much rent growth has slowed in some markets and just look at multifamily sector overall for the REITs, we've also seen growth slowing. How I think it's hard some people to imagine how cap rates won't move higher to reflect this? What are you seeing for asset values?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Well, Nick, I think I'll probably refer to Matt for acquisition. This position reports to him, but obviously, we've been active on the disposition side, both around portfolio and for as we wind down some of the funds and then we've been more active on the acquisition side in a couple of markets. But Matt, maybe just speak to kind of what we've been seeing from cap rate perspective.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it probably does vary by market and by asset side. And really,  it's a function of where the capital is most aggressive, so what we're finding is older assets and value assets story, particularly on the West coast, it's still very, very deep.
componenttext: Yes. I think it probably does vary by market and by asset side. And really,  it's a function of where the capital is most aggressive, so what we're finding is older assets and value assets story, particularly on the West coast, it's still very, very deep. We probably sold an asset out of in the northern suburbs of Seattle and that was a sub 5[ph] cap rate on an asset that was 15 years old, and a good submarket, but not one of the more sought after submarkets in metro Seattle, and that's just a reflection of the fact there's a lot of value add money chasing that story, if you will. In some other locations, I don't know, really, I couldn't tell you where Northern California cap rates are today. Obviously, there has been a lot of deceleration of NOI growth there, and we have not bought or sold anything in Northern Cal in a while. And I think asset volumes are done a little bit there because of that, so we haven't been selling kind of real core stuff, and that's where you might see the impacts felt more so, but we don't have any direct evidence to speak to that on either the buyer or the sell-side.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm here with one scenario. I guess just wanted to focus a little bit more, Tim, on some of your key points, talking about moderation equilibrium, the next 2 to 3 years. Obviously, this year there were a few issues to cause management to lower guidance. H
componenttext: I'm here with one scenario. I guess just wanted to focus a little bit more, Tim, on some of your key points, talking about moderation equilibrium, the next 2 to 3 years. Obviously, this year there were a few issues to cause management to lower guidance. How should we think about those comments in the next 2 to 3 years? What's giving you comfort that we stay there, or what are some of the assumptions behind that, behind those comments?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Jeff, we try to say that on Slide 9. I mean, first of all, in terms of changes in guidance, it's really a reflection of it being a weaker economic environment than consensus or as had anticipated. So the environment deteriorates further, and we are
componenttext: Well, Jeff, we try to say that on Slide 9. I mean, first of all, in terms of changes in guidance, it's really a reflection of it being a weaker economic environment than consensus or as had anticipated. So the environment deteriorates further, and we are anticipating some moderation in both the -- in job growth and an increase in supply in our market over the next couple of years. But I think we show on Slide 9 that we think it's roughly about -- and if you look at the overall housing picture, we're starting at between 1.1 million and 1.2 million units per year, and about 400,000 of those are multifamily, almost all of those are rental. That's about -- on a percentage basis, that's about what you're seeing in terms of renter propensities right now. It just seems like the market is producing housing that's consistent with what we're seeing at from a marginal demand standpoint which autotranslate into inflation or maybe a little bit better in terms of rent growth than I think it if you're seeing a tightness anywhere, it's probably more on the for sale arena where there's still being kind of 5% kind of growth in value. So we're not seeing too much supply in terms of the overall housing picture. We are seeing pockets of oversupply for sure, and we've talked about those markets, and so some will leave and some will lag. But overall, based upon an economy that's growing at, call it, 2%, and jobs that are growing around 1.5%, and supply that's been delivered into the market at about 1.5% of, that just looks like equilibrium to us, so supply being roughly equivalent to demand.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Does it -- do you also assume that in '18, that supply is going to really come down or no, that's not part of your thought process right now?
componenttext: Does it -- do you also assume that in '18, that supply is going to really come down or no, that's not part of your thought process right now?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Modestly, Jeff, I think it may come down less for a couple of reasons. One, I think the projection for '17 are probably going to prove out to be too high again because it just seems like supply just gets delayed. Some of the supply, I think, over the last
componenttext: Modestly, Jeff, I think it may come down less for a couple of reasons. One, I think the projection for '17 are probably going to prove out to be too high again because it just seems like supply just gets delayed. Some of the supply, I think, over the last couple of years, 15% to 20% of what we're expected hitting that year ended up getting delayed. So if anything, we've been overestimating supply for the next year. And so I suspect some of the '17 deliveries will leak into '18, and that you'll see a more -- I think you'll see a fairly level supply picture for the next couple of years is our own sense.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And Juan has a question.
componenttext: Okay. And Juan has a question.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could follow-up on Jeff's point. If you could just through your '17 supply assumptions across your major markets, and in particular, maybe if you could touch on Northern California, how that comes online throughout '17? Is it front end loaded or is i
componenttext: If I could follow-up on Jeff's point. If you could just through your '17 supply assumptions across your major markets, and in particular, maybe if you could touch on Northern California, how that comes online throughout '17? Is it front end loaded or is it kind of pretty evenly distributed throughout the year?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Juan, this is Sean. Why don't I take that one? In terms of the expectations for '17, before I kind of run through the markets, one thing to keep in mind, as Tim noted, is for the most part, over the last 3 years, I'd say supply has been, call it, str
componenttext: Yes. Juan, this is Sean. Why don't I take that one? In terms of the expectations for '17, before I kind of run through the markets, one thing to keep in mind, as Tim noted, is for the most part, over the last 3 years, I'd say supply has been, call it, stretched out, if you want to think about it that way, where expected deliveries are pushed off into the subsequent period. But in terms of what we're seeing for 2017 right now across our markets, the expectations we're going to be somewhere in the neighborhood of about 2% of inventory. And the way that breaks down, to give you some perspective, is the New England market, it's about 2.5, Metro New York, New Jersey, around 1.8, Mid-Atlantic, high 2s, Pacific Northwest, still elevated, up at 3.7, northern Cal, mid-2s, and Southern Cal, kind of the mid-1% range. My expectation is those are going to trend down as we digest numbers and refresh our supply pipeline when we get to January. One thing to keep in mind is some of those deals are in the pipeline and is projected starts, but when people start looking at their numbers and construction cost up quite a bit over the last couple of years of processing a deal, and then a tightening that we've seen in the financial markets as we look at the construction lending and a little bit on the equity side as well, yes, some of those aren't going to make.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And just one quick follow-up. Are you seeing any pull into San Francisco of demand that otherwise would have been in Oakland or San Jose from the discounting for the new projects?
componenttext: All right. And just one quick follow-up. Are you seeing any pull into San Francisco of demand that otherwise would have been in Oakland or San Jose from the discounting for the new projects?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know a little bit, but nothing that's really discernible that shows up in the data that you could call it a significant trend. Typically, it takes a period of time for that to happen. And we've been talking about still a decelerating growth in San Fra
componenttext: You know a little bit, but nothing that's really discernible that shows up in the data that you could call it a significant trend. Typically, it takes a period of time for that to happen. And we've been talking about still a decelerating growth in San Francisco for the last few quarters, but it's really only, I'd say, in the last 6 months that it's really come down quite a bit. And people are in a year[ph] leases and things like that, so it typically takes a year or two for that phenomenon really to occur. If you think about the early part of this cycle, San Francisco outperformed quite a while and San Jose as well, but for the East Bay sort of caught up, and East Bay has been outperforming in the last couple of years of the cycle.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Austin Wurschmidt here with Jordan. I was just curious if you could update on your outlook for job growth. I think last quarter, you mentioned it came down 50 basis points roughly from your expectation, but just curious what your outlook is as we mov
componenttext: It's Austin Wurschmidt here with Jordan. I was just curious if you could update on your outlook for job growth. I think last quarter, you mentioned it came down 50 basis points roughly from your expectation, but just curious what your outlook is as we move into '17.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Austin, this is Sean. Why don't I take the first half of it and then comment on that as well. But in terms of forecast for 2016, we rely on several different jobs to kind of get aligned around what where we think job growth is going to end up. It inc
componenttext: Yes. Austin, this is Sean. Why don't I take the first half of it and then comment on that as well. But in terms of forecast for 2016, we rely on several different jobs to kind of get aligned around what where we think job growth is going to end up. It includes sort of the consensus, as well as Moody's. And right now, the numbers are sort of in the 2.3 million to 2.4 million jobs range for the calendar year. And in terms of 2017, the expectation is for job growth at least at this point to be relatively similar to 2016. So certainly, that will be updated as Q4 evolves and we get to January, but the expectation is that job growth will be relatively similar next year as to this year, which is down, as Tim mentioned, relative to 2015 and 2014[ph].

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just as a follow-up to that. As I mentioned earlier, it's around 1.5%, and our markets were expecting about 1.7%. And the only real anomaly is a Seattle where we're still expecting job growth north of 3%. The others are kind of in the mid-1% range, al
componenttext: And just as a follow-up to that. As I mentioned earlier, it's around 1.5%, and our markets were expecting about 1.7%. And the only real anomaly is a Seattle where we're still expecting job growth north of 3%. The others are kind of in the mid-1% range, all of the regions.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: And then just on DC, it's been one of the few submarkets that's been accelerating. It stalled a bit this quarter. I know you highlighted from a question earlier in the call, but just curious what your thoughts are. And how this market -- how it should fare moving forward? Do you still see acceleration coming?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Sean, Austin. Yes, the trend we believe that will occur is continued acceleration in revenue performance there. We thought it would have accelerated probably a little bit more in the third quarter and fourth quarter, but it's still kind of a
componenttext: Yes. This is Sean, Austin. Yes, the trend we believe that will occur is continued acceleration in revenue performance there. We thought it would have accelerated probably a little bit more in the third quarter and fourth quarter, but it's still kind of a bump along here is so there is still -- one thing to realize is job growth has been much better in the DC metro area, but supply still been plentiful, so we're going to continue to see it rise, but it's going to be at a pretty moderate pace as we move into next year.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to talk about the 2 acquisitions, and I know you've mentioned attractive merchant deals in the past. Just wondering given the fact that you have such good economics in your own development pipe, how did you think about the 2 deals there? I thi
componenttext: I just want to talk about the 2 acquisitions, and I know you've mentioned attractive merchant deals in the past. Just wondering given the fact that you have such good economics in your own development pipe, how did you think about the 2 deals there? I think, if I'm not wrong one, one of them was a lease-up other than -- other one was a land swap of sorts. Could you provide more details on that and the yields you expect?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, this is Matt. I can speak to that. I wouldn't say it's either or between the 2 investment activities. We're really not funding acquisitions through expansion of the balance sheet. It's really portfolio management. So essentially, we are in the
componenttext: Yes. Sure, this is Matt. I can speak to that. I wouldn't say it's either or between the 2 investment activities. We're really not funding acquisitions through expansion of the balance sheet. It's really portfolio management. So essentially, we are in the market when we think that there are assets that are attractively priced. And if we find assets that we like, then we can always fund those through incremental dispositions. And we've wound up this year selling more than we probably plan to sell at the beginning of the year because we have been successful in finding some interesting acquisition candidates, so that doesn't really displace the development activity from a funding point of view. So that's the first thing. And then in terms of the specific deals, we have been concentrating in the Mid-Atlantic. For the most part, we sold down in the Mid-Atlantic back in '11 and '12, kind of saw the softness coming in the year, so we're actually under-allocated against our kind of our long-term targets. We haven't been as actively developing in this market through the cycle either. So the one deal we bought in South Arlington has been allocated to the retail we can basically, it's a low 5[ph] cap, 330,000 units for concrete frame construction that's 8 and 9 or 8 or 9 years old, that's below replacement costs for that submarket, so we saw a pretty compelling by that's a submarket that suffered some in the last couple of years, and we think it's bottomed down and we're starting to see positive revenue growth there again, so we feel like it was a well-timed acquisition and should be a great investment. The other deal we bought, just completed the lease-up. It's a smaller deal in North Hollywood, and that -- the other region I'd say we're under-allocated too at this point is Southern California. It's been more difficult there because cap rates are quite a bit lower than there in the Mid-Atlantic, but still, that deal, we think it's a low 4s cap. And after allocating it to the retail, we think the basis in the residential is about 400,000 units, which again is a pretty compelling basis for that location. And that's a submarket where we are looking for more exposure where we see a lot of good things happening and where we think that we're in a good point of the cycle there.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Yes. I mean that's kind of a typical lender reserve CapEx number in there, but it's consistent. The dispose we've been selling it here, we sold about $275 million in wholly-owned assets, and the cap rates there have been in the mid-5s. And then we've also sold some fund assets. And then, of course, we sold the asset in Seattle earlier this month. That's not in that $275 million, that was the high 4s cap.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. To be clear, cap rates, on a market convention basis in terms of how the market would underwrite CapEx, not necessarily how we might underwrite a particular asset.
componenttext: Yes. To be clear, cap rates, on a market convention basis in terms of how the market would underwrite CapEx, not necessarily how we might underwrite a particular asset.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sean, what were overall new and renewals in 3Q for the portfolio? And how is that trending into October?
componenttext: Sean, what were overall new and renewals in 3Q for the portfolio? And how is that trending into October?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Conor. In terms of move ins in Q3, average 2.1, renewals were 4.8, so blended to the 3.5 in Q3. And in October, obviously, call it a little bit earlier this year than last year, as I recall, but basically, low 2% range for October to date. This data
componenttext: Yes, Conor. In terms of move ins in Q3, average 2.1, renewals were 4.8, so blended to the 3.5 in Q3. And in October, obviously, call it a little bit earlier this year than last year, as I recall, but basically, low 2% range for October to date. This data is as of, call it, a few days ago, basically, and still running in the high 4s on the renewals, but slightly negative of the new move ins, which is primarily a result of Northern California, and New York and New England, the Boston market, a little bit of a push on our part to get a little more occupancy as we get into the latter part of the fourth quarter, so a little more pressure in rate in October.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Sean, I know last year in 3Q, you guys were aggressive in pushing price, taking a dip in occupancy. Do you think you were too aggressive this year in dropping occupancy to get price, and particularly in the Mid-Atlantic?
componenttext: And Sean, I know last year in 3Q, you guys were aggressive in pushing price, taking a dip in occupancy. Do you think you were too aggressive this year in dropping occupancy to get price, and particularly in the Mid-Atlantic?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean last year, I'd say we were relatively aggressive. This year, as the year has evolved, the posture has changed. Every market is a little bit different and really, every asset is a little bit different. But I am not sure that we would revisit th
componenttext: Yes. I mean last year, I'd say we were relatively aggressive. This year, as the year has evolved, the posture has changed. Every market is a little bit different and really, every asset is a little bit different. But I am not sure that we would revisit the decision I mean the Mid-Atlantic. We basically put out an expectation mid-year[ph] that things would continue to improve at a greater rate than what has actually occurred, but you could tie that back to rates of occupancy and say there were too aggressive, I wouldn't necessarily say that. We were trying to push a bit. But to get the rate growth, you got to have some of the occupancy and you're just not going to get it, so I think it's is really a blend of both. I wouldn't just tie to one piece or the other.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttextpreview: Conor, it's Tim, I can speak to that. I mean we've been demolishing the existing building there for a good part of the year. We're just completing that process now and still need to get a signoff, final signoff by the city. And so it's really been probabl
componenttext: Conor, it's Tim, I can speak to that. I mean we've been demolishing the existing building there for a good part of the year. We're just completing that process now and still need to get a signoff, final signoff by the city. And so it's really been probably more a function of that. I think as we reported maybe last quarter or the quarter before, we are still considering bringing in a capital partner there. And it's not necessarily a requirement from our perspective, but something that we are considering, but the isn't holding up for. It will probably get started with maybe some site enabling work here before the end of the year. But between kind of where -- how long it took us to get the demolition done and finishing up our plans is looking at, it's just looking like right around the end of the year for the start of the new building.

componenttext: Okay. And that will be the only deal that would possibly cause you to miss your guidance for $1.2 billion in starts this year?
