headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sean, you talked earlier about the weakness in Northern California and New York City among other markets. When you're looking at supply coming on line in those markets that are directly impacting your assets or likely to directly impact your assets, if yo
componenttext: Sean, you talked earlier about the weakness in Northern California and New York City among other markets. When you're looking at supply coming on line in those markets that are directly impacting your assets or likely to directly impact your assets, if you assume job growth remains static, I mean when is the sort of peak sort of disruption to your assets from an operational standpoint? Are we in that now? Is that sometime in early '17? Is that back end '17? How are you guys thinking about that?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And you're thinking about 2 specific markets there in terms of New York and Northern Cal, I assume?
componenttext: Yes. And you're thinking about 2 specific markets there in terms of New York and Northern Cal, I assume?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is that what you think about primarily?
componenttext: Is that what you think about primarily?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think for the most part, if you look at it, New York, it's a place actually expected to increase in '17 relative to '16, so I think the pain is going to continue in New York through '17 for certain. It's really going to be what Tim said, which is a f
componenttext: So I think for the most part, if you look at it, New York, it's a place actually expected to increase in '17 relative to '16, so I think the pain is going to continue in New York through '17 for certain. It's really going to be what Tim said, which is a function of job growth, whats happening in the economic environment that will determine rent change, performance, and ultimately, revenue performance, but supply is expected to continue. And as it relates to our specific portfolio in New York City, really what you worry about is supply being delivered in Midtown West is impacting us, that's probably the bulk of it. There are some supply in Long Island City, but it's more downtown than on the waterfront, and Long Island City is actually performing quite well. The other market that we're probably start to see more pressure is in Brooklyn as more deliveries in Brooklyn next year as compared to this year, for the most part has been a relatively light year in deliveries. It's just starting to pick up in Q4. So that's sort of the broad picture in New York. As it relates to Northern California, also expect to see a pickup in deliveries in Northern California next year, about 40, 50 basis points as compared to 2016. It goes from about 1 8 to 2 3. Again, we're going to be massaging those numbers as we get to December and January, and a number of those deals are already in the construction, of course, but the most part, what we've seen is that those deals have been delayed in terms of actually getting through the system, getting everything signed off, et cetera. But if you look at where the deliveries are going to be concentrated, it's sort of the same places really in terms of what's happening in midmarket, submarket, et cetera. So in terms of our portfolio in Mission Bay assets, $55 million will continue to be impacted in 2017. I don't have the quarterly breakdown for '18 at this point. It's probably a little premature to talk about it, but by January, we'll have a pretty good outline of that.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then your turnover levels look pretty sort of static. Are you seeing any material increase in days vacate between turns?
componenttext: Okay. And then your turnover levels look pretty sort of static. Are you seeing any material increase in days vacate between turns?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not really. When you look at it on a quarter-over-quarter basis, it's not really changing much. I think the third quarter around 22, 23, that's pretty consistent for the third quarter, a lot of leasing velocity, a lot of turn activity, so it's not changin
componenttext: Not really. When you look at it on a quarter-over-quarter basis, it's not really changing much. I think the third quarter around 22, 23, that's pretty consistent for the third quarter, a lot of leasing velocity, a lot of turn activity, so it's not changing materially. You will see that number increase in the fourth quarter. And in the first quarter, as a result of just the seasonal nature of the market and trends as fast because demand is not as robust in those quarters as compared to Q2 and Q3, therefore, you're not going to outsource turns and things like that, they cost more money just to get it done faster.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then any increase in bad debt?
componenttext: Okay. And then any increase in bad debt?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bad debt has been higher than our expectation pretty much all year, around 13, 14 basis points higher. We expect it to be around 76 basis points or so. We're running closer to 90. And really, if you look at it for the full year in terms of operating expen
componenttext: Bad debt has been higher than our expectation pretty much all year, around 13, 14 basis points higher. We expect it to be around 76 basis points or so. We're running closer to 90. And really, if you look at it for the full year in terms of operating expenses relative to our original budget, we're talking about an insignificant variance. It's like 0.2% in terms of total operating expenses relative to our original budget. And the only difference really is in bad debt.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Gaurav Mehta with Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Gaurav Mehta with Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So going back to your comments on the supply and the performance then between suburban and urban assets, I was wondering if you could comment if you expect that trend to continue, meaning suburban outperforming urban for the next couple of years and suppl
componenttext: So going back to your comments on the supply and the performance then between suburban and urban assets, I was wondering if you could comment if you expect that trend to continue, meaning suburban outperforming urban for the next couple of years and supply to remain focused on urban markets.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Maybe I can I'll start and maybe Matt or Sean will step in. I think we are expecting supply in urban markets, urban submarkets to be twice that of suburban submarkets in 2017, which is actually a larger disparity than what we saw in 2016. So you can
componenttext: Yes. Maybe I can I'll start and maybe Matt or Sean will step in. I think we are expecting supply in urban markets, urban submarkets to be twice that of suburban submarkets in 2017, which is actually a larger disparity than what we saw in 2016. So you can see on that chart, it's been about a 200 basis points delta on rent performance for the last, call it, 8 quarters, we would expect that certainly to continue into 2017, and maybe to a lesser extent, as into beyond '18, but in over the next 1 to 2 years, we think that trend is going to continue.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in your initial remarks, you also talked about equilibrium over the next couple of years and a disciplined approach to capital allocation. I was wondering what that translates into development starts over the next few years?
componenttext: Okay. And then in your initial remarks, you also talked about equilibrium over the next couple of years and a disciplined approach to capital allocation. I was wondering what that translates into development starts over the next few years?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have a pipeline of close to $4 billion, which suggests kind of low $1 billion range in terms of starts assuming they continue to make sense and to get through the process and the economics makes sense. But from at this point standpoint, I guess I
componenttext: Well, we have a pipeline of close to $4 billion, which suggests kind of low $1 billion range in terms of starts assuming they continue to make sense and to get through the process and the economics makes sense. But from at this point standpoint, I guess I'd say a few things. When we start Columbus circle and the Hollywood deal, we'll actually have less than 100 million of land on the balance sheet, which actually is a cyclical low and maybe in the last -- maybe little in the last 2 cycles. So a part of the discipline has been around managing that land exposure from a in terms of when you actually buy the land versus optional land. And then secondly, as we've been talking about over the last few quarters is how we capitalize the deals once we do start them. As I mentioned, we're around 85% match funded without consideration of any free cash flow right now. So in effect, we've already capitalized what's already and that's has been. As we get later and later in the cycle, we'll continue to be conservative with how we manage that exposure of our funding commitments. So it's going to be so I would spend on how attractive the deals are relative to the capital environment at this time. But as we said on one of the slides that we showed one of the slides, over the last 20 years as a public company, we had demonstrated we can continue to create value through all phases of the cycle as long as you are disciplined about how you bring those deals into the pipeline, and ultimately, how you capitalize them.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll now take our next question from Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: We'll now take our next question from Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 questions here. First, on Slide 15, the returns that you guys have had on the developments over time, just surprised that West Coast has had lower returns on average than the East Coast. I would've thought that there would've been more cap rate com
componenttext: Just 2 questions here. First, on Slide 15, the returns that you guys have had on the developments over time, just surprised that West Coast has had lower returns on average than the East Coast. I would've thought that there would've been more cap rate compression to drive higher returns. So if you could just give a comment maybe if the fact that just land from the get-go is more expensive out there, and therefore, you just never get there, but that part was a little surprising given cap rate compression.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Alex, it's Tim here. Yes, I guess the point here, and part of the slide is being a good or a skilled capital allocator is much of sort of timing and being tactically smart. And by the way, this is all investment, so it isn't just development. This wo
componenttext: Yes. Alex, it's Tim here. Yes, I guess the point here, and part of the slide is being a good or a skilled capital allocator is much of sort of timing and being tactically smart. And by the way, this is all investment, so it isn't just development. This would include acquisitions, to be clear. And interestingly, the return on acquisitions aren't materially different than development which sort of speaks to being highly disciplined sort of in terms of investing earlier in the cycle with respect to acquisitions. I mentioned in my our comments, we made more money where we've been the longest, Northern California and Mid-Atlantic, so a part of that is just understanding the markets, having deeper relationships, being confident that you are focused on the right deals at the right time at the right time of the cycle, which only comes through experience and track record, in our view. So I think -- and then last thing I'd say is, this is only through Q3 of 2014. So I think if you look at Seattle in particular just given some of our recent deals that have completed, those numbers actually won't go up from what you see there of around 10.3%. In the case of Southern California, you're just starting at such a low going in yield. Cap rate compression has really occurred throughout really all of our markets, and probably, through all market nationally. And if anything, where you've probably seeing it is probably more cap rate compression on the urban product than there has been in the suburban products. That's probably been -- it hasn't been geographical as much as it's been submarket focused. But again, it comes down -- we're looking at managing to total return, and sometimes, that's investing in higher-yielding slower growth markets. Sometime, it's lower yielding, higher growth markets. And I think this chart just really reflects that.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the second question is, in response to one of the analysts' questions earlier about San Francisco and if you're seeing a sort of a back flow from East Bay back in the San Francisco, you said you are not. Are you seeing any change in demand
componenttext: Okay. And then the second question is, in response to one of the analysts' questions earlier about San Francisco and if you're seeing a sort of a back flow from East Bay back in the San Francisco, you said you are not. Are you seeing any change in demand in San Francisco? Or is it because your portfolio has a good chunk of it is suburb, that maybe you're not seeing -- you're not feeling the impact of a lot of the 2 months rent concession that's attracting renters to move around San Francisco?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Alex, it's Sean. A couple of things. In terms of my comment earlier about people moving from the East Bay to back into the city or back into San Jose, my response is really that we've seen a little bit of that, but it's not a meaningful number at thi
componenttext: Yes. Alex, it's Sean. A couple of things. In terms of my comment earlier about people moving from the East Bay to back into the city or back into San Jose, my response is really that we've seen a little bit of that, but it's not a meaningful number at this point given things have decelerated in San Francisco obviously pretty quickly that if someone was considering living in San Francisco at this time last year relative to the East Bay, that is a pretty expensive proposition, and whether you can start to see meaningful deceleration in the second half of this year in that market, people sign 1-year leases, they typically lag a year or two before they say, okay, the rents have really come down. I think that's the right kind of trade to make. And my point was during the beginning part of the cycle, San Francisco and San Jose outperformed quite a while before the East Bay caught up. And then the East Bay has been outperforming in the last couple of years, so you would expect that in the opposite direction as the market decelerates. And in terms of the comment about demand. I mean, certainly, as Tim pointed out, is the weaker economic environment, and I think many of us anticipated, which has resulted in lower job growth across the markets, with the exception probably of Seattle and Northern California has not been immune from that, so there's certainly a weaker demand profile in Northern California. It just so happens to be at a time when we have meaningful supply being delivered in San Francisco, and therefore, you're seeing  month to 2-month concession sort of a norm on all of the new deliveries in San Francisco as an example.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: But do you feel -- Sean, do you feel that you're sort of on the tail end of that or you think that we're having you guys expect to have another year of that, and therefore, as you outlined, next year, you're still going to be talking about the pressure on
componenttext: But do you feel -- Sean, do you feel that you're sort of on the tail end of that or you think that we're having you guys expect to have another year of that, and therefore, as you outlined, next year, you're still going to be talking about the pressure on demand and the supply in San Francisco?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I still think there is going to be demand. I mean assuming that job growth is basically the same and deliveries continue at at the latest forecast to which pretty much is baked at this point because those buildings are delivering now, I would expect
componenttext: Yes. I still think there is going to be demand. I mean assuming that job growth is basically the same and deliveries continue at at the latest forecast to which pretty much is baked at this point because those buildings are delivering now, I would expect that Northern California and San Francisco specifically, that is what you're interested in, will continue to be a weak environment, so if we saw a significant uptick in good job growth, that equation might change.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take a question from Rich Hill with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll take a question from Rich Hill with Morgan Stanley.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was curious about your comment about the apartments reaching sort of a steady state. And as I am thinking about what you put on the board for the first 9 months relative to your full year guidance, it looks like to me maybe revenue growth and NOI growth
componenttext: I was curious about your comment about the apartments reaching sort of a steady state. And as I am thinking about what you put on the board for the first 9 months relative to your full year guidance, it looks like to me maybe revenue growth and NOI growth in the fourth quarter might be decelerating to 3.4% and 2.7%, so I'm wondering if I was thinking about that correctly. And then #2, if that's sort of a steady-state we should be thinking about going into 2017 or are we supposed to be more bullish or maybe a little bit more cautious? Any color or transparency would be helpful in that regard.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Rich, Tim here. In terms of Q4, I think your math is approximately correct as it relates to the kind of what we're looking for in terms of year-over-year growth. Steady-state for us or equilibrium, it shouldn't be a whole lot more than inflation, from
componenttext: So Rich, Tim here. In terms of Q4, I think your math is approximately correct as it relates to the kind of what we're looking for in terms of year-over-year growth. Steady-state for us or equilibrium, it shouldn't be a whole lot more than inflation, from our perspective. I think historically, if you look at our markets, we've been able to generate roughly 70, 75 basis points stronger growth than inflation or as nationally spend probably a little bit closer to inflation, and that's equated into a kind of high 2%, maybe just sub-3% kind of rent growth. And so we're talking about equilibrium, that's the kind of rate of growth we expect to see. We obviously started this year well above that trend. And so while we have seen moderation, our view has been it's been moderating more towards an industry that approach demand and supply being roughly equal after 6 years of really an imbalance, it's kind of what you would expect after a while and capital market where capital should flow freely to businesses that are sustaining outperformance.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. I mean and to that point, and maybe taking a little bit more of a positive and longer-term view, do you characterize this supply that's coming to market as more of a bottleneck? Or looking longer-term, can you make the case that we have enough a
componenttext: Yes, yes. I mean and to that point, and maybe taking a little bit more of a positive and longer-term view, do you characterize this supply that's coming to market as more of a bottleneck? Or looking longer-term, can you make the case that we have enough apartments in the United States or maybe we even need a little bit more apartments in the United States? I'm curious in your view, as an owner of apartments, and most likely, taking a 10-year view rather than a 6 to 12-month view, how do you think about that? So said another way, yes, go ahead.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, no I think I followed. Our expectation is we're going to see household formation of over 1 million, 1.2 million, 1.4 million kind of on a steady-state basis based upon a reasonable growth in population and jobs. And in our view is that if you jus
componenttext: Yes, no, no I think I followed. Our expectation is we're going to see household formation of over 1 million, 1.2 million, 1.4 million kind of on a steady-state basis based upon a reasonable growth in population and jobs. And in our view is that if you just look at underlying demographics and as the millennials age, that we're going to see based more balanced housing demand between for sale and rental. Most of the rental has been, I mean most of the multifamily that has been built has been purpose built as rental. And so right now, you have an industry that's generating about 1.2 million houses, new units, against demand that's about 1.2 million, about 2/3 of that is single-family, which is the only purpose built for sale, and about 1/3 of that is multifamily, which is purpose built as rental. Penumbras almost can't be more imbalanced than that. And that kind of -- so we're going from industry has been out of balance, where real housing demand has been close to 80% or more of total housing demand kind of an earlier of the cycle to where it seems like we found a new sort of a new normal, if you will, so that's our view.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Tayo Okusanya with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Tayo Okusanya with Jefferies.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's been a lot of talk recently about rent control hitting the ballot during the election season in the Bay Area. Just kind of curious what you're hearing, what you think the probability of that happening is, and what could be the potential impact to
componenttext: There's been a lot of talk recently about rent control hitting the ballot during the election season in the Bay Area. Just kind of curious what you're hearing, what you think the probability of that happening is, and what could be the potential impact to your portfolio.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Tayo, it's Sean. You are correct that rent control is on the ballot in about 5 different municipalities in the Northern California market. Only one of the -- I can't speak to exactly what passed and what's not, changes from week to week depending on
componenttext: Yes. Tayo, it's Sean. You are correct that rent control is on the ballot in about 5 different municipalities in the Northern California market. Only one of the -- I can't speak to exactly what passed and what's not, changes from week to week depending on which portfolio you read, but there is support for -- more than a majority of support for some of those ordinances based on kind of recent polling. There is really only 1 that potential impacts to our portfolio, which is the proposed rent control ordinance in Mountain View. And if you look at it, it depends on how it's actually adopted. It's actually 2 proposed ordinances on the ballot in Mountain View, one that's sponsored by the city and the other that is sort of a voter referendum. And to the extent that it comes to a fruition, Mountain View overall, when you look at the assets that are impacted, it would impact around 9% to 10% of our Northern California revenue in terms of the specific assets that that will be governed by the proposed ordinance. And the other rent increases, it is a blend. It's limited to CPI plus, but it's got a color on it, minimum 2, max 5. And you can think it so you can get it over time one way or another in terms of the what's happening in the market vacancy key control, et cetera.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

I assumed that's been driven more by New York City with New York suburban and New Jersey actually both showing sequential acceleration in terms of, did that sequential acceleration in your suburban markets surprise you or is it something that you have been underwriting?

componenttext: No, we did expect some acceleration in those markets. It actually came in a little bit short of our expectations, but we did expect some acceleration in those markets. componenttext: No, I wouldn't say that it's significantly weaker.  Just we thought things would take up a little bit more, but the job growth in that region has been weaker over the last 6 months, so I think it's more widespread as opposed to -- as it relates to -- most people are moving from Central Jersey to Manhattan, as an example, just that trade and rent usually doesn't make much sense, you don't see that happen, same thing when an Westchester or Long Island, making the trades to come in to the city is just prohibitively expensive.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Drew, this is Matt. It's really just when we get into finishing a building, particularly building of that size and complexity, when we're actually going to be able to kind of close out all the books and everything, and whether the last apartment homes tur
componenttext: Drew, this is Matt. It's really just when we get into finishing a building, particularly building of that size and complexity, when we're actually going to be able to kind of close out all the books and everything, and whether the last apartment homes turnover for occupancy in December or January, it's going to be somewhere right around that time frame. So it's not a response to anything we're seeing, as you point out, the lease-ups has been doing great, so it's just a question of it's at $440-some million assets, so we may keep the books open 1 quarter longer just to make sure we've got everything.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Most have been answered already. Relative to an earlier expectations, I would presume that's sort of Jersey City waterfront markets, but just curious it is more widespread than that.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Sean, Vincent. In terms of our portfolio, we really only have 1 asset in Jersey City, so there is certainly a meaningful amount of supply being delivered there, but the portfolio performance isn't significantly impacted by just that 1 asset.
componenttext: Yes, this is Sean, Vincent. In terms of our portfolio, we really only have 1 asset in Jersey City, so there is certainly a meaningful amount of supply being delivered there, but the portfolio performance isn't significantly impacted by just that 1 asset. As I mentioned, job growth has slowed in that region over the last 6 months, and I think it's more widespread than just represented what you're seeing across all of those markets, whether it'd be parts of Central Jersey, Northern, Long Island, Westchester, et cetera, job growth has come down across the entire region, so that's really what you're seeing as more softer demand. The supply is sort of as expected.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then we really talked about most of the market share except for L.A. so just curious if you give us some commentary on what you're seeing there. We have seen some slowing in the same-store revenue growth for a couple of quarters now and job gr
componenttext: Got it. And then we really talked about most of the market share except for L.A. so just curious if you give us some commentary on what you're seeing there. We have seen some slowing in the same-store revenue growth for a couple of quarters now and job growth there also seems to be also accelerating. So how should we be thinking about L.A. going into '17?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean for the most part, L.A. is performing quite well. I mean there is the -- the only places where there is any pockets of weakness really stabilized that, let's say, in downtown L.A. as an example, whether it's a meaningful amount of supply being
componenttext: Yes. I mean for the most part, L.A. is performing quite well. I mean there is the -- the only places where there is any pockets of weakness really stabilized that, let's say, in downtown L.A. as an example, whether it's a meaningful amount of supply being delivered there, we only have 1 operating asset there that we completed earlier in the cycle. But for the most part, L.A. is tracking just fine. Job growth has been slightly weaker, and so that performance a little bit, but in terms of our expectation for that market, we are tracking pretty close to what we expected at the back half of the year.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Our next question will come from Nick Joseph with Citigroup.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Michael Bilerman. Tim, I'm curious as you think back to that the transaction where you split up the portfolio. If assets were to come to market within your 6 regions, I guess where, and obviously, at the right price and at the right cost of capital,
componenttext: It's Michael Bilerman. Tim, I'm curious as you think back to that the transaction where you split up the portfolio. If assets were to come to market within your 6 regions, I guess where, and obviously, at the right price and at the right cost of capital, I guess, which regions or markets would be most interested to you to deepen your presence?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Michael, I've got a couple of comments. Yes, first of all, one of the things that was great about the transaction, it basically allowed us to get roughly to a target portfolio, particularly as it related to Southern California which we sort of and al
componenttext: Yes. Michael, I've got a couple of comments. Yes, first of all, one of the things that was great about the transaction, it basically allowed us to get roughly to a target portfolio, particularly as it related to Southern California which we sort of and always been short in. But right now, we're not significantly off kind of where we like to be in any one region. I think Matt mentioned, you spend a little bit behind our buying behind DC area. But we think, tactically, it's not a bad time to be buying there, and we have been a little under-allocated since we did the bid kind of in early 2010, earlier this decade. So it's probably from a market standpoint, it's probably still DC and Southern California because those are markets where we could probably still spend a little bit more allocation, and we don't think, from a market conditions standpoint and a cycle standpoint, it's too bad of a time to be investing a little bit more capital and trimming into some other areas.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as you think about sort of the debt and equity capital that's out there to finance transactions, obviously, we've been -- we've come off 2 years of significant activity by private equity and buying large apartment portfolios and platforms, how do you
componenttext: And as you think about sort of the debt and equity capital that's out there to finance transactions, obviously, we've been -- we've come off 2 years of significant activity by private equity and buying large apartment portfolios and platforms, how do you sort of look at the market today in terms of being able to finance larger deals, both from a debt and equity perspective?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll maybe just speak from a public market standpoint and maybe wake up Kevin over here, who has been -- he has been absent in this conversation.
componenttext: I'll maybe just speak from a public market standpoint and maybe wake up Kevin over here, who has been -- he has been absent in this conversation.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: He gets one, he gets one.
componenttext: He gets one, he gets one.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: But you look at where apartment REITs are trading, obviously, relative to underlying NAV, it doesn't make sense to be using your balance sheet to finance. Our portfolio out there looks better than what you currently own and you can finance it through some
componenttext: But you look at where apartment REITs are trading, obviously, relative to underlying NAV, it doesn't make sense to be using your balance sheet to finance. Our portfolio out there looks better than what you currently own and you can finance it through some kind of asset swap or 10 31, perhaps, that makes sense, that contains obviously plentiful from an unsecured standpoint, but we wouldn't be looking -- and I don't know that -- I guess I'd be surprised if anybody decided to be looking at really levering up to grow at this point in the cycle. And so unless you can find a way to get unleveraged-ed in a neutral way, I don't -- I think public entities are probably at a disadvantage today, but except something came to market. And Kevin, any other thoughts, want to say hello?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: A comment on Southern California leasing spreads, too. So no, Michael. I guess certainly from a financing point of view in the private market, things are tightening up a little bit, particularly in the construction area, as many of you are well aware alre
componenttext: A comment on Southern California leasing spreads, too. So no, Michael. I guess certainly from a financing point of view in the private market, things are tightening up a little bit, particularly in the construction area, as many of you are well aware already. So I think from a supply standpoint longer-term, that is a bit of a headwind for those who are looking to add new supply in the private side and finance it in the debt markets, particularly for small less more capitalized developers, pricing in construction financing has probably moved beyond 300 basis points over LIBOR, which it affects, of course, what kind of deal is. And then you've got the OTC which is -- it's pushing things to lend less on real estate. And the regulatory environment for banks has become more expensive for them to be active in the construction market and be profitable. So I think you're seeing that getting construction financing, particularly in some of these urban submarket, is a lot more difficult than it has been before. For stabilized financing, the GSEs certainly have been active for the uncapped business. There is certainly availability that's mostly affordable and the types of opportunities. I think they do expect a record production year. The caps have been lifted a number of times, but their interest in Class A product is more modest, as you are well aware. Nonetheless, banks and insurance companies have been pretty active, while CMBs has been far less so due to the risk retention rule. So I think when you step back in time to some of the comments Tim made, the capital is there deals that makes sense, but it's certainly not plentiful now as it has been in recent years on the debt market side. And I think probably, a lot of -- on the equity side, joint venture, sources of capital have been a lot more difficult because, A, and we've been seeing the same headlines about supply in some of the markets that are out there, so they're probably a little bit more cautious, but at the same time, relative to some other sectors in real estate, multifamily even at trend level, revenue growth does provide pretty healthy returns that one can reasonably bank on achieving over the long term.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. I guess this divergence between the public sector and the discounts and whether there's enough private capital out there, both from a debt and equity perspective, that we'd find those attractive enough to or the companies themselves saying, I don't
componenttext: Right. I guess this divergence between the public sector and the discounts and whether there's enough private capital out there, both from a debt and equity perspective, that we'd find those attractive enough to or the companies themselves saying, I don't want to trade at discounts anymore, I can monetize that spread by tapping into it. The question is, is that debt and equity as excited about multifamily does has been past couple of years given the volume of deals that has transpired already? I don't know the answer, that's why I'm looking for you for the answer.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I think it's going to be a somewhat a function of the balance sheet of the target except they're more secure versus unsecured and maybe more doable than and we've seen some recent examples of that in the apartment space, obviously, where it was -
componenttext: Yes. And I think it's going to be a somewhat a function of the balance sheet of the target except they're more secure versus unsecured and maybe more doable than and we've seen some recent examples of that in the apartment space, obviously, where it was -- we had cleaner balance sheets and more unsecured kind of more public to public and where you have more secured financing and maybe and a little higher leverage more attractive to the private side. So I think that's probably it's big of a factor as well as just kind of where private versus public market valuations sort of are trending.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Neil Malkin with RBC Capital Market.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Neil Malkin with RBC Capital Market.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first one is on jobs. You kind of made the commentary about job growth being basically in line with this year and next year. But I wonder, digging a little bit deeper. Do you guys look at the types or quality of that job creation? And I asked that bec
componenttext: The first one is on jobs. You kind of made the commentary about job growth being basically in line with this year and next year. But I wonder, digging a little bit deeper. Do you guys look at the types or quality of that job creation? And I asked that because you look at the higher paying jobs, professional business services, tech, stuff like that, and some cost the market we're seeing slowdowns which would augur for less traffic, especially at the high price point type of assets that you guys have. And I wonder if you kind of baked that into your guidance because not all jobs, not all demand is created equal. So how do you kind of think about that? In particular, let's say New York and San Francisco when you have job growth that may be flat but, for example, in New York, you have a lot of hotel and leisure jobs. And I don't know if they can afford $4,000 a month, $5,000 a month apartments. So could you guys have a view on that at all?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we look at jobs a number of ways. I mean it's a pretty good data out there related to kind of mid, high, and low wage job growth. And I think actually, we get later in the cycle, we've actually seen stronger growth in our markets kind of in the mid
componenttext: Well, we look at jobs a number of ways. I mean it's a pretty good data out there related to kind of mid, high, and low wage job growth. And I think actually, we get later in the cycle, we've actually seen stronger growth in our markets kind of in the mid to higher wage outside on the mid wage segment, whereas kind of early in the cycle, I think there is a little bit more tilted towards lower. There does seemed to be a bit of a disconnect right now. I mean openings are higher than hires right now which is putting which is a good thing from wage growth standpoint which allows pay higher rents for sure, but it does seem to be that there maybe a growing disconnect between kind of what jobs are open versus the availability of labor to fill them. Certainly, as you look at college graduates, the unemployment, more for employment for sure, people who have college degrees, and that is the majority of our residents. So you may not see as much job growth there, Neil, for that reason over the next year or 2. And I think it's likely to sort of mimic something closer to population growth, but on the other hand, it should translate into stronger wage growth than we've seen kind of earlier in the cycle.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then next question is just given that new leases have slowed across the board, but renewals stayed in the mid-single digits, what is the gain or loss leasing in your portfolio? And what's your comfort level on that, either way as you go into '17
componenttext: Okay. And then next question is just given that new leases have slowed across the board, but renewals stayed in the mid-single digits, what is the gain or loss leasing in your portfolio? And what's your comfort level on that, either way as you go into '17 or in maybe in a slower or more dubious part of the cycle?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, Neil, that's a good question. One thing to think about related to that is gain and loss lease sort of moves around throughout the seasons of the calendar year. In our business rents, grow pretty rapidly, market rents grow pretty rapidly from sort
componenttext: Yes. No, Neil, that's a good question. One thing to think about related to that is gain and loss lease sort of moves around throughout the seasons of the calendar year. In our business rents, grow pretty rapidly, market rents grow pretty rapidly from sort of early February up through July, early August, and then trail off in terms of what's expected for, basically, the latter part of the third quarter and the fourth quarter. So taken a snap shot of lost lease, at this moment in time doesn't necessarily represent how you want to think about rent growth for next year, so I think you've really got sort of model it in a way is that you'd look at typical trajectory of rents from the trough late in the fourth quarter to the peak to the fall in August, and then determine how much you think you're going to get during that period of time that will then ripple through this expirations, so that's how we think about it more so than we've got x percent or x dollars sort of rent at this moment based on today's market rent if that makes sense. Does it make sense?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, I understand. It goes through cycles based on peak or, rolling it over like third and fourth quarter period, right, you would have a full cycle or a leasing season, and I just wonder, I think someone asked the question earlier, I mean how when
componenttext: Well, yes, I understand. headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jessica, and welcome to AvalonBay Communities Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Before we begin, please note that forward-looking statements may be made during this discussion. There are a variety of risks and uncertainties associated w
componenttext:
Thanks, Jessica, and welcome to AvalonBay Communities Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Before we begin, please note that forward-looking statements may be made during this discussion. There are a variety of risks and uncertainties associated with the forward-looking statements, and actual results may differ materially. There is a discussion of these risks and uncertainties in yesterday afternoon's press release as well as in the company's Form 10-K and Form 10-Q filed with the SEC. As usual, this press release does include an attachment with definitions and reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures and other terms, which may be used in today's discussion. The attachment is also available on our website at www.avalonbay.com/earnings. And we encourage you to refer to this information during the review of our operating results and financial performance.
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Tim Naughton, Chairman and CEO of AvalonBay Communities, for his remarks. Tim?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Jason. And welcome to our third quarter call. With me today are Kevin O'Shea, Sean Breslin and Matt Birenbaum. I will be providing management commentary in the slides that we posted yesterday after the market closed, and all of this will be a
componenttext:
Yes. Thanks, Jason. And welcome to our third quarter call. With me today are Kevin O'Shea, Sean Breslin and Matt Birenbaum. I will be providing management commentary in the slides that we posted yesterday after the market closed, and all of this will be available for Q&A afterwards.
My comments will focus on providing a summary of Q3, year-to-date results, our outlook for 2016, a look at fundamentals, and lastly, an update on investment activity and a look back on our capital allocation track record.
So let's start on Slide 4. It was a solid quarter, where we achieved core FFO growth of 7.3% from a combination of same-store NOI growth of over 4% and healthy contributions continuing from new lease-ups. Year-to-date core FFO per share is up over 9%. And in Q3, we raised over $1 billion in new capital, including the October bond deal and disposition activity, to fund ongoing, and the upcoming development and to pay off maturing debt.
Turning to Slide 5, our updated outlook for the year. We have updated our outlook for FFO and same-store metrics. Core FFO per share has been reduced by $0.05 per share or 70 basis points for the full year to 8.3%, due to a combination of factors, including same-store revenue growth being trimmed by around 12 basis points from our midyear forecast from a mix of lower-projected occupancy and rate for Q4. Secondly, a higher same-store operating expenses, related primarily to higher utility costs and delayed resolution of several tax appeals. Thirdly, lower redevelopment NOI. And lastly, higher interest rate -- higher interest related costs in connection with our recent $650 million bond deal that we completed earlier this month.
Turning now to Slide 6. We thought we'd spend a couple of minutes on fundamentals that are shaping portfolio performance and the overall outlook for the apartment sector. GDP and job growth, as many of you know, continued to decelerate. GDP growth has been below 1.5% now for the last 3 quarters, while job growth is running more than 20% less than its cyclical peak and well off last year's pace so far year-to-date. Lower corporate profits and business confidence is resulting in less investment in labor and capital, as businesses appear reluctant to make new commitments.
Turning to Slide 7. While businesses are slowing down, the consumer appears to still be in good shape. The labor market continues to tighten with more job openings helping to contribute to an improved wage picture. Consumers' balance sheets are in the best shape in many years. And these trends are contributing to cyclically high consumer confidence, which in turn is helping to drive stronger household formation, which is running north of 1 million per year after lingering at generational lows earlier this cycle.
Turning to Slide 8. Longer term, secular trends should continue to support apartment demand. Young adult job growth is outpacing the U.S. average, driven obviously by strong growth in this age cohort. This generation is marrying and having children later. And unsurprisingly, we have seen a strongest household formation for singles and couples as 1- and 2-person households have been responsible for more than 80% of all net new households formed so far this cycle.
Homeownership rates have in turn continued to fall through this segment, helping to stimulate healthy apartment demand in this cycle. While the leading edge of millennials are now in their mid-30s, the largest part of this generation are still in their mid-20s and are expected to stimulate renter demand for several years.
So overall, despite slower economic activity, demand fundamentals are still healthy for the housing market in general and for the apartment sector, specifically.
Turning to Slide 9. Let's take a look at what these trends mean for our markets. So far this cycle, from 2010 to 2015, we've benefited from a significant imbalance between demand and supply. This slide looks at this in a couple of ways. On the left, we look at the broader housing picture, as household formation significantly outpaced housing starts during this period. And on the right, job growth outpaced new apartment deliveries by roughly 2x. So in the first part of the cycle, through 2015, demand has run well above supply and apartment rents have grown well above the long-term trend.
Going forward, over the next 2 to 3 years, and you can see from the right-hand side of both those charts, through 2018, we expect demand and supply to be more in balance, reflecting an industry moving toward equilibrium after years of significant outperformance.
Turning to Slide 10. That notion is certainly reflected in recent rent performance across our markets and in our same-store portfolio. Overall, market rent growth according to Axiometrics has declined from around 5% to 2% to 3% over the last 4 to 5 quarters. Similarly, in our same-store portfolio, we've seen same unit rent growth decline from over 6% to 3% to 4% range during that same time, where the levels that are closer to historical average.
Turning to Slide 11. And double-clicking through on our portfolio a bit here, you can see a couple of other trends. First, we are seeing convergence in performance between East and West, as the differentials in rent growth have narrowed by around 300 basis points over the last year, driven mainly by deceleration in Northern California and some improvement in the Mid-Atlantic. And second, and as we've been discussing in recent quarters, rent growth in the suburbs continues to outpace that in urban submarkets by around 200 basis points given this concentration of the new supply in urban centers.
Let's turn now to investment activity and to Slide 12. Lease-up performance continues to be strong as rents are roughly 200 basis points above pro forma and yields are 30 basis points higher. And with yields well above prevailing cap rates and our marginal cost of capital, new development is contributing meaningfully to NAV and earnings growth well into the current cycle.
Turning to Slide 13. And as discussed a couple of quarters ago, this really has been the case during our life as a public company. This slide depicts development performance across various phases of the cycle since 1995. The strongest performance generally occurs during the expansion phase for sure, but has been healthy even when new development has delivered into the downturn. We believe this speaks to our capability in this area and our disciplined approach to allocating capital to this activity.
Turning now to Slide 14. In addition, we continue to be disciplined in how we capitalize new development commitments. Excluding the benefit of any free cash flow or retained earnings we may enjoy, we're still currently 85% match-funded against our $3.1 billion pipeline, that is we've already raised most of the permanent capital for this bucket of assets well in advance of it producing operating cash flow. So as this development stabilizes, it will add meaningfully to future growth and free cash flow.
Turning to Slide 15 and shifting gears a bit. We thought it might be helpful to briefly review our capital allocation track record over our life as a public company. What we understand that there's a lot of focus right now in moderating fundamentals and the impacts on portfolio performance. We are investing in long-lived assets with an aim to deliver outside total returns over the long run.
As you can see on this chart, over the last 20-plus years, we've been able to generate strong investment and returns with an unlevered IRRs of around 13%. A few points worth noting here. First, we've been able to deliver healthy returns, double-digit IRRs across all of our regions. Second, we generated strong IRRs across both urban and the suburban submarkets. Third, we generated the highest returns in markets where we have the longest tenure, the Mid-Atlantic and Northern California. And our business tenure matters in terms of market intelligence, experience, reputation and relationships. And lastly, while these returns represent a mix of unrealized or projected returns and realized returns, the average is consistent with what has been realized through our dispositions over the last 10 years, as shown on the Attachment 12 of this release.
Now lastly, turning to Slide 16. This long-term track record has certainly extended to the current cycle. So far, this cycle, we've delivered around $4.5 billion of new development at yields that have generated initial NAV accretion of around $2 billion and healthier earnings accretion, contributing to annual compounded growth and core FFO of almost 13% over the last 6 years, a period of time when core FFO per share has more than doubled and dividends have grown by more than 50%.
So in summary, while we are seeing some moderation in fundamentals, it appears that we are settling into a period of equilibrium as the economic expansion plays out. Of course, submarkets and some markets will outperform, while others might lag, but overall, demand and supply seemed to be roughly in balance and projected to remain that way over the next 2 to 3 years. And as we move into the later stages of a very healthy apartment cycle, we continue to exercise a disciplined approach to capital allocation, both in how we raise and deploy capital. And that should allow us to generate solid earnings and NAV growth that will help us outperform.
And with that, Jessica, we'd be happy to open the call for some questions.

Obviously, it was a very modest reduction in terms of full year same-store revenue guidance. And essentially, where the shortfall is occurring is primarily in 4 places. It's Northern California; the greater New York region, including parts of New Jersey; the Mid-Atlantic; and then in Fairfield County. Those are the 4 main drivers of the shortfall relative to our original expectations. So it's not a meaningful difference, but enough that the adjustment was required.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then my final question here concerns development. So it looks like implicitly, I guess, starts are expected to go up in the fourth quarter versus what happened in the third quarter. And just a general question I guess, how are you guys feeling about the development pipeline today? And has any of your assumptions changed in terms of how you're underwriting or the projected yields on the overall pipeline or the things that you're starting in the near term?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, this is Matt. Yes, no, we are expecting a lot of start-up volume here in the fourth quarter. It was always really in the plan that the starts were going to be backloaded this year. And it's really just a function of when those deals work their way t
componenttext: Rich, this is Matt. Yes, no, we are expecting a lot of start-up volume here in the fourth quarter. It was always really in the plan that the starts were going to be backloaded this year. And it's really just a function of when those deals work their way through the system and are ready to start, so we haven't -- I wouldn't say our view has changed in any material way in terms of the attractiveness or the profitability of the development platform. We're still adding new development rights through the course of the year. They're still kind at the same current economics. Again, we underwrite kind of today's rents and costs and expenses that don't really trend, but we're still seeing, on average, our development rights pipeline underwriting to about a mid 6s yield, some variation by region, but that's been pretty consistent really for the last several years. The only thing that's really potentially changed is just different deals will move around quarter-to-quarter. So whether we wind up with this start volume for the total year that we expected at the beginning of the year, probably just depends on what happens with the Columbus Circle deal and whether that starts this quarter or it may slip into the first quarter of next year.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. I guess, I mean one follow-up there. Just simply to the extent that the current environment has deteriorated over the course of 2016, I think where we might be a little bit confused is just how some of the assumptions haven't changed much. I me
componenttext: All right. I guess, I mean one follow-up there. Just simply to the extent that the current environment has deteriorated over the course of 2016, I think where we might be a little bit confused is just how some of the assumptions haven't changed much. I mean is that just a function of underwriting rents versus the basis that you guys have locked in, or is it -- are we misinterpreting kind of the way the numbers move there?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Rich, this is Tim. I mean rents are continuing to increase in our markets generally, and it's a function of how it interplays with construction costs for sure. We are seeing some moderation in some markets on construction costs now. Land costs, as y
componenttext: Well, Rich, this is Tim. I mean rents are continuing to increase in our markets generally, and it's a function of how it interplays with construction costs for sure. We are seeing some moderation in some markets on construction costs now. Land costs, as you know, has locked in. So in terms of overall economics on a current basis, as Matt mentioned, we haven't seen a big change. We published the deals that completed this quarter that stabilized at a 6.4. We've got about $2.5 billion that are under construction that we still estimate at 6.4 and that's what most of that pipeline not remarked to market yet, which we would anticipate that to gravitate up and then just the deals we've been putting under our contract in 2016, which probably has been a little bit of a surprise that they have been as attractive as we -- from an economic standpoint as they've been are kind of consistent with those kinds of returns. So the assumptions are always based upon what we're seeing in the markets today. And I think that's what Matt meant in terms of our underlying assumptions haven't changed in terms of how they're derived.

componenttextpreview: Sean, you mentioned the increase to same-store expense growth is driven by utilities and the delay in tax appeals. Could you talk about what's driving the growth of the more controllable expenses? Looks like payroll, R&M and office operations were up this
componenttext: Sean, you mentioned the increase to same-store expense growth is driven by utilities and the delay in tax appeals. Could you talk about what's driving the growth of the more controllable expenses? Looks like payroll, R&M and office operations were up this quarter.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Nick, this is Sean. Why don't I give you an overview of the change from the midyear guidance that we provided as compared to what we provided last night, if that's helpful. But the growth change, if you look at, call it combined third quarter and fou
componenttext: Yes. Nick, this is Sean. Why don't I give you an overview of the change from the midyear guidance that we provided as compared to what we provided last night, if that's helpful. But the growth change, if you look at, call it combined third quarter and fourth quarter or back-half of the year, represents around $2.6 million, $2.7 million. About a third of that is timing-related. And the majority of that ties to 3 tax appeals in L.A. County that were scheduled and anticipated to occur in Q4 that looks like they're going to slip into Q1 and in the balance of the timing-related component related to the start-up of a cold chain facility at one of our New York high-rise assets, that's been delayed a little bit. So about a third of it, we'll get. We're just going to get a prior closer to Q1 as opposed to Q4. But in terms of the absolute amount of the change, it's about 70 basis points, if you look at the midyear guidance we provided, basically, around 2.4%, that where we're at 3.1% today. The major components are the utilities, it's about $1.8 million, taxes around $700,000, and then there's a couple of hundred thousand related to insurance and payroll. Again, that's sort of comparing back-half of 2016 as compared to our midyear re-forecast, so a big chunk of it again is timing-related, but those are the primary drivers of a difference as compared to what we had said earlier at midyear.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then you said concessions. Can you talk about if you're using concessions under your stabilized properties today. What markets you're doing that? And if it's free rent or gift cards or any other details you can provide on that.
componenttext: And then you said concessions. Can you talk about if you're using concessions under your stabilized properties today. What markets you're doing that? And if it's free rent or gift cards or any other details you can provide on that.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. For the most part, we don't use a lot of concessions, but we do use them in certain markets. And I'd say it depends on a couple of things, Nick. Obviously, in New York, you probably see a greater use of concession given some of the legal rent i
componenttext: Yes, sure. For the most part, we don't use a lot of concessions, but we do use them in certain markets. And I'd say it depends on a couple of things, Nick. Obviously, in New York, you probably see a greater use of concession given some of the legal rent issues that surround that market. And then in certain situations where we think there may be just the bulk of deliveries that's coming through in a particular quarter or 2 that sort of impacts the then current environment, and we want to take sort of a temporary hit as opposed to the full 12 months in reducing the rents when it comes to lease renewal for those customers, that we tend to use. But in terms of the concessions that we granted in the third quarter, it's about $440,000, about 50% of it was in San Francisco, about another 25% was in the Pacific Northwest, which is in a healthy market, but it tends to be a market where there is just a greater use of concessions. So we used concessions last year, we used concessions this year. It's just sort of the nature of the barter in Seattle. But if you look at the year-over-year change, about 85% of the year-over-year increase is really in San Francisco, and that's primarily concentrated at the Mission Bay assets, a little bit at 55 Ninth, a little bit at Ocean Avenue, which are competing with more than new deliveries.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Nick Yulico with UBS.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Nick Yulico with UBS.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of ones. First on a couple of markets like if you think about New York, San Francisco, I mean if you look at Axiometrics data showing that year-over-year has been no rent growth or slightly negative rent growth in the market. What point does that
componenttext: A couple of ones. First on a couple of markets like if you think about New York, San Francisco, I mean if you look at Axiometrics data showing that year-over-year has been no rent growth or slightly negative rent growth in the market. What point does that flow into your portfolio more so where if market rents just aren't moving, I mean how do you still keep up, let's say, positive renewals in both markets?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nick, this is Sean. In terms of a bleeding through the portfolio, I mean the softer market environment this year, obviously, has already started to bleed through the portfolio, which was our original expectation at the beginning of the year in the gu
componenttext: Yes, Nick, this is Sean. In terms of a bleeding through the portfolio, I mean the softer market environment this year, obviously, has already started to bleed through the portfolio, which was our original expectation at the beginning of the year in the guidance that we provided. The rate at which it bleeds through the portfolio really is a function of a couple of different things. For the most part, it really does depend on turnover rates, because if you're turning over say a 54% or a 55% of the portfolio every year, that's going to get mark-to-market to some degree, and then the balance of it really is in renewals. And historically, we have seen more pricing power with renewals relative to new move-ins because of switching costs and things of that sort. So it takes a period of time for that to happen. So obviously, in some markets we are seeing rents go down relative to this point last year, I'd say, particularly in the markets like San Francisco or a little bit in New York City, but we're seeing overall positive rent change currently in those markets, I'd say, due to 2 reasons. One is we probably are performing slightly better than the market average in those markets. And secondly, it's just a function of the renewals versus new move-ins that I described previously.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. Just second question, maybe for Tim. Are you seeing any change in cap rates for where multifamilies assets are trading in the private market? I mean if we think about how much rent growth has slowed in some markets and just look at m
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. Just second question, maybe for Tim. Are you seeing any change in cap rates for where multifamilies assets are trading in the private market? I mean if we think about how much rent growth has slowed in some markets and just look at multifamily sector overall for the REITs, we've also seen growth slowing. How -- it's hard for, I think, some people to imagine how cap rates won't move higher to reflect this? What are you seeing for asset values today?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Nick, I think I'll probably refer to Matt for acquisition disposition reports to him, but, obviously, we've been active on the disposition side, both around portfolio and for -- as we winded down some of the funds and then we get more active on the
componenttext: Well, Nick, I think I'll probably refer to Matt for acquisition disposition reports to him, but, obviously, we've been active on the disposition side, both around portfolio and for -- as we winded down some of the funds and then we get more active on the acquisition side in a couple of markets. But Matt, maybe just speak to kind of what we've been seeing there from a cap rate perspective.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it probably does vary by market and by asset type. And really,  it's a function of where the capital is most aggressive, so what we're finding is older assets to the value-added story, particularly on the West coast, it's still very, very dee
componenttext: Yes. I think it probably does vary by market and by asset type. And really,  it's a function of where the capital is most aggressive, so what we're finding is older assets to the value-added story, particularly on the West coast, it's still very, very deep. We probably sold an asset Avalon Brandemoor in the northern suburbs of Seattle and that was a sub-5 cap rate on an asset that was 15 years old, and a good submarket, but not one of the more sought-after submarkets in metro Seattle, and that's just a reflection of the fact there's a lot of value-added money chasing that story, if you will. In some other locations, I don't know, really, I couldn't tell you where Northern California cap rates are today. Obviously, there has been a lot of deceleration of NOI growth there, and we have not bought or sold anything in Northern Cal in a while. And I think asset volumes are down a little bit there because of that, so we haven't been selling kind of real core stuff, and that's where you might see the impacts felt more so, but we don't have any direct evidence to speak to that on either the buyer or the sell-side.
