What's giving you comfort that we stay there, or what are some of the assumptions behind that, behind those comments?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Jeff, we try to say that on Slide 9. I mean, first of all, in terms of changes in guidance, it's really a reflection of it being a weaker economic environment than consensus or us have anticipated. So as the environment deteriorates further, and we
componenttext: Well, Jeff, we try to say that on Slide 9. I mean, first of all, in terms of changes in guidance, it's really a reflection of it being a weaker economic environment than consensus or us have anticipated. So as the environment deteriorates further, and we are anticipating some moderation in both -- in job growth and an increase in supply in our markets over the next couple of years. But I think we show on Slide 9 that we think it's roughly about -- and if you look at the overall housing picture, we're starting at between 1.1 million and 1.2 million units per year, and about 400,000 of those are multifamily, almost all of those are rental. That's about -- on a percentage basis, that's about what you're seeing in terms of renter propensities right now. It just seems like the market is producing housing that's consistent with what we're seeing at -- from a marginal demand standpoint which autotranslate into inflation or maybe a little bit better in terms of rent growth. And I think if you're seeing tightness anywhere, it's probably more in the for-sale arena where there's still being kind of 5% kind of growth in value. So we're not seeing too much supply in terms of the overall housing picture. We are seeing pockets of oversupply for sure, and we've talked about those markets, and so some will leave and some will lag. But overall, based upon an economy that's growing at, call it, 2%, and jobs that are growing around 1.5%, and supply that's been delivered into the market at about 1.5% of, that just looks like equilibrium to us, so supply being roughly equivalent to demand.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Does it -- do you also assume that in '18 that supply is going to really come down or no, that's not part of your thought process right now?
componenttext: Does it -- do you also assume that in '18 that supply is going to really come down or no, that's not part of your thought process right now?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Modestly, Jeff, I think it may come down less for a couple of reasons. One, I think the projection for '17 are probably going to prove out to be too high again because it just seems like supply just gets delayed. Some of the supply, I think, over the last
componenttext: Modestly, Jeff, I think it may come down less for a couple of reasons. One, I think the projection for '17 are probably going to prove out to be too high again because it just seems like supply just gets delayed. Some of the supply, I think, over the last couple of years, 15% to 20% of what we're expected hitting that year ended up getting delayed. So if anything, we've been overestimating supply for the next year. And so I suspect some of the '17 deliveries will leak into '18, and that you'll see a more -- I think you'll see a fairly level supply picture for the next couple of years is our own sense.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And Juan has a question.
componenttext: Okay. And Juan has a question.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could follow-up on Jeff's point. If you could just through your '17 supply assumptions across your major markets, and in particular, maybe if you could touch on Northern California, how that comes online throughout '17? Is it front-end loaded or is i
componenttext: If I could follow-up on Jeff's point. If you could just through your '17 supply assumptions across your major markets, and in particular, maybe if you could touch on Northern California, how that comes online throughout '17? Is it front-end loaded or is it kind of pretty evenly distributed throughout the year?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Juan, this is Sean. Why don't I take that one? In terms of the expectations for '17, before I kind of run through the markets, one thing to keep in mind, as Tim noted, is for the most part, over the last 3 years, I'd say supply has been, call it, str
componenttext: Yes. Juan, this is Sean. Why don't I take that one? In terms of the expectations for '17, before I kind of run through the markets, one thing to keep in mind, as Tim noted, is for the most part, over the last 3 years, I'd say supply has been, call it, stretched out, if you want to think about it that way, where expected deliveries are pushed off into the subsequent period. But in terms of what we're seeing for 2017 right now across our markets, the expectations we're going to be somewhere in the neighborhood of about 2% of inventory. And the way that breaks down, to give you some perspective, is the New England market, it's about 2.5%, Metro New York-New Jersey around 1.8%, Mid-Atlantic high 2s, Pacific Northwest, still elevated, up at 3.7%, Northern Cal mid-2s, and Southern Cal, kind of in the mid-1% range. My expectation is those are going to trend down as we digest numbers and refresh our supply pipeline when we get to January. One thing to keep in mind is some of those deals are in the pipeline as projected starts, but when people start looking at their numbers and are seeing construction costs up quite a bit over the last couple of years they've been processing a deal, and then a tightening that we've seen in the financial markets as we it relates to construction lending and a little bit on the equity side as well, yes, some of those deals probably just aren't going to make.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And just one quick follow-up. Are you seeing any pull into San Francisco of demand that otherwise would have been in Oakland or San Jose from the discounting for the new projects?
componenttext: All right. And just one quick follow-up. Are you seeing any pull into San Francisco of demand that otherwise would have been in Oakland or San Jose from the discounting for the new projects?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know, a little bit, but nothing that's really discernible that shows up in the data that you could call it a significant trend. Typically, it takes a period of time for that to happen. And we've been talking about certainly a decelerating growth in Sa
componenttext: You know, a little bit, but nothing that's really discernible that shows up in the data that you could call it a significant trend. Typically, it takes a period of time for that to happen. And we've been talking about certainly a decelerating growth in San Francisco for the last few quarters, but it's really only, I'd say, in the last 6 months that it's really come down quite a bit. And people are on a year leases and things like that, so it typically takes a year or 2 for that phenomenon really to occur. If you think about the early part of this cycle, San Francisco outperformed quite a while and San Jose as well, but for the East Bay sort of caught up, and East Bay has been outperforming in the last couple of years of the cycle.

componenttext: It's Austin Wurschmidt here with Jordan. I was just curious if you could update on your outlook for job growth. I think last quarter, you mentioned it came down 50 basis points roughly from your expectation, but just curious what your outlook is as we move into 2017.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Austin, this is Sean. Why don't I take the first half of it and then Tim want to comment as well. But in terms of forecast for 2016, we rely on several different jobs to kind of get aligned around where we think job growth is going to end up. That in
componenttext: Yes. Austin, this is Sean. Why don't I take the first half of it and then Tim want to comment as well. But in terms of forecast for 2016, we rely on several different jobs to kind of get aligned around where we think job growth is going to end up. That includes sort of the native consensus as well as Moody's. And right now, the numbers are sort of in the 2.3 million to 2.4 million jobs range for the calendar year. And in terms of 2017, the expectation is for job growth at least at this point to be relatively similar to 2016. So certainly, that will be updated as Q4 evolves and we get to January, but the expectation is that job growth will be relatively similar next year as to this year, which is down, as Tim mentioned, relative to 2015 and 2014.

componenttext: And just as a follow-up to that. As I mentioned earlier, it's around 1.5%, and our markets were expecting about 1.7%. And the only real anomaly is Seattle where we're still expecting job growth north of 3%. The others are kind of in the mid-1% range, all of the regions.

componenttext: And then just on DC, it's been one of the few submarkets that's been accelerating. It stalled a bit this quarter. I know you highlighted it from a question earlier in the call, but just curious what your thoughts are. And how this market -- how it should fare moving forward? componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Sean, Austin. Yes, the trend we believe that will occur is continued acceleration in revenue performance there. We thought it would have accelerated probably a little bit more in the third quarter and fourth quarter, but it's still kind of a
componenttext: Yes. This is Sean, Austin. Yes, the trend we believe that will occur is continued acceleration in revenue performance there. We thought it would have accelerated probably a little bit more in the third quarter and fourth quarter, but it's still kind of a bump along here. So there is still -- one thing to realize is job growth has been much better in the DC metro area, but supply has still been plentiful, so we're going to continue to see it rise, but it's going to be at a pretty moderate pace as we move into next year.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to talk about the 2 acquisitions, and I know you've mentioned attractive merchant deals in the past. Just wondering given the fact that you have such good economics in your own development pipeline, how did you think about the 2 deals there? I
componenttext: Just wanted to talk about the 2 acquisitions, and I know you've mentioned attractive merchant deals in the past. Just wondering given the fact that you have such good economics in your own development pipeline, how did you think about the 2 deals there? I think, if I'm not wrong, one of them was a lease-up other than -- another one was a land swap of sorts. Could you provide more details on that and the yields you expect?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. This is Matt. I can speak to that. I wouldn't say it's either or between the 2 investment activities. We're really not funding acquisitions through expansion of the balance sheet. It's really portfolio management. So essentially, we are in the
componenttext: Yes, sure. This is Matt. I can speak to that. I wouldn't say it's either or between the 2 investment activities. We're really not funding acquisitions through expansion of the balance sheet. It's really portfolio management. So essentially, we are in the market when we think that there are assets that are attractively priced. And if we find assets that we like, then we can always fund those through incremental dispositions. And we've wound up this year selling more than we probably planned to sell at the beginning of the year because we have been successful in finding some interesting acquisition candidates, so that doesn't really displace the development activity from a funding point of view. So that's the first thing. And then in terms of the specific deals, we have been concentrating in the Mid-Atlantic. For the most part, we sold down in the Mid-Atlantic back in '11 and '12, kind of saw the softness coming here. So we're actually under-allocated against our kind of our long-term targets. We haven't been as actively developing in this market through the cycle either. So the one deal we bought in South Arlington has been allocated to the retail we -- basically, it's a low 5 cap, 330,000 units for concrete frame construction that's 8 or 9 years old, that's below replacement costs for that submarket, so we felt that as a pretty compelling by that's a submarket that's suffered some in the last couple of years, and we think has bottomed out, and we're starting to see positive revenue growth there again, so we feel like it was a well-timed acquisition and should be a great investment. The other deal we bought, just completed the lease-up. It's a smaller deal in North Hollywood, and that -- the other region I'd say we're under-allocated to at this point is Southern California. It's been more difficult there because cap rates are quite a bit lower than there in the Mid-Atlantic, but still that deal, we think it's a low 4s cap. And after allocating to the retail, we think the basis in the residential is about 400,000 units, which again is a pretty compelling basis for that location. And that's a submarket where we are looking for more exposure where we see a lot of good things happening and where we think that we're in a good point in the cycle there.

componenttextpreview: Sean, what were overall new and renewals in 3Q for the portfolio? And how is that trending into October?
componenttext: Sean, what were overall new and renewals in 3Q for the portfolio? And how is that trending into October?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Conor. In terms of move-ins in Q3, average 2.1%, renewals were 4.8%, so blended to the 3.5 in Q3. And in October, obviously, call it a little bit earlier this year than last year, as I recall, but basically, low 2% range for October to date. This dat
componenttext: Yes, Conor. In terms of move-ins in Q3, average 2.1%, renewals were 4.8%, so blended to the 3.5 in Q3. And in October, obviously, call it a little bit earlier this year than last year, as I recall, but basically, low 2% range for October to date. This data is as of, call it, a few days ago, basically, and still running in the high 4s on the renewals, but slightly negative on the new move-ins, which is primarily a result of Northern California, and New York and New England, and the Boston market, a little bit of a push on our part to get a little more occupancy as we get into the latter part of the fourth quarter. So a little more pressure on rate in October.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And Sean, I know last year in 3Q, you guys were aggressive in pushing price and taking a dip in occupancy. Do you think you were too aggressive this year in dropping occupancy to get price in -- particularly in the Mid-Atlantic?
componenttext: Great. And Sean, I know last year in 3Q, you guys were aggressive in pushing price and taking a dip in occupancy. Do you think you were too aggressive this year in dropping occupancy to get price in -- particularly in the Mid-Atlantic?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, last year I'd say we were relatively aggressive. This year as the year has evolved, the posture has changed. Every market is a little bit different and really every asset is a little bit different. But I'm not sure that we would revisit the d
componenttext: Yes, I mean, last year I'd say we were relatively aggressive. This year as the year has evolved, the posture has changed. Every market is a little bit different and really every asset is a little bit different. But I'm not sure that we would revisit the decisions a lot. I mean, the Mid-Atlantic, we basically put out an expectation mid-year that things would continue to improve at a greater rate than what's actually been -- what's actually occurred. Whether you could tie that back to rate of occupancy and say that we were too aggressive, I wouldn't necessarily say that. We were trying to push a bit. But to get the rate growth, you've got to have some of the occupancy. And if the occupancy didn't show up, you're just not going to get it. So I think it's really a blend of both. I wouldn't just tie it to 1 piece or the other.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Conor, it's Tim. I can speak to that. I mean, we've been demolishing the existing building there for a good part of the year. We're just completing that process now and still need to get sign-off -- final sign-off by the city. And so it's really been probably more a function of that. And I think we reported maybe last quarter or the quarter before, we are still considering bringing in a capital partner there. It's not necessarily a requirement from our perspective but something we are considering, but that isn't holding up work. And we'll probably get started with maybe some site-enabling work here before the end of the year. But between kind of where -- how long it took us to get the demolition done and finishing up our plans. It's looking -- it's just looking like right around the end of the year for the start of the new building.

componenttext: Okay. So -- and that would be the only deal that would possibly cause you to miss your guidance for $1.2 billion in starts this year?

componenttext: Sean, you talked earlier about the weakness in Northern California and New York City among other markets. When you're looking at supply coming online in those markets that are directly impacting your assets, or likely to directly impact your assets, if you assume job growth remains static, I mean, when is the sort of peak sort of disruption to your assets from an operational standpoint? Are we in that now? Is that sometime in early '17? Is that back end '17? How are you guys thinking about that?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think for the most part, if you look at it, New York, the supply is actually expected to increase in '17 relative to '16. So I think the pain is going to continue in New York through '17 for certain. It's really going to be what Tim said, which is a
componenttext: So I think for the most part, if you look at it, New York, the supply is actually expected to increase in '17 relative to '16. So I think the pain is going to continue in New York through '17 for certain. It's really going to be what Tim said, which is a function of job growth, what's happening in the economic environment that will determine rent change performance and ultimately revenue performance, but supply is expected to continue. And as it relates to our specific portfolio in New York City, really what you worry about is supply being delivered. And Midtown West is impacting us, that's probably the bulk of it. There's some supply in Long Island City, but it's more downtown than on the waterfront, and Long Island City is actually performing quite well. The other market that we'll probably going to start to see more pressure is in Brooklyn. There's more deliveries in Brooklyn next year as compared to this year. For the most part it's been a relatively light year in deliveries. It's just starting to pick up in Q4. So that sort of the broad picture in New York. As it relates to Northern California, also expect to see a pickup in deliveries in Northern California next year about 40 or 50 basis points as compared to 2016. It goes from about 1.8% to 2.3%. Again, we're going to be massaging those numbers as we get to December and January. A number of those deals are already under construction, of course. But for the most part what we have seen is that those deals have been delayed in terms of actually getting through the system, getting everything signed off, et cetera. But if you look at where the deliveries are going to be concentrated, it's sort of the same place as really in terms of what's happening in the mid-market, south market, et cetera. So in terms of our portfolio, the Mission Bay assets and 55 Ninth will continue to be impacted in 2017. I don't have the quarterly breakdown for '18 at this point. It's probably a little premature to talk about it, but by January we'll have a pretty good outline of that.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then your turnover levels look pretty sort of static. Are you seeing any material increase in days vacant between turns?
componenttext: Okay. And then your turnover levels look pretty sort of static. Are you seeing any material increase in days vacant between turns?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not really. When you look at it on a quarter-over-quarter basis, it's not really changing much. I think the third quarter around 22, 23. That's pretty consistent for the third quarter, a lot of leasing velocity, a lot of turn activity. So did not change m
componenttext: Not really. When you look at it on a quarter-over-quarter basis, it's not really changing much. I think the third quarter around 22, 23. That's pretty consistent for the third quarter, a lot of leasing velocity, a lot of turn activity. So did not change materially. You'll see that number increase in the fourth quarter and in the first quarter as a result of just the seasonal nature of the market. And you don't have to turn things as fast because demand is not as robust in those quarters as compared to Q2 and Q3. Therefore, you're not going to outsource turns and things like that, that costs more money just to get it done faster.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then any increase in bad debt?
componenttext: Okay. And then any increase in bad debt?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bad debt has been higher than our expectation pretty much all year, around 13, 14 basis points higher. We expect it to be around 76 basis points or so. We're running closer to 90. And really, if you look at it for the full year in terms of operating expen
componenttext: Bad debt has been higher than our expectation pretty much all year, around 13, 14 basis points higher. We expect it to be around 76 basis points or so. We're running closer to 90. And really, if you look at it for the full year in terms of operating expenses relative to our original budget, we're talking about an insignificant variance. It's like 0.2% in terms of total operating expenses relative to our original budget, and the only difference really is in bad debt.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So going back to your comments on supply and the performance that was between suburban and urban assets, I was wondering if you could comment if you expect that trend to continue, meaning suburban outperforming urban for next couple of years and supply to
componenttext: So going back to your comments on supply and the performance that was between suburban and urban assets, I was wondering if you could comment if you expect that trend to continue, meaning suburban outperforming urban for next couple of years and supply to remain focused on urban markets?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, maybe I can -- I'll start and maybe Matt or Sean will step in. I think we are expecting supply in urban markets -- urban submarkets to be twice that of suburban submarkets in 2017, which is actually a larger disparity than what we saw in 2016. So you
componenttext: Yes, maybe I can -- I'll start and maybe Matt or Sean will step in. I think we are expecting supply in urban markets -- urban submarkets to be twice that of suburban submarkets in 2017, which is actually a larger disparity than what we saw in 2016. So you can see on that chart, it's been about a 200 basis points delta on rent performance over the last, call it, 8 quarters. We would expect that certainly to continue into 2017 and maybe to a lesser extent as you go down into beyond 2018. But over the next 1 to 2 years, we think that trend is going to continue.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in your initial remarks you also talked about equilibrium over the next couple of years and disciplined approach to capital allocation. I was wondering what that translates into development starts over the next few years?
componenttext: Okay. And then in your initial remarks you also talked about equilibrium over the next couple of years and disciplined approach to capital allocation. I was wondering what that translates into development starts over the next few years?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have a pipeline of close to $4 billion, which would suggest kind of low $1 billion range in terms of starts assuming they continue to make sense and they get through the process and the economics make sense. But from a discipline standpoint, I gu
componenttext: Well, we have a pipeline of close to $4 billion, which would suggest kind of low $1 billion range in terms of starts assuming they continue to make sense and they get through the process and the economics make sense. But from a discipline standpoint, I guess, I'd say a few things. One, once we start the Columbus Circle and the Hollywood deal, we'll actually have less than $100 million of land on the balance sheet, which actually is a cyclical low in maybe over the last 2 cycles. So part of the discipline has been around managing that land exposure from -- in terms of when you actually buy the land versus optional land. And then secondly, as we've been talking about over the last few quarters is how we capitalize the deals once we do start them. As I mentioned we're around 85% match-funded without consideration of any free cash flow right now. So in effect, we've already capitalized what's already been started and not just in -- as we get later and later in the cycle, we'll continue to be conservative with how we manage that -- the exposure of unfunded commitments. So it's going to be -- so much depends on how attractive the deals are relative to the capital environment at this time. But as we said on one of the slides, and we showed this in one of the slides, over the last 20 years as a public company, we had demonstrated you can continue to create value through all phases of the cycle as long as you are disciplined about how you bring those deals into the pipeline and ultimately how you capitalize them.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll now take our next question from Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: We'll now take our next question from Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 questions here. First, on Slide 15, the returns that you guys have had on the developments over time, just surprised that the West Coast has had lower returns on average than the East Coast. I would have thought that there would have been more cap
componenttext: Just 2 questions here. First, on Slide 15, the returns that you guys have had on the developments over time, just surprised that the West Coast has had lower returns on average than the East Coast. I would have thought that there would have been more cap rate compression to drive higher returns. So if you could just give a comment, maybe it's the fact that just land from the get-go is more expensive out there and therefore, you just never get there. But that part was a little bit surprising, given cap rate compression.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alex, Tim here. Yes, I guess, the point here, and part of the slide is being a good or a skilled capital allocator is as much about sort of timing and being tactically smart. And by the way, this is all investment, so it isn't just development. This would
componenttext: Alex, Tim here. Yes, I guess, the point here, and part of the slide is being a good or a skilled capital allocator is as much about sort of timing and being tactically smart. And by the way, this is all investment, so it isn't just development. This would include acquisitions, to be clear. And interestingly, our -- the return on acquisitions aren't materially different than development, which sort of speaks to being highly disciplined sort of in terms of investing earlier in the cycle with respect to acquisitions. I mentioned in our comments, we've made more money where we've been the longest, Northern California and Mid-Atlantic. So part of that is just understanding the markets, having deeper relationships, being confident that you're focused on the right deals at the right time of the cycle, which only comes through experience and track record, in our view. So I think -- and then the last thing I'd say is this is only through Q3 of 2014. So I think if you looked at Seattle, in particular, just given some of our recent deals that have completed, those numbers actually will go up from what you see there, of around 10.3%. In the case of Southern California, you're just starting at such a low going in yield. Cap rate compression has really occurred throughout really all of our markets, probably through all the markets nationally. And if anything, where you have probably seen it is there's probably more cap rate compression on the urban product than there has been in the suburban product. So it's probably been -- it probably hasn't been geographical as much as it had been submarket-focused. But again, it comes down -- we're looking at managing to total return. And sometimes that's investing in higher-yielding, slower-growth market. Sometimes it's lower-yielding, higher-growth markets. And I think this chart just really reflects that.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the second question is in response to one of the analysts' questions earlier around San Francisco and if you're seeing sort of a backflow from East Bay back into San Francisco, you said you're not. Are you seeing any change in demand in San
componenttext: Okay. And then the second question is in response to one of the analysts' questions earlier around San Francisco and if you're seeing sort of a backflow from East Bay back into San Francisco, you said you're not. Are you seeing any change in demand in San Francisco? Or is it because your portfolio is -- has a -- a good chunk of it is suburb that maybe you're not seeing -- you're not feeling the impact of a lot of the 2-month rent concession that's attracting renters to move around San Francisco?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Alex, Sean. A couple of things. In terms of my comment earlier about people moving from the East Bay or back end of the city or back end of San Jose, my response is really that we've seen a little bit of that, but it's not a meaningful number at this
componenttext: Yes, Alex, Sean. A couple of things. In terms of my comment earlier about people moving from the East Bay or back end of the city or back end of San Jose, my response is really that we've seen a little bit of that, but it's not a meaningful number at this point, given things have decelerated in San Francisco, obviously, pretty quickly that if someone was considering living in San Francisco at this time last year relative to the East Bay, that's a pretty expensive proposition. And whether you've started to see meaningful deceleration in the second half of this year in that market, people sign 1-year leases, they typically lag a year or 2 before they say, "Okay. The rents have really come down. I think that's the right kind of trade to make." And my point was during the beginning part of the cycle, San Francisco and San Jose outperformed quite a while before the East Bay caught up and then the East Bay has been outperforming the last couple of years. So you would expect that to occur just in the opposite direction as the market decelerates. And in terms of the comment about demand. I mean certainly as Tim pointed out, it is a weaker economic environment than, I think, many of us anticipated, which has resulted in lower job growth across the markets with the exception probably of Seattle. And Northern California has not been immune from that. So there's certainly a weaker demand profile in Northern California that just so happens to be at a time when we have meaningful supply being delivered in San Francisco and, therefore, you're seeing 1-month or 2-month concession sort of the norm on all the new deliveries in San Francisco, as an example.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: But do you feel -- Sean, do you feel that you're sort of on the tail end of that? Or you think that we're having -- you guys expect to have another year of that and, therefore, as you outlined next year you're still going to be talking about the pressure
componenttext: But do you feel -- Sean, do you feel that you're sort of on the tail end of that? Or you think that we're having -- you guys expect to have another year of that and, therefore, as you outlined next year you're still going to be talking about the pressure on the demand and the supply in San Francisco?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I still think there's going to be demand. I mean, assuming that job growth is basically the same and deliveries continue at the rate that's forecasted, which pretty much is baked at this point because those buildings are delivering now, I would expec
componenttext: Yes, I still think there's going to be demand. I mean, assuming that job growth is basically the same and deliveries continue at the rate that's forecasted, which pretty much is baked at this point because those buildings are delivering now, I would expect that Northern California and San Francisco, specifically, that's what you're interested in, will continue to be a weak environment. So if we saw a significant uptick in good job growth, that equation might change.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take a question from Rich Hill with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll take a question from Rich Hill with Morgan Stanley.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just -- I was curious about your comment about the apartments  reaching sort of a steady-state. As I'm thinking about what you've put on the board for the first 9 months relative to your full year guidance, it looks like to me maybe revenue growth and NOI
componenttext: Just -- I was curious about your comment about the apartments  reaching sort of a steady-state. As I'm thinking about what you've put on the board for the first 9 months relative to your full year guidance, it looks like to me maybe revenue growth and NOI growth in the fourth quarter might be decelerating to 3.4% and 2.7%. So I'm wondering if I was thinking about that correctly. And then, number two, if that's sort of the steady-state we should be thinking about going into 2017? Or are we supposed to be more bullish or maybe a little bit more cautious? Any color or transparency would be helpful in that regard.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, Tim here. In terms of Q4. I think your math is approximately correct as it relates to kind of what we're looking for the -- in terms of year-over-year growth. Steady-state, for us, or equilibrium shouldn't be a whole lot more than inflation, from ou
componenttext: Rich, Tim here. In terms of Q4. I think your math is approximately correct as it relates to kind of what we're looking for the -- in terms of year-over-year growth. Steady-state, for us, or equilibrium shouldn't be a whole lot more than inflation, from our perspective I think historically, if you look at our markets, we've been able to generate roughly 70, 75 basis points stronger growth than inflation, whereas nationally it's been probably a little bit closer to inflation. And that's equated into kind of high 2%, maybe just sub-3% kind of rent growth. And so when we're talking about equilibrium, that's the kind of rate of growth we expect to see. We obviously started this year well above that trend. And so while we had seen moderation, it's -- our view has been it's been moderating more towards an industry that's starting to approach demand and supply being roughly equal after 6 years of really an imbalance. And it's kind of what you would expect after a while in capital markets where capital should flow freely to businesses that are sustaining outperformance.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. I mean -- and to that point and maybe taking a little bit more of a positive and longer-term view, do you characterize the supply that's coming to market as more of a bottleneck? Or looking longer-term, can you make the case that we have enough
componenttext: Yes, yes. I mean -- and to that point and maybe taking a little bit more of a positive and longer-term view, do you characterize the supply that's coming to market as more of a bottleneck? Or looking longer-term, can you make the case that we have enough apartments in the United States, or maybe we even need a little bit more apartments in the United States? So I'm curious in your view as an owner of apartments and most likely taking a 10-year view rather than a 6- to 12-month view, how do you think about that? So said another way -- yes, go ahead.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes -- no, no, I think I followed. Our expectation is we're going to see household formation of over 1 million, 1.2 million, 1.4 million kind of on a -- again, kind of on a steady-state basis based upon a reasonable growth in population and jobs. And, in
componenttext: Yes -- no, no, I think I followed. Our expectation is we're going to see household formation of over 1 million, 1.2 million, 1.4 million kind of on a -- again, kind of on a steady-state basis based upon a reasonable growth in population and jobs. And, in our view, is that if you just look at underlying demographics and as the millennials age, that we're going to see basically more balanced housing demand between for sale and rental. Most of the rental has been -- I mean, most of the multifamily that has been built has been purpose-built as rental. And so right now, you have an industry that's generating about 1.2 million houses, new units, against demand that's about 1.2 million. About 2/3 of that is single-family, which is the only purpose-built is for sale, and about 1/3 of that is multifamily, which is purpose-built as rental. The numbers almost can't be more imbalanced than that. And that kind of -- so we look at -- we're going from an industry that's been out of balance, where rental housing demand has been close to 80% or more of total housing demand kind of in early years of the cycle to where it seems like we've found a new -- sort of a new normal, if you will. So that's our view.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from, Tayo Okusanya with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question will come from, Tayo Okusanya with Jefferies.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just there's been a lot of talk recently about rent control hitting the ballot during the election season in the Bay Area. Just kind of curious what you're hearing, what you think the probability of that happening is, and what could be the potential impac
componenttext: Just there's been a lot of talk recently about rent control hitting the ballot during the election season in the Bay Area. Just kind of curious what you're hearing, what you think the probability of that happening is, and what could be the potential impact to your portfolio?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Tayo, it's Sean. You are correct that rent control is on the ballot in about 5 different municipalities in the Northern California market. Only one of the -- I can't speak to exactly what's likely to pass and what's not. That probably changes from we
componenttext: Yes. Tayo, it's Sean. You are correct that rent control is on the ballot in about 5 different municipalities in the Northern California market. Only one of the -- I can't speak to exactly what's likely to pass and what's not. That probably changes from week to week depending on which poll you read, but there is support for -- more than a majority support for some of those ordinances based on kind of recent polling. There's really only 1 that potential impacts our portfolio, which is the proposed rent control ordinance in Mountain View. And if you look at it, it depends on how it's actually adopted. It's actually 2 proposed ordinances on the ballot in Mountain View, one that's sponsored by the city and the other that is sort of a voter referendum. And to the extent that it comes to a fruition, Mountain View, overall, when you look at the assets that are impacted, it would impact around 9% to 10% of our Northern California revenue in terms of the specific assets that fit the vintage that would be governed by the proposed ordinance. And the rent increases, it is a blend. It's limited to CPI plus, but it's got a color on it, minimum 2, max 5. And you can bank it. So you're going to get it over time one way or another in terms of the -- what's happening in the market with vacant CT [ph] control, et cetera.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll now take a question from Drew Babin with Robert W. Baird & Company.
componenttext: We'll now take a question from Drew Babin with Robert W. Baird & Company.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to break down New York metro a little bit more. You mentioned that New York metro results have disappointed year-to-date relative to your expectations. I assume that's been driven more by New York City, with New York suburban and New Jersey actua
componenttext: I wanted to break down New York metro a little bit more. You mentioned that New York metro results have disappointed year-to-date relative to your expectations. I assume that's been driven more by New York City, with New York suburban and New Jersey actually both showing sequential acceleration in 3Q. Did that sequential acceleration in those suburban markets surprise you? Or is it something that was in the underwriting?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we did expect some acceleration in those markets. It actually came in a little bit short of our expectations, but we did expect some acceleration in those markets. And if you look at the fourth quarter, we are falling short across the geography, New Y
componenttext: No, we did expect some acceleration in those markets. It actually came in a little bit short of our expectations, but we did expect some acceleration in those markets. And if you look at the fourth quarter, we are falling short across the geography, New York and metro New Jersey. Less so in New Jersey than certainly in New York and particularly in New York City. But for the most part, I'd say the greater New York regions fall in short of expectations and, to a certain degree, in New Jersey, but just more moderately so.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: You would characterize the suburban kind of marginal weakness as kind of a trickle-down from what's happening in New York with new supply and people just adjusting the pricing in the market? Or what might be behind that?
componenttext: You would characterize the suburban kind of marginal weakness as kind of a trickle-down from what's happening in New York with new supply and people just adjusting the pricing in the market? Or what might be behind that?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I wouldn't say that it's significantly weaker, just we thought things would pick up a little bit more. But the job growth in that region has been weaker over the last 6 months, so I think it's more widespread as opposed to -- as it relates to -- most
componenttext: No, I wouldn't say that it's significantly weaker, just we thought things would pick up a little bit more. But the job growth in that region has been weaker over the last 6 months, so I think it's more widespread as opposed to -- as it relates to -- most people are moving from Central Jersey to Manhattan, as an example. Just that trade and rent usually doesn't make much sense. You don't see that happen. Same thing when you get into Westchester or Long Island, making the trades come into the city is just prohibitively expensive.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one quick one on the downtown Brooklyn development. I noticed the completion date was delayed from 4Q '16 to 1Q '17, but it looks like the leasing statistics and stabilization date are on pace and nothing has really changed there. So I was
componenttext: Okay. And then one quick one on the downtown Brooklyn development. I noticed the completion date was delayed from 4Q '16 to 1Q '17, but it looks like the leasing statistics and stabilization date are on pace and nothing has really changed there. So I was just curious what's behind kind of the move in the completion date.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Drew, this is Matt. It's really just when we get into finishing a building, particularly building of that size and complexity, when we're actually going to be able to kind of close out all the books and everything, and whether the last apartment homes tur
componenttext: Drew, this is Matt. It's really just when we get into finishing a building, particularly building of that size and complexity, when we're actually going to be able to kind of close out all the books and everything, and whether the last apartment homes turn over for occupancy in December or January, it's going to be somewhere right around that time frame. So it's not a response to anything we're seeing. As you point out, the lease-ups have been doing great. So it's just a question of it's up $440-some million assets, so we may keep the books open 1 quarter longer just to make sure we've got everything.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our next question from Vincent Chao with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our next question from Vincent Chao with Deutsche Bank.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most have been answered already, but just sticking with the New Jersey commentary, not necessarily the answer to just the last question, but earlier I thought it sounded like Jersey was specific markets where you're seeing some of that slowdown. Relative
componenttext: Most have been answered already, but just sticking with the New Jersey commentary, not necessarily the answer to just the last question, but earlier I thought it sounded like Jersey was specific markets where you're seeing some of that slowdown. Relative to an earlier expectations, I would presume that's sort of Jersey City waterfront markets, but just curious if it's more widespread than that.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Sean, Vincent. In terms of our portfolio, we really only have 1 asset in Jersey City. So there's certainly a meaningful amount of supply being delivered there, but the portfolio performance isn't significantly impacted by just that 1 asset. A
componenttext: Yes, this is Sean, Vincent. In terms of our portfolio, we really only have 1 asset in Jersey City. So there's certainly a meaningful amount of supply being delivered there, but the portfolio performance isn't significantly impacted by just that 1 asset. As I mentioned, I said job growth has slowed in that region over the last 6 months, and I think it's more widespread and just representative of what you're seeing across all of those markets. Whether it'd be parts of Central Jersey, Northern, Long Island, Westchester, et cetera, job growth has come down across the entire region. So that's really what you're seeing as more softer demand. The supply is sort of as expected.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then we really talked about most of the markets here except for L.A. So just curious if you could give us some commentary on what you're seeing there. We have seen some slowing in the same-store revenue growth for a couple of quarters now and
componenttext: Got it. And then we really talked about most of the markets here except for L.A. So just curious if you could give us some commentary on what you're seeing there. We have seen some slowing in the same-store revenue growth for a couple of quarters now and job growth there also seems to be also decelerating. So how should we be thinking about L.A. going into '17?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, for the most part, L.A. is performing quite well. I mean, there is the -- the only places where there's any pocket of weakness really is the stabilized assets, I'd say, in downtown L.A., as an example, where there's a meaningful amount of sup
componenttext: Yes. I mean, for the most part, L.A. is performing quite well. I mean, there is the -- the only places where there's any pocket of weakness really is the stabilized assets, I'd say, in downtown L.A., as an example, where there's a meaningful amount of supply being delivered there. We only have 1 operating asset there [indiscernible] that we completed earlier in the cycle. But for the most part, L.A. is tracking just fine. Job growth has been slightly weaker, and so that weighed on performance a little bit. But in terms of our expectation for that market, we're tracking pretty close to what we expected in the back half of the year.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Nick Joseph with Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Nick Joseph with Citigroup.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Michael Bilerman. Tim, I'm curious, as you think back to the Archstone transaction, where you and EQR split up the portfolio, if assets were to come to market within your 6 regions, I guess, where -- and obviously at the right price and at the right
componenttext: It's Michael Bilerman. Tim, I'm curious, as you think back to the Archstone transaction, where you and EQR split up the portfolio, if assets were to come to market within your 6 regions, I guess, where -- and obviously at the right price and at the right cost of capital, I guess, which regions or markets would be most interested to you to deepen your presence?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Michael, I've got a couple of comments. Yes, first of all, one of the things that was great about the Archstone transaction, it basically allowed us to get roughly to a target portfolio, particularly as it related to Southern California, which we sor
componenttext: Yes, Michael, I've got a couple of comments. Yes, first of all, one of the things that was great about the Archstone transaction, it basically allowed us to get roughly to a target portfolio, particularly as it related to Southern California, which we sort of had always been short in. But right now, we're not significantly off kind of where we'd like to be in any one region. I think Matt mentioned it's been a little bit behind our buying in the D.C. area. But we think, tactically, it's not a bad time to be buying there, and we had been a little under-allocated since we did the Telfair [ph] bid kind of in early 2010 -- earlier this decade. So it's probably from a market standpoint, it's probably still D.C. and Southern California because those are markets where we could probably still spend a little bit more allocation and we don't think, from a market condition standpoint and a cycle standpoint, it's too bad of a time to be investing a little bit more capital and trimming in some other areas.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as you think about sort of the debt and equity capital that's out there to finance apartment transactions, obviously, we've been -- we've come off 2 years of significant activity by private equity and buying large apartment portfolios and platforms, h
componenttext: And as you think about sort of the debt and equity capital that's out there to finance apartment transactions, obviously, we've been -- we've come off 2 years of significant activity by private equity and buying large apartment portfolios and platforms, how do you sort of look at the market today in terms of being able to finance larger deals, both from a debt and equity perspective?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll maybe just speak from a public market standpoint and maybe wake up Kevin over here, who has been absent in this conversation.
componenttext: I'll maybe just speak from a public market standpoint and maybe wake up Kevin over here, who has been absent in this conversation.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: He gets one. He gets one.
componenttext: He gets one. He gets one.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: But you look at where apartment REITs are trading, obviously, relative to underlying NAV. It doesn't make sense to be using your balance sheet to finance. To the extent you see a portfolio out there that looks better than what you currently own and you ca
componenttext: But you look at where apartment REITs are trading, obviously, relative to underlying NAV. It doesn't make sense to be using your balance sheet to finance. To the extent you see a portfolio out there that looks better than what you currently own and you can finance it through some kind of asset swap or 1031, perhaps that makes sense. Debt continuously obviously plentiful from an unsecured standpoint, but we wouldn't be looking -- and I don't know that -- I guess, I'd be surprised if anybody in the sector would be looking at really levering up to grow at this point in the cycle. And so unless you can find a way to do it on a leverage-neutral way, I don't -- I think public entities are probably at a disadvantage today, but to the extent something came to market. And Kevin, any other thoughts? Want to say hello?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can comment on Southern California and the leasing spreads, too. So no, Michael, I guess, certainly from a financing point of view in the private market, things are tightening up a little bit, particularly in the construction area, as many of you are we
componenttext: I can comment on Southern California and the leasing spreads, too. So no, Michael, I guess, certainly from a financing point of view in the private market, things are tightening up a little bit, particularly in the construction area, as many of you are well aware already. So I think from a supply standpoint longer term, that is a bit of a headwind for those who are looking to add new supply in the private side and finance it in the debt markets, particularly for small, less well-capitalized developers, pricing in construction financing has probably moved beyond 300 basis points over LIBOR, which it affects, of course, what kind of deal is pencil. And then you've got the OTC, which is -- it's pushing banks to lend less on real estate. And the regulatory environment for banks has become more expensive for them to be active in the construction market and be profitable. So I think you're seeing that getting construction financing, particularly in some of these urban submarkets, is a lot more difficult than it has been before. For stabilized financing, the GSEs certainly have been active. For the uncapped business, there is certainly availability that's mostly affordable and the types of opportunities. I think they do expect a record production year. The caps have been lifted a number of times, but their interest in Class A product is more modest, as you are well aware. Nonetheless, banks and insurance companies have been pretty active, while CMBS has been far less so due to the risk retention rule. So I think when you step back in time to some of the comments that Tim made, the capital is there for deals that makes sense, but it's certainly not plentiful now as it has been in recent years on the debt market side. And I think probably, a lot of -- on the equity side, joint venture, sources of capital have been a lot more disciplined because, A, like you and we have been seeing the same headlines about supply in some of the markets that are out there, so they're probably a little bit more cautious, but at the same time, relative to some other sectors in real estate, multifamily even at trend level, revenue growth does provide pretty healthy returns that one can reasonably bank on achieving over the long term.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Well, I guess that's what sets up this divergence between the public stock trading at discounts and whether there's enough private capital out there both from a debt and equity perspective that would find those attractive enough to, or the companie
componenttext: Right. Well, I guess that's what sets up this divergence between the public stock trading at discounts and whether there's enough private capital out there both from a debt and equity perspective that would find those attractive enough to, or the companies themselves saying, "I don't want to trade at a discount anymore. I can monetize that spread by tapping into it." The question is, is that debt and equity as excited about the multifamily business as it has been over the past couple of years, given the volume of deals that has transpired already?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I don't know the answer. That's why I'm looking for you for the answer.
componenttext: Yes, and I don't know the answer. That's why I'm looking for you for the answer.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and so I think it's going to be somewhat a function of the balance sheet as a target to the extent they are more -- they're financed more through secured versus unsecured. It may be more doable than -- and we've seen some recent examples of that in t
componenttext: Yes, and so I think it's going to be somewhat a function of the balance sheet as a target to the extent they are more -- they're financed more through secured versus unsecured. It may be more doable than -- and we've seen some recent examples of that in the apartment space. Obviously, where it was -- we had cleaner balance sheets and more unsecured it tended to be more kind of public to public and where you had more secured financing and tended to -- and maybe a little of a higher leverage tended to be more attractive to the private side.  So I think that's probably as big of a factor as well as just kind of where private versus public market valuations sort of are trending.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Neil Malkin with RBC Capital Market.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Neil Malkin with RBC Capital Market.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first one is on jobs. You kind of made a commentary about job growth being basically in line with this year and next year. But I wonder, digging a little bit deeper. Do you guys look at the types or quality of that job creation? And I asked that becau
componenttext: The first one is on jobs. You kind of made a commentary about job growth being basically in line with this year and next year. But I wonder, digging a little bit deeper. Do you guys look at the types or quality of that job creation? And I asked that because if you look at the higher paying jobs, professional business services, tech, stuff like that, in some coastal markets we're seeing slowdowns, which would augur for less traffic, especially at the high price point type of assets that you guys have. And I wonder if you kind of baked that into your guidance because not all jobs, not all demand is created equal. So how do you kind of think about that, particularly in, let's say, New York and San Francisco, when you have job growth that may be flat but, for example, in New York, you have a lot of hotel and leisure jobs? And I don't know if they can afford $4,000 a month, $5,000 a month apartments. So do you guys have a view on that at all?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we look at jobs a number of ways. I mean, there's pretty good data out there related to kind of mid, high and low-wage job growth in -- I think actually we've gotten -- later in the cycle, we've actually seen stronger growth in our markets in kind o
componenttext: Well, we look at jobs a number of ways. I mean, there's pretty good data out there related to kind of mid, high and low-wage job growth in -- I think actually we've gotten -- later in the cycle, we've actually seen stronger growth in our markets in kind of the mid to higher-wage segments, particularly the mid-wage segments. Whereas kind of early in the cycle, it was -- I think it was a little bit more tilted towards lower. There does seem to be a bit of a disconnect right now. I mean, openings are higher than hires right now, which is putting -- which is a good thing from wage growth standpoint, which allows people to pay higher rents for sure. But it does seem to be that there may be a growing disconnect between kind of what jobs are open versus the availability of labor to fill them. Certainly, as you look at college graduates, the unemployment -- we're at full employment, for sure, people who have college degrees, and that is the majority of our residents. So you may not see as much job growth there, Neil, for that reason over the next 2 -- a year or 2 and I think it's likely to sort of be mixed up and closer to population growth. But on the other hand, it should translate into stronger wage growth than we've seen maybe in kind of the early years of the cycle.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then next question is just given that new leases have slowed across the board, but renewals stay in the mid-single digits, what is the gain or loss lease in your portfolio? And what's your comfort level on that, either way as you go into '17 or
componenttext: Okay. And then next question is just given that new leases have slowed across the board, but renewals stay in the mid-single digits, what is the gain or loss lease in your portfolio? And what's your comfort level on that, either way as you go into '17 or in maybe a slower or more dubious part of the cycle?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes -- no, Neil, that's a good question. One thing to think about related to that is gain and loss lease sort of moves around throughout the seasons of the calendar year. In our business, rents grow pretty rapidly -- market rents grow pretty rapidly from
componenttext: Yes -- no, Neil, that's a good question. One thing to think about related to that is gain and loss lease sort of moves around throughout the seasons of the calendar year. In our business, rents grow pretty rapidly -- market rents grow pretty rapidly from sort of early February up through July, early August, and then trail off in terms of what's expected for, basically, the latter part of the third quarter and the fourth quarter. So taking a snapshot of loss lease, at this moment in time doesn't necessarily represent how you want to think about rent growth for next year. So I think you've really got to sort of model it in a way is that you'd look at typical trajectory of rents from the trough late in the fourth quarter to the peak, to the fall in August, and then determine how much you think you're going to get during that period of time that will then ripple through lease expirations. So that's how we think about it more so than we've got X percent or X dollars sort of vacant rent at this moment based on today's market rent, if that makes sense. Does it make sense?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, I understand it goes through cycles based on peak or shoulder season. I just mean if you think about how you're rolling over -- so like trailing 4-quarter period, right, you would have a full cycle or a leasing season. And I just wonder, I thin
componenttext: Well, yes, I understand it goes through cycles based on peak or shoulder season. I just mean if you think about how you're rolling over -- so like trailing 4-quarter period, right, you would have a full cycle or a leasing season. And I just wonder, I think someone asked the question earlier, I mean, how -- when does that start to impact potentially renewals? Essentially you don't want to generate a gain to lease that's unsustainable or that would leave you susceptible if markets turn or job growth slows more than you think.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I guess one way to describe that to you is if you just sort of take a snapshot of where the rent roll was today relative to what the rent roll has averaged for 2016. You're kind of in the low 1% range, 1.25% or something like that, that if no
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I guess one way to describe that to you is if you just sort of take a snapshot of where the rent roll was today relative to what the rent roll has averaged for 2016. You're kind of in the low 1% range, 1.25% or something like that, that if nothing happened next year in terms of rents growing at all you'd be delivering north of 1% revenue growth in sort of a static market. I mean, that's one way to look at it. And then you just have to apply what you think is going to happen with rent growth through the fourth quarter and then throughout '17 to determine what you think you're actually going to really do in '17.
