headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jessica, and welcome to AvalonBay Communities Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Before we begin, please note that forward-looking statements may be made during this discussion. There are a variety of risks and uncertainties associated w
componenttext:
Thanks, Jessica, and welcome to AvalonBay Communities Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Before we begin, please note that forward-looking statements may be made during this discussion. There are a variety of risks and uncertainties associated with the forward-looking statements, and actual results may differ materially. There is a discussion of these risks and uncertainties in yesterday afternoon's press release as well as in the company's Form 10-K and Form 10-Q filed with the SEC. As usual, this press release does include an attachment with definitions and reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures and other terms, which may be used in today's discussion. The attachment is also available on our website at www.avalonbay.com/earnings. And we encourage you to refer to this information during the review of our operating results and financial performance.
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Tim Naughton, Chairman and CEO of AvalonBay Communities, for his remarks. Tim?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Jason. And welcome to our third quarter call. With me today are Kevin O'Shea, Sean Breslin and Matt Birenbaum. I will be providing management commentary in the slides that we posted yesterday after the market closed, and all of us will be ava
componenttext:
Yes. Thanks, Jason. And welcome to our third quarter call. With me today are Kevin O'Shea, Sean Breslin and Matt Birenbaum. I will be providing management commentary in the slides that we posted yesterday after the market closed, and all of us will be available for Q&A afterwards.
My comments will focus on providing a summary of Q3, year-to-date results, our outlook for 2016, a look at fundamentals, and lastly, an update on investment activity and a look back on our capital allocation track record.
So let's start on Slide 4. It was a solid quarter, where we achieved core FFO growth of 7.3% from a combination of same-store NOI growth of over 4% and healthy contributions continuing from new lease-ups. Year-to-date core FFO per share is up over 9%. And in Q3, we raised over $1 billion in new capital, including the October bond deal and disposition activity, to fund ongoing, and the upcoming development and to pay off maturing debt.
Turning to Slide 5, our updated outlook for the year. We have updated our outlook for FFO and same-store metrics. Core FFO per share has been reduced by $0.05 per share or 70 basis points for the full year to 8.3%, due to a combination of factors, including same-store revenue growth being trimmed by around 12 basis points from our midyear forecast from a mix of lower-projected occupancy and rate for Q4. Secondly, a higher same-store operating expenses, related primarily to higher utility costs and delayed resolution of several tax appeals. Thirdly, lower redevelopment NOI. And lastly, higher interest rate -- higher interest related costs in connection with our recent $650 million bond deal that we completed earlier this month.
Turning now to Slide 6. We thought we'd spend a couple of minutes on fundamentals that are shaping portfolio performance and the overall outlook for the apartment sector. GDP and job growth, as many of you know, continued to decelerate. GDP growth has been below 1.5% now for the last 3 quarters, while job growth is running more than 20% less than its cyclical peak and well off last year's pace so far year-to-date. Lower corporate profits and business confidence is resulting in less investment in labor and capital, as businesses appear reluctant to make new commitments.
Turning to Slide 7. While businesses are slowing down, the consumer appears to still be in good shape. The labor market continues to tighten with more job openings helping to contribute to an improved wage picture. Consumers' balance sheets are in the best shape in many years. And these trends are contributing to cyclically high consumer confidence, which in turn is helping to drive stronger household formation, which is running north of 1 million per year after lingering at generational lows earlier this cycle.
Turning to Slide 8. Longer term, secular trends should continue to support apartment demand. Young adult job growth is outpacing the U.S. average, driven obviously by strong growth in this age cohort. This generation is marrying and having children later. And unsurprisingly, we have seen thea strongest household formation for singles and couples as 1- and 2-person households have been responsible for more than 80% of all net new households formed so far this cycle.
Homeownership rates have in turn continued to fall through this segment, helping to stimulate healthy apartment demand this cycle. While the leading edge of millennials are now in their mid-30s, the largest part of this generation are still in their mid-20s and are expected to stimulate renter demand for several years.
So overall, despite slower economic activity, demand fundamentals are still healthy for the housing market in general and for the apartment sector, specifically.
Turning to Slide 9. Let's take a look at what these trends mean for our markets. So far this cycle, from 2010 to 2015, we've benefited from a significant imbalance between demand and supply. This slide looks at this in a couple of ways. On the left, we look at the broader housing picture, as household formation significantly outpaced housing starts during this period. And on the right, job growth outpaced new apartment deliveries by roughly 2x. So in the first part of the cycle, through 2015, demand has run well above supply and apartment rents have grown well above the long-term trend.
Going forward, over the next 2 to 3 years, and you can see from the right-hand side of both those charts, through 2018, we expect demand and supply to be more in balance, reflecting an industry moving toward equilibrium after years of significant outperformance.
Turning to Slide 10. That notion is certainly reflected in recent rent performance across our markets and in our same-store portfolio. Overall, market rent growth according to Axiometrics has declined from around 5% to 2% to 3% over the last 4 to 5 quarters. Similarly, in our same-store portfolio, we've seen same unit rent growth decline from over 6% to 3% to 4% range during that same time, or to levels that are closer to historical average.
Turning to Slide 11. And double-clicking through on our portfolio a bit here, you can see a couple of other trends. First, we are seeing convergence in performance between East and West, as the differentials in rent growth have narrowed by around 300 basis points over the last year, driven mainly by deceleration in Northern California and some improvement in the Mid-Atlantic. And second, and as we've been discussing in recent quarters, rent growth in the suburbs continues to outpace that in urban submarkets by around 200 basis points given this concentration of the new supply in urban centers.
Let's turn now to investment activity and to Slide 12. Lease-up performance continues to be strong as rents are roughly 200 basis points above pro forma and yields are 30 basis points higher. And with yields well above prevailing cap rates and our marginal cost of capital, new development is contributing meaningfully to NAV and earnings growth well into the current cycle.
Turning to Slide 13. And as discussed a couple of quarters ago, this really has been the case during our life as a public company. This slide depicts development performance across various phases of the cycle since 1995. The strongest performance generally occurs during the expansion phase for sure, but has been healthy even when new development has delivered into the downturn. We believe this speaks to our capability in this area and our disciplined approach to allocating capital to this activity.
Turning now to Slide 14. In addition, we continue to be disciplined in how we capitalize new development commitments. Excluding the benefit of any free cash flow or retained earnings we may enjoy, we're still currently 85% match-funded against our $3.1 billion pipeline, that is, we've already raised most of the permanent capital for this bucket of assets well in advance of it producing operating cash flow. So as this development stabilizes, it will add meaningfully to future growth and free cash flow.
Turning to Slide 15 and shifting gears a bit. We thought it might be helpful to briefly review our capital allocation track record over our life as a public company. While we understand that there's a lot of focus right now in moderating fundamentals and the impacts on portfolio performance, we are investing in long-lived assets with an aim to deliver outside total returns over the long run.
As you can see on this chart, over the last 20-plus years, we've been able to generate strong investment returns with unlevered IRRs of around 13%. A few points worth noting here. First, we've been able to deliver healthy returns, double-digit IRRs across all of our regions. Second, we generated strong IRRs across both urban and suburban submarkets. Third, we generated the highest returns in markets where we have the longest tenure, the Mid-Atlantic and Northern California. In our business, tenure matters in terms of market intelligence, experience, reputation and relationships. And lastly, while these returns represent a mix of unrealized or projected returns and realized returns, the average is consistent with what has been realized through our dispositions over the last 10 years, as shown on the Attachment 12 of this release.
Now lastly, turning to Slide 16. This long-term track record has certainly extended to the current cycle. So far, this cycle, we've delivered around $4.5 billion of new development at yields that have generated initial NAV accretion of around $2 billion and healthier earnings accretion, contributing to annual compounded growth and core FFO of almost 13% over the last 6 years, a period of time when core FFO per share has more than doubled and dividends have grown by more than 50%.
So in summary, while we are seeing some moderation in fundamentals, it appears that we are settling into a period of equilibrium as the economic expansion plays out. Of course, submarkets and some markets will outperform, while others might lag, but overall, demand and supply seemed to be roughly in balance and projected to remain that way over the next 2 to 3 years. And as we move into the later stages of a very healthy apartment cycle, we continue to exercise a disciplined approach to capital allocation, both in how we raise and deploy capital. And that should allow us to generate solid earnings and NAV growth that will help us outperform.
And with that, Jessica, we'd be happy to open the call for some questions.

componenttext: Yes. Rich, this is Sean. I can give you sort of a general overview of where we're seeing market performance relative to our midyear expectations if that's helpful. Obviously, it was a very modest reduction in terms of full year same-store revenue guidance. And essentially, where the shortfall is occurring is primarily in 4 places. It's Northern California; the greater New York region, including parts of New Jersey; the Mid-Atlantic; and then in Fairfield County. Those are the 4 main drivers of the shortfall relative to our original expectations. So it's not a meaningful difference, but enough that the adjustment was required.

componenttext: Sure. For third quarter, blended rent change was 3.5%. And to just kind of walk through the markets here, that represents 3.2% in New England, about 2.5% in the Metro New York-New Jersey region, just over 3% in the Mid-Atlantic, 5.2% in the Pacific Northwest, 2.7% in Northern Cal, and mid-5% in Southern Cal, that blends to the 3.5%.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my final question here concerns development. So it looks like implicitly, I guess, starts are expected to go up in the fourth quarter versus what happened in the third quarter. And just a general question, I guess, how are you guys feeling
componenttext: Okay. And then my final question here concerns development. So it looks like implicitly, I guess, starts are expected to go up in the fourth quarter versus what happened in the third quarter. And just a general question, I guess, how are you guys feeling about the development pipeline today? And has any of your assumptions changed in terms of how you're underwriting or the projected yields on the overall pipeline or the things that you're starting in the near term?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, this is Matt. Yes, no, we are expecting a lot of start-up volume here in the fourth quarter. It was always really in the plan that the starts were going to be backloaded this year. And it's really just a function of when those deals work their way t
componenttext: Rich, this is Matt. Yes, no, we are expecting a lot of start-up volume here in the fourth quarter. It was always really in the plan that the starts were going to be backloaded this year. And it's really just a function of when those deals work their way through the system and are ready to start, so we haven't -- I wouldn't say our view has changed in any material way in terms of the attractiveness or the profitability of the development platform. We're still adding new development rights through the course of the year. They're still kind at the same current economics. Again, we underwrite to kind of today's rents and costs and expenses that don't really trend, but we're still seeing, on average, our development rights pipeline underwriting to about a mid-6s yield, some variation by region, but that's been pretty consistent really for the last several years. The only thing that's really potentially changed is just different deals will move around quarter-to-quarter. So whether we wind up with this start volume for the total year that we expected at the beginning of the year, probably just depends on what happens with the Columbus Circle deal and whether that starts this quarter or it may slip into the first quarter of next year.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. I guess, I mean one follow-up there. Just simply to the extent that the current environment has deteriorated over the course of 2016, I think where we might be a little bit confused is just how some of the assumptions haven't changed much. I me
componenttext: All right. I guess, I mean one follow-up there. Just simply to the extent that the current environment has deteriorated over the course of 2016, I think where we might be a little bit confused is just how some of the assumptions haven't changed much. I mean is that just a function of underwriting rents versus the basis that you guys have locked in, or is it -- are we misinterpreting kind of the way the numbers move there?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Rich, this is Tim. I mean rents are continuing to increase in our markets generally, and it's a function of how it interplays with construction costs for sure. We are seeing some moderation in some markets on construction costs now. Land costs, as y
componenttext: Well, Rich, this is Tim. I mean rents are continuing to increase in our markets generally, and it's a function of how it interplays with construction costs for sure. We are seeing some moderation in some markets on construction costs now. Land costs, as you know, has locked in. So in terms of overall economics on a current basis, as Matt mentioned, we haven't seen a big change. We published the deals that completed this quarter that stabilized at a 6.4. We've got about $2.5 billion that are under construction that we still estimate are at 6.4 and that's with most of that pipeline not remarked to market yet, which we would anticipate that to gravitate up and then just the deals we've been putting under our contract in 2016, which probably has been a little bit of a surprise that they have been as attractive as we -- from an economic standpoint as they've been are kind of consistent with those kinds of returns. So the assumptions are always based upon what we're seeing in the markets today. And I think that's what Matt meant in terms of our underlying assumptions haven't changed in terms of how they're derived.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, you mentioned the increase to same-store expense growth is driven by utilities and the delay in tax appeals. Could you talk about what's driving the growth of the more controllable expenses? Looks like payroll, R&M and office operations were up this
componenttext: Tim, you mentioned the increase to same-store expense growth is driven by utilities and the delay in tax appeals. Could you talk about what's driving the growth of the more controllable expenses? Looks like payroll, R&M and office operations were up this quarter.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Nick, this is Sean. Why don't I give you an overview of the change from the midyear guidance that we provided as compared to what we provided last night, if that's helpful. But the growth change, if you look at, call it combined third quarter and fou
componenttext: Yes. Nick, this is Sean. Why don't I give you an overview of the change from the midyear guidance that we provided as compared to what we provided last night, if that's helpful. But the growth change, if you look at, call it combined third quarter and fourth quarter or back-half of the year, represents around $2.6 million, $2.7 million. About a third of that is timing-related. And the majority of that ties to 3 tax appeals in L.A. County that were scheduled and anticipated to occur in Q4 that looks like they're going to slip into Q1 and in the balance of the timing-related component related to the start-up of a [indiscernible]  facility at one of our New York high-rise assets, that's been delayed a little bit. So about a third of it, we'll get. We're just going to get it probably closer to Q1 as opposed to Q4. But in terms of the absolute amount of the change, it's about 70 basis points, if you look at the midyear guidance we provided, basically, around 2.4% to where we're at 3.1% today. The major components are the utilities, it's about $1.8 million, taxes around $700,000, and then there's a couple of hundred thousand related to insurance and payroll. Again, that's sort of comparing back-half of 2016 as compared to our midyear re-forecast, so a big chunk of it again is timing-related, but those are the primary drivers of the difference as compared to what we had said earlier at midyear.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then you said concessions. Can you talk about if you're using concessions on any stabilized properties today? What markets you're doing that? And if it's free rent or gift cards or any other details you can provide on that.
componenttext: And then you said concessions. Can you talk about if you're using concessions on any stabilized properties today? What markets you're doing that? And if it's free rent or gift cards or any other details you can provide on that.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. For the most part, we don't use a lot of concessions, but we do use them in certain markets. And I'd say it depends on a couple of things, Nick. Obviously, in New York, you probably see a greater use of concession given some of the legal rent i
componenttext: Yes, sure. For the most part, we don't use a lot of concessions, but we do use them in certain markets. And I'd say it depends on a couple of things, Nick. Obviously, in New York, you probably see a greater use of concession given some of the legal rent issues that surround that market. And then in certain situations where we think there may be just the bulk of deliveries that's coming through in a particular quarter or 2 that sort of impacts the then current environment, and we want to take sort of a temporary hit as opposed to the full 12 months in reducing the rents when it comes to lease renewal for those customers, that we tend to use. But in terms of the concessions that we granted in the third quarter, it's about $440,000, about 50% of it was in San Francisco, about another 25% was in the Pacific Northwest, which is in a healthy market, but it tends to be a market where there is just a greater use of concessions. So we used concessions last year, we used concessions this year. It's just sort of the nature of the barter in Seattle. But if you look at the year-over-year change, about 85% of the year-over-year increase is really in San Francisco, and that's primarily concentrated at the Mission Bay assets, a little bit at 55 Ninth, a little bit at Ocean Avenue, which are competing with more than new deliveries.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Nick Yulico with UBS.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Nick Yulico with UBS.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of ones. First on a couple of markets like if you think about New York, San Francisco, I mean if you look at Axiometrics data showing that year-over-year there's been no rent growth or slightly negative rent growth in the markets. What point does
componenttext: A couple of ones. First on a couple of markets like if you think about New York, San Francisco, I mean if you look at Axiometrics data showing that year-over-year there's been no rent growth or slightly negative rent growth in the markets. What point does that flow into your portfolio more so where if market rents just aren't moving, I mean how do you still keep up, let's say, positive renewals in both markets?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nick, this is Sean. In terms of a bleeding through the portfolio, I mean the softer market environment this year, obviously, has already started to bleed through the portfolio, which was our original expectation at the beginning of the year in the gu
componenttext: Yes, Nick, this is Sean. In terms of a bleeding through the portfolio, I mean the softer market environment this year, obviously, has already started to bleed through the portfolio, which was our original expectation at the beginning of the year in the guidance that we provided. The rate at which it bleeds into the portfolio really is a function of a couple of different things. For the most part, it really does depend on turnover rates, because if you're turning over, say, a 54% or a 55% of the portfolio every year, that's going to get mark-to-market to some degree, and then the balance of it really is in renewals. And historically, we have seen more pricing power with renewals relative to new move-ins because of switching costs and things of that sort. So it takes a period of time for that to happen. So obviously, in some markets we are seeing rents go down relative to this point last year, I'd say, particularly in markets like San Francisco or a little bit in New York City, but we're seeing overall positive rent change currently in those markets, I'd say, due to 2 reasons. One is we probably are performing slightly better than the market average in those markets. And secondly, it's just a function of the renewals versus new move-ins that I described previously.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. Just second question, maybe for Tim. Are you seeing any change in cap rates for where multifamilies assets are trading in the private market? I mean if we think about how much rent growth has slowed in some markets and just look at m
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. Just second question, maybe for Tim. Are you seeing any change in cap rates for where multifamilies assets are trading in the private market? I mean if we think about how much rent growth has slowed in some markets and just look at multifamily sector overall for the REITs, we've also seen growth slowing. How -- it's hard for, I think, some people to imagine how cap rates won't move higher to reflect this? What are you seeing for asset values today?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Nick, I think I'll probably defer to Matt where acquisition disposition reports to him, but, obviously, we've been active on the disposition side, both around portfolio and for -- as we wind down some of the funds and then we get more active on the
componenttext: Well, Nick, I think I'll probably defer to Matt where acquisition disposition reports to him, but, obviously, we've been active on the disposition side, both around portfolio and for -- as we wind down some of the funds and then we get more active on the acquisition side in a couple of markets. But Matt, maybe just speak to kind of what we've been seeing there from a cap rate perspective.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it probably does vary by market and by asset type. And really,  it's a function of where the capital is most aggressive, so what we're finding is older assets to the value-added story, particularly on the West coast, it's still very, very dee
componenttext: Yes. I think it probably does vary by market and by asset type. And really,  it's a function of where the capital is most aggressive, so what we're finding is older assets to the value-added story, particularly on the West coast, it's still very, very deep. We probably sold an asset, Avalon Brandemoor, in the northern suburbs of Seattle and that was a sub-5 cap rate on an asset that was 15 years old, and a good submarket, but not one of the more sought-after submarkets in metro Seattle, and that's just a reflection of the fact there's a lot of value-added money chasing that story, if you will. In some other locations, I don't know, really, I couldn't tell you where Northern California cap rates are today. Obviously, there has been a lot of deceleration of NOI growth there, and we have not bought or sold anything in Northern Cal in a while. And I think asset volumes are down a little bit there because of that, so we haven't been selling kind of real core stuff, and that's where you might see the impacts felt more so, but we don't have any direct evidence to speak to that on either the buyer or the sell-side.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Jeff Spector with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: We'll go next to Jeff Spector with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm here with one scenario. I guess just wanted to focus a little bit more, Tim, on some of your key points, talking about moderation equilibrium, the next 2 to 3 years. Obviously, this year there were a few issues to cause management to lower guidance. H
componenttext: I'm here with one scenario. I guess just wanted to focus a little bit more, Tim, on some of your key points, talking about moderation equilibrium, the next 2 to 3 years. Obviously, this year there were a few issues to cause management to lower guidance. How should we think about those comments in the next 2 to 3 years? What's giving you comfort that we stay there, or what are some of the assumptions behind that, behind those comments?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Jeff, we try to say that on Slide 9. I mean, first of all, in terms of changes in guidance, it's really a reflection of it being a weaker economic environment than consensus or us have anticipated. So as the environment deteriorates further, and we
componenttext: Well, Jeff, we try to say that on Slide 9. I mean, first of all, in terms of changes in guidance, it's really a reflection of it being a weaker economic environment than consensus or us have anticipated. So as the environment deteriorates further, and we are anticipating some moderation in both -- in job growth and an increase in supply in our markets over the next couple of years. But I think we show on Slide 9 that we think it's roughly about -- and if you look at the overall housing picture, we're starting at between 1.1 million and 1.2 million units per year, and about 400,000 of those are multifamily, almost all of those are rental. That's about -- on a percentage basis, that's about what you're seeing in terms of renter propensities right now. It just seems like the market is producing housing that's consistent with what we're seeing at -- from a marginal demand standpoint which ought to translate into inflation or maybe a little bit better in terms of rent growth. And I think if you're seeing tightness anywhere, it's probably more in the for-sale arena where there's still being kind of 5% kind of growth in value. So we're not seeing too much supply in terms of the overall housing picture. We are seeing pockets of oversupply for sure, and we've talked about those markets, and so some will leave and some will lag. But overall, based upon an economy that's growing at, call it, 2%, and jobs that are growing around 1.5%, and supply that's being delivered into the market at about 1.5% is soft, that just looks like equilibrium to us, so supply being roughly equivalent to demand.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Does it -- do you also assume that in '18 that supply is going to really come down or no, that's not part of your thought process right now?
componenttext: Does it -- do you also assume that in '18 that supply is going to really come down or no, that's not part of your thought process right now?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Modestly, Jeff, I think it may come down less for a couple of reasons. One, I think the projection for '17 are probably going to prove out to be too high again because it just seems like supply just gets delayed. Some of the supply, I think, over the last
componenttext: Modestly, Jeff, I think it may come down less for a couple of reasons. One, I think the projection for '17 are probably going to prove out to be too high again because it just seems like supply just gets delayed. Some of the supply, I think, over the last couple of years, 15% to 20% of what we're expected hitting that year ended up getting delayed. So if anything, we've been overestimating supply for the next year. And so I suspect some of the '17 deliveries will leak into '18, and that you'll see a more -- I think you'll see a fairly level supply picture for the next couple of years is our own sense.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And Juan has a question.
componenttext: Okay. And Juan has a question.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could follow-up on Jeff's point. If you could just through your '17 supply assumptions across your major markets, and in particular, maybe if you could touch on Northern California, how that comes online throughout '17? Is it front-end loaded or is i
componenttext: If I could follow-up on Jeff's point. If you could just through your '17 supply assumptions across your major markets, and in particular, maybe if you could touch on Northern California, how that comes online throughout '17? Is it front-end loaded or is it kind of pretty evenly distributed throughout the year?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Juan, this is Sean. Why don't I take that one? In terms of the expectations for '17, before I kind of run through the markets, one thing to keep in mind, as Tim noted, is for the most part, over the last 3 years, I'd say supply has been, call it, str
componenttext: Yes. Juan, this is Sean. Why don't I take that one? In terms of the expectations for '17, before I kind of run through the markets, one thing to keep in mind, as Tim noted, is for the most part, over the last 3 years, I'd say supply has been, call it, stretched out, if you want to think about it that way, where expected deliveries are pushed off into the subsequent period. But in terms of what we're seeing for 2017 right now across our markets, the expectation is we're going to be somewhere in the neighborhood of about 2% of inventory. And the way that breaks down, to give you some perspective, is the New England market, it's about 2.5%, Metro New York-New Jersey around 1.8%, Mid-Atlantic high 2s, Pacific Northwest, still elevated, up at 3.7%, Northern Cal mid-2s, and Southern Cal, kind of in the mid-1% range. My expectation is those are going to trend down as we digest numbers and refresh our supply pipeline when we get to January. One thing to keep in mind is some of those deals are in the pipeline as projected starts, but when people start looking at their numbers and are seeing construction costs up quite a bit over the last couple of years as they've been processing a deal, and then a tightening that we've seen in the financial markets as it relates to construction lending and a little bit on the equity side as well, yes, some of those deals probably just aren't going to make.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just one quick follow-up. Are you seeing any pull into San Francisco of demand that otherwise would have been in Oakland or San Jose from the discounting for the new projects?
componenttext: Great. And just one quick follow-up. Are you seeing any pull into San Francisco of demand that otherwise would have been in Oakland or San Jose from the discounting for the new projects?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know, a little bit, but nothing that's really discernible that shows up in the data that you could call it a significant trend. Typically, it takes a period of time for that to happen. And we've been talking about certainly a decelerating growth in Sa
componenttext: You know, a little bit, but nothing that's really discernible that shows up in the data that you could call it a significant trend. Typically, it takes a period of time for that to happen. And we've been talking about certainly a decelerating growth in San Francisco for the last few quarters, but it's really only, I'd say, in the last 6 months that it's really come down quite a bit. And people are on year leases and things like that, so it typically takes a year or 2 for that phenomenon really to occur. If you think about the early part of this cycle, San Francisco outperformed quite a while and San Jose as well, before the East Bay sort of caught up, and East Bay has been outperforming in the last couple of years of the cycle.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttextpreview: It's Austin Wurschmidt here with Jordan. I was just curious if you could update on your outlook for job growth. I think last quarter, you mentioned it came down 50 basis points roughly from your expectation, but just curious what your outlook is as we mov
componenttext: It's Austin Wurschmidt here with Jordan. I was just curious if you could update on your outlook for job growth. I think last quarter, you mentioned it came down 50 basis points roughly from your expectation, but just curious what your outlook is as we move into 2017.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Austin, this is Sean. Why don't I take the first half of it and then Tim might want to comment as well. But in terms of the forecast for 2016, we rely on several different jobs to kind of get aligned around where we think job growth is going to end u
componenttext: Yes. Austin, this is Sean. Why don't I take the first half of it and then Tim might want to comment as well. But in terms of the forecast for 2016, we rely on several different jobs to kind of get aligned around where we think job growth is going to end up. That includes sort of the native consensus as well as Moody's. And right now, the numbers are sort of in the 2.3 million to 2.4 million jobs range for the calendar year. And in terms of 2017, the expectation is for job growth at least at this point to be relatively similar to 2016. So certainly, that will be updated as Q4 evolves and we get to January, but the expectation is that job growth will be relatively similar next year as to this year, which is down, as Tim mentioned, relative to 2015 and 2014.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just as a follow-up to that. As I mentioned earlier, it's around 1.5%, and our markets were expecting about 1.7%. And the only real anomaly is Seattle where we're still expecting job growth north of 3%. The others are kind of in the mid-1% range, all
componenttext: And just as a follow-up to that. As I mentioned earlier, it's around 1.5%, and our markets were expecting about 1.7%. And the only real anomaly is Seattle where we're still expecting job growth north of 3%. The others are kind of in the mid-1% range, all of the regions.

componenttext: And then just on DC, it's been one of the few submarkets that's been accelerating. It stalled a bit this quarter. I know you highlighted it from a question earlier in the call, but just curious what your thoughts are. And how this market -- how it should fare moving forward? headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Sean, Austin. Yes, the trend we believe that will occur is continued acceleration in revenue performance there. We thought it would have accelerated probably a little bit more in the third quarter and fourth quarter, but it's still kind of bu
componenttext: Yes. This is Sean, Austin. Yes, the trend we believe that will occur is continued acceleration in revenue performance there. We thought it would have accelerated probably a little bit more in the third quarter and fourth quarter, but it's still kind of bumping along here. So there is still -- one thing to realize is job growth has been much better in the DC metro area, but supply has still been plentiful, so we're going to continue to see it rise, but it's going to be at a pretty moderate pace as we move into next year.

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to talk about the 2 acquisitions, and I know you've mentioned attractive merchant deals in the past. Just wondering, given the fact that you have such good economics in your own development pipeline, how did you think about the 2 deals there?
componenttext: Just wanted to talk about the 2 acquisitions, and I know you've mentioned attractive merchant deals in the past. Just wondering, given the fact that you have such good economics in your own development pipeline, how did you think about the 2 deals there? I think, if I'm not wrong, one of them was a lease-up other than -- another one was a land swap of sorts. Could you provide more details on that and the yields you expect?

headline: AvalonBay Communities, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. This is Matt. I can speak to that. I wouldn't say it's either/or between the 2 investment activities. We're really not funding acquisitions through expansion of the balance sheet. It's really portfolio management. So essentially, we are in the
componenttext: Yes, sure. This is Matt. I can speak to that. I wouldn't say it's either/or between the 2 investment activities. We're really not funding acquisitions through expansion of the balance sheet. It's really portfolio management. So essentially, we are in the market when we think that there are assets that are attractively priced. And if we find assets that we like, then we can always fund those through incremental dispositions. And we've wound up this year selling more than we probably planned to sell at the beginning of the year because we have been successful in finding some interesting acquisition candidates, so that doesn't really displace the development activity from a funding point of view. So that's the first thing. And then in terms of the specific deals, we have been concentrating in the Mid-Atlantic. For the most part, we sold down in the Mid-Atlantic back in '11 and '12, kind of saw the softness coming here. So we're actually under-allocated against our kind of long-term targets. We haven't been as actively developing in this market through this cycle either. So the one deal we bought in South Arlington, after you allocate to the retail we -- basically, it's a low 5 cap, 330,000 a unit for concrete frame construction that's 8 or 9 years old, that's below replacement costs for that submarket, so we felt that was a pretty compelling buy. That's a submarket that's suffered some in the last couple of years, and we think has bottomed out, and we're starting to see positive revenue growth there again, so we feel like it was a well-timed acquisition and should be a great investment. The other deal we bought, just completed a lease-up. It's a smaller deal in North Hollywood, and that -- the other region I'd say we're under-allocated to at this point is Southern California. It's been more difficult there because cap rates are quite a bit lower than they are in the Mid-Atlantic, but still that deal, we think it's a low 4s cap. And after allocating to the retail, we think the basis in the residential is about 400,000 a unit, which again is a pretty compelling basis for that location. And that's a submarket where we are looking for more exposure where we see a lot of good things happening and where we think that we're in at a good point in the cycle there.
